content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I'm 17 years old. I'm sitting in front of my Pentium II PC and I've just finished installing Baldur's Gate. I've crafted my perfect character, and I'm now adventuring through a gorgeous world. I've fallen headfirst into the game reading novels worth of text and not noticing as hours melt away.It's 17 years later. I'm 34 years old. I'm doing it all over again and it's like I'm travelling through time.Every aspect of this game is perfect. I wouldn't change it even if I could. I find myself wondering how in-game mechanics work and I'm tempted to alt+tab and google what spell is best. Instead I just keep playing and figure it out myself. I can't even *remember* the last time I didn't look up this sort of info in a game. Who cares if this sword does a little more damage than that spear? My character likes that spear and he looks awesome wielding it.This is the first Kickstarter decision I've made that I am completely happy with. Thanks Obsidian for taking me back in time and reminding me that you don't need gamefaqs to enjoy a game.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												I noticed that most people reviewing this game have previously played similar games. I don't have much experience with CRPG'S at all, thats why I thought my view of the game can give another perspective on things. That means I have not played games like Dungeons & Dragons, Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale or Neverwinter Nights before playing this game.Pillars of Eternity starts of with a character creation. The amount of options that you have here is absolutely crazy. You can probably spend hours here, changing every little detail. You pick your sex, race, class, attributes, culture, appearance and finally voice.This game have many difficult settings and are obviously made for replayability. Pillars recommend that you start on easy difficulty, so I did. I most say that easy in this game isn't that simple! Loadscreens while you rest are pretty and some other environments in the game, like dungeons and forests. I like the details on the characters, it's very sharp, even when you zoom in. The only complaint I have is that some backgrounds are a little blurry and low res, which looks a little bit silly when it's next to a very detailed character. I get that they went for an "old-school look" but I still think that doesnt really match. But when you zoom out that won't really bother you.I recommend that you crank the volume up for this title, because background noise and sounds, in the dialogue and in combat, are great. It will help you get into the story and atmosphere better.Ventors in the cities and villages will buy all the trash you loot from enemies. You can buy camping tools, weapons and potions from them. If you have many followers you can carry more items, and all items can be transfered over between anybody in your party, which is great. So if I find a staff as barbarian I can simply open up the inventory and equip in on my mage.You will have to read most of the dialogue yourself, although some story related things are read for you. I still wouldn't recommend this game if you hate reading, because there's a lot of it. You can right click on items and spells to read everything about them as well. Some are just lore stuff, others are actually useful information.The story is dark and mysterious. Combat in done with real time and pause. You can also use slow motion in fights to make things more manageable and easy. As you level up your character and possible followers, you gain points which you can spend on things like sneak, survival, etc. You also get to pick spells.You can create really silly partys if you want. You can combine all the races and even have animal followers like bears. It's entirely up to you who you bring along the quests and you can choose how they will look like, what weapon they will use and what role they will have in combat.Options menu is very good. You can customize everything they way you like it in terms of controls. The graphics options are not as good, but for this type of game I wouldn't say its needed.The replayability is obviously insane when you think about how many races, followers and difficulty levels this game has. You can play the entire game solo, or you can choose to bring mages, dwarfs, godlikes, wizards, humans...and so on, with you. You can also create different kinds of humans, elfs, etc. It's fantastic.Obsidian Entertainment has created a great game overall, that even new CRPG players like me can enjoy. I have barely scratched the surface of this game, but I can already see that amount of work put into this title. It's fun, dark and mysterious and im having so much fun playing and learning new things everyday.Highly recommended title, if you don't mind reading of course.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is an isometric party-based computer RPG using real-time-with-pause combat.What is Great about this game:- Complex and deep story that moves the game along incredibly well- Deep character creation and multiple classes each with multiple viable playstyles bringing significant variety to your own playthrough- Rich and appropriate back story, lore, and flavor text added throughout the game that is worth reading- Enjoyable tactical combat with numerous options for pausing and other options to make the game more enjoyable- Unique and sometimes fascinating quest lines with multiple alternative methods for success (e.g. talk yourself out of a combat encounter)- An ending storyline that was possibly the most thought-provoking and intelligently written as any I have experiencedWhat is Good about this game:- The game looks quite nice but could have used more art/animantions to improve it further- The voice acting is quite good where it exists- Good use of Steam features (cloud saves, trading cards, achievements, etc)What is Bad about this game:- The combat could have been significantly improved (although still very good) by including methods to automate companions similar to the systems in FFXII or Dragon Age: Origins- Given how story heavy this game is, it would have been much improved by including more voice-over work.  The voice acting is very good, but is only available sparsely.  The writing is more than worth reading, but having it spoken would have been that much more engrossing.Conclusion:Pillars of Eternity is the current pinnacle of story-telling in RPGs with a great combat system and a classic style.9.5 / 10.0

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Pillars of EternityDeveloper: Obsidian EntertainmentPublisher: Paradox InteractiveNote: I will try to be as spoiler-free as possible.Note #2: I don't think I can do this game justice, but I'll try anyway.Introduction==========Quite possibly the best isometric CRPG to be released in recent years, Pillars of Eternity is an entirely new world expertly crafted and filled with lore created in the style of the classic Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale games. Any fan of these games will instantly fall in love with Pillars of Eternity and it's similar design.Gameplay==========Played from an isometric top-down view, Pillars is packed with things to do. You play the game entirely by mouse, pointing and clicking to navigate each area, converse with NPCs, battle enemies, and more. One of the best things about this game is that it is extremely detailed and immersive with it's superb storytelling. Pretty much exactly like the titles mentioned above. There is a literal TON of reading, as everything is presented to you in much the same way a dungeonmaster or storyteller in a tabletop game would. Every detail is spelled out for you, and you get to make you own choices in each dialogue. Most of these choices have a profound impact on the outcome of whatever quest you are on (people can and will die!), and even the main storyline.You start out by creating a character from a huge list of options. There are a small handful of races, several classes, and you can even choose some regional differences for each race. You could easily spend and hour or more creating your first character. Along with your "main" character, there are 8 (10 with The White March Part I add-on) unique companions you can recruit. You can also create more characters to join your party after a certain point. Each character can be customized the way you see fit from an extensive list of spells, abilities, auras, talents, and equipment.One of the big features of Pillars is the Stronghold. Shortly into the game you come into ownership of a stronghold called Caed Nua. Caed Nua, once owned, can be upgraded and repaired to offer you a variety of new features, goods, and services. For example, you can build an Inn that will allow you to rest. Another example is you can construct a barracks which unlocks the character creator. Also found underneath Caed Nua is an extensive maze-like dungeon, which can be explored throughout the game, with each floor getting more difficult. There are many options in battle, and probably the most helpful (but sometimes annoying) of which is the Auto-Pause feature. This can be set to activate when any number of events occur, such as a character's Endurance dropping too low. Pausing allows you to survey the battlefield and make the best decision possible to turn the tide back into your favor. An important part of any RPG is inventory management. With a game of this scope, there are naturally a ton of different items: weapons, armor, accessories, food, potions, scrolls, crafting ingredients, and more. With all of these items, you need a way to store and manage everything. Thankfully, each character has their own inventory, and you can freely move items between them at anytime. But the biggest boon to item management is the Stash. On your inventory screen, you will see a large button with a Treasure Chest on it. This is your Stash, which can be accessed from nearly anywhere, at anytime, and is seemingly infinite in capacity. If it has a limit, I never found it!Most RPGs are packed full of quests and tasks, and with this comes th eneed to manage them. The quest log in Pillars is pretty detailed, giving a sort of summary of any actions taken during a quest. This is extremely helpful, in that if you take a break from the game you can easily come back and jump right back to what you left off on. This is a common complaint of some of the larger RPGs, that when picking the game back up after awhile players have no idea what they were last doing, so they start over. Pillars eliminates that problem entirely.When you reach the edge of a map, you are able to leave the area and return to the World Map. From here, you can travel to any previously visited location no matter how far across the map it is. This fast travel is extremely helpful in navigating the world and completing objectives.Graphics==========If you liked the graphics of Baldur's Gate, then you'll love the updated style Pillars of Eternity offers. You can zoom in and out at anytime, and the closer you zoom in, the more detail you will see on nearly everything. The characters in particular are very well done, as are the environments and maps of each area. They all look superb. I simply cannot say enough about how good this game looks. All of it is very well-made and designed, and really draws your eye to the details. It's just so detailed and beautiful as a result. The only downside is that there isn't too much variety. The entire base game map is mostly woodlands and forests, and all of the dungeons look really similar...stone and darkness. It isn't until you get the White March Part 1 add-on that you start to see more varied environments (SNOW!).Sound and Music==========Absolutely amazing. The soundtrack is wonderfully immersive, and extremely well-done. Making the soundtrack available in the store was a great move. Once I'm able to afford the Champion Edition upgrade, I'll definitely get it JUST for the soundtrack alone. I'm a huge fan of video game music anyway. I found no problems with any of it. Every track was expertly paired with the right situations in-game for full immersion.The sound effects are extremely well done too, even footsteps. This is a game I play with my sound up full blast, there's a lot of details in each area that's conveyed via the sound. Each area has a lot of ambient effects, like crickets in a woodland setting or stones shifting as you traverse a dungeon.Performance==========This game ran flawlessly on my low mid-tier rig. No hiccups whatsosver. No framerate drops, lag, stuttering, or random crashes. The framerate did appear to be capped at 30 though, as I never saw it go over that. I'll need to pay attention next time I play and make a note about it.One of the main complaints (well, only complaint) I have with this game is that inbetween every single area you will run into a loading screen that takes anywhere from 5-15 seconds to clear off. Thankfully, these screens feature some beautiful artwork and often helpful tips about the game, so it's not too big of an issue.Final Thoughts==========Pillars of Eternity is a MUST PLAY for fans of the CRPG genre. A truly immersive and expansive adventure that you can play your way. If you enjoyed any of the games mentioned at the top of this review, you *need* to have this game in your library. And with the recently released White March Part 1 add-on and accompanying patch that added some much needed features to the game (Party AI), it's gotten even better! Don't pass this up, it's well worth the price of admission.Gameplay Demo==========

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												After over 100 hours I finally finished Pillars of Eternity and I think I'm ready to write this review.Is this game good? It's more than good, it's great. It's not only one of the best RPGs of all times, it's also one of the best games I've ever played. It has great story, beautiful graphics, sound and music, deep mechanics and everything what good RPG game needs. But don't expect revolution, this is just step ahead in comparison to best classics like Baldur's Gate.So what you may expect? Pillars of Eternity is pure old-school RPG in modern times. Engine is very classic, but modern in the same time. So you have 2D view, but with zoom. Combat is in real time with active pause. There is a lot of reading and dialogues. You will spend a lot of time to manage your party stats, skills and inventory. I played in hard difficulty and it was necessary to survive.What about world and mechanics? There is new world and RPG mechanics made by Obsidian, but it has a lot in common with Dungeons and Dragons. It's heroic fantasy with many races (there are elves and dwarves too) and classes (like paladins, warriors and clerics), which combines elements we all know and love, with some new ideas, which is great. One word about spellcasters. I love the way how each magic class is different to each other, they use totally different spells and strategy, there are many fresh ideas here.Also other thing is great. Best dialog system I've ever seen. Here you may feel your how your reputation and stats affects your dialog options.But not everything is perfect. There are some things in that game, that would be improved, like your castle for example. This is clear that potential of this idea isn't fully exploited. Sometimes I felt like this part of the game was done in a rush.VERDICT:If you're an old-school RPG fan, this is must have for you. With this game you will feel the same magic as you felt playing Baldur's Gate.If you're younger player, I'm not sure you will be so delighted as I am. I can recommend this game to everybody but I know there are many people which expect more intense RPGs in modern style. So if you like to read a lot and think what to do, try this game and find the ancient magic.Like this review? Consider to join Good Games Giveaways & Reviews group and maybe press big sexy "Follow this curator" button on our curation page to read more reviews and win free games.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												It's hard not to compare this with Divinity: Original Sin. Both were funded on Kickstarter, both have a 91% score on Steam, both are rich, engaging cRPGs, and they were released months apart. It's fair to say both games have been wild successes that have surprised even the developers. If you had to pick ONE of these to invest time in which should it be?Turn-based vs. Real-time with pause: I eventually came to accept and even enjoy the real-time with pause combat of Pillars, though I much prefer turn-based. Real-time combat presents many problems that aren't the result of player mistakes. On numerous occasions I'd have characters stuck in place because the pathfinding didn't work right. The real-time combat often felt like a jumbled, chaotic mess instead of the tactical plan I had set out. Divinity is much cleaner in this respect and offered a much better experience, especially with respect to using the environment as a weapon. With Divinity I felt each power had a time and place, whereas with Pillars I ended up spamming the same powers and hoping for the best.Story: Pillars of Eternity definity wins out here. While the story in Divinity:OS wasn't bad, I would call it playful to the point of campy. Pillars had a deep, mature fantasy story worthy of a novel. While it was almost too much reading at times, the story was serious, dark, and dealt with real themes. Art: Pillars harkens back to the golden age of Infinity Engine games like Balgur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape Torment, etc. The scenes are appealing, but prerendered and they felt a little static. This helps stoke the nostalgia for the late 90s, but Divinity feels up-to-date and immersive. Couple the art style of Divinity with it's highly interactive environments, and the world of Original Sin ends up feeling much more alive. Music: Both were great soundtracks but Pillars feels just a bit derivative of the Lord of the Rings movies. They aren't bad at all, but almost generically fantasy at times. Music is important here because when you spend tens of hours in these worlds, you're gonna get this music stuck in your head.In short, you should play both if you love deep, isometric, high-fantasy, western computer RPGs. If you MUST pick, consider the following choice. Choose Pillars of Eternity if you favor story and choose Divinity: Original Sin if you prefer combat. Both are hallmarks of a great RPG and each specializes beautifully.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity, one more try to make the "sucessor of Baldurs Gate", one of the biggest Kickstarter projects made by rpg veterans Obsidian Entertainment.So, after nearly 50 hours playtime (i´m around the last third of the game) what can i say to the big promises? First off, the world of PoE is very detailed for a newly made one, the history, races and classes are partly innovative, partly good old fantasy genre like.The gameplay itself naturally orientates itself on the old masters, you create your character, who can alter the fate of the world in an epic storyline, while finding allies for his group on the way through the story (which can alternatively be filled with custom made characters.. or you can even try to go through it alone).Regarding classes there are new ones like the cipher and many known ones from barbarian to priests to the different gods (a nice extra for these is, that the way how they act throughout the game influences how "satisfied" their deity is with them).Regarding classes and "improvements" here also shows one of the main changes of PoE, there are rather less skills, then usually known in old time rpgs. Also the classes are not limited as how they advance in them. For me, i honestly preferred the old way a bit, when not everyone could learn anything but to each his own. Also it seems to me that especially the rogue class suffers from that choice, as everyone can learn about traps etc. now.. so the only thing really special about them is backstabbing. Stealing isn´t possible anyways.When advancing in levels the classes differentiate again a bit more through perks, which can be aquired on selected levels (some general, some bound to different requirements).Graphic and music are top level for this kind of game, only the camera possibilities/movements could be improved, especially during battles or while in towns etc.Regarding quests, dialogue and story in general there are few things to complain about, the main storyline is branching and quite interesting, the happenings on the way have mostly more then one way to complete them. Furthermore there are different factions you encounter and can ally with them and in general the way you behave throughout the game affects every location/faction. Last but not least you also have the possibility to get your own stronghold, which is to be restored as well as cared about.. and even has an own multiple level dungeon. Personally i would have wished for some more class specific dialogue options (especially the cipher class), but that´s a minor complain.Your companions are well made and have their own personalities as well as quests, though could use some more banter.On a further note regarding Obsidian and their reputation for delivering bug plagued games, i think the self management through Kickstarter helped them, as i had few problems in that regard. Also the game keeps getting improved after release. The downside of the Kickstarter, if you want to call it one, are many KS characters, who stand around throughout towns mostly and some little sh*tstorm made once more by some extremists who were to dumb and fanatic to understand irony.Conclusio: If you are a fan of (old) isometric, group related rpgs on an epic scale then you can´t do anything wrong with this game.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
Pillars of EternityNote: Each field is weighted differently, and thus affects the overall score differently.  Field Rating Review   Graphics 8.5 While the isometric envrionments are absolutely gorgeous, the character models leave something to be desired. Overall though, the world that has been crafted in Pillars of Eternity is absolutely beautiful, and calls you to explore every damp dungeon, and every overgrown ruin. Combat animations, especially spells, are extremely satisfying to watch, as each spell has very unique and detailed animations.   Gameplay 9 A revival of the classic Infinity Engine style of gameplay, Pillars of Eternity is true to its roots. With pausable real-time combat, a maximum of 6 characters to control (12, if you choose all rangers with pets...if that's your thing), and plenty of spells and playstyles to choose from, you are bound to find a playstyle that fits you and that you enjoy. Choose between 11 different classes, 6 different races, and several more sub-races, and customize your characters look to start crafting the story you want to experience. With wonderful voice acting, fanstastic story-telling, a vast world with tons of content, and even your own Stronghold to upgrade and maintain, Pillars of Eternity welcomes both old and new players to the genre with open arms.   Story 10 The world in which Pillars of Eternity takes place has been lovingly crafted, with hours upon hours of lore to sift through and explore. Usually in games, I quickly open and close the books you pick up, and skip through dialogue rather quickly, simply wanting to get to the point (looking at you Skyrim, Dragon Age, etc). However, in Pillars of Eternity, I have found myself spending hours reading all the books available that explain the world of Eora, and talking to every NPC I can find, following every branch of dialogue. I have come to actually care about my companions that tag along with me, and want to know more about them and their background. The wonderful voice acting (though sometimes strangely absent) only helps to further create depth in this incredibly imagined world.   Multiplayer N/A This game is all about the single-player. Enjoy it.   Replayability 3 The drawback of such story heavy games, is there isn't often a reason to go back and play them, other than to experience the game through a different class. However, since you are able to have 6 companions at a time in Pillars of Eternity, you can experience each character class through a single play-through. Really the only reason I find to go back for another round at the game is to make some different choices, try a harder difficulty, or achievement hunt.    Overall 9.1/10 I was, personally, not a fan of the Baldur's Gate series, much less any games like it. But Pillars of Eternity has enthralled me enough with its story that I have come to love it dearly, and it has opened the door to similar games for me. If you enjoy story-rich games, Pillars of Eternity is easily near the top of the list and is the game for you. If you want to lose yourself in another world for hours on end, Pillars of Eternity is the game for you. If you want to experience an epic journey in a living, thriving world that is beautifully crafted, Pillars of Eternity is the game for you. All in all, Pillars of Eternity is a game that every gamer should take the time to experience, even if only to remember how incredible a game with a good story is. If you liked this review, feel free to check out my curator page:The TipsterYou are also welcome to join our group and play/discuss games together, here:  The Tipster

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												Eternity is a high-quality, top-down CRPG which borrows a lot from the classic style of Baldur's Gate 1 and Arcanum, with complex combat rules, complex setting full of lore, and a long plot with a number of side quests. It is meaty and enjoyable for many hours, and will be of particular interest to fans of classics like Icewind Dale, which it learns from and also refines on.However, some flaws of execution leave it a bit short of the very top CRPGs like Baldur's Gate 2, Torment and Fallout 2.They rolled their own new setting, which is serviceable and compares favorably to Arcanum, Dragon Age, or Elder Scrolls. However, many details of the setting are frankly silly and awkward. While I appreciate the effort and understand about licensing issues, I don't think this helps the game.Character creation is generally nice and detailed, but it's a bit fiddly. It's also not as flexible as one might hope relative to the greats. Relative to the greats, you have somewhat more limited scope for your character. You cannot, for example, be a Glenfathan, or any more evil than a cruel hero; and all your companions are basically neutral or good. The self-defining questions you answer aren't as deep as Torment's were, and don't really affect anything. There is no way to complete a pacifist playthrough. Again, your character creation and role options are a bit limited, but you still have a number of options.The writing gets a solid B. It's not the best I've seen, but it's decent. There are some interesting themes. But that is all. I also felt there was less written content in this than say Baldur's Gate 2, with a lot of the gameplay length coming from the "Endless Paths of Od Nua" which is a giant grind dungeon. There is more of a combat emphasis, somewhere in between Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale maybe. The game will afford more replays if you enjoy the combats.The art, music, sound, and voice acting are all of professional quality, but not remarkable. There is not much music, and it gets repetitive. The game works well at a technical level. Linux support is good, and greatly appreciated, although they decided never to implement capes, which I don't understand. It doesn't matter much. The pace of patches has been steady, which is refreshing.Many of the complaints you will see about this game are silly whining. The "gold plate" characters and the tomb inscriptions have really minimal impact on gameplay; you don't have to read them, and you can remove them with mods. I think it's reasonable that you have to sneak to find hidden things, just like Baldur's Gate. I think they've made good efforts on class balance as well.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is a RPG game developed by Obsidian Entertainment, releasing on Steam in March 2015. This game is a spiritual successor to the game series Baldur’s Gate and Icewind Dale. The game was kick-started in September 2012, with the highest ever funding at the time of over $4 million. Game play in POE is very much like the other games in the series, the tactical combat with your party of adventures, and an overwhelming amount of choices in terms of stats, equipment, skill points and attacks.  The game play does get easier the further into the game you get, as you characters grow in strength and you just become more tactically aware of your surroundings and you will work out how to get the most out of all of your characters. The game is has a heavy amount of dialog, if you don’t like reading then this game is definitely not for you. The game starts off very slowly and for the first three or four hours, you will spend the majority of that time reading text and getting started with the story. Throughout all of the dialog choices, you also get plenty of important decision that can change the outcome of certain events as you progressively get further in the game, such as siding with different factions etc. Whilst the outcome of your choice is not always very clear, the game does a very good job of masking those decisions without you realising how important they actually are. Right from the character creation screen, you will see how in-depth this game goes, there is an abundance of choice and options for you to make whilst creating your character. I was a little disappointed to see that I actually reached a level cap towards the end of act three, so almost half way through the game, I couldn’t progress my character any more. This in turn made the rest of the game seem somewhat imbalanced as I was able to just waltz through the enemies without batting an eyelid. POE whilst it doesn’t have super amazing graphics, the environment and locations that you find yourself in still look gorgeous. The way the world is presented makes you want to explore it inch by inch. The UI is the most important part of this game graphically; it is smooth and functions perfectly. You are able to find all the information you need within a click or two – believe me, there is a lot of information in this game you are going to need! This game is basically a novel inside of a game. The story is often criticized by some people, but I for one was completely intrigued and loved following it right from the start. The story is deep and moving, with plenty of cliff hangers, twists and turns as you progress.  On top of the main story line, you can follow plenty of optional side quests which add so much more immersion to the world you are in, it allows for extra character development and more choices. I actually really cared so much about my characters at the end due to what they have gone through, I spent more time than I would like to admit pondering over dialog choices. Like I said above, there is a lot of text in this game, whilst a good portion is voice acted, another good portion is not. So you better be prepared for some reading. Normally I much prefer my games to be completely voice acted; it helps me get more immersed in the story and I am probably a bit lazy, but I was completely happy to read everything this game had to offer. I honestly thought I was reading a book at times. When you begin the game, the difficulty level is fairly challenging. You have to really think about your adventures’ next actions and movement, but as with most games, as you become more familiar with how the mechanics actually work, you become more and more Intune with it, allowing you to breeze through the game at points. The end boss is somewhat of a challenge, which required me to retry a couple of times. Once you get a few bits of high quality equipment, and your characters become over levelled due to the amount of experience awards in the game, you won’t find any point to be impossible to conquer though. I finished my play through of POE in just under 60 hours (not sure why Steam says I only have 45?); this was doing the majority of side quests and exploring the world quit sufficiently whilst also taking the time to enjoy the dialog in the game too. I have seen some people put well over 100 hours into this game, and I suspect that is because of the game’s high replay ability factor.  One of the main elements which makes the game replay able, would have to be the in-depth character creation, you can create a brand new character that plays completely different to your last one, making your gameplay experience different too. Personally I don’t think I would do a second play through of the game because I feel I have got all I can out of the game right now, but those that really want to drill down this game for every inch, there is definitely a high amount of replay ability on offer. The game runs like a dream too; I was able to play on 4k resolutions with the graphics turned right up. At times I did attempt to use the Steam controller, but the mouse and keyboard is the much prefer method for this type of game. The game did release with a few bugs and glitches, but after the first patch, these have all been cleaned up so I was able to play without any problems. Pillars of Eternity is any classic RPG fan’s dream. If enjoyed Baldur’s gate, or want a completely immersive in depth role playing experience, then you need to be picking this game up. Steam’s price of £34, 99 to me seems a bit excessive, but you can pick this game up for almost half that on external websites if you shop around.  For me this is a stunningly good game, that I would consider a must play. Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Obsidian set the mandate from Day 1 of the Kickstarter that the game would be a spiritual successor to the Infinity engine games (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape: Torment).In all ways, Pillars of Eternity is a successful evolution of exactly that.  Where Infinity games were all based on Dungeons & Dragons, a system designed for turn-based combat, Pillars of Eternity maintains that same depth and feel, however built from the ground up for real time with pause combat.Pillars allows the player a choice of 11 character classes, each are a very unique experience much like the Dungeons & Dragons classes they're inspired by.  Unlike a lot of modern games that follow the MMO-inspired holy trinity design (tank, support and healer classes), Pillars, like early Dungeons & Dragons ruleset have a lot more variety in their class design.  Sure, when you go into combat, you will still have your frontline, damage, support and healing characters, but it is not quite as cut and dry.  Additionally, there is no weapon or armor type limits on your character because of your character class, so a character could be a wizard in heavy armor and a blunderbuss, whether that is a good idea or not is up for debate but it is possible.One of the biggest improvements to me over Infinity series as well as most RPG designs is the engagement system.  In most games, if a glass cannon character gets engaged by an enemy, their initial thought is to run and kite the enemy until a frontline character can reestablish engagement with the enemy.  However, if you attempt to run and kite in Pillars, you will suffer an automatic disengagement attack.  This system forces the combat to have more tactical value than what you see in most games with enemies just being kited around.Of course, that is a lot of talk about combat, Pillars also has very deep and reactive story telling through conversations and choose your own adventure style cut scenes.  In both, you will have a variety of choices based on your characters attributes and skills.  Additionally, in conversations, there is a disposition system which tracks your character in 10 different personality types such as cleverness, cruelty, honesty, and more.  These will allow for some additional role-playing through the game as you develop your character.With an unnamed expansion already announced, Pillars should have a lot of run time and with the variety of character classes and choices in the story, a lot of replayability as well.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												Get PoE on sale. It's a 6/10 for me.Here's what makes the game for me.PROs: - the game is beatiful to look at - the worldbuilding, I think the non-DND world setting came out just fineCONs:- When I think Pillars, I think loading screens. Lots of them. All the time. Getting longer and longer as you progress in the game. For 2015, a 2D game, with the amount of memory our computers have these days. No.  - The character system is designed to yield "sensible" characters, regardless of your choices. That's an explicit design goal. It's trying to save newcomers from thinking/planning out their parties, making sure they can be successful no matter what. I understand the attempt at minimizing frustration and catering to non-min-maxers first, concentrating on the narrative instead. But barring extreme scenarios like solo runs and speed runs, the end result is that no matter how you design your character(s), there's likely be very little difference in how you play most of the game. Your choices do not really imply a play style. - Character progression. There is little that makes a difference. The stats making a difference are defined by the level alone. That's following the "anything should be a sensible choice" philosophy, which translates to "anything is an equally uninteresting choice". So you outlevel every encounter eventually, you can't often outsmart it. There's just no speicalization choices that would make enough of a difference.- The game consists mostly of combat. Mostly of pointles combat against trash mobs. It's becomes repetetive and boring 1/3 into the game. Combat is not what I find most exciting about RPGs. I understand that combat is a very important aspect, but reducing the game to just that... - In general there is little choice and variety in how you tackle quests. In ACT I there *is* a single quest involving Raedric's Hold where you actually do have choices and options. Different points of access. Different decisions on the outcome. Different paths through the levels. Different *alliances* you can make on the way. The rest of the game: not so much. Linear "kill everything on this map before going to the next" design most of the time. - Buffs generally not practicalSo you're walking into the lair of a dangerous monster and you can't pre-buff your party to be more resistant to its particular attacks. You have to do this when combat starts. Which is to say, you'll not do it, because in combat it is much more beneficial to cast something offensive bringing the enemy down as quickly as possible, or debuffing him. That decision was to make sure the game did not have to be balanced around your party being pre-buffed in battles all the time, pre-buffing being considered a tedious repetitive activity. Well, in practice it results in the party not getting much of buffs at all, and the priest being a mostly useless character in or before battle, also reducing on the complexity of the game. The game could very well be balanced around having certain buffs on major fights. - Engagement mechanicsEngagement mechanics penalize movement with an almost guaranteed auto-hit (painful, since it would often crit) when trying to disengage from an opponent. That means, once you've 'crossed swords' with someone, you stay there. This was invented to prevent kiting enemies around, having them owned effortlessly by ranged party members. Again an understandable proposition. In practice, that means you play PoE much like you play an MMORPG: have 1-2 high defense units take "aggro" and finish them off with some high DPS units lurking in the back. Rinse repeat. It also means most fights are static and not tactical at all. Your tanks go first, your damage dealers and crowd control units go in the back. The enemy AI is mostly limited to "rush closest enemy". So they engage with the tanks and wait to be killed. Only exception being some caster enemies which are scripted to attack/dominate party members most susceptible to their attacks.- No innovation in RPG mechanics/character behaviour beyond what what was already there in IE games. For example: getting in combat mode. Consider this situation: some random unnamed NPC peasant catches your armed-to-the-teeth 6 man party stealing his rice bowl out of his cupboard. Most likely he'll turn hostile and try to kill you. Because that's what peasants armed with a wooden spoon generally do when defending their rice bowl against 6 hardened warriors ready for battle, waving swords around that are covered in magical flames. Even bodyguards at a brothel should run away if outnumbered 3 to 1. Oh, and nobody takes offence at the carnage if you 'legitimately' kill half a village, and two factions because 'the gods' demanded it as part of a quest to 'gain favor'... You're being a murderous villain and nobody even seems to care. That's not RPG. Even as far back as Gothic I you could beat somebody down, rob them blind with all the consequences for faction status etc, and yet not kill them. I expected something beyond "killing everyone is the best and most straight forward solution to every quest" in PoE. Where are some smarter choices like locking enemies in a trap for example?- The Stronghold mechanics are a joke. Its benefits are obscured by load screens. The investments you make you'll never recoup from the taxes you get across the entire duration of the game. It is mostly devoid of any life, and not the hub of operations at all. The benefits are not better than going to the next best city/village hub. And mostly, it's a bunch of annoyances waiting to happen: You have to keep coming back to defend the keep, you have to watch all your captives flee eventually, you have to micro-manage some chars to 'escort' visitors lest they cause trouble, you have to micro-manage some chars to go on '#prestige-modifier'-Adventure, to come back with some copper and no rewards to speak of, much less even a summary of what they were supposedly doing. There's not a single plot option open to you if you have invested in your keep, as opposed to not investing in it and letting it rot. So it's an annoyance that costs micromanagement effort and money. I expected better.instead of time-based mechanics for stronghold taxes everything hinges on 'stronghold turns' which are artificial units that tick away as you solve quests and tasks (of which there are only so many). That is to prevent rest-spamming and getting filthy rich from the tax income. Same for stronghold "adventures". So here you have it, you'll invest all that money into your stronghold to then not be able to "role-play", by just roaming the land for a bit, and wait for the next tax day to upgrade your kit with. Nope, you'll have to keep playing quests exactly like you would if the stronghold was not even there. And then eventually you'll get a pittance of a tax while you've just resolved a quest somewhere. - Crafting is uninspired. Yes you can do it. But you can do it anywhere, with pre-defined recipes that you know from the outset and hardly learn additions to. Apparently every brainless♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥can just pop out a flower, some bat ears, a ruby and 300 coppers to 'enchant' their favorite pair of pants to be #{damage-type}-proof on the spot. No probs. Oh, but only of they are at least level 4.- The story itself. I liked the world and writing. I did not like the pacing/presentation at all. To me it made no sense that the main character is chasing the villian so relentlessly. Aside from problems with player character motivation, it's just not original to have the story be an uninspired chase of an ever elusive villian from hub to hub. The motivations of the villain itself are not clear most of the time, so there isn't even a 'cause' to attach to. If you like BG1 as it is, you're going to like PoE. But unless you've spent the last 10 years under a rock, you'll feel the flaws most keenly as well. You've likely played better.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Have you ever played Baldur's Gate? Icewind Dale? Neverwinter Nights?Well, those games are called CRPGs: computer role-playing games.Pillars of Eternity fits just right in as their spiritual successor.ProsI bought it on a sale (60% off) so I felt my money was well spent!I finished it in about 80 hours and I took my time but didn't see everything. The money per hour ratio is pretty low, which is nice; I finished the game wanting for more! I won't buy the expansion now since I'm poor, but I'll add them to my wishlist; Gotta love the hoarding, exploring and destruction feelings; Weapon improvement is awesome; There's no such thing as an alignment: you get a reputation on regions by how you portray yourself on situations. I know some people say it's a con, but ♥♥♥♥ them.   Reputation: Irrational +1, Aggressive +1.  ConsSometimes dialogs are boring so I skipped them. The main story is about lost souls and past lives and stuff, but to be honest I felt it was too wordy sometimes; Dialogs are displayed like this: "What is he doing?" - you asked yourself while reading this guy's review. - "I guess I can see the point now", you mumbled while scratching your chin.  Sometimes the quoted sentences are voiced, but the other parts are not and there's no pause for you to read what's in between the voiced sentences. This actually irritated me a lot. It broke the immersion so much I just hurried the silent reading and considered the voice acting a distraction. I used to feel relief when the sentences weren't voiced so I could take my time; I couldn't find a key that centers the screen on character. Maybe there is one but I was way too lazy to find it; Some minor UI bugs, but none of them were a show-stopper. I'm a Unity developer myself and I know UIs can be a pain to fix, but sometimes pop-ups were flickering fast and making the text hard to read. This gave me a bad first impression since it happened at the character creation screen;Some things I learned the hard wayAny class can disarm traps: there's a skill called Mechanics so just invest on it. Make a rogue only if you love sneak attack like me;Characters are moving too slow? Press D to turn on Fast Mode;Endurance is how much punishment you can take before fainting in battle. When the battle is over, all characters get up and fill their Endurance with part of their overall Health. If a character faints in battle there's a severe random debuff that only go away when resting; I tried playing on normal difficulty, but after a while I sticked to easy.  This change only applies to maps you haven't visited yet.  I know some people like to suffer and get maimed by the game, but I'm in for the ride and good times; When picking up loot, you can put it all at your party's stash (it's the chest at the bottom-left corner of the UI). Every character has 20 slots for stuff, but you don't need to fill them. Ever; You can spend some gathered items to improve weapons and armor only AFAIK. Do it on unique items since they have buffs you can't get by any other means; Same bonuses given by equipment don't stack. If you have gloves that give you Might +1 and a headgear that gives Might +2, you'll only get the +2 bonus; Pets are cute but useless. I thought they would evolve to something fierce and dangerous, but no, they just follow you all over the place. A pretty useless feature if you ask me.Overall the experience is awesome and I believe it's worth the price and the effort.Unless you don't like CRPG, and in that case I'm wondering why you read this far.Thanks for reading and here's an ascii crooked cat to commend you on your efforts:|\- - -/||  o_o  | \ _^_/

												Pillars of Eternity is incredibly in-depth and one of the closest experiences to Dungeons & Dragons I've had in a video game. The storyline is definitely one of the more interesting ones, with an incredible amount of lore to explore and each character you meet has a background just waiting to be heard. The environments are gorgeous. And the combat is deep & challenging and a real plus for fans of Balder's Gate and Dragon Age. I would highly recommend checking it out. Especially for fans of the old Infinity Engine games and cRPGs. It's fun!

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is maybe a hard approach for people who never played Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale (or any other Infinity-Engine Game), as Diablo 3, Dragon Age and other Action-Roleplaying-Games are out these days. But if you have played e.g. Baldurs Gate (and so on...) it's like a warm welcome home. All characteristics of good and old fashioned roleplaying are fully included in Pillars of Eternity. On top of that comes a wonderfully detailed painted world, a great and lovely written Story along with very fine dialogues and character interaction. I highly recommend it to every fan of Infinity Engine Games, as well as to everybody who is looking for a challenge along roleplaying and to those who are not thrown back by slightly outdated graphical styles and the absence of a Coop- or Multiplayermode.To be honest, there are not that many overly outstanding features - I like the Keep Building and the way of character development very much, the fights are nice and tactical challenging sometimes (!). There are also some nice hints and referers to other games and stories. All I expected from PE was a solid RPG in the Style of Baldurs Gate - and yes, that's what I got.With that I want to adress the pricing, which seems to be a problem for many people out there at the moment. Judging about the worth of a game is pretty subjective, of course. But I'll try to approach it from an almost neutral point of view; in Germany it's at 41,99€ at the moment what makes it a fullpriced title. Does it contain playtime and replayabilty worth that price? Yes! But does it contain a mindblowing new experience to RPGamers? No! If you're looking for new and innovative games, better search elsewhere. This is an all-classic experience, polished to glow these days, but not to brightly shine.So the price may be a bit to high at the moment. People who either don't really care or are into the genre anyways should buy it. Those who just want to test and give it a quick look better shouldn't at the moment, instead they better wait for a steam sale or online-distributor deal.The point and the grounding of this choice is; Are you aware of what you get? Get informed - The Internet offers so many ways these days. Personally I have a great load of fun with it. And when I play I find myself spending almost 4+ hours a session afterwards, which is a mark for a good game to me. Thanks for reading!

number of helpful: 82 of 91 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
"What if we can be assured of nothing?" - Iovara ix EnsiosIt should be sometime around the summer of 2002 when I discovered the existence and the concept of not any computer RPG - but specifically Baldur's Gate, and every classic computer RPG Bioware and Black Isle Studios produced thereafter. I was just old enough to play a story oriented game by the time, and possessed enough language skills to get a liking to story narrative + fantasy literature. So my formidable adventure with CRPG games began, crafting a fascination for me in the manner of roleplaying and story narrative in video games forever.It's 2016 now, and as I installed Pillars of Eternity, the tremendous hype of thousands of CRPG lovers who experienced the genre back in the time in its full glory rang in my ears. A grand expectation was at hand, and I was worried that even though it would be a sweet shot at nostalgia, this might not be a genuine deal. Then I started playing this game. 170 hours in, I completed it and I am positive that Pillars of Eternity holds the promise of being a genuine successor to old CRPGs, deserving every little bit of praise coming to Obsidian Entertainment’s way. It is a glorious experience.The mysterious world of Eora - a high fantasy setting developed by Obsidian Entertainment, and home to many creatures and concepts of wonder, both new and old for us - holds many secrets, including the secret of the Watcher. As we begin the game, we create our character, attaining him/her both expected race/class combinations and abilities, and a background to establish former personal experience. The character customization options are various, and each new Watcher we would create would most certainly hold a new approach to this mysterious world. It should be useful to note that every background/class/race combination presents a new outlook and new dialogue options for the said character, promising a diverse gaming experience even as we start.Whomever we decide to play as in this world, starts up in a caravan journey, approaching the hardy region of Dyrwood, for whatever reason that we hold at the time. The rough journey gets rougher as we get sick with high fever and troubling dreams in the middle of the night, and as the caravan takes a pause near some ruins sacred to the local people of Glanfathans. An age old dispute occurs, a slaughter takes place, then... a biawac appears - a dreaded wind storm speculated to rob people of their souls. It rips the region apart, leaving everyone as hollow, lifeless shells and somehow, we become the only survivor. Witnessing the source of the storm and coming alive out of the chilling supernatural experience, tired and frustrated, we manage to arrive the small settlement of Gilded Vale, only to be called as "the Watcher" by the spirit of a dwarven woman...Now, we are able to perceive spirits and touch souls, reaching for the boundary between the physical and the spiritual. From thereon, we will take on a long journey, trying to learn the nature of our abilities and the cost they attain to our sanity, searching for the mystery of this biawac, an ancient servant of a secret sect and a life long forgotten by even time itself, yet not by the soul. As we journey, we'll gather companions with their own stories and missions, harbor companionship for many, enmity for some and we'll gather a reputation for our deeds throughout the realm. Involuntarily, we'll come to learn an ancient secret and change the face of Eora forever.Excited? I knew I was when I realized that I had just spent 8 hours nonstop as I just started to play the game. The world is quite rich, characters are realistic with various personalities, outlooks and aspirations of their own, narrative is elaborate both with philosophical, social and political context - and the humor itself is point on based on party interactions and comments! As I finish the game, I find myself already missing fiery demagogies of Durance, hilarious remarks of Hiravais, smart exaggerations of Aloth and comforting anecdotes of Eder... and quite so many other NPCs with colorful personalities that I'll miss.Independent from NPC personalities, the core story mechanics and interrelation of cause/consequence are surprisingly successful. There are various ways to conclude a quest, and the way to go with any of them would subtly alter the outcome of the main scenario, as well as the tone and interaction of the world to a degree. Your choices would attain your character some characteristic values like "benevolent", "cruel", "stoic", "smart" etc. As you attain those personality values through gameplay, some NPCs start to treat you differently based on your personality consistency and reputation, presenting new outcomes based on your actions.A minor example from my experience: At some point in the game I was in Defiance Bay - the main city of the scenario, bustling with side quests. A boy approached me and asked whether I'd get a steel dagger for him. When asked what a 10 year old boy would do with such as weapon, he stated that he'd like to become a squire to a knight and he could do anything with such a weapon. Big dreams, huh? I said "why not", completed the mission and carried on. Sometime later I revisited the city, and turned around the corner to shop, and the town crier declared that a boy lost 3 fingers in an accident! Just... wow.Graphics exemplify the capability of Unity engine in presenting a classic Infinity engine atmosphere, and behold: results are a glamorous beauty. We have the classic isometric mapping with a six people party formation to roam around, yet on close-up we are presented with tiny artworks at every corner from the architectural wonders to the natural beauties of the realm. Every new map that you tread into is a new source of respect for the labor put into the game. The soundtrack, environmental sound effects and voice acting are all top-notch, presenting an immersive environment in an isometric gameplay - which is a hard feat by nature.Here comes the trickiest part about any RPG - combat mechanics. I won't go so far to declare that they are the best, yet with various customization options similar to D&D 3.5 mechanics, character builds are formidable. Each and every class have their strong suits and flaws, so all combat mechanics - and even some diplomacy encounters - work better in a full party. Usually, having 1-2 tank fighters - Eder is quite appropriate for that - , 2-3 dps characters - both ranged or close quarter - and a healer - Durance all the way! - is a decent party combination that would put you through the game, with some decent challenges on the way. Side note: alongside both expansions, there are a total of 5 Dragons within the realm and dragons are no joke in this game, as it should be so. Prepare yourself heavily for those encounters, they would take careful planning and more than one venture.The game harbors various achievements. Some half of those are mostly story and exploration based that would come naturally with your progress. The other half though, contain difficulty achievements that would take you to solo the game on various excruciating difficulties. I heard that Barbarian class - or a carefully arranged Chanter with decent summons - would be the way to go for that, yet the game gets patched quite often even today so I have no idea what mechanic has been polished or watered down to arrange a balance. One single achievement is only granted to kickstarter backers though, so if you haven't been a backer it is sadly out of question to %100 the game in terms of achievements.As the last verdict, Pillars of Eternity is a game worthy of the experience. It is basicaly a must for any RPG gamer!Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

number of helpful: 157 of 205 people (77%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is an isometric CRPG from the studio that brought us Fallout: New Vegas and South Park: The Stick of Truth. One night you are travelling with a caravan through an area north of the Gilded Vale. The caravan stops for everyone to rest and you go out to get water for the group, you return to find a group of mercenaries who have killed all but one member of the caravan, a strange phenomenon occurs and you are forced to flee through a cave. When you reach the other side you find a strange ritual taking place and when it is complete, something about you is different. In Pillars of Eternity you must venture through Eora to find out what this change is and how you can reverse it.PoE is set in the fictional realm of Eora. Eora is full of different factions and races and as you play the game you will discover how they link to each other and why as well as discovering the rest of Eora's deep and incredibly well thought out lore.A couple of things to note before you carry on reading my review. Firstly I have not finished this game at the time of writing my review, I'd say I'm about a fifth of the way in but I feel like I've experienced enough of it to write a detailed review. Secondly this is the first time I have properly played a CRPG and so I'm inexperienced with this type of game so some of my opinions may differ from CRPG veterans.The Game Itself+Great graphics and well designed emvironments though the character models aren't the best+A reasonably detailed character creator with a number of different races, classes and backgrounds to choose from+An interesting main plot as well as some interesting side quests+There's a hell of a lot to do, as mentioned previously at 16 hours playtime I'm only around a fifth of the way through all of the content on offer+Due to the game's reputation system and side quests with different possible endings you can create your own story when playing PoE even though the outcome is the same+Fantastic writing, in particular the interaction of different characters who feel real due to how good the writing is, e.g. how they respond to what is being said+Some great voice acting+As mentioned before Eora has very deep lore and finding out about it over the course of the game and through the Digital Collector's book is fascinating+The combat is simple yet rewarding and you really have to think about who should attack who and with what so that you are successful, especially when fighting large groups+Eight different companions to find and team up with over the course of the game, each of a different class with unique abilities to help you in a fight+All eight companions have interesting backstories and all have a reason for being where you found them which is good to see+Relatively early in the game you get possesion of a rundown stronghold and you can restore it to its former glory, I absolutely love that kind of thing in games so I thoroughly enjoyed building it back up+The different locations in the game are rather large and each one either has or is linked to a fair few sidequest though the map looks a bit empty as there aren't too many different locations+Outstanding soundtrack and great sound effects throughout+The game's difficulty can be changed throughout+Big heads mode, thanks Josh!-Voice acting is used sporadically, the main characters all have their own voice actors yet most of their dialogue is unvoiced and you have to read it, I felt that it often broke the flow of dialogue as one section would be voiced and the next wouldn't be with seemingly no method behind it-As mentioned previously the character models don't look great-Frequent loading screens which take a long time-There's a Kickstarter backer only achievement so unless you backed it you can't get 100%Special Edition ContentThis covers the Royal Edition of the game, the first five are also available in the Champion edition. I will cover them in the order that they appear on the store page.+The OST is, as mentioned, fantastic+/-The Campaign Almanac is interesting but the font is difficult to read+The Digital Game Map is very nice and has a good amount of detail though it has a bit of a strange resolution+/-The Making Of Documentary isn't available yet-The Wallpapers are all very nice but they all have strange resolutions and aren't available in 1920x1080-The ringtones are nice little sound clips but I don't think you'd want them set as your phone's ringtone, most of them are soundclips of a character speaking+/-The Digital Novella isn't available yet+The Digital Collector's Book is very good and goes into great detail when explaining the game's lore+The Concept art is absolutely fantastic and very high quality, I thoroughly enjoyed looking through it+The Digital Strategy guide is very helpful and well writtenVerdict:9.5A truly outstanding isometric CRPG with great graphics, an extremely well-written story, good combat and rich lore to back it all up. If you're a fan of CRPGs you've done yourself a disservice by not picking this game up sooner.***This review was written using a key provided by the Publisher for review purposes***El K.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												What a fantastic game, I have been completely blown away so far. After playing Divinity Original Sin last year, I didn't think it could get any better but this gem has proven me wrong. The story and writing is absolutely incredible, the lore is very rich, and best of all the game is HARD. In just my 7 hours of playing so far, I have had to redo many fights, planning out new strategies, trying out new spells and weapons, all in the goal of bashing those pesky monsters to bits. Did I mention the bits, or rather giblets? Yeah, many times when an enemy is crittically injured by a blow and dies, he will explode in a shower of blood and fleshly bits, and it's always a fun sight. In the graphics department, this is a very debatable topic, but I think these lovely hand drawn backgrounds surpass many modern games in their simplistic beauty. Music and sound is also very well done, and I've taken a special interest in the great way ranged weapons sound and feel in this game.The two companions that I have come across my travels so far have been very well written, and their backstories very diverse. My only complaint on their regard is that at the moment the game has no rogue, barbarian or monk companions, so you will most likely end up filling those roles with custom adventurers or your own player character, but that is a minor gripe.In regards to equipment, scrolls, potions and a plethora of other goodies, this game has them in spades. Hundreds of common and magical weapons and armor are just waiting to be discovered, many of them very unique in both name and appearance. Thankfully, the game has a stash mechanic to store your massive hoard of items, so you can gather to your heart's content.All in all, I couldn't be happier with my purchase. The one very minor bug I've ran across so far was restricted to the tutorial popups and a very odd sound loop, but disabling those easily rectified the issue so in no way does it hamper the game for me. If you are one of the many avid baldurs gate, icewind dale, or neverwinter nights fans that yearn to revist the glory days of old, look no farther because Pillars of Eternity is the perfect choice for you.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Yes it's early.  But whoa...    This game should be up for literary awards.  Only the written word can so easily, and completely, convey meaningful emotion and nuance.  Perfected along with the vibrant backgrounds, subtle yet solid soundtrack, and actually legible at high resolution text (adjustable font size in menu), this game will hold to be the test amongst all story based rpgs.  What little I have played of the combat engine has been intuitive.  Infinity engine perfected.  This game plays like a MUCH better written Baldur's Gate, except buttery as well, ...butter!   The extremely competent game mechanics hide away nicely, so that the immersion in environment and story stands unbroken for hours.  There have already been some large mood shifts and some mouth open gasps within the first 2 hours of gameplay.  I admit that I am already a huge fan of Obsidian, but it is with great reason.  I do not game for victory.  I do not game for competition.  I game to be entertained.  A 50-100 hour interactive book or movie is an immesurably better option than scrolling endlessly thru Facebook, or watching "reality" advervision.  Mr Sawyer, Avellone, Cain, Brennecke, Urquhart, and the rest of that team deserve an award.  Not an award given to shooters because of realistic ballistics.  No.  I am talking Pulitzer prize level descriptive writing..(in my opinion obviously).  Kickstarter gave them the freedom to be as flowery as they wanna be, and boy oh boy did it pay off.  AAA publishers and  mindless console drones, screw you and your multiplayer gib shot twitch muscle "e-sports".  No, not really, as that stuff has merit to you if you enjoy it.  But for me, THIS IS WHERE IT'S AT!  I have the butterflies like the first time I read LOTR, long before Elijah Wood supplanted my vision of what  Frodo looked like.  Bring your imagination and ENJOY!!>>>>UPDATE<<<<56 hours in and I love this game even more!  I have played thru some bad (mechanically) games just to see a decent story.  Not a worry here!  This story seems layered and rich, and even the game mechanics are amazing.  Anybody who doesn't like the way it plays are either looking for something specific (it does NOT play exactly like Baldur's Gate, despite similar appearance and mechanics), or they just haven't taken the time to learn the system.  If you choose to pass up an amazing artistic Tour de Force due to "mages not being as OP as in BG" or something along these lines, then you are very hard to please and I believe it to be a mistake.  If you like RPGs, and when you think of "RPG" you don't immediately think of skyrim, then this is worth a shot!!

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!Gorglax the Destroyer, an orlan aristocratic ranger, was far from home. Hell, she was far from civilization. The nearest town was a day's walk, and she needed medical attention. Ever since that storm she hadn't felt herself. She stared for a while at the clearing ahead, a quiet meadow painted purple by wildflowers in bloom. Birds chirped, flitted and fluttered. Bugs droned, bumbled and buzzed. A symphony orchestra was blasting all around her, which was more than a little jarring. Finally she was jerked from her daze by her antelope companion, Gary. “We have to get to Gilded Vale,” she said, breaking the silence. “MRRABLURGHHBLURGH,” agreed Gary the antelope (that is an approximate onomatopoeia of antelope noises). They set off to find the road when two young wolves, truants probably, attacked. Gorglax raised her arbalest, wound it, and loosed a bolt into one wolf. It whined and bled out on the soft blanket of wildflowers as the other closed in, bearing its canines. Gorglax was done for, she couldn't wind her arbalest fast enough. She shut her eyes and had all but accepted her fate when Gary the ♥♥♥♥ing antelope butted the beast, causing it to explode in a gory geyser. After acknowledging how metal that just was, the pair continued on their adventure.I liken video games to baking. Yes, the recipes are frequently rigid and mostly unforgiving of experimental deviation (one such deviation I made while baking resulted in what I've coined as “bread soup”); but even the most structured recipe allots for the 'dash,' the mysterious magic that often defines the finished product. “Oh, this is simply DELICIOUS. What did you put in this?”“Oh, this old thing? It's pretty standard: egg, milk, flour... and just a dash of magic.”“MAGIC ISN'T AN INGREDIENT, TED.”And yet that douchey non-response best describes what makes Pillars of Eternity so excellent:  it's an original CRPG with the combined minds, bodies, and souls of its classic predecessors. It is, perhaps, greater than the sum of its parts.So for the mildly spoiler sensitive crowd, let's revisit at the last paragraph. Everyone else keep your hands and feet inside the review at all times.Pillars of Eternity has you, the hero, traveling the land of Dyrwood, a mystical realm filled with beings, creatures, ruins, and adra – a sort of organic rock jutting from the earth like jade claws from the depths. You are (shockingly!) the chosen one of sorts, a Watcher – beings capable of seeing the previous lives of the inhabitants of Dyrwood, speaking to the dead. Most that claim to be Watchers are hucksters, charlatans, and the rest are often driven positively batty by all of the intrusive soul fragmented former lives (theirs included). There's mystery, intrigue, ancient civilizations and arcane magics, unique party members to drag along... pretty standard RPG fare. There are troubled hamlets, a large city, a ruined fortress, and natural wonders to gawk at, all lovingly prerendered. The world and those settled there feel alive, and for the first time in a while I felt compelled to listen to every bit of dialogue, read every bit of codex, flavor text, all just to familiarize myself with this fascinating new world.Of course you'll have to do some killing, it is an RPG after all. And you'll kill 'em all: wolves, giant spiders, lizard men, ghosts, bandits, trolls, wizards, spooky skeletons, mushroom men and dragons... Pillars of Eternity doesn't exactly break the mold when it comes to mythical beasties and foes, but the combat does. When an enemy is spotted your party will pause and you'll be able to select a general attack or take the time to individually select special actions for each party member.When you do engage you'll see their various defenses, strengths, and weaknesses of your foe – dependent on factors like weapon type, flanking, status effects, etc. It's thoroughly tactical and engaging, and even on lower difficulty settings I watched my entire party succumb to one or two enemies because I just tossed them into the fray all willy nilly. After dispatching enemies your bestiary will be updated with pertinent information. There's also often sweet, sweet corpse loot; loot can be equipped, used for crafting, or sold to vendors.I'll also touch briefly on the travel/sleepy time mechanics. See, the Eastern Reach is pretty expansive, and you'll be hoofing it from the get go. Day and night cycles, and characters will become fatigued from travel (not to mention bogged down by negative status effects after lots of fights). You have one of two options: camping out “in it” while adventuring, or shacking up at a number of permanent locations. Camping should only be used as is necessary, since you only have so many supplies to set up camp with, and some of the longer adventures will require your party to get that much needed refreshing between combat.The minor-est of complaints! Here they come, ready yourselves. Because the world is prerendered and mostly static, fights will sometimes break out behind solid objects, which is a little frustrating (if you zoom in on a solid object obscuring a character it will become semi-translucent, but it's still a pain). And when you have a full party attacking enemies the notifications fly by in a flurry of text, which can make optimizing attacks difficult on the fly. Other than these quibbles the game is great. I've encountered no bugs, no glitches, and it's just overall a delight to play. Anyone familiar with classic BioWare fare and CRPGs will find themselves very much at home.Pillars of Eternity is, simply put, really really good. The scope of it is dizzying, your first hour ingame may very well be in the character creation menu (but in a good way!), the combat is deeply satisfying, the score is GoT/LotR/Souls Series/Elder Scrolls Series all wrapped up in one, and  the story is thoroughly captivating. I haven't completed this game (it looks like the first of many playthroughs may well take 60+ hours), but short of it ending with an about-face “it was all a dream” or an elaborate song and dance number my sentiment will remain unmoved: Pillars of Eternity is a spectacular game, proof that old-school done right is timeless... it certainly helps that I'm playing as a dwarf/elf with a wisecracking antelope sidekick that explodes wolves.  That's always a plus.

												Excellent old-school game if a little unpolished at release. Now after all patches and expansions it's worth every penny. Well thought-out lore is especially great for immersion.Thumbs up to Obsidian for maintaining excellent quality of content and staying true to RPG/D&D roots with PoE and Tyranny projects. This is particularly worthy of respect in today's dark times when PC games are clustered around two terrible extremes: dumb AAA chewing gum titles on one end, and half-baked pixel-art indie garbage on the other end of the spectrum.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Baldur's Gate was the ultimate videogame for me when I was a kid, but I've always had trouble convincing my friends to like it. The same is true now for Pillars of Eternity. The quality of the game is superlative, it's just an inaccessable format to some people.  I think this is probably the game for you if you can enjoy a fantasy novel or have ever read up on the lore of a videogame outside of the game. The thing this type of game does best is world building. The characters you meet have weight, everything matters, and the universe feels unique. It's not a cheap knockoff fantasy world where they just switch around the names of familiar tropes. There's a holistic personality to the world you're in and you just want to get to know it. And the best part is that getting to know the world doesn't mean reading through the codexes in a menu somewhere. The game teases bits of lore and it's up to you to find out more. You learn about a war and you have to meet a veteran to find out what happened. You find the name of a god and you seek out a priest to learn their beliefs. You'll hear someone tell a myth and you'll actually seek out the book in game so you can get the full story. And even then, no one source is definitive, so you're delighted if you ever stumble upon a new tidbit.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												A game that old school RPG players waited for a long time. A true isometric RPG in Baldur's Gate style. Fantastic gameplay where tactical combat is more important than fast clicking. For example, the old/new stats system really make you question and forces you to think seriously when it comes to choosing your weapon or armour that grants specific attribute bonuses, or, for that matter, when you are creating you character. The endurance - health system is also one of the factors you must consider when you enter a battle, because, when you lose all the endurance in the battle you get knocked out. When the battle is over you regain your senses, but you lose health. The only way to regain your health is by sleeping in the Inn, using the camping supplies, and, of course, keeping an eye out on the endurance levels all together, because, when your character health is depleted, he/she will die. There are so many things you can do in the game and you can easily be side-tracked, but, as it happens, the main story doesn't get lost in the mix. It only expands, whether it is by adding the content and backstory to your companions, or by upgrading your stronghold and solving quests inside it. All in all, it is a great kickstarted game for the die hard and greenhorn RPGers alike.
