content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
Pillars of Eternity is the best roleplaying game I've played since Neverwinter Nights.It's a classical western fantasy RPG - the player guides a party of adventurers through an epic journey, where the fate of the world just might hang in the balance.It's clear that Pillars draws heavy inspiration from Dungeons & Dragons - when creating a character, the player chooses a race and class, then assigns attributes and skills, and the game mechanics are obviously supported by a rigid ruleset and powered by virtual dice rolls. In addition, some of the classes, weapons, etc. may be familiar to D&D aficionados, but Obsidian has done an outstanding job of creating a distinct, vibrant world for Pillars of Eternity, from a wide variety of races and (orthogonal, in some cases) cultures to a range of traditional and innovative classes to geography and folklore to political rivalries to its own pantheon of living deities, around which the main storyline revolves.Many of the reviews of this game mention Baldur's Gate, and with good reason - gameplay-wise, Pillars borrows heavily from BG: isometric perspective, formation-oriented party management, fast-paced realtime combat with a variety of conditional autopause settings, even the "You must gather your party before venturing forth" message when transitioning between areas. However, these are all good things (maybe not the message), and everything feels right, whether exploring the wilderness,  creeping anxiously through a crypt, navigating a bustling city, or frantically trying to survive an ambush. I particularly enjoyed an original mechanic they've added: there are several sections where the player is guided through a sort of illustrated choose-your-own-adventure sequence, where the various options may involve intuition, tactics, or skill checks, and will almost certainly have nontrivial consequences.I do have a few minor quibbles: for example, it's possible to accept at least one of the optional quests and get fairly entangled in it before realizing that there's no hope of completing it at the party's current level. Each entry or exit from even the most insignificant building involves a loading screen, which means that exploring new town or village becomes a long sequence of these screens, divided by short segments of walking between buildings. Finally, the player, through a special ability she gains early on, is able to gain insight into the lives of many of the non-playable characters - however, these insights have absolutely no impact on the game in any way.The story is epic, complex, and engaging - one of the finest I've encountered in a computer RPG, and the personas and backstories of the auxiliary playable characters the player will encounter on her travels weave seamlessly in, enriching the depth and color of the experience.All in all, Pillars of Eternity is a fantastic game, and I would unhesitatingly recommend it to any roleplaying enthusiast.

												Everyone who grew up with the Infinity Engine games -- Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, etc. -- owes it to themselves to play Pillars of Eternity. This is the sequel we've all been waiting for. The heart and soul of the isometric RPGs remain, complete with gorgeous environments and an inspired combat system outside the constraints of D&D. The only thing that's changed is, well, all the stuff that you could possibly make better.57 hours spent to complete the base game missing only a small handful of sidequests. Sensational game.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is Obsidian's first try to make a game without any publisher pushing (which is what fans believed was always the problem with the bugs in their games for example) thansk to their kickstarter campaign. As it turns out yes they can release a well polished game (even with a huge complicated world like poe). Managed to finish the game after 75 hours more or less so you can see this is a huge game. there is tons of quests both main and sidequests and most of them are actually decent (not the go there and get me 5 furs kind). Even in the few "fetch" quests there is a story there and twists that made them fresh and enjoyable. The game looks very pretty if you like the old school isometric style, has a great soundtrack which managed not to bore me after playing the game for 70+ hours. Everyone who likes the genre this is perhaps the top crpg that has come out in the last 10+ years and certainly the best kickstarted project i have backed so far (although shadowrun is a close second). There is a ton of options in the dialogues and choices that can and will affect the world in quite a big way (unlike other "rpgs" which will not be named). The combat was interesting and engaging and quite hard even on normal especially on the start of the game. There is also a huge totally optional dungeon in game (14-15 floors). Definitely recommend this game and i hope obsidian can go back to ks and would gladly back them for more.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Yes this game is enjoyable - no I still wouldn't recommend it.This game is mostly a shallow attempt at recreating the succes of Baldurs Gate and similar infinity engine games but fails coming close to them.Better play Baldurs Gate 2 or Dragon Age: Origins again or just wait for 75% sale.Positive: + The graphics are beautiful yet stay true to it's sucsessors art style.Negative:- Loading times and perfomanceThere are pretier games out there. But there are few that take so long to load. And it get's far worse the longer you play. And for a game with such a nostalgic look the perfomance is horrible(low framrate and freezing). This game just is badly optimised in many ways.- The game just gives the illusion of choices. Nothing what you do and say matters. E.g. Godlikes are decribed as beeing hated on - you will never see any reaction on beeing a godlike.Or you can be a mass murder and people still react friendly to you. There are almost no quests where any of your choices change something. There are a few where a person dies or not accourding to your actions - but thats the most you get. Normally you can kill everyone involved or try to solve everyting peaceful - the outcome is the same. Your party members wont leave no matter what♥♥♥♥♥♥you do, even if you sacrifice one person from your party. - The game is full of Kickstarter "comercials"1/4 of all Characters you see in the game are from kickstarter funders - that do nothing, say nothing and often have totally unfitting names. They are just there so you can read the little stories the funders wrote. Even worse are the Kickstarter-tombstones. In every dungeon you see tombstones that are filled with funder texts - often nonsense ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The loading screen advise is even to not read them because they break the 4th wall.- Content was cut and put into the Expansion - it feels like an unfinished game without.Without the addon you don't even have a character for every class. Yet those Expansion characters where put on the cover of PoE. The items in the base game are very bland - all interesting weapons, especially the souldbound ones are expansion only. It feels like this content has been cut out and put in the expansion to sell these. Which wouln't even be that much  of a problem if we wouldn't be talking about more than 40€ for the base version amd 24€ for the DLC.- The game feels low-budgeted or rushed at many parts.* I have seen few crpgs with so few spoken text lines. There are many NPCs which don't even have one sentence which features voice acting. Yet for many NPCs it's exactly one spoken line and nothing more.  Oh other languages don't even get that 1 sentence spoken - voices stay english.* You are the only character contributing to the story. You followers don't matter. In conversations only your skills matter - even if one of your followers boosts a much higher skill than you. You are the only person involved in talking - the best you get is some meaningless comments from followers but these are quite rare.* Most uniques are not unique, they are just crafted with the same stats that you can craft by yourself. There are like 5 helmets with stats, and normal headwear doesn't gives any stats(why is so much of it even there?). Even full helmets don't give armor(=deflection).* You will come accros bugs that make you feel you play a beta game. Items that don't work and show code-blocks, quests that you can't finish because you took a path that the devs didn't saw, save games going corrupt, very odd balance choices.- The game is at an awkward spot regarding story vs. gameplayThe story followers are built to bad that you feel punished for playing with them. Custom Characters are FAR stronger.Custom Characters don't talk.Even if they don't talk that much the story followers add much to the gameplay. Without them PoE feels more like reading trough a "choose your own adventure" book. Especially on the higher difficulties you are forced to play with custom Characters which reduces the amount of fluff and story you experience.So what do you want: A party with talking characters or a good party?- There are LOTS of informations missing.It begins with the lacking informations on weapon speed and other stats. You need to look up how everything works like you want to write a min maxing guide on some MMORPG to understand basic combat math - and you better look that up.- Minor nitpickings* You can't pickpocket. * Looting/stealing stuff reduces your reputations - unless you kill all bystanders. But the slaughter doens't affects your reputation most of the time. You can even play a "rightous" Paladin and don't suffer for killing & looting unimportant NPCs.* Combat is best solved in the cheesiest way possible 90% of the time - putting a tank in a chokepoint and the damage dealers behind him.* Often you can't loot the items that charaters obviously got.* Balance patches can make your party obsolete. I can understand that you can't play a character in the beta and expect that he will be as good as when you started. But PoE got a few heavy balance patches that made good characters nigh unplayable. One of these is coming soon, heavily nerfing one class (cipher).* The guide from the Royal Edition is wrong in many points because of changes after the release.In the end this game is not horrible. But there are so many odd design choices, lacking parts and bugs that this game is not that enjoyable. I would only advice to buy on 75% sale or in a bundle with the 2 DLCs.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												I have to say the game has surpassed my expectations thus far. I fell in love with Baldur's Gate in 1998, and this is the game I was waiting all those years for as a lifelong RPG fan.It has all the important pieces firmly in place- Great story- Deep gameplay mechanics (even if I would like it to be D&D 5th edition)- The dialogues are well written and utilize the attributes in a clever and interesting way- The party banter is here (yay)- The world is nicely crafted (I would prefer Forgotten Realms though, but beggars can't be choosers)- Added great additional mechanics (Choose your adventure style encounters)- Doesn't treat the player like an idiot, gives a solid amount of challenge- The graphics, music and the atmosphere are ideal, and unbeatable, especially for the heroic fantasy fans- Interesting quests, and amazing writing (i have mentioned that before, but can't stress in enough)I do hope this gem will sell millions and will herald a true RPG revival, not only from Obsidian (love you guys), but from other talented developers as well. I am sick and tired of the cancer modern Bioware-EA and other soulless developers were publishing after the demise of infinity engine era games, trying to pass dumb, console oriented, 'streamlined' uninspired turds as 'rpgs'.Like other reviewer wrote "Dear Baldur's Gate fans, welcome home." Thanks Obsidian, I do not regret backing this gem, thanks for bringing my home back.

												So far the (c)RPG reinnessance that started 2-3 years ago, brought by Kickstarter and independent efforts, has been nothing short of wonderful, with multiple minor titles and some great highlights as Shadowrun Dragonfall and Divinity Original Sin. But each game, while brilliant in their own way, was just short of a masterpiece as a whole.I'm pleased to say that Pillars of Eternity has become the first one to achieve total grandness. Combining intelligent writing and storytelling with depth of gameplay and this little concept we call "fun", it immerses you in an original world full of adventure and hours upon hours of immersion.If you are an RPG/cRPG fan at all, love Fantasy, or you are even interested in narrative games with in-depth choice and consequence at all, you owe yourself to play this game.What a great time to be alive.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												Pillars of Eternity is a top-down isometric party-based RPG in an original High Fantasy setting. Combat is in real-time but with optional pauses to sort out strategy. The influence of the D&D Infinity Engine games are strong, many of the developers had previously worked on those titles. I would compare this game mostly to Baldurs Gate II, as Pillars of Eternity has incorporated elements of the cancelled sequel (The Black Hound) to this game. Much like the Baldurs Gate games, you create your main character by selecting the sex, race, attributes, skills, class, portrait and physical appearance. Different from Baldurs Gate, you can now select a background history. This will not influence too much in the game, but they can open up new dialogue options, a few characters will treat you differently, and you'll have different skill points to use.My character I played through to beat the game and both the expansion packs was a rapier wielding Paladin with a smart mouth. For the rest of the team, I alternated between the in-game companions and ones I created from scratch. Pretty much any playstyle is supported (you can roll with a party of  only rangers, or only spell-casters, or just go solo and murder almost anyone) at least up to Hard mode. And each class offers a far more flexible play, Wizards don't have to be weak glass-cannons to be useful, and Barbarians don't have to be stupid either. Paladins have some of the strongest defensive play options, but that didn't mean my own character had to feel particularly gimped by going for a more offensive set-up.Two original classes included in the game is a spin on bards, called Chanters (in combat, their singing buffs or debuffs anyone near them, they are also the primary summoners of this game) and Ciphers. Ciphers are the “spellswords” of this game, instead of relying on an inventory of memorised spells, they build up physic energy by attacking enemy targets, and can use this energy to cast devastating spells onto the enemy. Whereas Priests and Wizards deplete their spells through usage, Chanters and Ciphers get stronger as the fighting goes on longer.Although I did enjoy the world the game was set in, the story and lore in the main-game does get a bit muddy around the third and fourth acts, the expansion packs feel much more tighter. Much like what Baldurs Gate III was supposed to be, souls and past lives are extremely central to the plot. My two biggest gripes with this game is the performance of the game, particularly in the more busier areas like cities. I have a GTX 680, and most of the more populated areas have a very noticeable drop in frame-rate, down to low 20s in some areas. The second is that going for the more grounded approach to fantasy means that there are far less interesting locales to visit. BGII had you visit a city under the sea, travel to different dimensions/planes, visit the Underdark, and much larger locations and maps. PoE might be more detailed, but it does feels much, much smaller, even with the expansion packs. That said, there are some nice QOL features that never existed in the old Baldurs Gate titles I wish they had now, for example: an option to speed up walking in some areas, a timer based stealth mode, plenty of easily accessibly information on how certain mechanics work, spell and ability radius circles, perma-death mode, and so on.As for the extras in the upgraded editions: map is nice to look at to give you context of where you are in that world, even just the once. The ringtones are bad, the wallpapers are meh, the documentary is fine, so is the almanac an enjoyable read. Soundtrack is awesome. My edition didn't include the novella.tl;dr: great if you loved top-down RPGs of old, there's plenty of this game to keep you engrossed. Not as epic as BGII, which is up to you if prefer the tone.

number of helpful: 111 of 174 people (64%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is average, enthusiastic fan fiction.Don't get me wrong. I loved BG1. And BG2. But not so much Throne of Baal. And Planescape: Torment is one of the best games I've ever played. However, Pillars of Eternity just feels like it was cobbled together by some diehard fans who couldn't let go. They're writing fan fiction to relieve the "glory days".The story itself is so so, and it can't decide if it wants to take itself seriously or wants to be a tongue in cheek fantasy parody. For example, there's an endless dungeon filled with vampires and mages and monsters right underneath your home, called the Endless Paths of Od Nua. Seriously? And the game takes pains to remind you in every town and forest you go to that it was crowdfunded, with little in-jokes and even name lists of sponsors plastered everywhere.  The big reveal at the end is predictable and underwhelming, especially since it basically begs the questions: "okay, so what?" and "so what exactly am I supposed to do about it? if anything?"As for the system itself, it's a D&D pastiche. Unlike Dragon Age: Origins, ShadowRun or even Risen, there's no reason for why the character classes are in the setting. It's just a grab bag of D&D tropes. Let's get the monk, the psychic, the barbarian, the druid, etc. etc. and copy paste them into our take on Forgotten Realms. You've got your elves and half-orcs (sorry, Aumaua), and dwarves. Whatever race and class you pick, don't worry. It has virtually no impact. The only thing the game tries to do for originality is that it combines attributes together in new and crazy ways, to pretend it's fresh and creative. However, why a fireball-hurling wizard needs to be a mountain of muscle to do real damage doesn't make any logical sense to me!All in all, this game will appeal to two types of gamers. The old-school Icewind Dale and Baldur's Gate fans who can't move on, and think modern games are rubbish. And secondly, for people new to the genre who want to be old school without having to deal with the dated graphics and hardcore difficulties of the really old games.Me? I thought the game was alright. A weak 3 out of 5. But I prefer to both replay my old favorites AND enjoying the new, cutting edge RPGs, rather than get lost in fan-fiction recreations of old legends. YMMV.

number of helpful: 35 of 45 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
Teal DeerDevelopers: Obsidian Entertainment Publishers: Paradox Interactive Initial release: March 2015Genre: CRPG, Strategy, Dungeon Crawler #Worth/NotWorth: #Worth Exposition, Concurrence and SummationPillars of Eternity a throwback back to the days of proper Role Playing games. Where character sheets and making actual dialogue decisions (coinciding with some stat checks, I don't believe there are dice rolls) were par for the course. An only slightly more modern take on Balders Gate or Icewind Dale.The game pretty quickly drops you into the action and tells you you're very important. Its up to you what to do with that or how to react. Combat takes place in real time. With each action using a cooldown to activate in order to avoid an interrupt, aside from movement. A sort of active turn based variety of combat. Character creation is extremely in depth perhaps lacking in physical customization but the character traits, stats, class and narrative background are all available for customization. There are many many many classes to choose from to fill out your 6 person party.  Barbarian – pretty self explanatory  Fighter – Most well rounded class Chanter – magic user (units – 'lines chanted' during battle) Druid – Shapeshifter (DPS) Cipher – magic user (units – 'Focus' earned from doing damage with regular weapon) Monk – Special abilities earned from 'Wounds' or damage taken  Paladin – Can be tankish, healer Priest – magic user, healer, pos+ neg- buff, debuff dealer  Ranger – has pet, (slightly useless rogue in my opinion) Rogue – charismatic, DPS, scouts, disarms and detects traps  Wizard – magic user (most effective use of Grimoire) Perma Death is a real thing on higher difficulties. The green bar on the character portrait is Heath, the overall status of that character. The portrait itself, when taking damage fills in red, this is endurance and when depleted is what will knock someone out of battle. If someones Health is depleted entirely. Bad News Bears I'm afraid. You'll run into characters that have quests associated with them and require you to take them on your journey. These characters are also voice acted as well as some important NPC's. Though not every line has a voice over as this was a kickstarter game (as the loading screen is very apt to point out) That's simply not a realistic goal for something with as much text and dialogue. I should mention that though another character can interact with NPC's you are making the dialogue choices based on your base character for any stat checks that may occur in conversation.  You can re-spec any character at any inn for a relatively inexpensive price if you've made a terrible judgment in choosing traits or some other facet that would otherwise make your current quest more difficult. You can 'hire' a new recruit at any inn, by which I mean you can just make the exact type of character you are missing from your party. More money equals higher starting level. Fairly early on, you arrive at a place called Caed Nua, which becomes your own stronghold and fairly integral part of the game. You can upgrade it, repair it and use it as a place to rest and receive bonuses from. Depending on how much prestige you and your party have as well as the overall status of your stronghold it can be attacked by bandits (or by other groups) in which you are given the option between hiring some mercenaries and auto-resolving from afar (they can help in a manual resolve as well) if your travels have taken you too far away to make it back in time before they strike or you can travel back yourself and manual resolve to defend your keep. There is also a rather extensive side mission available here among other things.  THE GISTA true delight for the days of old when RPG's were more than 'press button for sarcastic response'. One can only hope that games of this depth and caliber remain popular enough to be feasible for proper development in the future.Follow my curation for more

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												So....this game was everything I hoped for and more. Obsidian really set the bar for CRPG's. Beyond that, I think Avellone and company really elevated their game further as far as their story writing goes as well. Just flat out superb, seamless, and fairly well flawless IMO.There has been a lot written about this game already, obviously, but I will say that with all the hype and all the funding that went into this, the potential for a let down was great, so to have the game not only deliver, but deliver in such grand fashion was amazing.The character development was deep and fulfilling and the quests actually made sense....rather than just simple fetch and escort quests with no rhyme or reason, everything had an actual reason in this game, and even where they didnt serve to advance the main story, they still had a very real role in filling out the depth of the world itself.The actual story line itself was pretty gripping. The end of Act 1 gave you the sense of a journey really just beginning, the end of Act 2 was a "holy♥♥♥♥♥♥" moment, and the end of Act 3 let you know there was no turning back and that everything was about to get all too real as you approached the end of the game. That doesnt even factor in some of the other, non main quests story lines that develop throughout the game, which are also stellar.The journey itself was filled with pretty much any emotion you can imagine. The moral choices were often difficult due to the realistic consequences that come with every decision.Speaking of decisions, quite a few of them factor into the ending...and speaking of endings, I cant remember another game that had such a well thought out one. There also seems to be potential for a lot of variations to the ending depending on what choices you made at pivotal moments throughout. My ending was a fair mix of incredibly good and depressingly bad consequences to what I had done during my extensive playthrough. I loved that fact. I am thoroughly impressed with this game, and I have to give it the edge over Baldurs Gate 2 as maybe the best CRPG of all time, and a top 5 all time great game from any genre.I have a lot more to say, but so vast was the story and so deep the experience, that I think maybe it's better if I leave the rest unsaid and let you form your own opinion instead. Play this.Can there be a 15 out of 10? Because seriously, I think that is how I am going to rate this game.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												After 40 odd hours of play time and extensive experience with the old Iso Infinity Engine games; There was a real hype surrounding this title. Thankfully the wait has not been a dissapointment for me. Since Launch I took the weekend to play through the campaign and currently 40 hours in I have not even scratched the surface yet, so a short experience in gametime is not an issue.The story is 100% worth experiencing and is pretty close to Planescapes Experience if you enjoyed that classic. The sidequests can be engrossing and feel as detailed as the main campaign at times. Tasks are your fetch/kill/item quests for extra xp, so the three tiers of quest types cover all the usual ground.I am loving the companions, Obsidian have always made well written characters. Durance is probably my favourite so far. ♥♥♥♥♥S!!! Combat is fairly clunky but provides a challenge and a lot of patience late in the game on normal to hard difficulty. I played for a good 10 hours or so on hard but switched down to normal to experience the game over the engine issues that need fixing. No doubt various balance patches will come out for this. Obsidian are hardly known for their clean bugless games on launch..historically their QA department are a bunch of clowns, which is a shame considering how good their game design can be.I would say the only flaw (albeit a subjective one) is that Obsidian did make some progressive choices with NWN2 with regards to game performance (faster loading or no loading when moving upstairs in a building etc. For some reason they have regressed to having a loading screen for every map change similar to Baldurs and Icewind Dale engines. While I realise this is a nostalgia trip for some, to completley dismiss advances of modern tech to cater to some purists is an oversight in the long term now you're marketing to people beyond the backers.Eitherway, I am loving my experience of this game and purposefully have said nothing about the plot.Reccomended if you enjoy detailed, lore rich, micromanagement, tabletop inspired, story driven CRPG's

number of helpful: 68 of 103 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												Honestly, this is only a thumbs-down because there is no way of putting something 'middle ground', and with all those positive reviews, potential buyers must beware of this game's flaws.Before starting, I'm a veteran of this kind of rpg, Baldur's Gate Saga, Icewind Dale, Planescape Torment (my favorite of all time), I've played it all, so you know I won't be some 'noob' who bumbles around with the controls and is incapable of handling a manual.Pillars of Eternity is an important game in this generation that was forcefed games made by publishers that had no contact with their public, it was successfully financed by the public, and from that standpoint Obsidian was more than successful. This game was made with love, and with lots of holes...Starting with the good aspects, every companion so far has interesting stories to tell and different personalities that can be deep. The way the characters are generated are meant to avoid Minmaxing, every single stat can help any kind of character in some way, enabling different builds for different classes. Speaking of which, equipment works differently. Every weapon has pros and cons, and any class can use anything. A wizard can use heavy plating, a warrior can use a long-range wand, heavy armor makes actions slower, and certain enemies are immune to certain kinds of damage, so you can't rely on a single sword all the time. The music made by Justin Bell is... practically a carbon copy the old rpgs like Baldur's gate's Michael Hoenig (Which is a good thing). There is a diverse set of quests for you to take care of, some have pretty emotional stories to tell, and there is always something hidden for you to see.Other good thing is the time manipulation, you can not only make time run faster, but slower, good to micro-manage a fight. SPOILERS, you get a keep, and the ability to manage some sort of building or fortress is always welcome on my book, provided you be  able to -really- manage it (I'm looking at you, Baldur's gate 2, the precursor for 'hero gets a keep', but that frustrated me awfully due limiting said keep to just gain gold from time to time.) and in an interesting twist, you have not one, but two kinds of fame, local fame, and personal fame. Some actions can brand you as a specific kind of person, be charitable, and people will find you benevolent, be harsh, and you might get points as a Stoic person. And with bad/good reputation systems per region, like Fallout 2, you can really make yourself a hero of a thousand fames. I can't tell much about the plot, but it has its ups and downs. The game not only acknowledge helpers, but celebrate them, and here and there you will see names of backers in the shape of special npcs with unique stories and messages on cemeteries.Now, for the bad part.Every single trait explained before has huge, huge, huge flaws.Every single point explained can be insanely frustrating, sometimes nearly gamebreaking at times. The backers? You will see thousands of those characters just lying around waiting to be clicked and expecting you to read their stories time after time after time. After the first city, I started to ignore them altogether. They are EVERYWHERE and sometimes they can be downright immersion-shattering. None of them interact with you, in any way, they are just there to be basked upon and so their 'awesome stories' can be read.Combat is a mess. The Allied A.I is so idiotic that it's nearly impossible to have a single fight without micromanagement. If they set on a target, they won't disengage from it without a direct command. Meaning, they can be mowed down by 'opportunity attacks' made by the enemies and worse, step on traps, run inside the area of a fireball (friendly or foe), and much worse. You can't tweak the A.I to me more specific than "kill everything in sight" "Only move if the enemy attacks you", and as another reviewer noted, the enemy AI knows how to work VERY WELL as a team. You can't buff your team before fights, you can't lay more than ONE TRAP and ONE SPELL TRAP, which severely limits strategy. The cleric spells are nearly useless, since many of the status effects that low level enemies can cause on you (Paralysis, Dizzy, Charmed) can be only countered with high-level spells. Which you won't have. Skills are another mess, they are rarely used, useful, and only the main character can use his skills in interactions, meaning, if you are a wizard and spent all your points in lore, no matter if you have two super-warriors with 10 in athletics, you will have to waste a rope or cheat. The devs wanted to avoid minmaxing? Awesome! Then why in the name of Bhaal they chose to put So many interactions with such a high stat requirements? I had to use 18 intelligence to haggle prices with a courtesan, but had to use -Resolve- to talk about an ancient relic with a scholar!? Oh, and you can't stack boosts given by items. Nice, no problem, except that the boosts given are just +1 or +2, items with +3 are awfully rare. Oh and either you get a cape, or a necklace... WHY!?The quests... where to begin? I'm not against straightforward good vs. evil plots. Baldur's Gate 1 main criticisms was that evil characters were screwed because of the dualist nature of the game. I agree with the criticism, but I don't mind that, the game itself was honest in acknowledging it's nature. but many (thankfully not a lot) of quests in Pillars will offer a false sense of morality. A Moral Conundrum is when you can't choose based on the fact that each choice has equally convincing and important arguments. Pillars just pretends to give 'hard' moral choices by offering either something 'good', or something 'evil' that will give you an item, boost, or more money. Again, it would be all fine and dandy... except that Reputation hardly matters except in key points. It doesn't help you buying/selling stuff much, no random groups will try to hunt you down. And the game pretends to always offer you a 'third choice' if you have stats/skills, which it doesn't in points that would really matter. And many, MANY are severely flawed or bugged. There was a quest in which I had to save a group of soldiers from a banshee that enthralled them. I killed  the banshee without a single soldier dying, only to discover that the devs never gave you an option of saving said soldiers. You have to kill them. Also, without a warning, you might be suddenly drafted into a faction without the option of getting out, if you merely accept a quest. And many, many personal quests with your companions won't change a SINGLE thing in their story. You could treat certain members awfully, insult them, but... nothing changes, you just gain xp.The game allows you to make items, potions and scrolls, yaaayy! To make something really useful, you will need rare ingredients that rarely appear. The enchantments that you can place on a piece of armor or weapon are severely limited and expensive due said ingredients being rare, so you're better off buying weapons with a shopper, or finding special gear in dungeons. For the last part, the Keep. Having a keep in itself is awesome, a place to call home, a base to build... except that the mechanics are utterly broken. See, to avoid making the players just sit on their asses waiting time to pass to collect money, the devs made time pass in the keep in two senses, turns, and days. Days are used to build stuff like walls and houses, and turns only pass when you finish quests. It has two special stats, security and prestige. They SUPPOSEDLY should bring you more money and guests (prestige), and protect said money and guests (security). I maxed them both, and my money kept getting stolen by bandits.So, it's a good game, but be warned!

												Immersive, intelligently written with a rich narrative backdrop that compels you to keep coming back. Its extremely rewarding if you enjoy tactics and class building that offer immense depth. Its a great deal of fun, but not fun solely for nostalgia's sake. content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												There's a lot of talk out there about how if you liked the old infinity engine games (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, etc.) that you will love Pillars of Eternity. This is almost certainly true, but not everyone has played those, so if you are just looking for another good RPG. If this is the case, get it, let me tell you why! Just keep in mind this the continuation of an older and much different kind of RPG, one that you read much more than you see visually. Some might see the 2D backgrounds and relatively unimpressive 3D models and think "why play this when I can play the much sexier new Dragon Age?" Well, if Dragon Age is akin to an interactive movie, Pillars is like an interactive book. It's brimming with excellent writing and interesting characters, not to mention some fascinating lore. It can seem a bit like standard fantasy with dwarves and elves running around, but after only 7 or so hours it's got me hooked. I don't want to go into too much detail about mechanics and things, other reviews have surely covered that. TL;DR: This a thinking man's RPG, it may not have had a huge budget, but the folks at Obsidian are (in my opinion) some of the best in the business, and this an excellent game. If that sounds good to you, buy it, and support some of gaming's best content creators.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												A great retro-style, isometric view RPG, probably the best of its kind since Dragon Age: Origins. Though the writing quality is uneven, with some names feeling as though they came out of a fantasy name generator and some plotlines being disappointingly anticlimactic, the narrative as a whole and most of the major side quests are extraordinarily well designed. This, paired with the game's beuatiful, painterly art style and the amount of freedom granted to the player in terms of narrative choices are what makes the game worth playing. The game is not without its faults: the level of cap of 12 is too low for a game with so much to do, and if you're the sort of player who likes to complete all side quests, you'll find yourself reaching it long before the final dungeon. The megadungeon which forms a major side quest in the game is irritatingly grindy, with interesting points popping up so rarely in between frequently redundant battles as to make the trek through the entirety of it rather infuriating. Finally, and perhaps most problematically, the game's mechanics are a mess: skills, attributes, the array of 8 different damages, and a confused jumble of traits intertwined together just feel incongruous and make no intuitive sense. Despite all of that, however, the excellent storytelling and fascinating lore of the world are what make this game shine. All in all: a fantastic throwback.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												I've quite a history when it comes to playing infinity engine games and D&D oriented games in general and I can not in good faith recommend this game for the price it's being offered. I've played Baldur's Gate 1 and 2, including the expansion throne of Bhaal. Yes I've played Icewind Dale 1 and 2 and even Neverwinter nights 1 and 2. Pillars of Eternity just doesn't measure up, in large part due to the laziness of the developers and an overall lack of innovation. This is the first time I've played through a Bioware/Obsidian rooted game and skipped through the text conversations out of the shear dreariness/tediousness of the story in PoE. The combat is dull and a step backwards from the scripted companion AI in the infinity engine games. If the idea of micromanaging every action of your party members sounds appetizing, then you might very well enjoy this game, that is if the bugged AI and invisible walls don't ruin your experience, as quite regularly you will find that your party members will twitch or stand around aimlessly while you attempt to slog through the game's ever boring world. I should also mention the fact that your party stops getting xp from battles after getting enough kills of certain mobs and completing that mob's beastiary, making battles an annoyance and borefest later in the game). I paid $38 for this and regret doing so, for those infinity engine fans wishing to purchase this game, I would suggest waiting for a price drop and paying no more than $8. Don't believe the hype, this is not the lovingly made Baldur's gate successor you had hoped for.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Pillars of Eternity is a reminder of a different time and not only because it tries to recreate the atmosphere of the immortal classics, but because it treats the player the same way the games a decade ago did. It doesn’t straightly assume that the players are clueless (can be read as stupid) and doesn’t hold their hands in everything they do, instead it gives the players the opportunity to learn through trial and error and discover the game by themselves. Difficulty and logic are notions almost lost to this new generation of games and with some producers saying that their games are more difficult than they should be (when it is quite the opposite), the future doesn’t look so bright. Games like this one come to stand against the current trend and their success show that there is still hope.                Pillars of Eternity is not a flawless game and knowing Obsidian’s work, that was never going to happen, as the people working there have a huge history with bugs dating before the existence of this studio. The game makes an appeal to nostalgia for a time that is never coming back, but it stands on its own and shines like a diamond, a little rough on the edges, in a sea of carbon yet failing to be the masterpiece of this age.This title also stands as proof that Kickstarter crowdfunding is not a way of just cashing on the hopes the fans, redeeming this concept from the latest mishaps.                If I can let my suppressed subjective side speak freely for a short passage during this review, I want to say that I enjoyed this game immensely, more than most of the games in the last couple of years. It was a heart breaking moment for me when I heard that Obsidian Entertainment was so close to bankruptcy and I’m glad that the fans of this genre and of this studio made their continued existence possible. By the time I write this review, Pillars of Eternity is a known success, it has an expansion in works (already announced during Kickstarter) and this can only make me happier.  Obsidian Entertainment (inXile and some other smaller studios), don’t ever leave us, because without you and your games, the PC gaming industry and the RPG genre will be much bleaker.                As an ending note I would like to say this: The Witcher 3, Shadowrun: Hong Kong and Torment: Tides of Numenera, come and challenge Pillars of Eternity if you can, because this RPG is high up there!Pros:+ Perfect combination of artistic and painted-like 2D graphics with 3D characters+ Epic soundtrack+ A story full of adventure, mystery and choices+ Extremely well written dialogues and some captivating characters+ Tactical combat with many challenging fights+ The DnD vibe+ The Endless Paths+ Loot system and the itemization+ 60-70+ hours of gameplay and enough replay value+ Infinity engine games feelingCons:- Enough game breaking bugs and lots of other glitches at launch- Some of the combat mechanics don’t work too well- The skills system is an underwhelming copy of DnD- Many small maps- The stronghold is nothing more than a money spender/maker- The big number of loading screens can become a nuisance- No vegetation animationsRead the full review at:http://thegameslashers.blogspot.ro/2015/04/pillars-of-eternity-review.html

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												I'm going to keep this very short. For the fans of the genre, this is a must-have. The old school feel, dialogue boxes, the hud and the isometric landscape will bring tears to your eyes if you were around for the first BGs like me.BUT, as you progress you'll start seeing through the nostalgia and noticing the flaws. And there are a few; 1- Spell menu designs; horrible! Spells only appear when you hover your mouse over the spell level slot, which is frustrating because you keep missing it by an inch and it goes to the next slot, or worse cast the wrong one just to realize turns later. Sounds like a small thing, but considering the hours you spend casting them I would have expected something better. 2- auto leveled companions; yeah, you start your game, hang around for a couple of levels then meet this great guy, priest or something; you should be happy, but you can't. Because their level always matches yours and as usual they are complete idiots when it comes to picking talents. Don't be surprised to find your exact build (happened to me with a paladin) and stupid worthless crap like extra level 1 spell slot?!.3- very inconsistent difficulty curve; won't be a problem for a some of you but I have friends giving up on the game just because the first few levels were near impossible to beat. this game starts really tough but once you reach level 8, you'll start butchering people like crazy. The problem is the dungeon below your castle which you can use as a grinding area and get a few levels without advancing in the story. So from that point on you'll breeze through the dungeons, stopping only for a few occasions like a few bosses (the master below!).4- And finally, subplots. I have to say the story is great here, but all of us oldschoolers expected funny sidequests, really wacky npcs with stupid motives, the occasional wondering idiot and so on. Also everything kinda ties into the main arc, which is great in a way, but what about stuff like the knights of solamnia in BG2, vampires and such? I miss those.Apart from all that, this is a very good game, and I was hooked. The game has a very good story, great voice acting, beautiful sceneries and intense battles. my rating: 8/10

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												I wanted to love this game, I was so excited to love this game. But from the moment I started playing something was off. There is so much here, but all of it falls flat. There is a ton of exposition about the fantasy world you’re dropped into, names of peoples, places, history, religion and past wars. But every bit of it feels like a meaningless amature fantasy novel. At no point are you given anything to care about. You are simply thrown one generic fantasy name after another. The first dialog is full of things like, "welcome to the land of glaflagin, where the people of dubligloonin fought off the flaflarin!" I loved the old games in this style but this one is missing the important bits I liked about those. It’s like they made a game that looks like the old ones that were good but don't have any of the parts you liked about the old ones. I will give this game some props because it made me realize the parts of those old games that didn't add anything, but this one utterly misses the point. It sure looks pretty but it’s an empty and shallow world. It doesn't help that the combat system is a slog, with lists upon lists of spells and abilities feel like a pain to get through, multiply that by your whole party. A strategic system that would work well on the grid of a D&D table but is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥full of trial and error on the screen. So then I turn the difficulty down to just play the "story" but it just never hits the right cords. There are characters you can click on in the game, random NPC's with names that give you rich back stories of their past lives, THAT HAVE NOTHING TO DO WITH ANYTHING. I finally just stopped clicking on them because there were nothing but a waste of time. Why? If I wanted to read someone's crappy disjointed fantasy novel I will look for fanfiction. The stretches of time between plays got longer and longer until finally I had to grapple with he fact that it simply wasn't fun for me to play. A kind of game I really, really, want to encourage but this just happens to be an example of a not that great one.

number of helpful: 21 of 23 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
Pros:+ Extremely well-written+ Customization options for many features (when to auto-pause, how the stash can be used, dialogue displays, UI, etc)+ Modernized Baldur's Gate experience+ Deep, three-dimensional characters+ Expansive lore+ Character stronghold+ Mega-dungeon+ Choices and consequences matter and are rarely black and white decisions+ Custom system that's easy to learn but hard to master+ Dialogue and character interaction is extremely complex, and relies on varying attributes, abilities, reputations and previous character choices to determine available options and how those options are received+ The ending actually reflects your choices in game and gives a sense of closureCons:- Loading screens.  So.  Many.  Loading screens.- Spotty voice acting- Combat pathfinding can be kinda stupid- Immersion-breaking backer content- Extremely text-reliantOverall: Pillars is a great game that's extremely immersive and fun.  If you are a fan of isometric games like Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale, but can't get into them due to their age, this is a perfect game to try.  Obsidian did everything right.  The game is streamlined and their original system works wonderfully.  The text is beautifully written, and if you can ignore the backer content (any tombstones or yellow-name characters) the game is one of the most immersive you'll find.  Voice acting gets choppy (one frame is narrated, the next is not, then another narrated, etc), and there are a lot of loading screens.  These are minor issues in an otherwise perfect game.  Every choice matters in this game, and if Bioware pays attention, maybe they can take a few notes on how to properly end a Mass Effect game.Bottom Line: You probably already know if you want this game or not.  But if you're on the fence, wait for a solid sale and buy it.  It's a blast to play, and whatever problems the game may have fade away in the face of the final package.  I will never not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 41 of 58 people (71%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												An exceedingly high quality RPG drawing inspiration from the the golden age of the genre, and PC gaming itself. The easiest way to describe it is as a spiritual successor to Bioware's Infinity Engine games, like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale most notably. I don't want to devalue it with that term (same as how I felt another excellent game in the CRPG revival scene, Wasteland 2, was too often simplified as a successor to the isometric Fallout games) as it has a lot going for it. If anything I think it drew a lot of inspiration from Planescape: Torment, as well as 2009's cult classic Inquisitor. Pillars actually strongly reminds me of Inquisitor, just with tighter mechanics and better production values. The lore itself isn't too out there, it's a fairly Tolkien-esque world. What really lifts it is the excellent writing quality and sheer abundance of it. The last game I can remember with such good writing was the aformentioned Planescape: Torment, back in late 1999. The game's lore is richly crafted and with a huge attention to detail. You can really get lost just reading the books and the cyclopedia. The in-game dialogue is similarly well done, it really has that cosy feel of DnD and 90s CRPGs but on a higher level of quality. The other two strong points are the graphics and the strategic combat. The visual style of the game is just fantastic. Enviroments almost look like paintings and the lighting effects are especially notable. The production value of the game is as a whole, really good. Sound effects and music are both very well done too. The combat is excellent too, it really pairs well with the deep RPG elements and character building. The system is based off DnD but is pretty much custom made for the game and it works very well. The combat is consistently enjoyable and different classes offer many different options for the player to approach and conduct combat with. All in all, the game is another excellent release in the CRPG revival of recent years. Highly recommended for any RPG fan and practically a must buy if you're a CRPG fan. In the era of the action RPG, it's great to see games like Pillars of Eternity keep the old-school flame alive.

number of helpful: 31 of 41 people (76%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												If a modern slant on the deep RPGs of yesteryear are what you have been looking for (and, frankly, who hasn't) then this is certainly the game for you. But newbies be warned - this is a slow-burner of a game. By which I mean early sections include a LOT more walking around and talking to people than actual fighting - if you can't live with that then just don't bother -rather than writing silly negative reviews based on a sole aspect and 30mins play. About the "bland" combat - it isn't bland. It changes as you progress in much the same way as it has in EVERY DnD type game in history. If you want shallow hack n slash look elsewhere kiddies.Which brings us to the story. And, to my mind at least, storylines in RPGs are ALWAYS the most important aspect. This one is original and the new setting and weirdness of the developing situation (which is really quite dark in parts) create a great sense of intrigue and immersion AS LONG AS YOU HAVE THE PATIENCE NOT TO WANT TO BE FIGHTING HORDES FROM DAY ONE.For me, then, this is nigh on the perfect game. But it will not appeal to the impatient or those who are only about instant high octane killing. 98%

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												OK, I have to get this out.I loved BGII (not BGI) and consider planescape:torment an ideal game. Everyone loves this game, and if you buy the game, you probably will too. But I feel like I am the only one who sees all the problems with this game.We need to move forward. The old crpg's were great, but they were not to be idolized. We need to understand why we loved them, and let the genre grow with us and become better.This game feels like it was made by a team of writers who felt that combat was an interruption. Far too much emphasis is placed on words words words. Dear god the reading. I'm even a huge reader myself, but I do not turn on the computer to read a novel.The addition of write-your-own-story style vignettes was a great idea, but honestly they were never that shocking or a real decision. If you took a risk you gained an item and usually just lost some hit points (overall not a huge detriment).I want to go off-track and rant for a bit. Can we please not make any more ultra-generic fantasy games? Nothing about this world was remotely interesting until the 3rd act. It was the same, "the mayors daughter's is lost" stories that I have seen so many times I'm over it. But everyone gobbles it up and I don't know why.The game demanded I do their textbook reading. They had people speak, and the dialogue written so you could read along, but they always added in their little descriptive sentences so they could make sure you knew what happened. So often I had to struggle to picture scenes told entirely through text. If only they had some way to use characters and voiced dialogue to make me understand what happened. Oh wait, they can, but they spent all their @#$@% effort figuring out which adjective should describe a leaf.*spoiler* After I beat the game, you would think that my character was a baby♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥with a gambling problem. Every damn story-line they wrapped up was some horrendous or heart-breaking event. Keep in mind that I did not help some characters with their problems because they were annoying and I did not know where to go. I worked my♥♥♥♥♥off to try and clear one district of undead people and turn off the device to recover it. What does the epilogue tell me? That I somehow messed up my choice and now it is overrun again after some people moved in.The WORST part of the epilogue was the story about me taking back a keep from a cliche insane king (I'm glad the writers stayed up all night developing him) that really any human with a shred of decency would try to eradicate. They said the crazy king came back as a lich or something, killed his nephew, and now reigns over the dead region because he killed everyone. Wait wait, that is cool as♥♥♥♥♥♥ I WISH I could have had to deal with that. I wishan entire act was fighting an undead king and determining how to keep him in the ground. This is awful because they had an awesome idea that they just relegated to a paragraph, then threw the cliche mountain at me instead.*End Spoiler*In the end, I just wanted to get through the game. The combat is incredibly overcomplicated. There are 10 or so status effects, and none of them are intuitive or seem to matter besides stun and knockdown (which apparently are the same). Sometimes your weapons would be ineffective, and there would be a character saying it, but the combat log was so dense I had to hire an accountant to find it. When I considered the amount of real life time I spent in combat, it was actually faster to not use many abilities, and instead just give my characters passive abilities so they auto-attack harder.Let's also talk about there being no party AI. Baldur's Gate had AI. That was over a decade ago. Computers have octupled in power, and ducking obsidian can't get together to write simple AI.Combat encounters were slapped together. There was no actual encounter design, they just had groups and open areas.When you leveled up characters, there were very few meaningful choices. There are 6 different weapon specialization talents that all do the same thing, but you know, if you want to choose them and not really care that is good too.Finally, combat difficulty could go from tutorial level to final scene of Ender's Game difficulty. The final boss was sooooooooooo hard. Why? Their defenses were so high that everything was a graze, doing 1-3 damage versus full damage of 30-40. I basically had to exploit to win.So yeah, everyone loves it, and I feel like this game will become the dances with wolves of video games: enjoyed at the time it came out, but a decade later nodbody knows why they liked it.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												After finally finishing this after 100 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hours, I think it honestly might be one of my favourite RPG's ever.I always have faith in Obsidian. Their ability to create RPG's is unmatched. Or maybe I say that because Fallout: New Vegas showed just how utterly dogshit Bethesda are at it.Anyway, if you've played old infinity engine games like Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate, I can tell you that Pillars Of Eternity is a more refined version of those CRPG's with some mechanics to improve upon it, along with a more medieval, gritty world and lore. It also doesn't ultimately follow traditional DnD rules, but personally I liked the way it did things.The story is basically that a crisis is happening that is leaving newborns without souls, and like all RPG's, you are majorly involved in this and you set out to uncover the answer. The story is honestly pretty deep and thought out. The ending was a bit anti-climatic, but the ending SCENE was good. The DLC was honestly even more climatic and tense than the main game, and I would highly recommend playing through it.Mechanic wise, it's a huge improvement from older RPG's. The endurance system means no more losing party members every 10 minutes, as they just get knocked out in fights instead. (They still have max health and can die, it's just it takes a while to wear them down.)Classes are set out to be proficient at pretty much most things, each having a different main proficiency though (like most RPG's). For example, fighters are good at taking damage, Beserkers are good at DEALING it, Paladins are good at attack and support, clerics are good at support spells, wizards, attack spells. It's all a really fun system and no class isn't fun to play. The soundtrack is god-tier, the lore and world is incredibly interesting, the characters are pretty well done. This has genuinely been the only game in existence that made me warrant getting the collector's stuff BECAUSE I loved this♥♥♥♥♥♥so much.Definitely recommend buying and playing. For how much content this has, it is truly worth more than it is. All I can say is that you shouldn't play it with the mindset that it will blow traditional CRPG's out of the water. You'll just dissappoint yourself. Play it and expect something you expect out of any other game.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												Having finished my first and more or less thorough walkthrough I think I'm ready to write a little something about this game. Short version: this game is beautiful and I enjoyed playing it immensely. And now for details.I didn't back this game on Kickstarter. I must say I had my doubts, even when the beta was out I wasn't sure I liked what I saw.  Gladly, I was wrong, but nonetheless let me start with negative criticism:- Bugs. Yes, there are bugs. Back when the game was released there were quite a lot of them, some of them rather nasty. However, bugs are only a temporary issue as long as developers work hard at fixing them and right now Obsidian is doing fine. You can see a lot of communication between gamers and developers going on at the forums, most issues are already reported and will be addressed at some time. Which is why I don't think that bugs are that much of a problem.- Bad/weird design decisions. Those are much worse than bugs because those are a part of the game. The interface, for one, is far from being perfect. Pathfinding is terrible, especially in battle. Battles themselves are separated from the peaceful exploration which means that pre-buffing or pre-summoning or other things like that are not possible. So there are things like that, but not that many of them. Not enough to spoil the pleasure of playing but for some players probably enough to wince once in a while.- Backer content. I have deepest respect for Kickstarter backers, but all that backer content is better off somewhere... well, not in the game itself. The tombstones can be ignored, but I would trade all those 'special' NPCs for just one real NPC of Obsidian's design, or, better still, for a little quest.- Role-playing system. The game utilizes an original role-playing system that was designed to kind of remind you of D&D while not being D&D, which benefited the game and harmed it at the same time. Some things work nicely: combat mechanics work, original classes like Chanters and Ciphers are awesome, ability and skill checks function properly. However, such classes as priests, wizards or druids seem (to me) like they were just copied from D&D without much thought. Also I have a real problem with attributes, skills and abilities. Why don't they influence each other? And why are the skills so odd? Outside of dialogue interaction, each skill has exactly one use. Then there are attributes. For example, in this game Might represents both physical and spiritual power, which means that virtually every class needs Might to be able to do damage. At the same time, Intellect only affects the duration of effects and such, so a Wizard might fare better with high Might and low Intelligence. Interesting, but doesn't make much sense if you compare it to how attributes are treated in dialogue options. In textual interactions Might is just plain physical Strength and Intelligence is, well, how smart you are. This means that attributes fail to describe your character. So do I make a mighty wizard to be effective in battle or do I make an intelligent wizard to actually roleplay in dialogues? Anyway, chances are you won't even pay attention to all this while you're playing. However, in the long run, in case there are sequels, not having a coherent and thought-through role-playing system might do some harm.- White text on dark background. Had to note that specifically. My eyesight is not perfect, I know, but this bright white  font against dark background is killing meeeee. And there's a lot of reading to be done in this game...But enough with the negative. The good things! There are actually a lot of them so I'll only mention what comes to mind immediately.- The game is very rich in content. It isn't some linear sham that gets shorter and plainer the longer you play. The game is very consistent with lots of quests, NPCs, fractions and locations to explore.- Exploration is pure joy in this game. Actually, I believe that PoE has the best dungeon-crawl gameplay ever. Dungeons are so beautiful, so lovingly crafted, so interesting to explore that I wouldn't probably mind if the whole game was one big mega-dungeon. And I have never been a big fan of dungeon-delving before!- Options. There are a lot of options in the game. A lot of different ways to finish quests, but also a lot of plain game options. Fast mode, slow mode, bigger fonts, smaller fonts, color-blind mode, auto-pause, languages, subtitles - everything is adjustable and this is awesome.- Most importantly, this game has that elusive charm that BG2 or IWD had. The feeling that makes you explore map after map until it's morning and your eyes can't read the dialogues anymore. It is immersive, it is thrilling, it is intriguing. Obsidian put their hearts and souls into this game, they genuinely care about it and it really shows. Which is the main reason I have to call this game a major success. Everything that is wrong with this game can be corrected, it isn't such a big deal. The only thing that you cannot patch is the absense of the soul. This game deals with the problem of human souls and of so called Hollowborn - children born soulless. Today, there are a lot of games that seem to be Hollowborn too, but not this one. I hope Obsidian makes many more games like this and next time I'll try my best to support them early on!P.S. Something I forgot to mention. Doing a complete playthrough took me 70+ hours, but for some time I had to play offline due to a very odd bug that several other people encountered too. So don't mind the 'hours on record' thing too much.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												An exceptionally well-crafted game.  Some of the reviews here confuse me.  I would not say this game is a Witcher III, but it doesn't pretend to be, and it doesn't carry the same price tag.  I would say I did buy the Champion Edition on sale for 66% off, and I have never regretted the purchase.  As you can see, I have quite a few hours in the game, so I've gotten my money's worth.  I'd buy the game for $25 or less (Champion Edition).The game does drop you into the world, like most classic rpgs, but once you're there it pulls you in.  I suspect some reviewers don't read the storylines much, and if so, then of course, much of the flavor of the world is lost.  Some characters are narrated, but many are not, so reading is a requirement.  I'd play this game when you'd like a relaxing game with a beer or coffee, when you've had your fill of intense FPS games or even rpg games that requirement all hands on deck and 100% attention.  This is truly Baldur's Gate style - when game were just fun, and often their story, while subtle, sticks with you for quite some time.  NPCs: 8/10The NPC character you find have decently interesting storylines, though I do wish they had a couple romance options, and it doesn't quite seem as dynamic as the Baldur's Gate conversations. That is, your responses don't seem to have as many or as dramatic of an effect on relationships in your party.  I do miss that.Storyline: 8/10The storyline, as mentioned above, doesn't necessarily start off incredibly deep, and the NPC storylines don't do a terrible amount to pull at your heartstrings, but they aren't dull as some reviewers have said.  That would be unfair to them.  It's a unique story with lots of interesting turns and plenty to discover and that keeps me interested in the next chapter.  More importantly, the world is teeming with interesting stories.  For instance, some of the stories connected with the keep are absolutely great, and your choices feel important.  Similarly, some of your choices in other stories can lead to unexpected allies or prisoners in your keep.  That is an exceptional aspect of this game and there are few other games like this.  Reminds me of table-top rpg games I've played for years.  And it's certainly not any worse than something like Divinity: Original Sin which I eventually got bored of and didn't finish the main storyline.Graphics, Visual Design: 8/10The graphic aren't exemplary.  The photos do an accurate job showing potential buyers what they'll get.  It's basically a prettier Baldur's Gate.  Or, to use a newer game, it's much like Divinity: Original Sin.  It's, perhaps, a touch less pretty, but it's got unique art design.  Again, you're not getting Witcher III, but nor should you be expecting that.Gameplay: 8/10Here's where I think some reviewers have totally lost their minds.  The game play is in some ways, what you'll expect - once again, like Baldur's Gate.  It's *certainly* not worse.  That's complete madness to say.  And in some ways, it's unique and wonderful; I find some features incredibly refreshing and superior to Divinity: Original Sin which seems to be a fan favorite.  The short instances that you occasionally find for grappling hooks, prybars, and lockpicks are beautifully rendered and the choice to provide a mini-Choose Your Own Adventure in those is beautiful!  It makes me feel like a kid again, making important choices and discovering new treasures or adventures.  Traps can be useful depending on the scenery.  Unfortunately you can only put down one so it's sometimes hard to lead enemies into them, but that's realistic.  Combat lacks the synergies of Dragon Age and Divinity, and in that respect resembles old-school D&D games most.  But the endurance and health mechanic is new and interesting, and gives a realistic feel.  The limited number of campfire rests makes the player reluctant to rest all the time, which leads to some nailbiting combat, but there are just the right amount of extra campfire supplies spread throughout maps to reward players that carefully push on and manage their spells and health.  I've been playing on the hardest difficult on my first playthrough (without Iron Man of course, though).  And it's been a perfect difficulty for a cautious player.  In the beginning I did have to retry quite a few battles as I was getting my characters leveled up to a sweet spot and I was learning the system, as well as acquiring loot.  But once I did that, I've been moving along at a good but challenging pace, occasionally turning my attention away when I realize that I'm in too deep.  This is the perfect balance between challenging and fun.In all, the game has some very innovative aspects.  I haven't mentioned a number of other interesting features like the stronghold aspect (which is simple but highly engaging) or the balance between quick stories and deep dungeons, or the crafting (which is expensive at first, but overall balanced) or the interesting unique items you can find.  There's so much love put into this game that it would be unfair to rate it at anything below an 8.  But it would also be inaccurate to put it at a 9, alongside the likes of Witcher III.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												This review is based on a 99% done playthrough on Hard difficulty.Let's start with the story and the eight NPC recruits first.  While it's hard to top 'You are immune to death, but your memories are gone. Have fun out there.' and 'Remember when you almost died to that wolf? Ok now go kill a god', Pillars of Eternity's main plot is very engaging and weaves itself well into the set pieces and characters you meet throughout your journey.  You are a random person in a caravan that approaches some weird cult and it's leader fiddling with an ancient machine. You're knocked out and wake up with the ability to peer into other people's souls.  Meanwhile sometime before the events of the game started Everyone's Favorite Benevolent God starts punishing heretics before finally being destroyed by a big F-off weapon and has not been seen since.  The main plot involves chasing down this cult leader while either dodging or supporting the influence of the many more gods present in the world. Many of the NPCs you can recruit have their own struggles with their own gods, and if you stick with them long enough, you can help them resolve their issues as well.  The game's reputation system, where you get 'points' towards the different attitudes you present while speaking with others (benevolent, cruel, rational, honest, etc.) is very well done and is sure to result in repeat playthroughs. Conversations can also depend on what class and backstory you picked during character creation. During one particular quest in Act 2, I found myself wishing I was a Priest of Skaen (evil jerks) just to see how it would have played out differently.The recruitable NPCs are written very well, have good party banter, and help you understand the quite wordy backstory of the world, however many of their pre-selected combat talents are either very poor or don't make any sense at all.  This has been known to cause players to rush to them before gaining too many levels so that they can build them how they see fit.  Min-maxers are going to do what they do in this regard, but I believe this to be justified until they are tweaked a bit to more accurately reflect what the game expects from you while in combat.The combat is what you can expect from the 'real-time with pause' games that it emulates such as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale but with a few major changes.  The first major change deals with stealth.  When you go into stealth mode, your whole party goes into stealth mode. When one person is caught, everyone is caught.  This makes absolutely no sense whatsoever, and renders a rogue's major class talent, backstab, completely and utterly useless.  It's such a terrible, incomprehensible combat mechanic that I have to wonder if we, the players, are doing something wrong, and the developers intended it for some other use that we haven't thought of yet.Another quite jarring combat mechanic is 'engagement.'  Once you engage with an enemy, you are basically rooted to that spot. Any attempt to even move an inch will open you up to a huge free hit to your character.  While there are both items and talents that help with your defense while breaking engagement, it is still not enough for me to consider it a fun, worthwile addition to combat.  The AI pathing isn't good enough, especially when fighting in hallways and doors. I find myself tolerating engagement rather than enjoying it as a challenge to overcome. With all that said I am greatly enjoying my time with the game and can't wait to start another character.  It truly is a successor to the great Baldur's Gate games and it is one I will be playing for a long, long time.
