content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												tl;dr:Pro:   Great writing (plot, character dialog, scene description, lore), awesome artwork and music, long playtime. Weirdly gratifying combat, challenging gameplay*. Lots of classes, specs, and gear to choose from, huge number of viable playstyles.Con:   Micromanagement can be hard if you aren't used to it, and combat overwhelming* (controlling six characters at once is hard until you master the "pause" function). Player may have to choose between more immersive roleplay (voice-acted, scripted NPC companions) and a better chance in combat (character-made, optional companions). *Higher difficulties are only for veterans of squad-combat games. Don't be a hero, start on Normal if you aren't sure. The Long:Extremely well-executed fantasy squad-combat game. Game has something for everybody; if your like exploration, the map is sprawling. If you like character development, the game's core companions have some of the backgrounds and personalities I've found in gaming, and their dialog is greatly altered and nuanced by the player's background and actions. If you're into the RP part of RPGs, your experience will be greatly improved by the running NPC commentary on your exploits, and the game's wrting is so good it could've been moderately successful as a text-based game or novella.  The gameplay itself is intuitive and satisfying, though there are some mechanics players might not be used to. Experience can't be grinded, for example, because the game gives exp rewards by the quest/encounter, not by the body count. In other words, if confronted by highwaymen, the player can get experience from killing them all, yes, but also from talking them down. Hunting down random bandits in the woods, however, nets no experience unless they were part of a quest or encounter. This system is great for players who might be interested in more diplomatic or pacifistic characters.   If you've played Wasteland II (which was developed with the help of Obsidian, who made Pillars of Eternity), you're somewhat familiar with the gameplay of Pillars of Eternity (they both use the Unity Engine). There are a lot of gameplay differences, since one's setting is post-apocalyptic and the other's is Tolkienic fantasy, but the feel is roughly the same, although Pillars seems much more fleshed-out in terms of story, writing, and artwork. Don't expect Wasteland II when you buy this game, though. There are key differences in party and combat mechanics that might change the game for you.  Mainly, Wasteland focused on four main, player-designed characters and a few NPC companions you could invite to tag along. Personally, I really just used my main 4 characters, so mine was a manageable party. Pillars of Eternity begins with one player character and up to five companions that the player will rapidly accumulate, to the point where several of these masterfully-written, convincing, and engaging companions will have to sit out because there's no more room for them in the party. It's hard to choose which NPCs you want, and you can choose to have none, if you're suicidal.   (The player can also buy (with the game's currency, relax) custom-made companions, created in the same way the main character was, with all the same options. These companions have no conversation options or anything, so they're not for the roleplayer.)  So, Wasteland could support 7 characters and Pillars supports 6, but Pillars of Eternity's combat is much, much more difficult than Wasteland's, and that's due in no small part to the learning curve of playing 6 characters at once. Wasteland didn't have this problem because of the one massive difference between these two games: Pillars of Eternity is not turn-based.  Because Pillars isn't turn-based, there's a "pause" feature that lets the player stop combat and issue commands (common feature in squad-combat games, notably Dragon Age). The level of micromanagement demanded from the higher difficulties is not to be underestimated. You will have to make sure your party members are actually attacking, instead of staring into space. You will have to manually click each of your part members, then click the skills or spells you want them to use, every time you want them to use them (you can queue actions with SHIFT, as in Starcraft, which helps a little). You'll worry often whether your healer will have time to cast his big heal before he gets knocked flat by a huge wolf, and there's no real way to know the timing without just unpausing and letting it happen.  Also, equipping your characters, individually, with up-to-date gear, enchanted and selected to suit their role, will take up time. Be prepared for micromanagement.  Micromanagement in all things. Especially combat.  You will have to find ways to block enemies from reaching your squishier party members, and you will have to find these formations on the fly, in every conceivable type of terrain, against enemies that can surprise you by, say, teleporting behind your healer, who you left too far away to be saved by your tank.   You will have to use weapons appropriate for the enemy's resistances, alternating between slashing, crushing, and piercing (and the elemental damage types, of course). This means keeping different weapon sets equipped (in combat, you can only change weapons if you equipped alternate weapons in the dedicated slots for them beforehand), and being prepared to command your characters to switch weapons on the fly. Thus, you might have to pick out multiple weapons for each character, and keep each set updated.   Armor is a gradient between Damage Reduction and action speed. Heavy armor makes everything slower, from melee attacks to spellcasting to potion-drinking.   You'll have to fight groups of small enemies several times more numerous than your party, and you will have to figure out what to do with your single-target attackers in these cases. You'll have to decide whether it's worth going for the enemy's healer, and you'll have to load when you choose wrongly. You'll have to change your party's armor sets regularly depending on the encounter.Don't let this dissuade you. The game is hard, but that only makes it so much more satisfying when you flawlessly dismantle a squad of high-level enemies despite having weaker and fewer characters. It's also incredibly gratifying to mow down mobs with hopelessly lower stats than yours, fair fight or no. It's always worth it when you get the loot.

												Pillars of Eternity is riddled with irksome flaws from dodgy AI pathing that should have stayed in the '90s to a story which sometimes offers only an illusion of choice.Not one of these flaws undermine what is the deepest, most personal adventure to grace the genre in many years. Obsidian's writing is on form; the combat's vast array of strategic options deeply satisfying. Whether you're a life-long Infinity fan or you've never so much as seen a cRPG, Pillars is a quest which everyone should attempt. Here's to many more.Full nostalgia-free review (link contains mild non-story spoilers):

content:
Posted: March 9
												Even if I didn't know it at the time I bought it, PoE was the kind of game I was yearning  for some time. Perhaps I'm getting old but been feeling over the last few years that games are less and less immersive, more shallow and mechanical even if more impressive technically with a few honorable exceptions. From the first moment I launched the game, I felt something special just by hearing the easily recognizable music of the start screen and menu. PoE as you probably know, is a retro styled game inspired by games such as Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate and so, its' gameplay, interface and overall feeling is unapologetically cloned from those games.I'm usually not much of a fan of retro styled games but PoE is certainly different. The graphics are very classic but high resolution isometric 2D scenarios with 3D rendered characters. The scenarios range from beautiful to nice and some of the dungeons are incredible while others are a bit bland. A thing that usually bothers me in classic games is the generic look of everything and every piece of equipment. Such is not the case with PoE where unique items certainly look unique and special.The combat is actually quite nice. The combat is real time and pausable. While pausing, you must micromanage your party to certain actions and develop strategies. Don't mistake yourself, this game is hard but it is playable by anyone willing to think rather than aimlessly click for spells or attacks. There are other games much better for that.The companions are very interesting and I certainly loose my time reading through their dialogues but I don't care much for the souls of random NPCs written by the backers of the game. In fact, in game memorials to the backers sometimes break the immersion a lot since you read their nicknames or real names that simply don't fit the game universe. I wish they've done this homages differently. Most of the bigger side quests are very interesting and allow you to explore the world freely. There are endless items, spells and abilities which can be a bit overwhelming if you are OCD about optimizing your combat and stats, but it's fine if you play casually. I only stop to refine my characters when I feel difficulties in game. With the exception of some bounties and dragons, the combat is challenging but quite playable, dragons and some bounties can become really tough fights and require a lot of patience, thought and Google. I enjoy most of the dialogues and many of them are voiced but I feel that sometimes they extend a bit beyond reasonable depending on the subject. Certain mundane topics simply don't deserve so much text and feel snobbish and pretentious at some point but after a while you easily predict such cases and simply skim through them with no problem.For me, the worst feature of this game is the main quest. Despite some very interesting characters or moments from time to time, I simply find it boring to death more than I would like and it would be impossible to keep me in this game if the world itself and the other quests weren't so addictive. But I feel that the introduction of the world of Eora perhaps guided the tone and feeling of the main quest. I expect a much better main quest in PoE2. I think the main quests in both the expansion packs are much better. To give you a hint of what kind of story I enjoy, for me, good main quests were the ones of Elder Scrolls: Morrowind and Skyrim. On the other hand, I simply couldn't stand the Oblivion main quest and almost lost interest in the TES series.As negative aspects I must also point the loading screens which are a drag if you have a regular hard drive and the interface in this kind of games usually takes a while getting used to if you don't have the patience and of course, the ocasional bugs.I strongly recommend this game with both expansion packs. If you have the patience and time, buy the extras since it includes a lot of stuff you can read if you enjoy that. If you are not a reader, unless you are really eager to obtain a few wallpapers, soundtrack and such, don't waste your money.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												My fiance bought me this game based on the hype from streamers. He also knew that I loved the Baldur's Gate games and Pillars of Eternity was being hailed as a spiritual successor. I bought in the hype myself, and was very excited to play it.I'll overlook the glaring bugs that I encountered initially (having to do with Unity's network management [including Hamachi and wired ethernet adapters], which isn't even used for the game) because those don't have anything to do with the story, writing, shoddy combat system, or massive class imbalances.I started with a rogue, which I quickly learned was a mistake. Any character can use rogue skills like stealth and lockpicking, and the backstab bonuses are negligible. The game's monsters ranged from easy one-shot skills to groups of Shadows that will ignore your warrior and pick off your party by swarming the weakest character first.I don't have any problem with this type of mob, but when they occur within the first hour or so of the game without any learning curve, it's a bit imbalanced. I really wonder if people who aren't used to CPRGs even enjoy it.The writing is cumbersome and extremely difficult to suffer through. There's just too much of it. Which wouldn't be a problem if it wasn't mediocre to start with. That's nothing new in games, but the writing borders on shakespearean levels of twisted, confusing wording without any of the art or cleverness. I find myself either re-reading passages to figure out exactly why they're over-describing some scene or I just read a few words and skim through.This game is not unplayably difficult but the combat is extremely imbalanced and random. It just saps out the fun.This is just not a good game. And it's frustrating that since this is a Kickstarter-backed game, there is nothing but insane hype and blind support. People who gave money to the development of this game will support it unconditionally. Even when I seek help for some difficult parts, forums are filled with "maybe you shouldn't suck so much" instead of acknowledgements that *MAYBE* Oblivion's custom combat mechanics are s***.If you're thinking about buying this game, read the negative reviews first. Be prepared for what's wrong with it so there aren't any nasty surprises.

number of helpful: 24 of 31 people (77%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
To begin with: Pillars of Eternity is a great game and worth every cent! The music and graphics will make every Baldur's Gate fan feel at home right away. It feels and appears to be a worthy disciple of the classic RPGs (Baldur's Gate, Nox, D&D, Icewind Dale, ...).However, there are some nasty "buts" which spoil the pleasure of playing.For example the loadingsscreens appear to last for ever after some hours of gaming. Especially the first load of every session takes sometimes several minutes (It's not my system!) Also the leveling is kind of expendable, because except of the athletic skill for every character, and the mechanics and lore skill for one of your character you can't really increase useful skills. Why raise survival if you never really have to eat something?Furthermore a level cap of 12 is kind of low and you need forever to get there (isn't ascending levels step by step the essence of RPG?).Another big nasty "BUT" for me is, that you can't see boots, belts and gloves on you character and that unenchanted helmets do not protect your character against weapons...Yeah there's no difference between wearing no helmet and a big, heavy steal helmet!All in all, a great game, but the Pillars of eternity have some cracks and won't last for the promised eternity...Update: Big plus, great story and many, many side-quest!Update: Maaaaaaan, there are really a whole lot of side-quests...nearly too much! :-D Only thing bothering after some time: too much reading --> some of the main quest story lines should be narrated via videos or drawings...P.S.: The loading screens are shorter now, maybe the the patch 1.05 solved the problem!!And another update: The pathfinding of all characters is sometimes very crappy.And my last Update:Really?! okay, so I'm Level 12 (Last Level) and playing on hard. I killed every enemy without any problems and was kind of overpowering everyone. This was a bit lame... So the end fight against Thaos came. I thought: "Okay this will be challenging..." But he and his living statues were totally invincible!! I tried for hours until I caved in and played the fight on easy... A very ♥♥♥♥ing frustrating end: at first easy and lame, then unfair and infuriating...Pity!And really my last Update:So I heard that many of the cons of this game have now been fixed!! That's great, but for me there is this bitter aftertaste: Why not fix all the little bugs and glitches and especially big mistakes in gameplay BEFORE releasing a game?!!?  I feel kind of ripped of, when a buy a game for 20 €, it's NOT EARLY ACCESS, play it for 80 hours + and then little by little everything that bugged me is fixed over the 	period of nearly one year.Right now there is version 2.XXX out --> I think that says it all!!I would have wanted the unalloyed joy of playing it in this condition right away. Or at least a warning that it's early access!Okay, it wasn't my last Update:Sooo, there Update 3.03 out now...I mean, it's great that they are stil working on this game, but...3.03 ..................Really?!It's so absurd, that I'm almost tempted to play it again just to see what's different and if it's 3.03 times better^^

number of helpful: 500 of 874 people (57%) found this review helpful51 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												First of all I have to say I'm a huge fan of computer role playing games, some of my favorite ones being Planescape Torment, Baldur's Gate series, Icewind dale series, Arcanum and Fallout 1 and 2 which I've re-played a number of time over the years. I'm also a pen and paper player of D&D. I have been waiting for years and years for a true successor to Baldur's Gate to come, and sadly, I've fell to the hype and foolishly believed this is finally it. In few short points I will try to describe why I'm disappointed with this game. - It was widely advertised as a spiritual successor to Baldur's gate series so I was naturally expecting an epic storyline similar to a "child of Lord of Murder" and addictive combat mechanics similar to AD&D ruleset. Both are missing from this game. Obsidian tried to invent their own ruleset which just doesn't work as well and in the end makes every class too similar to each other. I rolled a rogue and was surprised to see my only rogue skill was mechanics, which every other character in the game could also level up, so why have the rogue class at all? There's no hide is shadows skill, only hide in shadows combat ability which can be used only 2 times per rest (which are very limited in this game), so in the end I outfitted him in plate and went full melee ignoring my rogue skills completely. Even though there's perception attribute, you have to use stealth mode to actually find hidden caches and since there's a lot of hidden items in the areas you visit, you'll be stealthy (and thus slow) almost all the time. No wonder this game brags with 100 hours of gameplay. Every class or race can use every item in the game, the only penalty being the reaction time (speed) of the character influencing casting or weapon attack time. Everyone can also use scrolls, all potions, etc.Spellcasting is also very bad and limited in this game, as almost every spell is combat only, meaning there are no pre-battle buffs, and taking into account that many useful spells are area of effect, and that there is friendly fire - nothing bad with that per se, but since your spellcaster has to get real close to cast them, it's virtually impossible to use them effectively.  There's no traditional spellbook but a grimoire which can hold infinite amount of spells but only 4 per level can be selected for use at a time, and then again you have a limited per rest usage of them. And since they are combat only, expect generic boring spells, different by damage type only (fire, ice, poison, etc.). Transcribing the spell from another caster's grimoire costs money, depending of the level of the spell. Why? I guess the grimoire you carry has a slot that says "insert coin here" or something. There are no actual materials used in the process, so... A lot of these immersion breaking and irritating little things in the game.There's also a infinite shared item stash which is carried by you all the time, there's no encumbrance, so strength makes no impact on how much you can wear or carry, you get the picture. - The story. It started interesting but very quickly went to "visit this guy, oh he's dead, visit that guy, oh's he's dead also - let's visit another guy and hope he gives us some answers". I'm 25 hours in the game and don't know crap about what's going on except I'm some kind of Watcher that can see the person's soul. There's a skill you get early on which let's you reach into someone's soul and read about that person's past life. There's a ton of those people around and it's not interactive in any way or integrated into a story, just walls and walls of texts. I started fearing visiting new locations because of it, just how much pointless stories I will have to read in this tavern? In the end I beat my OCD and just skipped those. The game just bombards you with lore, names and history from the get go, even on the character creation screen. It's very hard to process all that information, the names are not memorable, and I'm not even familiar yet with the layout of the world, so dumping all that information all of the sudden can be overwhelming. Races, provinces, wars, deities, cities, islands... OK, OK... let me care about something at least a bit before you hit me with info over the head. I had like 50 books on me in the first 5 hours of the game. - Crafting and lootThere's crafting in the game and it's available to every character, you do it from your inventory screen. Some items can be enhanced, some can not. You can put some properties on your gear and increase it's damage potential or defense. It' very generic and uninspired and I guess it's there only to serve as a money sink. In 25 hours playing or normal (which people say it's hard compared to similar games), I haven't used one consumable or a scroll. I don't see a situation where I'm spending thousands of coins to make a single scroll.Loot is also very generic, there are some named items in the game, but nothing special, nothing that lets you feel really powerful. In the end you can make your own stuff by crafting, I had everyone dual wield flaming weapons, which I made myself. If there's no good and interesting loot, there's NO REASON to explore. take into consideration there's also no XP from killing stuff, and you lose interest in exploration completely. Skyrim and Dragon Age Origins made the same mistake. RPG's are all about risk and reward. You risk your party to overcome an obstacle to get riches, items, artifacts, experience and with it new skills that again make you feel more powerful. The game should ideally throw increasingly difficult obstacles onto you, and in return giving you nicer things, it's a very simple process, really. Makes you feel satisfied. Do I feel satisfied with PoE when after a fight I find just same old vendor trash I found 20 hours before? No, I don't. I did not feel compelled to explore in PoE, at all. You literally explore the whole map, and find nothing except for a few crafting herbs. - QuestsNothing special or original, at all. Fetch quests. A guy in the woods I've never seen before asks me to overthrow a local noble. I accept and go to the keep of that lord, only to be attacked on sight. Why? Is that standard practice to attack everyone who comes to the door? I guess the interactivity lies in the 3 different entrances into the keep (main gate, sewer, over the wall). OK, so I kill them all, the crazy lord included and the first guy reappears and just takes the throne and keep over. That's it. No more conversation with the guy. NPC 1 changed by NPC 2. I actually still enjoyed that part of the game, the art of the keep was very nice but was surprised how shallow the writing was. Is that really the best what you could do with that story? Perhaps it get's better later on, but in 25h I've yet to see a memorable NPC or an enemy who has something interesting to say. Think of first level of BG2, I'm sure you remember the genie you encounter. That genie has a lot more personality than any NPC I've seen in this game so far. Final thoughts:The Pillars of Eternity is not a terrible game, it's OK, I guess. In fact, I liked it considerably more that the Wasteland 2. What PoE is missing is addictive gameplay, and better writing. I wish they bought the D&D license and went with Forgotten Realms setting and ruleset. This way it feels more like Drakensang: The Dark Eye than Baldur's Gate. A missed opportunity. When my honeymoon period with the game ended, about at 15h, I had to force myself to start the game again, and that's not a good sign. You know that feeling when you can't put your finger on a specific thing that's wrong but you feel it just isn't it. I'm not sure I will finish it at all, in fact it reminded me how Arcanum was great and I got a craving for that game, over this one. Don't believe the hype, it's not the best thing ever and can't measure up to 15+ yo games. Buy it, but only when heavily discounted.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												Like many decisions I made at 17, I had no idea the impact that installing Baldur'sGate would have on my life.  Fast forward to a man in his 30s returning to that special, hopelessly immersed, "yes I know what time it is!", place with the absolute gem that is Pillars of Eternity. The game is not so much a return to old glory, as much as it is old glory catching up to those of us who thought it past and gone.  The plot is VERY dark, gritty, and grown up.  There are volumes worth of lore, history, and politics written in detail, yours for the reading, which flesh out the setting and pivotal time in which you enter the story. The world is beautifully drawn.  The character and combat system, while not D&D rules and conventions, feels more like an evolutionary step forward for D&D e.g. Do you like your wizard to fire the same old magic missiles all of the time? Fine.  But after that I want him to pull out his pistol and shoot a filthy iron theif in the face! Can do.Faerun? Never heard of her.10/10Would wait 15 years again.

												This is what I craved for since Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale series.I expected more than 38 hours of gameplay and more locations but even I consider it too short it was beautiful.Nice story with some original elements, lots of side quests, but characters personal quests seems underdeveloped. I wanted more story for some of them, like Pallegina or Grieving Mother. Some backgrounds are impressive but not all of them. Voice acting is good, music is enjoyable.Anyway, if you really want to get the story you will have to read and imagine for yourself a lot.Entire scenes are only in text, so if you lack imagination or you really hate reading don't try it, as there is no animations and no sounds for lots of scenes (like souls memories). Also not all dialogues are spoken.Crafting is so-so but Enchanting is really nice - why waiting to loot a good weapon or armor when you can make one yourself?I am an old gamer and I know to appreciate a good game, so I give it 9,5/10. Might seem outdated for some people but for me is a returning to CRPG roots and Obsidian knew how to made this enjoyable. Sorry for my poor English.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												I wanted to like POE and I played it through to the end but there are just too many issues. First of all there is WAY too much dialogue and lore to sift through. Instead of adding to the immersion it really becomes a chore. I can't imagine doing another play through primarily for this reason. With the exception of the Roderic's Hold quest the game is relatively linear and there are few choices you can make that materially effect the world. The castle upgrades seem tacked on and pointless. The skill system is very basic and doesn't allow for much specialization. Characters will often end up with similar stats and the only ones that seem to really matter are lore, lockpick and traps. They've updated some basic party AI for this game but it is woefully insufficient. Programmable AI was a feature in IE games 15 years ago. So there really is no excuse for the lack of its inclusion originally.As it is the system they have doesn't work effectively on the higher dificulty levels. Be prepared to click hundreds of times in a tough battle rather than have your party follow a simple script. There is SO much combat in this game it really does become a grind and I don't understand why people defend the massive amount of micromangement it requires. The load times in POE simply take way too long. I have an average system but I've heard that even players with good rigs still suffer from bad load times. This shouldn't be an issue for a 2D game running an old engine. The plot is meh and the characters aren't particularly memorable. This game is a dungeon crawler first and foremost and more like Icewind Dale than BG1 or 2. The party AI and dialogue just kill it for me but if you're a fan of this genre it might be worth a play through if it's on sale. RPG masterpiece it certainly is not.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												Incredible game, EPIC plot in a fantastic world, and characters I will miss for a long time. Just the right balance of mystery,  philosophy, humour, grit, dark fantasy, choice-'n'-consequence, and awe-inspiring regions and architectures. Highly recommended for the world and the story alone. The tactical combat is just my style, but I'm aware it's a bit of a love/hate system for some people. I find that it works great, personally.Though for honesty's sake, I will list some of the negatives you could expect of the game:Has a few issues around pacing, you can feel a bit bogged down in Act II, but persevere because it is totally worth it. Combat , even just on Normal mode, can be punishing and tough to get used to (especially if you're used to RPGs where *you* *alone* are the hero and doing everything, not calling the shots for a group of six), but - like Dark Souls - once it clicks, it *clicks*, and you'll be running through on Hard with few problems.Assuming you don't go with any of the game mechanic limiters (limited access to stash, etc), there's nothing really stopping you from spamming "Loot All" at everything and end up sitting on a money empire that even a Doemenel would envy. But this is a minor issue, at worst. If you don't like it, all the tools are there in the options menu.Still a few rare combat bugs, I know I nabbed a Blunderbuss that would blind most of my frontline when it fired.But no, seriously, give this game a whirl. One of the best RPGs on the market, in my books.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Huge disappointment (I helped to kickstart it, so no - I am not a guy who expected Diablo 4). The world is utterly boring and unimaginative (a copy of medieval Europe... without any twist), companions vary from good (Durance) through OK (Grieving Mother, Eder) to absolute rubbish (the rest... extra terrible is that dwarf who's totally not an inuit and who dumps walls of texts about seal hunting and other "fascinating" stuff). I found out later that Carrie Patel was narrative lead - which explains a lot, I actually bought one of her books (I was really hyped for this game) and couldn't get past first 100 pages which is a rare thing for me.There's a ton of useless NPCs with some stories provided by backers (usually bad ones) - and although you can avoid them, they clutter cities and pubs and the whole idea of having them is completely silly. Other characters talk a lot but have nothing to say. I am a guy who enjoys "games you can read through", but I expect some decent level of writing, not just an outlet for some untalented nerd's graphomania. And don't make me start on game mechanics. All stats are dump stats, only your level matters. Crafting and enchanting feels like... crafted... 2 hours before release. Main antagoinst has charisma of shredded carrot. I actually couldn't even care about the story or what was going on, it was so boring. Actually, the game felt like Diablo 4 at times, since I was going through million instances of the same encounter where all I had to do was click on enemies in proper order, while getting annoyed with the engagement feature (good idea, bad implementation) - zero challenge, even on hard difficulty (except for that final fight under Caed Nua, for which you need level 12).But yeah, graphics is great... That's why we play games, right?

number of helpful: 140 of 237 people (59%) found this review helpful27 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												5/10  - That's being generous.Baldur's Gate this certainly isn'tPros -1 - Graphically it's adequate. A step up from the games it claims to be emulating but certainly nothing to get all hot and bothered about. After 15 years, this type of game should look better than BG and BG2. Why people are going mad about this is as if its a new innovation, is beyond me.2 - I'm struggling to think of a 2.Cons - 1 - Character generation. Too many crap classes so that you either go for the old faithful fighter (dull, very dull) or a cipher (gets dull real quick). It all comes down to random dice rolls anyway, so it doesn't really matter what points you put where. 2 - As a game, either you're going to be new or old. If you're going to have new races, don't have elves or dwarves. Either forge your own identity, or don't. This just feels like a lazy attempt to pretend POE is somehow a new experience wrapped in a nostalgic bubble. By either description, it falls way short.3 - Wow the items are dull. Looting your local grocery store would result in more interesting items than you'll generally find at the end of a dungeon in this game. You'll grind your way through generic mob after generic mob, just to find a chest full of crap. So then, you're left with crafting, which while available, feels half hearted and ill thought out. They added crafting as a tick box exercise, rather than make the effort to make it rewarding. 4 - Combat. Okay.....open You Tube and find the Benny Hill theme. Then start a combat. Play the theme as your enemies target your spell caster. Watch the spell caster flee around the screen, followed by the enemy, followed by your tank hopelessly trying to reacquire the enemy.5- Combat. It's so bad it deserves more mentions. Combat will go like this. Fire off the spell you always fire off. Switch to your standard attack. Go downstairs. Make some dinner. Ring a friend. Come back to find the party still trading boring blows with boring enemies. This is if you're lucky.6 - Combat - If you're unlucky, you'll fire off a spell and set your tank(s) fighting, only to find that your ranged attackers have bizarrely ceased to attack and are now stood around doing nothing. That or they've been killed by the super teleporting shadow monsters that appear on top of them. In this case, you have the choice to either try and run, dying immediately due to the absurd game mechanics, or stand and die anyway. Your spells are mostly useless, so you'll be presented with a big list of crap to choose from each time you level, rather than spells that feel useful. In 30 hours, I have never found an item with any kind of wow factor. Nothing that I equipped gave me any sense that the effort of slogging my way through the generic, uninspiring dungeon was actually worth it.7 - The NPCs. Talking to strangers at the bus stop is more rewarding than engaging these generic, dull characters in conversation. They have as much life when they've been killed as they do alive. They have no reason to follow you and nothing much to say when they do. Baldur's Gate etc are old games now, but they managed to produce real characters. Fifteen years later and POE has undone this. I didn't care if they lived. I didn't care if they died. In an RPG of this price in 2015, that's just not good enough. I didn't expect Mass Effect character development, but I certainly hoped for more than walking cliches, that largely dissolved into taciturn automatons after their initial, uninvolving dialogue. 8 - The Lore/World - Lots of lore can be a good thing. It's been done well in other games. It's not done well here. It's like a commitee pulled together a load of standard fantasy fiction and slung it together to create a world notable only by it's staggering blandness. Blah, blah, elves, dwarves, blah, blah, ancient ruins, blah, blah dungeons. It's all so lazy and predictable. 9 - Having to rest to somehow regain your ability to use magic is a mechanic that was crap fifteen years ago. It belongs in table top roleplaying gaming, and that is the type of player attracted to POE. They want to play D&D again, but no one does anymore, so they wax lyrical about POE instead. That kind of limiting, tedious mechanic doesn't appear in computer RPGs anymore for a reason. Unless you're an old school roleplaying gamer, with the accompanying problems with OCD, this kind of mechanic has no place in computer RPGs.10 - Price - If you loved BG and BG2, then maybe you'll like this. I didn't, but you might. Wait for a sale though. To price this in a similar band to Witcher 3 or DAI is ridiculous. What you're getting is a  facsimile of games that are 15 years old. There's nothing new here and certainly not one iota of innovation. I would argue that POE is in fact a huge step back from the old games it seeks to emulate. Don't pay full price for this. It's not worth it when you can pay a fraction of the price and pick up the original and vastly superior genre games from the early 2000s, like Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights.Conclusion- For the price, this just isn't good enough. POE is bogged down by a bland world, uninvolving characters and a dull, bugged combat system. I spent hour after hour hoping it would get better. That somehow the world would come to life. It never did. For 5.99 this game would be okay. For 34.99, it's a been one huge and, frankly unacceptable disappointment. It piggy backs on the reputation of much older and far superior games, without ever matching their achievements. Baldur's Gate will be remembered in another fifteen years. Barring bargain basement sales, POE will have been forgotten in fifteen months.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												It is a very good return to RPG but unfortunately it's plagued by technical issues.what I liked: + Your character has a personality that builds up during dialogues, and there seems to be a lot of triggers for different reputations in most unexpected discussions, it's wonderful. + Your companions often have some comments to discussion you're having. + Pretty big world with a lot of memorable people, even if they only give you one tiny taskwhat I disliked - The stories are far too predictable, and attempts at jokes somehow produce a cringe instead - too hollywood style, the bad kind of it. - Monstrously long loading screens for every door, even if it's just a cupboard of an "inside" where your party barely fits with a chest that has negligible coin. - Weak loot. Finding a non-trash item is winning a lottery, let alone something actually useful for your style. And they're unique, which is heavily impacted by the below: - a game-breaking bug that seems to go unfixed for over a year. Your party configuration gets stuck and if you don't have an earlier save - ... You can unscrew it somewhat with a lot of fiddling, but all gear on some of the characters vanishes. Unique pieces that you won't ever have again and nothing can replace them.All in all, I've been having fun with it, by finding other stuff to do during loading screens. Until I got that bug. Which made losing these 44 hours painful enough to give it a negative. It's far too long to have several playthroughs.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												A true homage to the infinity engine games. Probably my favorite game of the CRPG kickstarter revival so far.A good story, although sometimes too wrapped up in its own lore for its own good. There are times when the NPCs will be using words that aren't defined, and you sort of have to use context clues to figure it out. There's also a lot of talk of different gods, regions, etc, and with no prior knowledge of the setting it can be a bit overwhelming. Still, the story was good and the world created was interesting.Mechanically, the game is basically a modernization of the old infinity engine games. The interface looks the same, the combat works the same, and it's all pretty great. My only complaint might be that the underlying game system is basically just a rip of D&D (which is to be expected), but to the point where you might wonder why they bothered to differenciate in terms between the systems. Might vs strength, deflection vs armor, etc. I encounted a couple of bugs, but nothing too serious. I had to use a third party program to fix a characters run speed at some point, but i'm sure that will be fixed in a patch.The kickstarter stuff is, thankfully, easily avoided. If you want to dive into it you're welcome to, but it's easy to know what to avoid if you don't care.Overall, a great game. I highly recommend it.

												Obsidian delivered again.All their known qualities (world building, deep lore, profound story and characters) are present in this game. Combat system and exploration are also great. There are some cons here and there such as little unique loot, short companion quests and medium combat difficulty (at least on normal) but the potential is there for future installments to tap into it.Most of rpgs in recent years are just a footnote to its magnificence. Pillars of Eternity is a classic of our times, prepare to be enthralled by it.

number of helpful: 38 of 57 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												As a huge fan of the old Infinite Engine games like Baldur's Gate I had hoped for so much *more* from this game. Whilst it did much to modernise the genre, in many areas it failed to live up to the nostalgia.Graphics - The game kept true to the art style whilst bringing it forwards into the modern era of gaming, the backdrops were breathtakingly beautiful and it played smoothly without any issues.Sound/Voice Acting - The sound/voice acting wasn't particularly noteworthy, it wasn't terrible yet it wasnt great either, it didn't really stand out much.Story-telling/narrative - The story was a bit vague and didn't really have much direction during the first act but it quickly picked up during the second act before slowly tapering off towards the end. There weren't any really exciting revelations or twists that made it wow me. The villain, their motivations and relationship to the protagonist were somewhat interesting but it wasn't anything that stood out. Often at times to convey just how filled out the world and backstory was you're presented with a wall of text which probably wasn't necessary and felt like it detracted from the story at times.Gameplay Mechanics/Combat - This is probably the most disappointing aspect of the game. The game feels like it's more of a stealth crpg because they limited the experience gained from combat to just the first few initial run ins with each foe type and kept the overall experience gained from combat to a very minimal amount, along with the plethora of items that dropped from enemies being utterly useless, it often felt like the better choice was to sneak/avoid enemy encounters which just slows down the pace of the game. Avoiding combat entirely was also made more desirable by the fact that you were heavily penalised for trying to escape combat or run around or disengage with an enemy during combat which often resulted in the character dying quicker than had you just stayed in place and tried to (but likely fail to do so anyway) tank it. Spell casting also felt more burdensome and tiring than in the older IE titles because of the resting mechanics of the game whereby you had to carry supplies to rest and were limited to only carry a certain amount of supplies with you, so if you ran out of supplies you were forced to return to a store to purchase more or not rest and not be able to heal, or restore spells for combat.Itemisation - The difference between a normal, un-enchanted item and a unique item felt lacking. The difference in damage was minimal, I played as a barbarian and would do 80s with normal items and as high as 96 using a unique item of the same type. Another problem with the itemisation is that so many items gave boosts to player stats, but conflicting stat boosts (ie. gloves that give +1 might and boots that give +2 might) would be nullified meant that gearing most slots felt like a waste of time and forced players down the route of jack of all trades, master of none.Overall I would rate this game as a 6/10, or in terms of similarities to the old IE games it has the combat of Planescape Torment with the story of Icewind Dale, it tries to relive the nostalgia but focuses on the wrong aspects of what made them great games.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Still a bit early but I'm making a review regardless. I backed this game for $160, that was not a poor decision, because so far PoE is really fun.I'm not a big fan of the old D&D WRPGs, personally I think they're convoluted messes and I only really played through Planescape because the writing, atmosphere, and roleplaying made up for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat, and they really, really did, Planescape is one of my favorite games. I backed PoE because Obsidian are pretty much head and shoulders above almost every other dev team when it comes to writing, atmosphere, and actual roleplaying and I always want to see more games from them. (I’m also happy to have saved Obsidian from bankruptcy too) PoE being a spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate, still feels a tad bit grognardy to me compared to something like Shadownrun’s more streamlined and accessible combat but I'm getting the hang of it and having fun with it and the game does a good game explaning itself for the most part such as telling you exactly what stats you should be dumping into for each class you roll. It still does has a few dumb grognardy mechanics that it doesn't explain very well though, they're not dealbreakers but they can be annoying at times, such as seprate equipment not being able to buff  the same stats and no way to aggro enemies. Playing on Easy helps, but I still can’t play too stupidly so it’s not braindead easy. If you want a challenge though this game is very happy to oblige. The three reasons I backed this game for are all definitely here. The game can get pretty expostiony with its world building but its interesting worldbuilding so it’s cool. As said still too early to make a true final verdict but if this game keeps it up it will be a really good game and a must play for all the old D&D RPG and normal RPG fans alike.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												I really wish I didn't buy this game. There are so many awful design choices (or oversights) that ruin the experience. The gameplay basically boils down to having your tank in the front and having as little melee as possible. It's so immersion breaking that, in order to make your crew more effective, you don't use armor to make sure they refresh faster. There are tons of cheap fights where enemies spawn on top of you (spectres) or you enter a room and you engage in a fight right off the bat and your guys are in a terrible formation and just get slaughtered.I was doing fine for awhile until I couldn't beat certain fights and then I learned that simply having all your characters use ranged weapons (preferably guns) without wearing armor is the best way to go. It totally killed the game knowing that's how you roll through this game.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Best 120 hours of gaming I have spent. Quality from start till finish, and throughout every single side-step in between. Pillars of Eternity is extremely well written. The stories are told in very rich language that is way above average even in fantasy literature. The game is one grand adventure and feels like reading/watching an epic and long story where it's up to you when and where the main characters will go and what course of action they will take. To fully appreciate this game you need to read  a lot of in-game texts, like books, dialogues with other characters, descriptions and all the information that shows up in your journal. And this is a very welcome gameplay element for me. Not only is it a pleasure to read due to how well written it is, it also fosters your own imagination. I love everything about this game: the combat, the stories, the main story, the lore. But most of all I love it because it's a properly executed awesome and epic long adventure that I never wanted to end.

												I've played only a very small amount of the original Baldur's Gate, so my nostalgia for the Infinity engine games is pretty much nonexistant. However, I still find myself absolutely captivated by this game. The visuals, tone, lore and characters are top-tier in terms of modern RPGs. If you enjoy reading huge walls of very well written fantasy text, this game is for you. Also, your choices matter! The combat is satisfying, though 90% of encounters so far basically boil down to:Send in the tank dudes, while my main character wizard dude nukes everyone from the back. There are occasions where teleporting enemies will disrupt this tactic, but even so it's satisfying every time your party is victorious. I'm about 10 hours into my new playthrough after I stopped playing last year, but I'm determined to see this adventure through. Would recommend for anyone wanting a decent long RPG to last the summer.

number of helpful: 25 of 35 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is a well-written and strongly executed spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate II. No RPG in the last decade can hold a candle to its immersive role-playing experience or engrossing, highly believable world. This modernized take on the classic CRPG is a must-buy for any fan of the genre.But how does it measure up to it's predecessor?Below I will list a few points from the perspective of a veteran gamer who values immersion in his RPGs above all else, and will attempt to measure it against one of the greatest RPGs of all time.You must gather your party before venturing forth…Pillars is much easier to play than the Baldur's Gate trilogy, doing away with several annoyances Infinity Engine veterans won’t miss:  ++ Flawless path-finding   ++ Sexy as ♥♥♥♥  ++ Excellent UI design  ++ Level design plus “fast mode” saves a ton of time  ++ Tutorial, though heavy, is very informative  + Tooltips!  + New stash system for painless inventory management  + Flags for stat-qualifying conversation options  + Quest notifiers  + …and much more!  ++ Options to turn off most of the above if you feel it interferes with your role-playing  ++ Does all of this while retaining the feel of classic CRPGs (major nostalgia bonus)Character BuildingAt the systems level, Pillars biggest departure from classic CRPGs lies in its new attribute and skills system. To me this has been a mixed bag:  +++ Every attribute and skill has a place in conversations and scripted sequences  ++ A ton of options for each class, much more customization than classic CRPGs  ++ Updated reputation system is excellent and works as intended  ++ Very challenging early game– hallmark of the classic RPG  ++ Every attribute influences combat, no dead-weight attributes  + Skill system allows more freedom for customization  + Mastering new attributes is a fresh challenge for RPG vets  + Can build custom NPC adventurers whenever you want  - - - Classes are not nearly as unique as in classic CRPGs  - - No multi-class / dual-class, classes all have same XP chart for leveling  - - Leveling up doesn’t have the occasional power spike that was so satisfying in BG  - - No alignments! This affects companions most, more on that belowSo to sum up there is a big tradeoff here: much deeper customization at the cost of much weaker character identity / personality on each character sheet. Is this modernization worth it? Depends on the player.Modernized CombatIn general, combat in Pillars is much more enjoyable, though Baldur’s Gate still does some things better:  +++ More combat, challenging combat –closer to Icewind Dale than Baldur’s Gate  +++ Limited resting plus “per rest” and “per encounter”  system rounds out encounters!  ++ Melee engagement completes the positional party-based combat feature-set  ++ New damage-type and defense-type systems are excellently executed  + New friend/foe AoE mechanics add a bit more depth  + Modernized combat UI with AoE overlays decrease yolo-ness of spell-casting  + Item enchanting adds customization to combat style  +/- In general, more abilities and options, less impact of each individual ability  - - - Spells and abilities feel nerfed compared to classic CRPGs  - - Not as many crazy encounters as in BG.  - - Challenge is more in mastering the system than in new encounters.  - AoEs everywhere, not enough single-target spellsCharacters, Story & WritingFirst off: good effort by the new narrator, but not even close to the narrator of Baldur’s Gate!Obsidian’s writing may be its greatest strength as a studio, and I would say that several of their sequel projects exceeded the writing quality of the original (Fallout: New Vegas, KOTOR2, Mask of the Betrayer). In my opinion:  +++ Better high-level concept, deals with religion, philosophy and identity better  ++ Original world, characters, etc. are extremely fleshed out  + Main player arc is basically same story as BG, but written better  - - - BG still tells the small stories better, with more detail and broader range of outcome  - - Writing feels rushed sometimesThe companions, though, are where Pillars loses clearly to Baldur’s Gate:  - - - - - - - - - - Nothing close to a Minsc :(  - - - Less personality range of companions. Companions are not differentiated strongly  - - - Weaker classes and no alignments means companion identity and opinions are not as convincing  - - Companions rarely interact directly with other NPCs and events. When they do, feels forced.  - Less companionsAside from my extreme Minsc bias (shared by many), Pillars has significant weaknesses in its systems-level representation of characters, and therefore clearly falls short of Baldur’s Gate in storytelling.Content Design & Parameter DesignThe obvious complaint here is that Baldurs Gate is bigger, takes the player to more places, and exposes the player to a wider variety of characters and factions. No comparison can be made until Obsidian is done with the Pillars franchise– which hopefully will not be anytime soon.However, in many cases, Pillars is too balanced and too accessible, leading to some significant drawbacks:  - - - In BG, you can walk into a random house and start a huge quest, not the case here  - - - Very few chances to permanently gain (or lose) stats  - - - Related to above: less consequences for decisions and therefore less interesting choices  - - - Conversation and NPC interaction in general is not as varied as in Baldur’s Gate  - - Only one stronghold type, less replayability with different classes / characters  - - In general, items feel less unique– especially when compared to Baldur’s Gate  - Curve of item acquisition is more linear, so no dramatic item-based power spikes  - Effect suppression system is healthy for game systems but disappointing for playerPillars is not Torment, and was not designed to be, but its choices above make it modern at the expense of the “anything can happen” feel of Baldur’s Gate. As a role-playing game, the balance feels more like a smooth and guided experience– cleverly giving you the trappings of choice and freedom, while remaining very accessible.The result is a game with strengths that most players will experience, but lacking in the varied details and unbalance that made Baldur’s Gate so special. I would submit that those small details: silly side-quests, ridiculously unfair interactions, huge amounts of content almost completely hidden, etc. They are the quintessence of the open-world RPG experience. And still…There have been many advances to systems design since BG2, and Pillars exploits them to its full advantage. However, in many cases it does so at the expense of immersion. In the end, Obsidian has made conscious choices to make an experience that carries the torch of classic CRPGs in a new, accessible package. As they have said, Pillars does not replace the Infinity Engine games.Pillars of Eternity is a great RPG, and the best RPG of the last decade. With updates, expansions and sequels it may become the greatest of all time.But for now, and in my humble opinion, Baldur’s Gate retains its seat as the king of CRPGs.

number of helpful: 116 of 199 people (58%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												I'll keep this short for you: If you know what TSR, Black Isle, or Interplay are, you'll either nod knowingly or have things to flame me about, by the end of this. If not, you might have some poorly informed opinion-hate for me by the end, anyway. For safety's sake, if you still defend -- say, the D&D alignment system, assume you will hate this review, and me. Oh well.BUCKLE UP AND BRANDISH YOUR D20'S!This will come as a strange response, from a player of older cRPGs, such as the Baldur's Gate series, Icewind Dale, Neverwinter Nights, and Planescape Torment, but, after playing Pillars of Eternity through to its resolution, I suddenly come to realize that the Infinity engine has not aged well.The entire game is plagued by cliches of Tabletop gaming, and does little, either to adapt them for PC gaming beyond what Baldur's Gate and its successors already did, or to turn the conventions harshly on their head, the way Planescape: Torment's story was able. Even most of the enemies are ripped remorselessly from your Saturday night campaign, and given mildly gaelic redubs; Ghouls are Guls, Vampires are Fampyrs, Banshees are Cean Gwla, but it's blatantly transparent. The variety of enemies is even drastically down, from say, Baldur's Gate II. (You've got your typical 'horrible' living dead, bad-mouthed bandits and fanatical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ zealots, some slimes, some beasties, trolls, dryads, and dragons. Yay. I probably missed something and will be narked at about it. Bring me back killing my own mortality.)Worse yet, I never felt the story came to any decent level of 'resolution', for my character--one needling plague of open-ended gameplay that eternally haunts.For perspective for current gamers who are some five paragraphs in, and have never heard of Gary Gygax--if you felt like, say--the ending to Fallout 3 was stupid (having an anticlimactic final battle, being guilted to martyr yourself needlessly to someone else's morality, or suffering a lousy ending because you weren't a completionist when it came to sidequests), you'll feel cheated by the end of PoE, even when you think you're heading toward the ending you want--simply by the system of flags and scripts that determines what disappointing exposition scene you get. (No, Fawkes. You're not denying me my destiny, now get in the '♥♥♥♥ing' GECK chamber. I have a dog to walk away with while the narrator smugly talks about War. No, I am not buying the expansion DLC!)While the end boss to PoE is wholeheartedly on the opposite end of the difficulty spectrum to Fallout 3's ending, you can bet that the outcome doesn't justify the effort.Again for perspective, Torment's boss can be killed in dialogue, but provides a massively more satisfying resolution, that resonates with the overall 'message' of the game. The big bad of this game, by contrast, utterly refutes every line you throw, regardless of stats or what you've accomplished, to the point that you may as well fast-forward to immediate combat (--and past that, just turn on cheats, mouse over him and hit the key to shut him up.) Afterward, the game gives you the ending it has mathed out that you maybe could want, if Obsidian didn't have to spread itself thin covering all the bases (and you'd best bet they had to, the title was nearly their swan song.)Even these things weren't dealbreakers, alone. What truly threw me out of the experience was simply reaching the end stretch of the game, and realizing just how little has changed from older cRPGs in the engine--in fact, in terms of gameplay, things have taken a backslide, in the sense that the descriptions for the function of many of PoE's items are vague at best, and the merits of many of the different stat tweaks and perks pale in comparison to just exploiting the shoddy AI of the Infinity engine. Many encounters I won simply by targetting a single difficult enemy and having a character run around in circles to distract it, or spamming summons and pinning the enemies in corners, while my expendable characters took their time shooting. And if I feel like I'm coming up with tricks to outsmart bits and bytes, and doing complex math before battles, rather than winning out of a sense of skill... welp... Screw math, I'll save that for making stock investments. Back to games that make me care, rather than teabagging my corpse over algebra.MY BURNING QUESTION: IS +10 WILL more valuable than HITTING THINGS FOR 1.2x more DAMAGE?! I HAVE NO IDEA.What made sense as a general guideline for pen-and-paper get togethers over chips and Mountain Dew has never worked particularly well as filler for functional gameplay, on Infinity's part. Hearing the same statistical song and dance try to dress up as something new and improved over twenty years later just makes me groan.Point in Case: Borderlands 2 has a jumbled mess of statistics handed to me to sort out, for its guns--but I can tell what 'fire rate' or 'pellet count' or 'reload speed' are, without a glossary. If I get an amazing weapon, I can tell it's amazing at a glance, and it feels like an event. I know what elements on weapons are effective against what kinds of threats, at a glance, without a monster encylopedia. More to the point, the struggles of Roland and the Crimson Raiders, and the humour of characters like Hammerlock and Claptrap, keep me going in spite of needless number crunches that the devs may as well have handled. Pillars of Eternity gets as far as 'telling' me to care, and then 'literally' sets all my efforts on fire to advance its shallow tale, within the second act.One particularly egregious example: I kill a raving mad local lord who is driving his village into extinction, and appoint his idealistic cousin as successor. By the end of my overly arduous final boss-fight, hidden numbers assigned with dealing out the game's ending montage have determined that my old foe gets up from being dead, goes even crazier, and wipes out everyone in said village before the end credits can even roll. And I have no say in it--how was I supposed to forecast that? ♥♥♥♥♥♥move, game. Imagine if Handsome Jack got away with nuking Sanctuary despite your best efforts defeating the Warrior, in Borderlands 2. How lame would that be?But since I'm not twinking out six me's with optimum gear and stats, maybe I'm not doing something right. I'll never know--I'll be playing other things. Tip for you geniuses of metagaming preparing to flame me: none of the enemies provide combat exp, and the level of encounters scales with your level. Fighting trash mobs produces equivalent results to running to the far end of the room. Have fun with your grind.In summary: Pillars of Eternity neither renews the Infinity engine's myriad wrinkles, nor does it tell a particularly fresh or engaging tale. It's not particularly horrible either--just woefully over-promising, mediocrity on all counts. It was a lukewarm reminder that old things can get a second chance to show how well they've festered, and that's all a good little twink can ask for: spoilt milk and stale cookies with a great big fat +10 to some stat I'll have to look up the applications for, on the end.There's always Torment: Tides of Numenara, coming Q4, right?

content:
Posted: February 26
TL;DR - I wouldn't blindly recommend it.  Know what you're getting into, if it sounds like something you'd enjoy then you very likely will.  It represents a high point for this sort of game, but this sort of game feels dated... or my tastes have just changed.If you enjoyed Baldur's Gate, you'll probably enjoy this.If you never played Baldur's Gate or a similar CRPG, there's a good chance you won't find this very entertaining.The combat is interesting and well explained, if, and only if, you dig for it.  Unfortunately, while it has real-time systems, everything happens so fast that frequently pausing and unpausing is a necessity.  It doesn't feel like I can relax and just enjoy the spectacle, which is unfortunate for a game I thought I would find laid back.The story sometimes feels slow and I never really found myself feeling invested in the characters.  Often times I found myself just blowing past dialogue due to boredom and simply not caring.  That's not to say the characters don't have good backstories; nor that they don't go through some amount of development.  Simply put, it just didn't hook me.  Maybe I've grown out of this sort of story telling?It took me a ludicrous amount of time to finally beat the game.  I would get bored and take breaks for months before feeling guilty that I hadn't finished it and come back to it.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												So let me start by saying that this is A Very Good Game (tm).I was a bit pessimistic about it -- after all, how many times has Obsidian come so close to releasing a truly great game, yet failed to completely deliver (granted, often through no fault of their own). I got to play a bit of Pillars at Gamescom last summer and was left feeling pretty meh about it. In hindsight this was probably more because the limited time I had to play it wasn't enough to really properly "get" the game from the very beginning.The writing is very Obsidian, and the worldbuilding is deep and complex. After a few hours in, I can already see Obsidian's trademark moral choices everywhere, and they definitely appreciate the shades of grey that they always have. Some of the choices you're forced to make leave you seriously wondering if you're -actually- supporting the good/bad guys, and I think that's honestly really great. Pretty much exactly what you'd come to expect from Obsidian.Now for some gameplay stuff: I'm playing on Normal difficulty, and as a vet of Infinity Engine games, I'm finding it quite challenging... though that could be my party composition. Being able to create adventurers to fill in gaps in your party is a great feature, but the writing on the companions is good enough that you'll definitely be missing something by using the cookie-cutter custom adventurers. That being said, one thing I'm definitely going to say now is HAVE A ROGUE in your party. The first hour or two of the game you can get by fairly easily without one, but I'm now running into a lot of areas that are laden with traps/lockpickable doors, and I really don't have anyone in my party that is adept at 1.) seeing traps before triggering them, and 2.) deactivating them when necessary. You can probably get away with a Ranger instead of a Rogue, with a bunch of points dumped into Mechanics/Stealth, but nothing is as good as the real deal.All in all, I do not regret paying full price for this game. It's really great, and simultaneously scratches that nostalgic itch for a Baldur's Gate-type game while at the same time offering many current features that make it stand apart on its own as well.I hope Obsidian makes bucketloads of money with this and then goes on to make spiritual successors to some other Infinity Engine-era CRPGs. Arcanum, anyone?

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												I'm a huge fans of Chris Avellone and Obsidian Entertainment. However, I will comment this game very honestly. This game I rated for (6/10) because it does not hit my expectation.It is a good/OK game. I do not recommend to buy this game based on the current price.<Pro>Great GraphicsImproved UI of the baldur's gate version. Awesome weather effects, detailed surroundings.Endurance SystemGreat introduction of the endurance system that affects the Health Point system.Event Sandbox mode:User action based that on the stats is good concept.Warden System:It is a better game grinding version of Caed Nua Levels.<Less Impressive>Storyline:There is no breakthrough in the storyline. The reincarnation that retain the previous life memory is just too lame to be rewritten again and again in so many games and novels. If you are expecting Torment or Fallout 2 level of storyline, you might be disappointed. It's still an overall OK storyline.Stronghold:The concept is awesome but the system not impressive. It allows you idle NPC to join the adventure and get items/exp. The shops inside your stronghold sell normal stuffs that can be bought from any NPC sellers you find in the game. To travel all the way (very long hours/days) to get the a free rest bonus is redundant, you could get a better rest bonus at very cheap rate in any Inn.Dungeons:Basically you just hold  5-6 prisoners of the game. That's it. You mihght get rare items in exchange the prisoners but is entirely unnecesary in this game.Caed Nua Levels:Basically is designated for the player who likes to grind the game to prolong the game play hours.Godlike Race:The only race that is stood-out in this game. The rest are just the replica of the typical elves, dwarfs, halflings race with different names.<Cons>Bad combat system: There is no tactical position neceasary for your NPC. The easiest way to win the combat is group your teamates all togather and wait for the enemy to come to attack you. All you need to do is slow mode or pause the game to spam your spells and skills.Buggy combat system: The characters always got stucked or take the longer/danger route to reach enemy.Boring Side Quests: The side quests are easy, boring and insignificant. It does not really impact too much on the storyline but only the epilodges. The only side quest that capture my attention is the Undying Heritage.Unmotivated Main Quest:Basically you are just chasing an old man who did 'something' on you. There is no 'A MUST' reason to motivate you to continue the main quest. You could just live at your stronghold for the rest of your life.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												This is one damn fine game. It takes a classic formula and breathes new life to it in the form of a modern game with modern production values but all the atmosphere of the original Infinity Engine games. In addition, it takes a careful look at the mechanics, not tied to the AD&D rules, and sets about determining what works and should be kept essentially as is, what doesn't and should be either jettisoned or improved, and what new things could be brought in to further improve the formula. The result is a game that, while not without flaws, is not just a worthy follower to classics like Baldur's Gate but an improvement in most ways that count. The main thing the game could be improved with would be a slightly larger selection of companions.Still, if you're fan of cerebral, atmospheric CRPGs with lots of reading, good world-building and slick but not simplified mechanics, this game is for you.

Posted: March 28, 2015
												Unbelievably unexpecetd masterpiece. I did not expect to spend $45 on a self-titled "isometric rpg". I expected a poor attempt at Baldur's Gate / Temple of Elemental Evil. I've lately been reminiscing about the glory days of Neverwinter Nights, wondering which RPGs I could play to rekindle the D&D 3.5 feel. Holy crap, this game nailed it out of the park. Metacritic score of 93 is a good indication of quality, and if you've played NWN/Baldur's Gate/ToEE, you are getting exactly what you paid for. The story telling and writing is spectacular; I'm actually reading all the dialogue, While this doesn't call itself D&D (licensing issues with 3.5, apparently), it's got the feel perfectly down; fighters fight, paladins lay hands, and wizards cast a magic missle-esque spell. Good god, if you're not playing this game, something is seriously wrong with you.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
Note: I recommend installing on an SSD in order to reduce load times, especially if you’re a meticulous explorer type. You can also use a mod to disable auto-saving, but remember to quick save/manual save occasionally.Pillars of Eternity, a beautifully crafted crpg filled to the brim with content, will hold your attention for a long time. A single playthrough can easily take over 70+ hours depending on how much of the world and quests you to decide to explore. I spent hours reading as many in-game books as I could and even spent some time reading the bestiary. There's even a character journal that'll summarize the things you've done in the game. You can also expect your choices to affect outcomes and your reputation with people and factions. This game is extremely dense and I suggest not rushing through it. Take your time and enjoy yourself. At this point in time, the game is also much more stable than when it first released. They supported the game with patches that solved many issues and squashed interfering bugs. They’ll continue to support with version 2.0 in the future which will add more functionality.Freedom of Choice This game’s degree of freedom and consequences lends itself well to roleplaying and being the character you want to be whether that’s a vengeful barbarian, a monk that’s just trying to set things right, or even a gigantic jerkface. Most of quests have multiple outcomes depending on your actions. Dialogue choices are abundant too and your character stats/background can also affect what you might be able to say. Sometimes the extra responses are for flavor or can result in a fight being completely avoided. Keep that in mind should you decide to have a smooth-talking intelligent character or a mighty sort of person who intimidates. All of the main stats can influence conversations, but some do so much more often than others such as Intelligence and Resolve. If you really wanted to, you could just fly through the game solo, though I’d expect more talking and sneaking around if you chose that kind of path.GraphicsThe game's art assets look fantastic for the most part. I only noticed a building or two and maybe some walls that appeared to be in a low resolution compared to the rest of the game. Just don't zoom in all the way and keep the camera at an appropriate distance, things become blurry if you go in all the way. Every place in the game is a work of art. I especially like the leaves on trees. The trees are gorgeous as are the big, scary spells in the game. It’s quite the sight when a druid calls down a thunderstorm. It’s a beautiful game. Hmm, I suppose I should mention the character models are a bit funny looking since they’re usually seen from an isometric view until you’re in the inventory screen. Also, please try big head mode at least once.Story I thought the story was fine for the most part, but my efforts and interests focused on everything else since I wanted to do as much as possible. I’ll be unspecific to avoid spoilers. The world is a dark place filled with murder, vengeance, and betrayal. The side-quests benefit from the settings by doing interesting things with it. It felt good to vanquish foes that I thought were deserving since my monk didn’t like liars or murderers in general. I thought the main villain’s motivations were interesting and how far he went to accomplish his goals went beyond insanity. The companion storylines/quests might be a mixed bag for some people, but I did end up liking most of them all except for Kana and Pallegina. Pallegina was definitely underutilized and should have had a more fleshed out companion quest. Kana was an interesting person, but his quest seemed underwhelming. On the other hand, Durance and Grieving Mother had some fantastic storylines. I highly recommend seeing the quests of those two to the end. There’s plenty of story to find and read. Even the unique items have different legends associated with them. Some of them function like tragic short stories and are told well.CombatThe combat is a mixture of real-time and turn-based in the sense that you can pause the game mid-combat and issue orders to your party. You can also change the settings to have the game auto-pause when certain conditions are met like low Endurance or when someone is knocked out. I found normal to be somewhat easy for the most part after I had a full party of six members. The game’s difficult encounters still had me pausing and considering my movement and orders very carefully. “Okay, I need a damage reduction buff here. You’ll make it rain thunderbolts, you two try and knock the big guy down, and I’ll have you summon some shades.” The combat has a nice amount of complexity to it when you come across a worthy challenge. If you decide to not have such a large party, then you can expect the game to become harder if combat is your primary way of handling situations. Pause often and succeed, this is not meant to be a 100% real-time experience.Hopefully Pillars entertains you for a long time if it’s your type of game. It has much to offer unless you hate reading, but if you play, you’ll have the added benefit of an increased reading stat. Hooray.
