content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												Guys, this game♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off so many times. It really did. I absolutely hated the fact that it's... where do I start from?!1. Clunkily isometric - no camera rotation - what you see is what you have to work with.2. Objects would intersect with one another so many times, that I barely knew what was going on.3. My guys would wiggle left and right behind one another in a futile attempt to find a way towards the enemy. And even when there is actually space for them to occupy, they would not. Unless I click. Seriously?!4. My guys will absolutely leave the positions i have carefully put them in to expose my weak rear line. There goes Aloth... Again!5. My guy(s) would sit and wait like they are braindead while their comrades are getting slaughtered, waiting for a command on my part while I am way too busy making sure my Priest is on top of the whole endurance/conditions/buffs situation.6. Breaking my space key cause, honestly, that is where your left or right hand should be all the time, based on your orientation.To continue, although I was a teenager during the dawn of the crpgs, I never ever played one - I was way too busy with games like Might and Magic 6-9, Heroes of MIght and Magic 1-4, Starcraft, Caesar 3-4, Pharaoh & Cleopatra, Zeus - Master of Olympus & Poseidon, etc. I never got into that genre. And now, since Divinity: OS launched, I was slowly drawn to it. And I embraced PoE for all it is:1. The rich lore.2. The interesting companions with their own rich story and personality.3. The companion interactions that made me sit, listen, smile and laugh.4. The little side stories which were making me connect even to the npcs that I had nothing to do with.5. The gorgeous handdrawn maps.6. The approach to combat. I have never ever prepared so painstakingly for my battles. Feels really good.7. The exploration, looking under every nook and cranny. Spending half a minute carefully moving your mouse over the screen in search for hidden stuff has never been more satisfying.AND FINALLY, that damn crpg's tons-of-math-and-formulae combat system. At one point I found myself looking into every equation and every calculation and trying to improve my odds.Holy hell, what has become of me... From a guy flagging PoE as "Not Interested" to a person who delves into its mechanics, busying himself making plans for future playthroughs and builds and whatnot.To conclude - buy this game, even if you hate the stuff I hated before it appeared. It has this weird way of drawing you in as the game progresses. I played a good part of it with clenched teeth, sometimes even shouted at my monitor - while waiting for the next time my guys will♥♥♥♥♥♥me off in combat by doing the very exact thing I dont expect of them. And I still went on and enjoyed everything it threw at me, and boy was it worth it. I can't wait for the expansion!

												The time has come for me to review my first game, and so it shall be Pillars of Eternity.So far the game has enthralled me with musical cues, surprisingly intricate graphics, and a gripping storyline. content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												It took me 50 hours to play it through in a rather slow and calm kind of way. While it obviously cannot nearly keep up to the amount of content of a Baldur's Gate II, (lenght of the campaign, amount of optional quests, interesting storylines), it yet does some things better than its predecessors.It is in every sense indeed a game for adults. Dialogues are very well-conceived and sophisticated, and so is the whole background of the story and this new world. Prepare yourself for a LOT of careful reading, if you want to really understand what's going on and take some insights from this game. If you don't, there is still a very good tactical fighting system to explore, but that's obviously not the major purpose here.You find yourself confronted with truly hard moral decisions, where you really have to think about what's right and what's wrong. That is so because the game gives you absolutely no hints where things might lead you or what is now the "good character"-choice. Sometimes I found myself staring for five minutes on some dialogue options before i chose one, thinking really hard what to answer. The game, in its way, rewards you for the effort, building plausible consequences even on the nuances of how your character behaves and what he says.There is no black and white and grey like we are used to from the fantasy genre. Every situation is unique, and sometimes several or even all options lead to consequences that you can't morally justify, but yet you have to come to a decision!It's just like in the real world.That's why i liked this game.

number of helpful: 29 of 45 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												The day steam makes a "tread lightly" reccomendation is the day I actually start using it for serious reviews.PoE was some experience, alright. I could easily write a review singing it's praises and proclaiming it to be a work of genius, and I could also make a review attacking it as a charleton, unacceptably flawed RPG, and neither one would require me to stretch the truth very much.It's a pretty good game. It deserves, at the very least, a 7.5/10, just for the concentrated effort to the self-contained world-building alone. The combat could be robots fornicating and I would still probably think the game was worth a look because of how rare it is that a project takes world creation professionally. There's enough "vanilla fantasy" to understand what's happening without navigating encylcopedia entries, but enough subtle changes to make it interesting. It feels like a Bioware game, and I mean that in the most positive sense that could possibly be conveyed: small story setpieces, tasks, nonessential conversations...lots of little things that don't really mean anything but do make you feel at home. Player agency exists, but only through a filter, much like in Baldur's Gate, so don't expect a choice & consequences game along the glory of Fallout, or even New Vegas.The UI is absolutely fantastic, the inventory and map screens are totally flawless. Despite all the huballoo about the graphics I found the game to be among the best looking RPGs I have ever played, with even the apparently "low detail" character models looking pretty good to me. Most of the clothes and armor look great and the minis are awesome. The soundtrack is a bit too Baldur's Gate for me, but it can easily be ignored except in cases were it loops improperly (which it unfortunately does quite a bit). Engine-wise my only criticism are the loading times, which are far too long even considering my aged laptop.The "guidance" of Baldur's Gate seems to be both a blessing and a curse. Nearly all of the major problems in PoE are things that were major problems for the Baldur's Gate games, so it's a wonder why these problems exist at all. As many of the more negative critics have said, why bother making a spiritual successor to the IE engine games if you're not even going to improve on them? Probably my biggest problem with Baldur's Gate was the D&D system, which is pretty much total♥♥♥♥♥ But what PoE provides instead is somehow worse, which I didn't even know was possible. Perhaps this is secretely a Pathfinder CRPG? This is unmistakably a game that Josh Sawyer directed, seeing how there are "no hard counters" which is basically code for "nothing can be stopped and nothing is fun". 99% of the loot you get is terrible because special weapons have barely any unique attributes besides "do more better damage". Eder's armor is the best armor in the entire game because it means you revive yourself on KO about 50% of the time, which is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing, and you get that about 2% into the game. I put it on my main character immediately and was still wearing it at the end of the game. Nothing else you get even comes close, even the game's equivilant of Excalibur. Maybe this Pillars of Eternity wanted to be like that other game with a PoE acronym on this. Thankfully I don't really much care for item progression in my RPGs.There are only two types of maps: way too ♥♥♥♥ing big and way too ♥♥♥♥ing small. The big maps are actually really cool when you first get to them. Probably my favorite part of the game, and most likely the thing I'll look forward to on replays, was navigating through the big areas like Defiance Bay and Twin Elms and discovering what everyone's deal was. The problem is that these maps are usually the ones with key resources like vendors and inns and you have to walk 500 ♥♥♥♥ing miles to get there, then go through a loading screen, do your thing, then go back to a loading screen again, and then do it all over again if you have two trips to make. It takes way too long to get anywhere, probably longer than those MMORPGs that artificially lengthen travel time so you're eager to purchase mounts. The scenery is absolutely gorgeous but I don't want to stop and smell the flowers all the time, I want to ♥♥♥♥ing progress. The small maps are usually almost pointless wilderness maps, which was another one of my big problems with Baldur's Gate. And then there's the combat. Here's where things really get ugly. Despite the massive hate for it, I found that engagement barely effected me at all, though I do agree with the critics that it is 100% punitive to the players, so the game would lose little retiring the mechanic. The real problem here is the encounter design, which is astronomically terrible. In PoE, there are really only two combat scenarios in the entire game:-You're in a wide open area with many enemies. Send one melee or a ranger pet to help out your backliners and have your tanks engage as many enemies as possible to allow someone to get some AOE spells off.You're in a closed area with a single chokepoint. Send a tank to block off the choke and have your ranged attacks shoot the hell out of the closest enemy.That's seriously it. Even as someone who regularly struggles with enemy placement in tabletop RPGs, it's a very poor effort. There are no flying enemies that soar over your melee attackers and force the hand of magic and arrows, no archers placed in sniper spots, no poison-inflcting venomancers that slowly drag down your party, no battles inside infernal traps, nothing. There is only a single mechanic which forces you to switch up your tactics, and that is charm/domination, which many people hate and get protection against just because it's the only thing you'll ever have to really worry about. Bad combat in RPGs really isn't a surprise, in fact, one of my favorite games, Arcanum, had far worse combat. But there is just SO MUCH OF IT. On my first playthrough I ended up killing 1502 enemies, 302 more than the number required for the "Super Murderer" achievement, and I only ended up killing maybe 20 NPCs that didn't go hostile on me first. I've always been one to hate the diplomacy-is-god style of RPGs where you can literally get away with murder by being a lovable scamp (see New Vegas) but this is ridiculous. I can't understate this: I probably fought more enemies in this playthrough of PoE than I did in my last 5 playthroughs of other CRPGs, including Dragonfall, which is a tactics RPG. So much combat and so little variety.I enjoyed my experience, and probably even agree with my purchase ($45, far more than I am willing to spend on most games), but it was a gruelling effort and I am kind of glad it's over. It's a good game made with a lot of love and care, with some occasional dips in quality, both combat-wise and narrative-wise. There's room for huge improvements with patches, and I would love to see a sequel so long as they don't double dip on kickstarter. But I won't be replaying it anytime soon.

None.

number of helpful: 17 of 23 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												“She’s a goddess, as fickle as they come… and with all the failings you’d expect of an empress and a ♥♥♥♥♥”, Durance says to me in his growly voice. He is a priest talking about his own goddess Magran in whose name he helped kill Waidwen (who claimed to be the living vessel of the god Eothas) during the Saint’s War. Such is the relationship between gods and people in Pillars of Eternity. Gods are not abstract terms used only in blind faith, they are among us every step of the way providing blessing and punishment as they see fit. They are deeply woven within the very fabric of society, with everyone opting for a god to serve and follow. As you start your journey, you learn of Waidwen’s Legacy, a horrible plague beset upon the people of Dyrwood which sees their newborn come into the world soulless. It is definitely true that faith and religion are overarching themes in Pillars of Eternity, but it’s the liberty to create a personal touch provided by Obsidian that makes it so compelling.You witness a strange ritual at the beginning of the game and something strange happens to you. From there, your motivations are up to you. Nobody designates you as the would-be savior of the world, nobody even tasks you to look into Waidwen’s Legacy. You are simply a person making his way through the world designing your own motivations and choosing your own actions. It was this aspect of the game that I found most liberating and compelling. Too often in games you are simply tasked and/or commanded what to do with clear goals set before you. Pillars of Eternity removes all that which makes the whole journey very organic and natural. It’s devoid of that silly feeling of clearly knowing you have something grand to do, but you simply opt to do a lot of things on the side despite everyone constantly reminding you how the world’s fate rests in your hands. This may be a subtle effect, but I found it extremely refreshing and compelling.Obsidian was clear on what it set out to do with Pillars of Eternity, it is definitely a throwback to classic Infinity engine games most notably Baldur’s Gate and Icewind Dale. It even looks the part with its rather simplistic 2D graphics that will instantly remind anyone of those glory days of computer RPGs. However, even though Obsidian didn’t really push any big new ideas, Pillars of Eternity is still very much imbued with many modern takes on what we’ve seen and played a long time ago. The visuals aren’t going to blow anyone away, but the 3D character models, some very nice effects and a strong art style go a long way to make it visually appealing, even gorgeous at times.The combat is real-time with pause, very reminiscent of the first Dragon Age. It is highly tactical with plenty of abilities, spells and traps to choose from. The only problem regarding the combat is the atrociously bad pathfinding. Outside of combat, it works perfectly fine, but during combat, characters will very often get stuck on walls, obstacles and each other requiring you to very closely monitor everything that is going on and manually select each character to get them out of a bind, particularly in confined areas. This can be alleviated to a degree by smart group formation and a bit of micromanagement, but that shouldn’t be necessary. What’s different about the combat is its emphasis on endurance over health. Monitoring health is a long-term affair in each battle, but a far more pressing matter is each character’s endurance level. As they receive damage, their endurance decreases, if it reaches zero, they get knocked out. There are ways to get fallen members back up again and certain classes specialize in such abilities. However, if any character’s health should reach zero, it’s game over for that particular character. So it is possible to lose designed party members for good. However, you can create your own party members at taverns for a fee. There is a large number of character classes and races to choose from, some of which are rather unique such as the cipher class or the godlike race. The downside is the extremely low level cap (12).The game world is very big, there are quite a lot of different and interesting locations to visit from your map view whereas each location is spacious yet not overwhelming. You will also get your own stronghold ruin at one point which you will be able to build up again and receive various benefits. The best thing about the stronghold is that it hides a massive dungeon consisting of 15 levels and a nasty boss fight at the end. What is overwhelming at times is the lore and dialogue which sometimes goes on for too long. Also, the writing, while generally very good, can get a bit opaque. The main story is interesting, it raises many questions, but leaves the conclusions up to the player. There is a great number of choices to be made throughout the game and a lot of them will be addressed at the very end.There’s a lot to love about Pillars of Eternity. The way it liberates players by letting them play their own way at their own pace through the story, by letting them decide on both their motivations and actions, the interesting game world and lore, memorable characters and a very tactical combat system. By liberating themselves from existing worlds and publisher demands, Obsidian had complete control to create their best game to date and one of the best RPGs in recent years.9 OUT OF 10 (SUPERB)

Posted: April 18, 2016
												W A R N I N G This game DOES NOT include: - Quicktime events. - Climbing towers. - Poor writing. - Plastic drama. - Tacked-on multiplayer. - Social features. - Microtransactions. - Delusions of being an MMO. - Sesquipedalophobia. - Contempt for its own audience. - Scenes added for the trailer's sake. - Hollywood envy. - Obsessive excessism. - "Press X for Awesome!" - Skyrim's approach to map markers. - Ubisoft's approach to optimization. - Game-breaking DRM. - Spyware. - Malware. - Mass Effect 3's ending (or so I hope).If you're like me, that's a good thing.Pillars of Eternity is the best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ RPG I have played in years. It's atmospheric, genuine, filled with awe and constantly laying down little mysteries you just want to know the answers to.I'm yet to finish it, but after the time I've spent with it already, I'm ready to crown it, wrap it in the comfiest of blankets--like the world's softest burrito--and proceed to discharge medieval Polish poetry and foot massages until it knows how precious it is to me and how much I appreciate its stubborn refusal to treat me in the same disrespectful way most of today's entertainment products do.Good job, Obsidian, you beautiful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.10/10

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity was expressly created as an homage to the Infinity Engine games; the interface and beautiful painted backgrounds definitely make it look the part.  But what made games like Baldur’s Gate, Icewind Dale, and Planescape so special was more than just an aesthetic: they were vast, sprawling settings with epic stories that delivered engaging tactical encounters.  And when judged by those criteria, I feel that Pillars of Eternity is a worthy successor to carry on the legacy of the Infinity Engine.  Though the loss of the AD&D engine and settings does take some getting used to, the mechanics are solid and the world is compelling and fun to discover.  It’s an easy recommendation for fans of of the Infinity Engine and I’d also recommend it for anyone interested in an engrossing quest through a fantastic land.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is the much anticipated spiritual successor to the Bioware Infinity Engine RPGs many of us loved (and some still do). If you enjoyed those games, Pillars is a must buy. If you didn't, Pillars probably won't change your find and it stays pretty true to that formula. Pillars is a party based RPG with a strong sense of story. It's personalized to your character by incorporating your character's traits into conversations with NPCs - for example, your knowledge of the wilderness or a reputation of being kind may open new options. The sheer number of ways Obsidian  accomplished this was one of the highlights of the game. Of course playing out the tactical battles is another large aspect to the game. While they are well done, too many of them were easy on hard difficulty while a smaller number were challenging. The game would have benefited from a better balancing of battles to provide a more uniform challenge. Quibbles aside, I recommend Pillars for fans of this type of game. You can find my full review here.[www.oneguytoomanygames.com]

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												129 Hours Later, Finished! (Thoughts On The Game)First off a big thank you to Obsidian for such a wonderful game and second, thanks to all the kickstarter backers. I was only able to back the amount for the game (25 or 35) and I also added on the addition for the beta backer later on, so a huge thank you to the backers who put in the big money! Now onto my thoughts on the game!The things I loved:- Writing was fantastic, from the dialogue to the story to the characters, wonderful writing once again Obsidian- Art Design is so beautiful, seriously... so seriously, love it- Combat is fun, at first I wasn't to sure about it but I have grown to love it. While not 100% perfect, it is a well done combat system.- Soundtrack is fantastic, really sets the atmosphere for me as I am exploring or going along my adventures- The Stronghold is a cool idea and i like it, but it was def not perfect, alot could be added to this aspect in an expansion pack- Had zero crashes, no fps issues, no gamebreaking bugs and no broken quests.- Some of the decisions I had to make had me really thinking about it- Atmosphere is very well done- Enjoyable final fight!- The character creation and classes I feel are all well done Things I didn't like or that I think can be improved:- The Pathfinding was honestly my biggest issue. There was times when I would tell guys to go attack this game and they would either try and go the long way or try and go through another player. Some other times moving around cities one would get stuck on something. Nothing gamebreaking but this was the biggest thing that annoyed me during my time with the game.- The Stronghold could be alot better, while I enjoyed it and think its improved over Inquisition and Dragon Age Awakening, it could still use some improvements. Maybe more things to build? A type of trial aspect where you decide on issues people have? Give us more options as to what we can do with prisoners and allow more random people to come and live in your stronghold. Things That could be added for expansion pack:- A coop mode like Divinity Original Sin for an expansion pack? As much as I loved this game, I think it would be even more fun if I could play the campaign with ONE friend (as long as it didn't effect the singleplayer)- More character Portraits next time. I love that we can import our own, but in future expansion packs maybe get the artists to do a handful more with more variety for difference races,etc..Love the game! I enjoyed Divinity Original Sin, Wasteland 2 and Shadowrun Dragonfall last year but this is even better imo. So wonderful to see this revival of a genre that was my favorite for so many years. Here is to more Pillars Of Eternity, more CRPG's in general in gaming and more Obsidian magic.Someone asked me for a score, I don't usually give out scores, I prefer just writing thoughts on the game. But, I can appreciate any review score from 8 to 10. If you had a gun to my head and asked for a score though? I would say its a 9.5/10 for me personally. Not perfect but a hell of a wonderful experience! I have liked so many Black Isle and Obsidian games over the years, but you really didn't fool around with this game did you!I know there is a tank game coming from Obsidian and another unannounced game and two expansion packs for Pillars in the future, hope to see many more rpg's from Obsidian in the future, keep up the wonderful work! I have to deal with chronic pain every day so when a nice rpg like this comes around (or a good foreign movie or book/tv show,etc..) and has the ability to pull me into its world so well with and take my mind off of things it is a wonderful thing. Thank you Obsidian, I can tell this game was crafted with love!

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												When I first got the game, the starting intro was intriguing enough, but I started to get very frustrated a few hours in, so I will start with the negatives since thats what most people will experience and notice first.  In the end, I came back to it a year later, got the expansion season pass and enjoyed it, but to do so, I had to forget my hopes and expectations and approach it as a new game again.  It was easier to do this when I knew the things I hated about it and could make adjustments (not playing as a wizard for my main character, and focusing on the story vs the combat)Even though the game captures the look and feel of an infinity engine game, they chose to create a new game system instead of liscensing the D&D or some other popular system, and this was the primary source of my frustration.  In particular, the new system is very limited in the spell selection of both wis and int casters compared to the baldur's gate games.  The other thing I dislike about the new system is that rogue backstabing is nearly impossible to pull off, and even when you do, the results are underwhelming for the effort.  Part of it is that even with stealth maxed for your level, it is nearly impossible to sneak close enough to anything to do a backstab, and when you do, the multiplier is only something like 1.5 or 2x, and it is never enough to outright kill anything that is not incredibly weak compared to you.The stronghold was also a disapointment.  Obsidian did a pretty good job with the stronghold in NWN2, so I had high hopes for the implimentation in this, and they did have some interesting ideas, but they just felt rushed or unfinihsed.  Its not so much that the stronghold is bad, its just not as good as it could have been, and not as good as what they did with NWN2.Now for the good points.The story is different and interesting with a lot of twists I did not see coming.  The first part of the game is pretty slow going as you are getting acquinted with the world it is set in, but things really start to pick up once you get to the main city.  I don't want to spoil anything, so I'll just say that the story was good enough to me that it was worth getting past the negatives I listed to enjoy it. The story and quests in the expansion (Whitmarch) are also very well done, and the expansion is well worth getting if you decide to get the game.I'm gonna give it a positive rating, but for anyone who has not played the Baldur's Gate or Neverwiner Nights series, I would highly recomend any of those over this, and I would also recomend Dragon Age: Origins and Awakening over this (but skip Dragon Age 2, that game is a steaming pile of rubbish).TLDR: Great story, disapointing game mechanisms.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												A nostalgic romp in an original and engaging world. Obsidian has made good on it's promise to bring you a fantastic and unforgiving isometric RPG.If you've played games like Baldurs Gate, or Planescape: Torment, then you know what you're getting into, but for the uninitiated, this is a text heavy roleplaying game. Instead of the constant grinding of enemies to level up associated with most similar games currently on the market, your experience will largely be rewarded from exploring new areas and completing quests, of which you'll find plenty.This is not to say that the combat system was neglected, it is both engaging and relentless. You'll need to take control of your entire party (unless you choose to go solo) and plan your attacks and formations accordingly. A host of spells, abilities and talents help you maintain control of the battlefield in real time as you dispatch your foes and progress through an compelling and well written story. Definitely a contender for Game of the Year.

Posted: February 1, 2016
												Pros: + Obsidian + Going on 80 hours and just got to the 2nd act (I prefer to chew on something great rather than swallow it whole)+ Great story+ Dialogue+ Art direction+ Depth of customization (including combat options such as slowing down time for better control, auto-pausing when encountering an enemy or not auto-pausing, etc.)+ Nearly endless amounts of spells, upgrade options when levelling, and loot + Branching story and consequential decision making + Managing a stronghold provides some interesting options+ Interesting factions + Great replability + Awesome enemy variability + Enchantments are actually worth a damn+ PLENTY of stuff (quests, tasks, bounties, dungeon crawling) to do+ A sprawling mega dungeon that will make fans of good old fashioned dungeon crawling do cartwheels Neutral:+- You don't gain experience points from regular battles with enemies (as with most RPGs) but from completing quests, at first this really irked me because I'm used to gaining XP from encounters but as you play you understand why they did it. This is more a positive than negative for me, but I placed it here because I can see some people not liking this aspect of the game. Cons:- Durance's♥♥♥♥♥♥- The game has to end I honestly can't recommend this game enough, it can be daunting at first but stick with it and figure out what builds work for your playstyle and what strategies synergize and which don't. I promise you it's an incredibly rewarding experience.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Well, as it's already been stated by many, this is a revisit to Baldur's Gate (1 & 2). It doesn't have the story depth of the characters of those classics, and it doesn't quite match up to the immersion of Planescape: Torment, but when it comes to isometric cRPGs this is one that stands out. You won't have the, "Squeak SQUEAK" of the "Boo" that is Minsc's hamster or the haughty judgementalism that is Jaheira in the character interactions, and you certainly won't get the gender-changing possibilities of your companions, but . . . it's not bad for a crowd-funded game.If you're expecting that level of depth and that's what you're looking for, you're not going to find it with this game. There is, however, interaction and some degree of character growth of the NPCs that can join your party. All NPCs have personal quests - not as rewarding as BG2, for instance - but it's there.Having said that, this is an isometric cRPG that allows you to create a character of your choice and choose, at your leisure, a party of either pre-built NPCs you meet in-game or recruit and define for youself. Your party grows in strength and experience, you stylistically decide how to develop yourself and your NPCs to suit your expectations, and you go through the game playing these decisions against the battle encounters you face.And that's kind of where it breaks down. The story - the plot - is interesting, but what you will find is that you approach all conflicts and battle in pretty much the same way. "I put my 'tanks' or 'warriors' here, and everyone else destroys the enemies from afar." is not an unfair description of how most fights go. If you're in it for the story, then great - it's like playing any RPG, such a Dragon Age: Inquisition, on casual mode. If you're in it for hardcore combat challenge, then you're just going to end up with larger groups of enemies against whom you already have effective strategies and tactics to defeat.Point is, the battles get repetitive. The story is there between the battles, but the story doesn't progress without the battles. Looking back, all those years ago at Baldur's Gate and Planescape: Torment, it probably wasn't much different. But at least at that time it was novel ideas and made me a captive audience. In this re-incarnation, it's the same thing except I know what to expect, and that diminishes the overall experience.I recommend the game, however, because of the story. That is, ultimately, why we play RPGs. I want to know what happens next; I am the protagonist and get to make choices that may affect future consequences, and I have a BIG♥♥♥♥♥DAMN SWORD that can cut you in two. As a revisitation on older cRPG games, it's nothing less than awesome. Graphics are decent, soundtrack is great, voice-acting is okay - there's just enough to bring those memories back from the 90's. And since I'm sentimental, I'll run with that.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												Do you enjoy spending hours at a time working on a branching questline only for all of your actions to be rendered completely pointless? Do you like micromanaging obtuse and obsolete game mechanics? Do you want a game that throws all its potential out a window in favour of being 'safe'? Then boy do I have a game for you! Pillars of Eternity presents itself as a throwback to the classic CRPGs, like Baldur's Gate and Planescape: Torment. However, it actually comes across as a game made by people who liked those games but did not understand why they were good. Pillars throws at you the trappings of choice, of an interactive world, of interactive design, but does not actually include these in any meaningful way. As an example, let's look at character creation. You're presented with a half-dozen options for races, all with different stats and backstory, then a handful of different class options based on the traditional DnD classes (fighter, wizard, rogue, bard, etc.) and then finish up with options for personalising the character's backstory, appearance, etc. Sounds great, right? Just what you'd expect. But when you come to actually play the game, you'll find that none of it really matters. The classes really just resolve into "ranged" and "not ranged", and everything else is just fluff. Your actual playstyle will be exactly the same whether you play a big, tough warrior or a small, sneaky rogue. The character options present different possibilities for interacting with the world, but these almost never actually come up in the story. If you play as a goblin (I don't care what you actually call them, they're still goblins), the game will tell you that your race is hated and discriminated against. This came up ONCE, in the 20-odd hours I wasted on this game. In a single option, hidden behind another conversation option, while talking with a single minor character. Quests and storylines may have multiple ways of approaching them, and multiple ways of progressing, but almost all that I played ultimately had only one single outcome, which had nothing at all to do with what I did. You can spend hours at a time working carefully on choosing which faction you're going to support, choosing which quests to do for that faction, deciding how you're going to accomplish your quests from the several options presented to you, weighing the pros and cons of each possible outcome, only for all of this to be rendered pointless when the storyline progresses with absolutely no impact from you or your actions. The writers are determined to tell you their story, despite what you do, without you being involved in that story. There is no real choice, no actual 'multiple paths' as advertised, there is just "well, that's nice, now here's what is ACTUALLY going to happen." Ultimately my problem with this game is that there is no real choice in anything. It is a crude imitation of what came before, with nothing new to add or innovations to include. 20 years ago, this game would have been a brilliant new addition to the CRPG library. It would have stood up against the best of its genre. Unfortunately, it's not 20 years ago. But I don't think the developers know that.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												This is an example of a game made to 'please the fans' rather that to have something actually enjoyable.Because of the kickstarter they felt obliged to stick to an uninspired backbone that killed any possibility to create a great game by adding features organically. They rather had a list of thing they wanted to show that they had, for the fans, and rushed them into the game.You can't make a game good because on paper its features look good. A good game is something that is crafted and tested iterativelly. Here the different ideas don't hold together properly.On paper you have for example :Good graphicsLots of lore'Innovative' class and combat system'Innovative' xp system (combats give no xp)In pratice:Loading times between tiny maps are embarrassingly long. Unacceptable for a 2015 game that pretends to emulates a 2000 one.I couldn't care less about the story, the characters. As it was said everywhere else, it looks like a collection of fan fictions.Class system is dull, characters feel all the same.Combats are a joke. You can't prepare for the combat before you engage the enemy (can't use spells and so on). Enemies are overpowered and even though there are lots of different lloking enemies in the game they don't feel very different. Abilities are boring and their effects interchangeable.The xp system is an absolute joke. This game as 10 monsters per square meter and combats give absolutely no xp ??!!Basically the entire game feels like a ripoff (I have barelly played it but I can imagine it is consistent trough the entire game). Is it supposed to be more realistic? So gaining levels and improving your combat skill by doing stupid quests is more realistic than doing so by winning fights? I will rephrase it : The entire purpose of experience points in this game is to improve combat related skills, but then combats give no experience? This game drifts too far away from what normally makes a good game.  That idea of having to go back to town almost every fights because you need to sleep to regain your spells... In baldur's gate it was ok because you could outsmart/outpower your enemies with well thought tactics and items, but this game suffers from the tall poppy syndrome and there isn't much you can do to feel clever/good. You feel like you're playing the same way everyone is playing, like on a rail.Apparently helmets in this game are purely decorative, give no stats. You can have an iron helm or a simple hat on your magician, it makes no difference. Is it for more realism, like the xp system?In this game everything feels so generic, watered down. What a waste of crowdfunding money! They could have just copied baldur's gates mechanics with better graphics and made an awesome game but no, they had to 'dust it off'.What worries me the most about this game is all the positive critiques it managed to get. It is neither an old school game nor a modern one, so what is it? What do people find in it ?

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												I backed this game on Kickstarter, despite never having played Baldur's Gate or any of the other predecessors this draws on. I thought the concept was interesting and I knew I liked Obsidian's work in the past, so I took a chance on it, and it paid off!First the niggles, because this game still suffers from a lot of the same problems most other RPGs do. You inevitably accumulate piles and piles of garbage loot for no apparent purpose other than to sell it, which requires you to individually select every item you want to sell. You get quests like "Find a druid who knows about this thing" but you can't actually ask anybody "Hey, any idea where I might find a druid who knows about this thing?" so you have to ask every single person you meet until you find the right one. And... well, really, those are the only complaints I have - ridiculous loot bloat, and quests that rely on brute-forcing through dialog options to find what you're looking for (which may tempt you to just check out the wiki). These are pretty common RPG problems, though, nothing Pillars is any more guilty of than its competitors.What Pillars of Eternity does have is really interesting worldbuilding, for one. The way souls are woven into the fabric of the world's magic and science is really interesting, and presents a lot of unexpected parallels to real life. The game's take on gods and religion is interesting too, and there's a great sense of local history and politics in the story. The only shame is that despite presenting the player with a wide-ranging, complicated controversy around the subject of animancy, that controversy ends up fading into a secondary plotline. Really, the world is crying out for a sequel that especially delves deeper into the politics and culture of animancy. The rest of the writing is also great, though the voice acting can sometimes sound like the actors thought what they were saying was kind of ridiculous (which it sometimes is).The gameplay is also pretty fun, with a fairly broad variety of spells and abilities, and so many class/race/weapon/skill/talent combos that I frankly got a little overwhelmed at all the possible ways I could develop my character. But hey, as far as I'm concerned character development is a key part of RPGs, so the more choice, the better. I played on an easier setting, because I have a job and a life and don't have time to bang my head against a wall, and while the easy settings felt perfectly fun and balanced during the first half of the game, I eventually over-levelled compared to the enemies to the point where I wiped the floor with them on autofight, and made the mistake of choosing to stay at the easy difficult when prompted (you get prompts when you start The White March, Act III, and Act IV if you're too high level, and can choose to scale up the difficulty for sport). This is really just my bad, though; if you are playing on Story or Easy, I recommend increasing the difficulty when you're given the option to do so later on in the campaign.I played with The White March, which is also excellent, but a word or warning - I think that the best narrative effect comes form playing Part I of the White March and then running around in the main game again for a bit before returning to Part II. I'm not sure if this is possible if you have both of them installed, but the way the White March II starts makes the most sense emotionally and narratively if you've been away from Part I for a bit.Overall, this was a really fun RPG with very interesting lore and characters and fun gameplay, even if it doesn't dodge some of my personal RPG pet peeves. Give it a shot!

Its not fun when your barbarian at level 10 has 3 skills one of them is a toggle passive basically and you miss every 2 attacks. There is a terrible loot system which feels as lifeless as the game also. I seriously would pick up Divinity Original Sin instead, of course its personal taste but I wasnt even going to review this game until Divinity made me see how lifeless Pillars is. I didn't play baldurs gate much when I was younger so maybe its the lack of rose tinted glasses that makes me unable to get through the first few parts of the game without making a new character.

												An excellent spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale, while having a unique world to explore with its own mechanics and a richly imagined lore. The character customization is deep and varied, the character progression well balanced and the main story is interesting, if coming across a bit short. I played almost 180 hours of this game, restarting several times before finding a character combination of race and  class that worked with my playing style. (in the end, I settled for rogue to get the extra experience for unlocking containers and disarming traps early in the game)I've finshed the game and am already chomping at the bit to have another go at it. Can't say enough good things about the execution of this classic style CRPG.

												Thought I’d finally do a short update to my review now that I have actually played through the game, took me a long time to get into it (you should hopefully be able to infer from the text below why).Too long; didn’t write hur hur, self awareness  – Pillars of Eternity, from a story perspective, is a fantastic fantasy (borderline science fantasy) cRPG that is held back by issues with the narrative design and thick, purple prose ridden writing (!!!) as well as the ambition and the scale of the project (the story would have been much more impactful on the ‘surface level’ if this were the 2nd or 3rd game of a series). If players push on in spite of these issues, it ultimately does tell a very unique story that can be critically analysed and likewise handles some unique themes with a lot of nuance.

number of helpful: 16 of 23 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
Product received for free
												*Review of original initial release only. Does not account for changes via DLC or subsequent patches.*Pillars of Eternity is a triumph.You start the game as just another traveller looking for a fresh start in a new land, flavoured by the choices you made during character creation. A LOT of terrible things happen and before long you are caught up in world where souls are endlessly reincarnated and the natural balance has been shattered. Some individuals can even see and manipulate souls. A lot of the strife, mystery and wonder in this game ties directly back to souls in some way, shape, or form.Your attributes, talents and choices also ripple out into the greater world. It is not possible to be on everyone’s good side. Treat one group well and another group may become hostile to you for helping their enemies. NPC’s and main characters will react to your race, class, nationality and affiliations. Conversations are influenced by a number of factors, providing you with a number of different conversation options. All of which ties to a reputation system. This helps the world feel much more grey, with right and wrong being a matter of perspective.The visuals are gorgeous if you have an appreciation for the style being used, even if the world could use a bit more colour in places. PoE does not have traditional cinematics. Instead players are given interactive text adventures with illustrations and sound effects that are directly informed by your stats and choices. The writing is almost always exceptional. Far, far above the usual flavour text that wraps around typical binary conversations in other games. The text based dialogue and the voice acting are really great. You might not hear as much banter as you will in other games but what is there is entertaining and sometimes surprising. The 8 official companions all bring something unique to the table.Character creation is one of my favourite parts of RPG’s. PoE is a wonderland in this respect. There are a lot of stats and mechanics to wrap your head around. You absolutely can build a viable character just following the on-screen tips and jumping into a game. The thing is, you won’t know WHY you are making those suggested choices. You’ll have descriptions to read sure, but you just won’t have an appreciation for the nuances of PoE‘s rule-set without experimentation. The game is setup in such a way that anyone can make a safe, viable character following the on-screen suggestions. Failure to Min/Max every damn stat won’t cripple you. Which is not to say you could not create a broken character, just that you’d have to travel pretty far off the beaten path to do it. By the same extent it is possible to break out “the maths” and attempt to make the most deadly backstabbing Orlan Rogue this side of Gilded Vale.You have lots of choices when it comes to creating your character and they all come with some kind of stat. There are 6 races, 15 sub-races and 11 classes. Some of the races are fantasy stalwarts that have been given a PoE spin like Humans, Dwarves and Elves. Others are a bit more unique.Combat in PoE is almost always a white knuckle affair. Fights happens in real time but you can pause and issue commands. As a bonus, you can also slow down or speed up time at the press of a button, allowing you that extra time to react to subtle changes on the battlefield or cross a big map as quickly as possible. During combat you have to keep in mind both your Endurance and your Health. Endurance represents how much of a beating your character can take before being knocked unconscious. You can replenish Endurance with items, abilities and spells. While most damage affects Endurance you will also lose Health during combat. Lose all your health and you’ll be maimed. Get hit again and you are dead. Companions can die for good. You can’t replenish Health or remove maimed status without resting at either a camp or an inn.Party composition, formation, location and more all have major effects on combat. You have to play smart, not just bold. Your party is incredibly powerful so long as you make your choices with care. The enemies in PoE are super aggressive, varied and absolutely ruthless when it comes to hammering weakness. One of the ways PoE is different from other RPG’s is that the restrictions on equipment have been relaxed, meaning your casters can wear heavy armour and wield great swords if you want them too. There are considerations when it comes to armour of course, but it is nice that your casters and such don’t have to be so squishy.PoE is not a game about grinding. Generally when you clear an area or map it stays cleared. Instead the game rewards players for exploration, discovery, completing quests and making choices. Whether you plan on fighting or sneaking your way through you are always going to have to be on your toes. You can’t just roll over anything you encounter. Some enemies will be too tough to beat. Some areas will be inaccessible without the right gear. You’ll have way more active quests and tasks than you can immediately complete. This means you need to make hard choices and return to questlines and areas when you are better equipped to tackle them.Besides the standard questing and combat (and a million other little things to be honest), PoE has two big features I love. The first of which is your Stronghold Caed Nua. Once you’re done battling through the Stronghold proper it becomes your base of operations. You’ll repair its buildings, shore up its defences, man it with soldiers, send companions out on quests and more from within its walls. You can even manage it while you are away. In some aspects it may seem a bit dry, but there is enough incentive there to keep making progress. Sometimes your Stronghold will come under attack. Other times you’ll take someone captive and hold them in your dungeons until somebody begs for their release. Even though the game has 8 official companions, you can recruit your own custom made adventurers any time you want as long as you have the cash. Since you can only have 5 companions in your party at a time, when your companions are not traveling with you they can be running quests from the Stronghold for a variety of rewards.The other unique feature I love is The Endless Paths, which is a sprawling mega dungeon underneath your Stronghold. It’s almost like a game within a game. You’ll encounter all sorts of monsters, heroes and quests as you fight your way deeper and deeper. The whole time you are rebuilding the Stronghold in the back of your mind you worry about The Master Below.Playing on Normal will provide a serious challenge. You WILL die many, many times. Hard mode is just that; HARD. Playing on Path of the Damned difficulty is pure masochism. Players can even take it a step further by turning on Expert Mode which completely removes all hints and suggestions from the game. If you are feeling truly crazy you can even try playing the game with Trials of Iron turned on which gives you just one save and one life. If you die, that’s it.The game also comes with some more subtle touches that have a big effect on the game. For one, you’ll never run out of storage space when you are out questing. Each of your companions can hold 16 items in their inventory, but everyone always has access to your party Stash, which as far as I can tell is bottomless. The UI is clean, practical and easy to use. The game allows you to control font size and includes a colour-blind mode.As far as bugs and glitches go I’ve encountered very few. The game never crashed on me once. I had to reload a save once to get a quest to trigger and I encountered text wrapping around improperly during a conversation with a random NPC. That’s it.*This review is heavily trimmed due to the limit Steam places on the length of reviews. Check out my profile for a link to the website I write for to see the full review.*

content:
Posted: April 12
												If you are looking for a RPG in the same style as the classics, look no further. This game brings back memories of Baldurs Gate and Icewind Dale, and it definitely delivers the same high level of quality and immersion as those games. The setting is well designed, and you have a lot of lore to dig into if that is your thing. At no point does the game force you to do so, so you have a lot of freedom. The stories are good, and you are rewarded mostly from completing quests as opposed to hacking and slahing your way through the game. This enables you to better roleplay your character, as opposed to having to slay mobs for XP, which can sometimes be a problem in RPGs. Expect to invest a lot of hours into this game if you plan to complete it. This can be good or bad I guess, depending on what you are looking for. The main plot can be completed in about 50 hours, but to get the full experience, it is recommended to study a bit away from the game - what does each stat do (there is a lot of them), what about conditions, class mechanics, spells and so on. It is quite detailed and rich. There's some problems with the game you should be aware of: - Tanky characters often fail to hold aggro- The ending seems a bit rushed compared to the rest of the game- The main plot becomes increasingly predictable- It is difficult to build a proper healer, so you rely a lot on potionsTHese points are minor, and might be due to me misunderstadning mechanics, and it also comes down to personal preference. I have played a lot of RPGs, so it takes a lot to surprise me with a story these days - hence storylines becomes predictable. If this is one of your first RPGs, expect a great story! Overall, I would highly recommend this game, if you enjoy games that encourage you to learn more, and if you enjoy the style of the classic RPGs, as it brings out a lot of nostalgia.

content:
Posted: January 24
												First off, I really like this game. I've completed both expansions and it's definitely grown on me over time. My first playthrough was as a death godlike cipher, which I didn't find nearly as fun as as an orlan wizard. In my first playthrough I made the mistake of not having high enough perception and resolve (which you need for speech checks). As my wizard, I rectified that issue and dialogue became more enjoyable. What I liked about the game:It's text heavy with interesting lore and world, some interesting characters, good dialogue, and a decent plot (not groundbreaking, but it's good). There are a variety of races to choose from, some of which are unique to the world and have different sub-types. You can also choose a culture in addition to race, which affects stats, and to a lesser degree, dialogue options. There are also quite a few classes, one of which is unique to the game. Classes and background (philosopher, slave, etc) also affect dialogue options to a small degree. All of these options make character building quite fun and interesting. The combat can be fun if you aren't constantly getting swarmed with enemiesThere are a lot of spells and abilities, some of which are pretty fun to use Can level up abilities in Lore, Athletics, Survival, and Mechanics (lockpicking) which affect dialogue options and how you interact with the world A lot of playtime (around 70 hours without expansions)There's a fast mode (press D), if you want to traverse areas fasterThe environments are beautifulYou acquire real estate early in the gameWhat I didn't like:Too many spells, a good chunk which aren't worth usingThe load times are quite long, even if you are just entering a house. This makes exploring cities tedious.Too many enemies, especially at higher difficulties. Too much combat in general - there are diplomatic options, but not as much as, say, Planescape: Torment. This game is more like Icewind Dale with all the combat. You have to camp or rest at an inn in order to regain healthThere's a few tedious as ♥♥♥♥ dungeons. However, at least they're optionalAll of the inns have the same musicYou can only use so many spells before you have to restEndurance/Health relationship might take a bit to figure out Companions don't take much convincing to follow you to uncertain death. Companions make more sense in Planescape: Torment and Tyranny, where companions most are manipulated or conscripted. I know it seems like there are a lot of cons, but these are only the things that bothered me (and I'm a bit cynical) - they probably won't bother others, except for the load times. Everything considered, it's a great relaxing game to get immersed in, and it's definitely worth playing, especially if you've got time to kill.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												Let me begin this by saying I really wanted to like this game. I desperately wanted to. I tried in as many different ways as I could to convince myself that I just wasn't seeing Pillars from the right angle, that if I tried one more time I could get into it, but in the end I had to admit the truth to myself. Pillars of Eternity is garbage. This game falls flat on its face when it comes to important elements that make a great role-playing game. The first is the terrible cast of characters. In a game that revolves around a party of companions, they design an extremely limited (what, six, maybe seven total?) and bland cast of joinable NPCs that would never, ever travel together if you were looking at this from a story perspective. That might be forgivable if they were interesting with their own romances and side quests and intricate backstories, but they're not. The game designers seem to attempt an apology for this by shoehorning in some mechanic to design your own party of characters from the tavern, but for me that's just as half♥♥♥♥♥as apologizing for the terrible magic weapons they designed by letting you enchant your own gear.The second is clearly the combat. From the basic system to the character classes to the way enemies behaved and battles generally went, it's a big gigantic mess that is not intuitive or fun to play. The basic concept of Pillars combat mechanics are confusing and annoying. Items you find are woefully inferior to the bland generic items you can enchant, and the way stats interact with your class is unbalanced and at times extremely confusing (physical strength dictates the damage wizards do with their spells -- WHAT?). Many enemies are given stunlock abilities or endlessly heal each other (such as the Paladins in Raedrics Keep), and all are automatically designed to rush your weakest characters. There's no real way to stop this, short of sending your fragile characters away from the fight at maximum range, but as soon as they move in to do anything to help, they will get rushed and die. The worst part is that after you finish that tough-as-nails epic fight, you realize you're not a damn step closer to the next level for it because of a pretentious XP system that only rewards quest completion and not body count of defeated foes.Third is the lack of immersion or replayability. The game makes a big deal about character race, background, culture and all that, but ultimately those choices have no impact on the actual events of the story. The 'reputation' system they tried to implement is confusing and poorly designed, so that by the time you finish the game, you will have a car crash of many different reputation types. This is made even worse when certain classes (Priest and Paladin) have class abilities whose strength depend on this broken reputation system. Quest lines allow the illusion of choice at some points, but the result is the same regardless of what you do.Fourth, and finally, is the story. It's not interesting. The main character can talk to dead people, and some Big Bad Evil Guy in a mask is stealing souls for some unknown, shallow and ultimately pointless purpose. The hook for even placing you where the events of the game take place is immediately revoked a couple hours in after Raedric decides to yank his offer, leaving you as some wandering nobody with no purpose other than to chase down why you have funny voices in your head. Being a Watcher is supposed to be this super-rare unique Kewl D00d power, but the most reaction I ever got out of anyone amounted to: 'You're a Watcher? Huh. That's funny.' As plot devices go it's really weak and I found myself struggling to give a single damn about magic rocks coming out of the ground, hooded people performing nefarious rituals, or my character's involvement in the whole mess at all.The fact that this game has gorgeous aesthetic and production value makes all of this worse. With such crucial design flaws, this is literally the RPG equivalent of a hot girl that won't put out. She'll tease you, but in the end you'll walk away with nothing but blue balls, resorting to your only option of finding some relief by drunk dialing your ex.That's it. Pillars of Eternity is a hot girl that doesn't put out. End of review.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Really liked the tactical combat in this game. Primarily emphasizes preparation, using narrow doorways to your advantage, and generally positioning your folks properly. This leads to delightfully varied and challenging encounters. Do note, however, that micromanagement is also an important part of combat (they even tell you that when you're choosing a difficulty level), so if you don't like that sorta stuff, this game might not be your cup of tea. When it comes to story and such, I almost don't know where to begin. The world in this game is really creative and unique (just the fact that it's more of a fantasy version of the Age of Discovery rather than medieval Europe is refreshing), your companions are all interesting characters (really felt like I was friends with most of them, rather than being their leader), and since it's an Obsidian game, there are some really delicious philosophical ponderings here and there. Special mention goes to all the different dialogue choices you can make, though. Instead of just being different solutions to quests and such, there are also plenty of options that exist solely for the sake of roleplaying, to further flesh out your character's motivations and so on. That's really neat.If there's one major gripe I have with this game, though, it's that pathfinding can be really rubbish sometimes. Seeing folks politely waiting behind their allies because they don't realise they could go around that guy in order to bludgeon someone is something that happens too often.Oh yeah, and you can get at least three cats and a piglet in this game (but you can't give them little hats or armors, which I hope will be remedied in a future expansion).

												9/10 +1 if you are looking for a game to scratch the BG2 itch. -1 if you don't like old school games.This is the best isometric cprg since BG2. It out does other recent "old school" rpgs on many fronts. PROS: Story, character creator, interface, tactical combat, inventory management, and rpg aspects are all very well done.   There is a lot of content here.CONS: Bugs in the initial release, poor path finding, long load times(in  a 2d game.  Why?), and some of the encounters feel like filler.  Note to designers: every step of every map doesn't need to be filled with hostile creatures. Also, no repsec options in a long game with several skill options as you level may be off putting to some.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												Having thrown myself against this game twice now I think it's safe to say it is not my cup of tea and while it is incredibly gauche to make comparisons, the most glaring flaw is that Pillars of Eternity isn't Baldur's Gate. Or even Neverwinter Nights for that matter.The "D&D but not" RPG system just feels so incredibly awkward in every single facet: the attributes are all jumbled up and different, there are a plethora of status effects that overlap but are often ineffectual and the spells/abilities are familiar but slightly shifted in some manner. The endurance/health system is garbage and seems to exist solely to justify enemies doing absurd damage because technically you have health that you can heal into. Just let them have 400 health and having healing act normally, there's nothing unique or useful about the endurance system.It's unfortunate that the gameplay and combat are so god awful because the worldbuilding and side characters are at least intriguing. The story isn't anything new but it's serviceable and works for the intention of establishing a new IP.If they didn't try so hard to make an alternate gaming system this could have been a decent game.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												I'd have loved to love this game. From the outside it looks just like I'd want a modern successor to the Baldur's Gate and the Planescape stlye of RPG to look. And indeed it's gorgeous. It looks and sounds just right. But I just can't seem to be able to play it right. I simply keep getting killed. On the easiest settings. Repeatedly. I can't make heads nor tails of the spells (most of them seem to buff some ability I've never read of by 0.5%) nor of the combat system in general. Which is a pity cause everything looks so great. But now, almost 10 hours into the game I don't think I've progressed further than discovering the first hints of what the plot would have been about. I mean, I can live with a low power level. But I'd far prefer my wizard to have a magic missile and my cleric to have a simple healing spell instead of just some obscure buffs or offensive debuffs. In my days the only buff we had was the Bless spell (and, seriously, who ever really used that one?)...I'll be deinstalling the game to free up HD space again, but I feel sorry that I'm missing out on what appears to be a great game for others. But it's just too complicated for me. And I *did* finish Planescape. Thrice.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Most of the people I know who play CRPGs consider the Infinity Engine games like Baldur's Gate I & II, Icewind Dale, Planescape Torment, Fallout 1 & 2 (although they were not IE) to be the "Golden Age" of RPGs. It's been sort of downhill since. Oblivion & Skyrim were beautiful but sort of empty and in my opinion unplayable without mods. And many of the RPGs of the last 10 years forgot the RP part. Yes I'm talking about you Fallout 3, Dungeon Siege, etc.Well, RPG fans, if you loved and missed Baldur's Gate & Icewind Dale, you will LOVE Pillars of Eternity. It is everything that was good about them come again with a modern look and feel. The level of detail, atmosphere, design craft, and forethought that went into this game is amazing. It is beautiful to look at, interesting to play with compelling characters and deep dialouge trees that really let you role play and tease the details of the story out.The game play is not perfect. And for those not used to the IE style of play might have some trouble getting used to it at first, but you will quickly master it. This is not Dragon Age, they won't ram the plot down your throat you have to work for it. Talk to people. It is not an Elder Scrolls game with unlimited exploration over a world that turns out to be sort of empty and after a while all looks the same. Each area in PoE is smaller but alive with activity. Give this a try. If you've never played the old IE games after this you'll want to. If you have and loved them, this is the game you have been waiting for for years.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Pillars of Eternity is the type of RPG that can keep you on the character creation screen for hours. The moment to moment gameplay of Pillars is unlikely to surprise you if you've been following the revival of the CRPG genre through Kickstarter. You'll go on quests and slay dragons, and once your potentially 100 hour journey is complete you'll have read a couple novel's worth of text. Unfortunately the text is the superior half of the game; although some small improvements have been made to the CRPG formula a lot of its systems feel like they come right out of 1999.  Micromanagement is the name of the game here. Each member of your 6 person party can come equipped with what feels like dozens of spells. Every encounter is a test of both skill and patience if you plan on using your party members effectively. The game features a pause button for those who want to make the most out of all of their fighters, but I found this to chop up the combat and turn fights into a chore. I struggle to find a reason why the game uses real time combat at all, a turn based system like the one found in Pillars' Kickstarted cousin, Divinity: Original Sin, would feel more apt here. If you're like me you'll opt to push the difficulty down to "Story Time" in order to breeze through combat and allow yourself to experience everything else the game has to offer.The combat system in place doesn't use Dungeons and Dragon's ruleset, but that was near impossible to tell as an outsider. Characters hitting and missing are determined by dice rolls that are weighed by their statistics. If you love deciding whether you want the chest piece with 12 Resolve but lower Athleticism then you'll love min-maxing all of your character's loadouts, but I found the games ruleset to be a bit complex for my tastes. I much prefer when I have a great amount of choice in how I want my characters to perform not through small stat changes, but through large easy to comprehend choices; something akin to World of Warcraft's post 2010 talent system.Spells are handled on a "per rest" and "per encounter" system, where more powerful spells can only be used a limited amount of times until you get your characters back to an inn or campfire. Weaker spell are limited by how many times you can cast them in a given fight. Though this system will likely appeal to those who want to map out their descent into a dungeon, I found it really constricting and made me reluctant to use any of my character's cool abilities at all.Though my piece on the game doesn't look like a glowing recommendation so far, it was actually one of my favorite games of 2015. Though the clunky combat and complicated rules were large gripes of mine, that's where most of my issues with the game end. Pillars succeeds tremendously in nearly every other aspect, most importantly is how much it allowed for players to role play. Player agency in all aspects of the game was clearly a huge design philosophy for Obsidian, it's apparent from the moment you make your character. Your character's race, class, and background will influence the way other characters interact with you as well as opening up new dialogue options. Although all of this seems par the course, it's the superb writing that brings the role playing to life.Regardless of how you allocate your stat points, your character will be a Watcher: a person who can look into the soul of others. Though this gift starts as but a faint whisper, you will eventually be able to read the intentions of others that you talk to as well as manipulate their soul. Souls end up being a driving force of the plot of the game as well. You will hear from many a townsfolk about "Waidwen's Legacy", a supposed curse that prevents newborn children from being born with souls and are instead born as hollow shells. The matter of souls also ties into the games many religious themes. The in-game deities play a large role in the game's world and you'll find yourself opening your codex to refresh yourself on them many times. Understanding each of the provinces' deities as well as the gods of your followers is important to understanding the plot as well as the world's history. Religious themes in art can occasionally turn off people but the game's messages about religion are handled with grace and don't come off as overly preachy.The characters you'll meet on your adventure are layered and complicated, specifically your party members. Out of the eight total companions  in the base game I only found one to be boring, but even as the weakest of the bunch she's more compelling than most characters in other big budget role playing games. Each companion has their own personal quest that could have been a game of its own. You'll definitely want to pursue these quests as they contain a bulk of the characterization in the game, which is arguably the titles' strongest point. I found most of the quests to be an emotional roller coaster, some ending in tremendous highs and others ending in crushing lows. What's important to note about these mini stories is your ability to steer them. Your action, or sometimes inaction, will change the way that these plots unfold. After I finished my first playthrough of the game I was anxious to start all over and play in a whole new way.Occasionally the game will break away into "choose your own adventure book" style sequences. These sequences will require you to choose actions, frequently based on the type of character you play, in order to push the scene forward. Sometimes they are short scenes that have you jumping over a large gap, or longer sequences that require multiple inputs such as climbing a cliff while being pursued by enemies. These sequences were a great addition to the game that helped break up the standard action, I only wish there were more of them.The game isn't only combat and dialogue however, you'll obviously also spend a lot of time exploring the games rich and detailed world. The game doesn't take place in one large open world but rather in a bunch of smaller zones connected by load screens. Each self contained zone is dense with people, both friend and foe, that you can interact with. One zone in particular that you'll stumble across early on is your stronghold. The stronghold is a base-building side quest you can do for some small bonuses. The lore of the stronghold was compelling as you learn more about its previous owner and delve deeper into the labyrinth that exists underneath it, but unfortunately the same can't be said for the gameplay. It's a Farmville style upgrading system where you pump resources into your base and wait in-game days for the next upgrade to be pursued. Thankfully the bonuses you get from doing the stronghold are minor, so it can easily be ignored while you pursue other quests.The visual and sound design are magnificent. Hand painted backgrounds are a joy to walk through and the music feels like it would be right at home as the background to Lord of the Rings. Unfortunately, character models clash with the rest of the games aesthetic and appear far older than the world their contained in.Despite my qualms with its clunky combat, Pillars of Eternity was an amazing role playing experience with a fantastic world and equally fantastic characters. It's an easy recommendation to anyone who enjoys the CRPG style of game. The future is bright for Obsidian's own IP and I can't wait to see what they have in store for us next.
