number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												Pillars of Eternity is, in my opinion, one of the best RPGs to ever hit the market. The stories are excellent, the environments are beautiful, the music is superb, the effects are gorgeous without being overpowering, the combat system feels natural, the spells and abilities are very easy to understand, and it all works together to bring to life a world of magic, mystery, danger, intrigue, and adventure.One of the things that really struck me was the fact that this game, while definitely appropriate for kids (tweens and teenagers), is so obviously geared toward adults. There's some mature content, but it's not over the top or "in your face", it's just the right amount of serious for more mature gamers to enjoy things without feeling like they're taking part in some guilty pleasure.  I am also really impressed with the sheer amount of writing involved in this game. There are storybooks, history books, reference books, journals, and diaries, not to mention the scripted interactions, companion banter, and the unique stories of characters with certain gold nameplates which adds to bringing the world to life.Another thing that I really like is the use of links in the UI. Certain keywords appear similarly to URL tags in web pages, you mouse over those words and you get a tooltip explaining what that word means in context. This makes understanding spells and abilities very easy which makes enjoying the game very accessible to those who are probably not as familiar as some of us when it comes to fantasy RPGs. Kudos to the team at Obsidian for catering to more than hard-core RPG fans.The last thing I'll talk about is the Linux support: It's excellent! After Divinity: Original Sin I felt really disappointed in how Linux support was handled (it came over a year later and only in the "Enhanced Edition") and didn't have high hopes for yet another game funded by Kickstarter burning me and other Linux users. I was very happy to be proven wrong by Obsidian, to say the least. I didn't have to do anything special to get the game to run, didn't need to avoid certain graphics settings, none of that. The game just works.I highly recommend this game to anyone who's even the least bit curious about fantasy RPGs and especially to those who are fans of the Baldur's Gate series. If you're a beginner with these types of games, Obsidian's development team thought about you and included a "Story Time" difficulty so that you can focus more on the story and less on being punished in combat. There's no excuse, the game isn't "too hard" and all of the barriers to understanding how things work in previous games have been considered and fixed in Pillars of Eternity. Enjoy!

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Well, hello...I grew up playing BioWare's fantastic RPG titles... Baldur's Gate was my favourite game for a very long time.--- Might contain mild spoilers ---Now, for Pillars of Eternity... It is a nice game with quite a few problems, so I'll try to summarize my whole experience...When I started playing it, aside from strong feeling of nostalgia I was stunned by beautiful background graphics (characters are pretty low quality for today's standards, but they do the job)... Interface design is also fantastic...Anyway, I was immersed in game, story was interesting, depressive town of Gilded Vale was... well, depressing, and I really felt that... I started doing all the quests (as I normally do), and enjoyed it...That changed, and after some time the whole game became a kind of chore... I wasn't as immersed as at the beginning, I stopped caring for characters... i.e. I really cared of Calisca and her sister and I generally liked stories of characters in Gilded Vale... After that, I didn't feel that vibe... I probably don't have enough time (as I had 10-15 years ago) to be immersed in the game for that long, but I played Witcher 3 for about 120 hours, and enjoyed every second of it...Od Nua is interesting idea, but I didn't find it to be very important... Endless Paths are just to Hack-n-Slashy for this type of game (and combat), I didn't like it... And that is another problem of this game; It is full of uninteresting and unimportant combat. Some encounters are very easy, and have no point both storywise and for gameplay, but are there to build up playing hours, and then some of them are so hard that it is impossible to complete them (ie when you enter the last fight location, you won't be able to go back and build up your levels, and the last combat is really, really hard... it's ridiculous).Talking about combat, I didn't find special abilities to be special at all... Aside from healing and summoning spells... Damage spells are ok, but you can't use them too often...I really liked other adventurers, and their personalities... Side quests are hit and miss... The main quest starts really strong, but ends up being... well, not as good as the beginning..."Reading" souls can be frustrating from time to time... It is often written in some kind of riddles or in strange sentences, that I needed a lot of effort to understand them... Or I just don't have as much patience... It has it's strengths; it shows that it is not so easy to read souls, and shows the chaos that is building up in his head, but it was just too hard, sometimes... Of course, for native English speaker, this is probably not a problem...Another problem is tied to travel times... Not so important, generally, but it really damage up immersion... When travelling from location to location that are one next to the other you'll need i.e. 4 (or more) hours... That is not a problem as it is (those to locations might be that far away)... But then, in one instance, you'll actually enter underground tunnel in one location and exit it in another... In about 2 minutes, when not fighting... As I said, not so important, but hurts the immersion...When I speak about locations, it is hard not to talk about loading screens that take too much time... Every little house that you want to enter in game, will take tenish seconds of your time to load... And for you to realise there is nothing in there... And now back, loading the location where you are...------------------------------------------Verdict:Although I wrote many problems about Pillars of Eternity, I think it is a nice game... A lot of these problems that I have now are probably tied to my subjective opinion, and the fact that I don't have as much time as I had when I played Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, etc... Then, again, I liked some parts, mostly because of nostalgia, but we're all very subjective xDAnyway, my final rating would be... 6.5/10

												Pillars of Eternity is a solid CRPG with a lot going for it. It doesnt exactly bring much new to the table, but that isnt a bad thing. content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												As a backer, I really believed in this game, but mayeb that's why I am so disappointed!There are other reviews that describe the problems in detail, but here are some things that are pretty bad:- the abilities/skills of the characters are not distinct enough; it also doesn't really matter what you equip them with- the game is unbalanced, with fights that are way too difficult on normal popping up without warning- the loot is not worth the effort, usually- the reputation system is illogical- you have to sneak ALL the time- most spells can hurt your characters too, so your wizard has to be in the front line- your character is generic, regardless of how you build him/her, and there is no feeling of relationships with the rest of the partyThere's more. These are all problems with the design, so not fixable.There are strange bugs during combat:- party members forget that they are fighting and just hang around after you use one of their abilities. This happens sometimes, so you never know if you need to manage them or not.- abilities don't work as advertised, e.g. the fighters ability that lets him engage 3 enemies sometimes just doesn't register and he is flanked even with just 2.I am not sure if I wil continue playng - it's become quite boring.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												I was sceptical at first to this game, despite having played (and adored) Baldur's Gate. I thought I wouldn't be able to enjoy an old school RPG like this in these times where the RPG genre looks quite different. I was so wrong.+The story is engaging and very fulfilling. It made it close to impossible to stop playing.+Side questing is as epic as side questing comes. No rats in the cellar, no collecting bear asses.+Combat is fun, and difficult. Fights can be extremely tough, which makes it all the more sweeter when you manage to take an enemy down.+Graphics are gorgeous and very reminiscent of old Baldur's Gate games.+Atmosphere! Little notes you find can tell you an entire story if you read them.-A few bugs here and there. Make sure to save often.-There is an inconsistency in conversations when it comes to voice acting. Some conversations have lines that are voiced, and then the next paragraph isn't.I actually have a hard times coming up with cons to this game. If you are at all interested in immersive RPG games and lore, this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game, and initially, I did.  I liked the atmosphere it created, especially in the first town (ooh, dark and edgy) and creating my character was interesting and full of possibilities.  But one thing brought it all down for me:  Combat.  I look forward to combat in RPGs and in this game I did not like it at all.  Once the honeymoon of the campaign setting wore off, I kept playing, hoping the sum of its parts would overcome my distaste for the combat.  Sadly, this did not happen for me.Despite how I carefully crafted my characters and selected their spells & abilities, I was not at liberty to use them in everyday encounters... which is where I spent most of my combat time (lots of small encounters).  So I ended up basic attacking (which is boring) through every fight I could, being afraid to expend "real" power.  I had a lot of trouble positioning my attacks and abilities.  It made me yearn for proper turn-based combat.  I would carefully indicate what I wanted to happen, but once I unpaused the game my attacks would fire in the wrong place or not as quickly as I had hoped.  The result is that many of my useful abilities "on paper" were not easy to use at all. Nevertheless, I liked the music, the story was moderately compelling, and the NPCs were interesting enough... so I pressed on until I had liberated my stronghold, thinking finally, this will tip the balance: I love having a base I get to improve.  And yet, it was not enough.  I still needed to do a lot of combat to make progress, and through clearing the rest of my stronghold I realized I couldn't take the combat anymore.  It's too imprecise compared to true turn-based combat, and rationing my neat abilities may have added to the challenge but it took away what fun was left for me.  If I could have turned on a mode to allow resting and remove resource management, I might have kept playing for the story and the characters (basically trivializing combat, but hey, I didn’t' like it anyway, may as well go for broke).That said, I hope you enjoy the game if you buy it.  It has a lot to like, and just because it wasn't for me doesn't mean it's not for you.  Unfortunately for me, combat is my thing, and this type of combat is not.  :)PS - Why did I have to stealth my entire party to search a room?  I felt like an idiot stealthing in front of people so I could "search" their room.  I think search and stealth should be separate actions.  That was my only nitpick worth mentioning, though, which is a good thing.Edit: Typos fixed.Edit 2: Well what do you know, it's not just me.  ;)   http://www.pcgamer.com/why-i-hate-pausable-real-time-rpg-combat

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												Having only heard about this game on the day of it's release, my curiosity got the better of me and I couldn't hold out more than 24 hours before I bought it. I would say the best way to go into this game is to go completely blind, knowing nothing, just the assurance that is is a fantastic game (exactly as I did, no regrets). The writing and story in this game is unparalled, in plenty of games where I am never too interested in the story and am skipping over all the text, I actually feel compelled to read every little tidbit about the lore and history of the world, as it really draws me in. I may only have 6 hours in the game so far, but that is really a testament as to how deep this game draws you in!Made by Obsidian (Fallout NV, KoTor, among others) on kickstarter (perhaps why I had never heard of this game until now), it is a well thought out, sometimes complex (but not overwhelmingly so, everything is explained very well in tooltips) old school party RPG. However the complexity lends itself to variety, in all the classes, abilities, weapons, spells, so that no two playthroughs will be the same, even if you are using exactly the same class as last time.The combat, is first and foremost really really fun. As complex as it is, I never felt like I didn't know what I was doing, and after getting used to it, pulling of really awesome combos of spells and attacks is really satisfying, and I never felt like the game was unfair, any mistakes were made by me, and I learnt from those, for the next fight.I would recommend anyone who is a fan of RPGs in general and good storytelling. Is the game worth it's full price? Hell yes. Did I pay full price for it? ..... Student life.In what other game can I shapeshift into a bear and maul my enemies when sh*t hits the fan?

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Over the years the RPG on computers has evolved into something that is a hybrid of FPS/Third Person with an RPG element. Even FPS and Third Person games have begun this transformation taking on RPG elements.Pillars of Eternity is a step back to the pure essence of the early forays of the RPG world into the computer. It takes some of the tech advancementsa we have seen and combines it with the classic style and game play of the early days of computer RPGs. Gone is the twitch gamer mentality that has so invaded the RPG world and in it's place is the slow, methodical game play that drew you into a story. This is a game that will not impress you with eye candy and glitz, it is more than skin deep.If you love RPGs and loved the classic RPGs beofre they tried to become FPS, then you will love this game.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity has a nasty tone. I regret buying it. I played it for a couple hours and struggled to find anything likeable about it. Now, I've played Divinity: Original Sin, Baldur's Gate and many other isometric fantasy games so I *wanted* to like this.The opening story is a railroad. I saved some NPCs' lives but they got auto-killed by "the plot".Then I had to start over because my mage couldn't survive fights alone.Once I got into town, an NPC forced me to get involved in a fight with town drunks that he instigated. No matter what I said, the fight started anyway so I was forced to kill them. Nobody noticed the random murder of three helpless drunks in the town square, especially since once you loot them, the bodies disappear.Of course you can go around opening and looting objects that clearly aren't your own. Nobody cares about theft in broad daylight.So if you want your choices to be meaningless, and you want to murder innocents and steal, this game is just for you.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												An unfortunate blend of pure combat, overly silly background and a very sad attempt at storytelling, especially given the pedigree this game was trying to recreate.   NPCs tend to fall flat, and it is a very recycled tale of how you, the Chosen One, will completely ignore the special abilites that mark you out as special, the complete lack of consequences that should accompany them (or your actions), and hapharzardly wander to the Overly Tedious Bossfight that has no meaning beyond being the end of your suffering (as a player). The designers made a lot of questionable decisions regarding the utility of abilities, choosing to ape the approach of 4e D&D, where if combat music isn't playing, your class abilities mysteriously don't work, and nothing outside of combat is particularly meaningful.   Unfortunately, combat is a muddy mess of poor programming and bad AI, and the best approach to any combat is find a doorway and exploit the hell out of the repetitive handful of critters.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												10/10 This is by far one of the best games like this that I have played (I believe they are called CRPGs, idk). Where to begin... From the good ol' days of Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment and Icewind Dale; this masterfully crafted games stands side by side with the classics! Outstanding writing and plot, plus amazing characters (and character development). The setting is truly unique, and I feel right at home in this original world. The game is as challenging as it is rewarding, at times I had to do other quests and level up to progress past certain points. It was not annoyingly challenging, just enough to make it feel great when you finally down that tough boss. This game is full of intrigue, diplomacy and other non-combat interactions you would expect from something like D&D. The music is always fitting for the moment, and I thoroughly enjoy all of the music and sounds. The voice acting is great, but be ready for lots of reading (as expected with a game like this). There is so much that I love about this game, and I am unable to describe it all. What I know is that this is an instant classic, and it deserves all the praise that it has received. I am so pleased that this game exists, and I shall continue to support it through the great DLC that they continue to release! Wish you all the best of luck out there, have a blast with this masterwork! A TRUE 10/10!

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I've been playing the old isomorphic D&D RPG's like Baldur's Gate (EE) again recently, and compared to Pillars, they still are way superior.It comes down to world building, basically. In the old D&D RPG's, you'd have hundreds upon hundres of NPC's you could talk to and would have funny conversations or possible side quests leading into other side quests; and so on and so forth. That made the world seem real and created an immersive experience.In Pillars however, the number of NPC's who will actually interact with the player are so limited, you're reminded all the time you're playing a game. Same with maps. They're so repetitive and foes are so predictably scattered, it's signaling all the time: 'You're playing a computer game'. Not immersive; boring. If you're looking for this type of game, go play Baldur's Gate I & II or Icewind Dale. They're vastly superior.

number of helpful: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Baldur's Gate I and II and Planescape Torment are among my favorite games of all time, Icewind Dale was not great but still a lot better than this.The world feels very lifeless, the first town is full of completely unconnected NPC background stories and nobody other than a few quest givers to talk to.The party system is badly balanced as choosing a class that can't survive and fight on its own makes fights much harder than they would probably be otherwise (in my case I picked a priest). This is compounded by the fact that there is a limit to how often you can rest with the available supplies.There is a lot of lore and system information to remember but the explanatory popups work only in some of the places where e.g. the names of gods or skills appear.Most of the areas I visited so far are just your regular old wilderness spot with evenly spaced enemies and a few plants to collect, making for a very boring gameplay.If you are thinking of buying this game because you enjoyed the old Infinity Engine games I would strongly recommend against it. It is nothing like them and does not make up for it for having either particularly strong writing or engaging combat.

												UNINTERESTING STORY - NEEDS MORE NPCS/LIFE - GREAT GRAPHICS - FUN FIGHTS I'm a fan of the Baldur's Gate series (Greatest game and story of all time) and to make this short, if you like RPGs you might enjoy this one though it's not nearly as good as the Baldur's Gate games (which is the standard I measure these games to).It needs a better story, I first tried playing this game when it released and was confused and lost, then after trying again I've now found myself skipping dialogue (something I normally don't do with these games) because the story isn't very interesting.. I don't have the urge to push on, I just kinda play it.. Needs more life... Most of the NPCs are flavor text or just there to make cities and villages look alive...I want more side quests, or random dialouge like in the Baldur's Gate games...The soul stories are even less interesting than the story.Combat is good, and fun though it takes some adapting to if you're used to the D&D style games and rules.Graphics are amazing.If you like RPGs, buy it. Obsidian needs to make a better story for the next game however and build on what they've done successfully here.

number of helpful: 45 of 84 people (54%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												It is not bad, but it is so horribly mediocre.Obsidian could have done so much better, especially as they have experience with choice&consequence mechanics, did Neverwinter Nights 2, Fallout: New Vegas and Alpha Protocol (which I highly recommend - an underrated gem).But PoE is their first game that I really cannot enjoy. Why? Because after the very nice character creation and the tutorial the game destroys its atmosphere directly after arriving in the first village.- Boring party members. Boring backstory, no romancing, no depth.- Poor quest design - you get too little information during your quest and cannot ask enough questions, or you cannot select the option that you would expect to solve the corresponding issue. This makes your decisions totally random and unsatisfying.- Some people or factions are obviously evil, you have more than significant proof against them - and nobody cares.- You can be a death Godlike which is usually killed directly after birth as it is a bad sign or sth like that - but nobody makes you feel it. You expect a world with problems, racism, corruption and in the description it is there. But when you play, you don't feel it at all.- Why so many blobs, spiders, elemental fogs or little lizard warriors to kill? Most enemies are horribly boring.- Was it really necessary to put dozens or even hundreds of unnecessary kickstarter backer-inspired characters into the game, which totally break the atmosphere? The story (which doesn't flow well) basically announces a dark adventure, but you find places with lots colourfully styled NPCs... which have no purpose at all. They are just there and destroy the feeling.- The game world doesn't breath as almost nobody cares about your reputation or race. Other games told so much more about individual problems, social topics (racism etc.) and political issues.You find examples for wasted potential everywhere in the game. It feels like a spiritual successor of Baldur's Gate 1, leaving out every innovation or good example in quest design and story telling of the last 17 years.You can make a retro RPG, yes. But is it wise to leave out all the good ideas that Baldur's Gate 2, Dragon Age: Origins, Mass Effect or the Witcher series gave is in the last years? I don't think so.I'd rate this 5/10 if you play it in English, but only 4/10 if you play in German. The German translation is the worst I've seen in 20 years of gaming - a real insult towards my native language. Did those people even know that they were translating a fantasy RPG, or a computer game at all? There are weird mistakes in every sentence, words left out, wrong translations, incorrect formal speech, wrong formulations in the context... You get the strong feeling that the translator(s) had no idea at all about what they were doing.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Still wondering if this game worth your money? YES!This is the game I waited for so many years. If you miss such CRPGs like Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, you will love this game! Updated: After playing this game for 20+ hours I only managed to finish the first act, and not because the main quest is long and boring, I was distracted by the great number of secondary quests which are as much interesting as the main story and less cliche. In this game you don't need to go and kill 10 rabbits to get a reputation from some guy. The story here is deep and catch you till the end. As you play you feel that you have much more freedom than in some of the modern RPG. Your choices aren't so evident, most of the times you can't say if it's going to add you the certain reputation or not. You choose by your concious (or your character's). I love how much of in control you feel.It feels like Baldur's Gate by the look of it and it's game mechanics, but it also feels modern, bringing CRPG to the new level. Any character can equip any item, but some classes will handle those items better than others. I love how instead of DnD alignment system they added their own personality system that depends on your choices in game. Like punching people? People will call you aggressive. Or maybe your character prefers diplomatic solution. All those characteristics also open more choices during dialogs.This game is not ideal, it still have some bugs, which I hope will be fixed soon. Your stronghold feels kinda useless, at first I was quite excited and spent much money to build it up, but then it almost gave me nothing and you want more from it. Your companions are great, they are interesting and each has their own story, but they don't have much impact on your story, and maybe I spoiled by BioWare games, but you don't feel so bound to them, they are your companions, not friends. There are no fightings between them like there was between Viconia and Keldorn. You can't romance them too. Pros:+ Freedom of choices+ Great secondary quests+ Huge beautiful and interesting world+ Roleplay+ The gameplay you know from BG series, but now it's even better!Cons:- Stronghold that you don't really need- Your companions are interesting guys but they have almost no impact on the story- Some minor bugs

content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												My opinion is kinda split on this one. the one hand the writing is compelling, the character and party options are staggering, the art is pretty, the quest solution options are plentiful, and the dungeons have a decent variety of traps and secrets.However, there are some issues that dragged down my enjoyment of the game.  Melee is based around "engagements" where a melee unit gets a free attack if an enemy tries to retreat from it. However, this also applies if the enemy tries to shift at all.  This is... problematic in the narrow corridors and dungeons that make up half of the combat arenas, with maybe one or two of your units clogging a doorway that could fit four if engagment allowed shifting of positions.  I now loathe this mechanic, which could be fixed by simply allowing units to slide around each other without breaking engagement.The interface is muddy at best.  Battles are obscured behind a cloud of muddy particle effects that don't settle until one or the other side is dead, leaving you looking at a cluster of indistinguishable green and red circles and imagining the epic battle that must be going on under the looney-tunes cloud of dust. I'm a fan of taking tactical advantage of terrain in a fight, and this game did nothing to scratch that itch.  Different dungeons are tactically interchangable.  I was particularly disappointed by several abilites with strong pushback being thwarted by the fact that every deadly cliff and pit of acid is guarded by an invisible wall.  After a while I found myself using the exact same opening combo of brute-force abilties to defeat mooks and bosses alike, leaving the majority of my characters' talents unused.I wish I could recommend it wholeheartedly.  But I'm not sure slogging through another dozen fights to catch the story are worth it.`

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												The full review can be found on Start 2 Continue[start2continue.com].Excerpt:I will admit, I was but a wee lad when Baldur’s Gate first came out back in 1998. I watched my father play it and gave it a try myself (as good as a six-year-old could, at least) and I remember being so enraptured by the story and universe. Aside from the lore of Warcraft, it was Baldur’s Gate that helped shape my understanding of high fantasy--not Lord of the Rings, as many people seem surprised by.Since then, the original developers of Baldur’s Gate have shuffled around the past few years, some of them sticking together, others branching out on their own projects, though it seems to be common to equate Obsidian Entertainment as the most direct successor of the original Black Isle Studios. Obsidian’s known for some pretty high profile stuff in recent years: South Park: The Stick of Truth; Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II; Fallout: New Vegas (and, in a past life, the original two Fallout games), among others....I definitely recommend Pillars of Eternity to any and all gamers, especially those who have been yearning for an RPG like the good ol’ days. Though it was made with a target audience in mind, the fact that this game is easily one of the best games of 2015 thus far, but its achievements and what it represents for Kickstarter projects, crowdfunding, and honoring quality and the passion of game development, as well as the amount of power we gamers have, keeping Obsidian afloat in what seemed to be a last ditch fundraising effort… this is one for the history books.I’d be so bold as to say that Pillars of Eternity is the cRPG equivalent to Skyrim: it exhibits mastery, charm, and a standard of excellence that ought to make Obsidian proud, and that other developers should strive for.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												It's a role playing game that stomps out any sort of role playing or fun.  It's all about meta gaming and ignoring the poorly thought out game mechanics.  All the best stuff or stuff that even works, involves doing something boring, like playing 4-6 characters all of the same class.  You go on any forum full of veteran players and ask them what the best party comp is, and it'll be something stupid like 6 rangers, or 2 fighters and 4 rangers.  Or other asshattery.  There are tanking classes and builds, but they're worthless in every sense, pretty much just wasting a party slot with an otherwise gimped character.  When I beat path of the damned dificulty, the games hardest, I didn't even use a tank.  But my roleplay party that I wanted to do for fun with my own characters in a 3 man party can't even beat normal because I brought a tank.  The way "tanking" works, is by a poorly done "engagement" mechanic.  It works a bit like attacks of opportunity in D&D, your tank, with talents that allow them to engage more then one enemy, runs up and engages the group of enemies, discouraging them from just running by and attacking your squishy DPS characters. EXCEPT THEY DO ANYWAY.  Because all you get for disengaging, is a free attack from the character who is engaging.  So basically, the tank lovetaps them with whatever pathetic amount of damage and whatever worthless one handed weapon you put on them and probably misses or grazes due to their pathetic accuracy because of all the armor and lack of perception.  I put all the talents I could for engagement on my tank, ran up to aggro a group of six mobs, AND ONLY ONE OF THEM STAYED BEHIND TO FIGHT THE TANK.  All the rest of them just filed past, each taking one engagement free hit for♥♥♥♥♥♥damage and just running to my backline.  So the only way to properly tank, is to use funnels and corridors that are only one body wide, or use two tanks in wider corridors, which makes the whole engagement mechanic useless anyway, because you're physically blocking them from going past.  When Pillars of Eternity 2 comes out, I really hope they rethink disengagement, because the whole mechanic is just terrible.  A free hit is nothing, even if you have to disengage from a DPS.  The AI knows this, and abuses the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of it, especially on your tank.  There needs to be a talent that causes disengagement hits to have a large chance to knockdown, daze, something, even just remove it entirely would be better and rely on positioning for tanking, because an engaged tank is a tank that can't reposition without getting melted by six free hits just by stepping slightly to the left.  Because as it is right now, it's pretty much use all fighters, or use no fighters.  The strongest party compositions are ones packed full of multiple amounts of one or two diferent classes, rather then a mix.  And I find this infuriatingly boring.I've been told a lot that the solution is to just trim the dificulty down, but it's just extremely unsatisfying when you do.  Like, there might as well only be 3 dificulties.  Easy, Normal, and Path of the Damned.  There are two other dificulties that I honestly could not tell the diference between.  Story, which is supposed to be easier then easy, but I sure couldn't notice.  Hard, which is supposed to be harder then normal, but again I couldn't notice.  The gap between easy and normal is utterly ridiculous.  In normal, an encounter would be like one or two boss mobs, with 4-6 minions with him.  In easy, the same encounter would be just one or two regular mobs.  Thats a HUGE diference.  A ridiculous diference.  You couldn't make anything between that?  Don't get me wrong, I still like the game and what it's trying to do.  I bought it on gog, and then on steam when it was on sale with the white march expansion, but I'm really hoping that they see stuff like this and fix it for the sequel.  There's just nothing satisfying from watching your unique self made characters of a variety of classes, builds, backstorys that you roleplay out get destroyed, only to finally break down and reroll something stupid like 6 rangers, and boringly and utterly roflstomp the game in the hardest dificulty.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												If you're a fan of isometric RPGs, this is a must-have.That being said, if you aren't a fan of Iso-RPGs, or you don't know enough about them - this is an excellent game to start the genre with. It's not as brutal as Baldur's Gate straight out the door, unless you want it to be brutal as hell. The difficulty customization is extensive as all hell, from generic difficulties to Iron Man to even more customizations in expert mode settings. You can set the game up as hard as you want, and the actual in-game customization options are intuitive for new players as well.An excellent addition to the Iso-RPG genre, and I hope we get even more!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												What a great game.The look and feel of this game is in the style of some of the classic cRPGs like Baldur's Gate. Pillars of Eternity has a rich story, good character creation, and excellently written dialogue. 												If you like old school RPG's or if you want to try one but with modern graphics then I fully recommend PoE. The story is great, combat is deep and challenging, the world looks fantastic and theres potentially hundreds of hours of content.Right now the game is on sale for just under £15, at this price I would wholeheartly recommend getting PoE even if you havent played similar games. At its full price you may want to do a bit of research before paying £35 as this style wont be for everyone, the game is challenging especially if you're new to the genre.Updated: I never managed to bring myself to finish PoE, I believe this is because while I did enjoy the graphics, combat and elements of the main story, I felt the world building left a lot to be desired. The problem being that despite having played similar games with PoE I could never truly get into the lore or gain an understanding of the overall world because it simply didn't hold my interest and at times felt a tad like generic fantasy. Plus the NPC's and gravestones created by the contributors to the kickstarter are just plain horrible, rarely holding useful infomation and often breaking my immersion, its always dissapointing to see an interesting looking character and find out its another of these contributor made NPC's. The game would be better of without them, they add nothing but constantly break immersion.I would still recommend the game when on sale but I wouldn't recommend it for full price.

content:
Posted: January 4
												I just cannot put this game down! My first attempt didn't go so well since I had made some critical errors on my class decision and I didn't want to put it on Easy mode for any portion of the game. Second attempt has got me loving the Druid, I mean... game, more than ever. To help out I recommend reading some non spoiler guides from the lovely folks on the discussion board since there is quite a learning curve with this game if you're not familiar with the type. The community for this game has been great from what I can tell so far. Personal recommendations: Save often. Take time to really try out every single spell you have in a fight, re-load it and try it all over again with new spells. Reason being, is that I didn't understand most of the spells initially and whether they would have friendly fire, etc, so give em a shot, you'll be glad you mastered your lvl 1,2 spells even at the end game. Watch your positioning - tailor the custom formation to maximize party. These are just a few key things that had barred me from continuing the game initially and I don't want anyone else to lose out on this game because of it. Above all, be prepared to dive off into a story that'll have you thinking about it every time you exit the game!

												This is an amazing crp in the vein of Baldur's Gate. It is still very challenging and filled with excellent writing and it is in no way dumbed down for modern audiences. There is some welcome streamlining like not needing arrows to use bows. The combat is all about positioning, it is absolutely critical to make sure your casters and squishy characters are in the back. You will pause a lot to try and get things just right. The dragon battles are absolutely epic and on the hardest difficulty POTD are brutal (dark souls level brutal imho). I loved this game. My only complaint is that it still has a few bugs and the UI in combat is really weird - hard to select friends. Go buy this if you loved old isometric rpgs. 9/10

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Good:+ Engaging story. I even read some of the in-game books, unlike in Elder Scrolls games.+ Fantastic companion voice dialog.+ Morally ambiguous decisions and factions.+ It's stable. I've had it crash on me once in 45+ hours of play.+ Just an addictive and rewarding play experience.+ Lots of game for your money. I'm 45 hours in, and estimate that I'm less than halfway done. And there are chacter classes I haven't even tried yet.Bad:- Terrible framerates and loading times. - Not enough graphics settings.- Not nearly enough variability in terms of character and gear appearence.- NPCs don't feel real, They don't follow daily routines, just stand in the same place forever.- Obnoxious kickstarter-related content.- Your party members will sometimes get stuck or wander away from battles at the worst times.Overall, it's a very good game that could be made into an excellent game if more work is put into optimization. This is 2016, I shouldn't need to sit through a 15 second loading screen just to enter a one-room hut, and then again when I exit. And a system that can run Skyrim smoothly shouldn't struggle to achieve 30fps with this game. I'm hoping for a good optimization patch. There should also be an option to disable kickstarter content, because the game world is infested with NPCs that can't talk, and tombstones with immersion-destroying text. With all it's flaws, though, I still think it's fun as hell.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												After supporting the game on Kickstarter (one of very few games I supported), after patiently waiting for two part expansion to get released, I finally played Pillars of Eternity in it's complete current 3.x version and it was an amazing adventure to have. All of my expectations were met and exceeded and not just because we sadly lacked games with truly great stories for the past decade, but because even if there were many, Pillars would be just as great. It's everything you loved about Black Isle, early Bioware, Troika and, of course, Obsidian themselves, but perfected, taken to a new level, despite the very nostalgic interface. It's simple enough to get sucked into it, but complex and deep enough not to be a very fast food-ish feeling game a lot more recent AAA RPGs have become.So what is Pillars of Eternity with both parts of White March expansion and latest patch? It's an RPG with an active pause and Infinity Engine-inspired aesthetic. But where Infinity Engine felt restrictive in later games, both technologically and storytelling mechanics-wise, where D&D rulesets felt restrictive for the stories BioWare and especially Black Isle wanted to tell, Obsidian made something perfectly suited for their needs. The inteface is highly customisable and smart, technologically the game is much less restricted and the ruleset they created for their world is a joy to play with. You pretty much cannot create a "bad character" unless you try to (and if you do something you regret you can respec easily). All mechanics and ideas complement the concept of you playing the game the way you want and shaping the story the way you want. It isn't as freeform as what Fallout tried to be, but wow it is trying and is much more flexible than even Planescape: Torment. As an example - combat itself doesn't give you experience now, so you never feel like you NEED to kill everything you see and doing things in other ways is perfectly viable. And the idea of very text adventure-like segments that focus even more on your deeds and abilities to do things normal gameplay wouldn't allow is an incredibly smart decision.The adventure itself is structured close to how the original Baldur's Gate worked (a region where you open new destinations on the world map to go to), but every map tries to bring something new, something unique, something exciting to learn and do. The world lore, the main story, mini stories, companion stories are very fun and try to ask interesting questions and put new perspectives on what you think you already know. In the way how deep and amazing story is, I wouldn't even compare it to Baldur's Gate games, but more to Planescape: Torment or probably a bit of Arcanum. Now, in the White March part 1, story is considerably simpler (and the events take place as an extension of the main story, not as a post-game thing), but part 2 brings back the excitement of the main game topics and questions game asks of you, even if it's still not as great as the main game.There are, of course, some nitpicks to be had. Loadings for every map, for example, do become frustrating even if it was the only way to preserve the pre-rendered beauty of the backgrounds, especially since as you play longer game seems to start becoming "heavier" for the system. There are rather frustrating AI things as in the fight all party members seem to follow very simple pathing algorithms and can block each other without any logic to go around or shuffle to the side without breaking engadgement with the enemy. The party AI and presets, on the other hand, are very good most of the time, so it's just weird to see pathing being so much of an issue. And there are also some occasional glitches - wrong script triggers, character getting thrown over the path boundries and getting stuck there forever, controls just refusing to work suddenly and even few crashes. These happened VERY rarely, but they did.These things aside, however, I had fantastic time with Pillars of Eternity and it's two-part expansion and I'd recommend the game to anyone who loves a really great story that you help shape the way you want. One of the best RPGs in a decade, probably best game from Obsidian so far and and adventure to be had. I really wish there will be more games in this universe.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I learned about "Pillars of Eternity" when it was already done and it took me by surprise. In 2015 being able to play a classic RPG from the creators of Fallout, Arcanum and Baldur's Gate is a real treat.Overall I had a good time playing "Pillars of Eternity". The main storyline is quite interesting to follow. The world is very detailed, has its own history, gods, nations. There are very different characters you can travel with, each having goals and views.Graphics, music and sound effects are superb!The game has A LOT of text. It is very well written and most of the time interesting to read. But sometimes it adds nothing to the story and is just boring. In that case you can always skip it. You won't miss important information because it is recorded in the Journal.I've found combat system to be difficult to understand. Never learned how to use enemy vulnerabilities against them. It helped that I played on "Easy" and so didn't have many problems killing the monsters.The most annoying thing for me were long loading screens. Even when you go to the other floor in the same building a loading screen shows up for half a minute. It is unaccaptable in 2015 with all the resources current computers have!I don't think "Pillars of Eternity" is as great as its predecessors, but it is very good and is very much worth playing if you like good old RPGs.Now waiting for the documentary to come out!

												I'm not typically one for top down RPG's nor am I a fan of squad or party managment. But I have to give it to the kickstarter community on this one. I freaking love this game. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Pros:- Nice environments, good level design, beautiful backgrounds.- Great music (!) and sound effects.- Great storytelling, writing and atmosphere. The world calls out to be explored.- The main plot is mature and engaging, the world well built, the lore rich and deep. More in line with Planescape: Torment than BG or Neverwinter Nights.- Voice acting is a bit of a mixed bag (Grieving Mother, Kana, Aloth), but mostly good (Eder, Sagani, Durance, Lady Webb).- OMG moments, like entering Gilded Vale for the first time, or talking to Uscgrim or the animancy hearing at the Duc's.- Chanter's 'The Thunder Rolled like Waves on Black Seas' invoked that badass feeling no other iso game ever did for me.Cons:- Combat may get boring after a while, as the vast majority of encounters feel repetetive. You gain access to several classes and a crapload of abilities, but in the end it all makes little to no difference on the actual gameplay. Sometimes less is more. Original Sin it isn't.- The engagement mechanic, coupled with terrible pathfinding, dumb collisions and your own party members blocking each other is more of an annoyance than anything else.- Random difficulty spikes, eg. Sky Dragon or the final fight...- ... yet paralysis/petrificacion + spell nuke will easily win every boss fight within seconds.- Certain parts of the dialogue tree are voiced while others are not. Additionally you get a lot of written storytelling in between, which is totally ignored by the voice actors. The game can't really decide whether you should be reading or listening, and this in turn breaks immersion a lot. - A minor gripe, which is the Kickstarter content, eg. meaningless NPCs stories and cheesy tombstone memorials. Makes you ignore most yellow NPCs after a while.- The Keep feels like an afterthought.- Bugs. Played it twice, the first time on hard but got stuck in the final dungeon due to a bug. Second time on normal+expert mode. Overall an enjoyable experience, writing and atmosphere is where the game really shines, while what it lacks is some meaningful, well designed combat encounters. Never been a fan of the BG series, so I'd place it before BG1 and BG2, but certainly after PS:T. Verdict: 8/10

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												To anyone wanting to get into the CRPG genre, then I can completely recommend this game. I grew up with RPG's in the vain of Skyrim and the modern Fallout's and while these were good games, there was something missing from the experience. I felt this most acutely from Fallout 4, where many of the key role-playing aspects and the impact of your choices in the world felt incredibly limited. Seeking out a more true role-playing experience, I decided to give Pillars of Eternity a go, despite having never played a game in the CRPG genre. I'm very happy I did. This game offers you a great story, an original world, interesting characters, fun quests, Obsidian's brilliant writing and impactful choices. The combat is a bit clunky in places, but it didn't come close to ruining the experience for me. If you want to experience a true RPG, then look no further than Pillars of Eternity.

												I do not have too much experience with CRPG's, but I fell in love with this game. I like to compare it to Dragon Age Origins, the first and best game in the trilogy, or Knights of the Old Republic but with a top down isometric view. The action is very satisfying and complex. Do you want 6 rangers with 6 bear companions? go for it. How about 6 Fiery Godlike fighters, soaking up massive amounts of damage and hardly losing any health. Do you want to be a good guy in every conversation, or gain some dark side points and be a d*** to everyone, the choice is yours. Give the game a few hours and if you like RPG's at all, you will fall in love with Pillars too.

												This game is the closest thing to the RPG of old that I've been salivating to experience again after almost two decades. Everything, every part, every detail falls into place perfectly. The plot, pacing, and main story grips you the minute you get into it. Character building is as good as role playing is going to get. While Baldur's Gate 2's RTwP combat was fun for its time, this game needed to be better and modernized and they delivered exactly that experience. If the old infinity games were to be made today, it would have been Pillars of Eternity.9.5. Amazing game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Pillars of Eternity Chanter Gameplay #1: Character Creation and Intro 

			Views: 492		

			Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/user/TheTroublmaker/ From Obsidian comes Pillars of Eternity, the latest in isometric RPGs.		

If you want to tell people that you played Baldur's Gate growing up there's no better way to fulfill that lie by playing a game like Baldur's Gate first.  No this is not Diablo light.  That would be Torchlight 2, which some would argue has now made Diablo 3 into Torchlight Light.  This is a game that is going to be closer to Fallout/Skyrim than it is going to be to Diablo.In it you control a party of heroes with a fully customizable adventure from what missions you choose, what results you pick, dialogue that effects how people interact with you, fully customizable 6-member party, fully customizable classes and simple and intuitive controls.The game is not beautiful.  I'm certain this game isn't even in HD.  But that shouldn't dissuade you from giving this mentally handicapped game a try, it's a lot of fun.ARE YOU INTO CRAFTING?  Yes, it has crafting.  And much like similar titles you gain experience through just about every single thing you do (except for walking because that would be really dumb).  Unlocked a door, awesome level up.  Better put more points in that door unlocking so I can get more experience from unlocking doors!It is truly a choose your own adventure game that you can play many many times with differing results.  In my first playthrough I played the role of the warmonger running around sweeping down enemies.  In my second playthrough I'm peacefully moving around looking for middle ground solutions to resolve everyone's issues.The biggest downside to the game is that you can't 100% it.  Apparently simply buying it doesn't mean you support the game.  Apparently only people who contributed to the initial kickstarter campaign are allowed to 100% the game.  Other than that (which seriously developers go ♥♥♥♥ yourself) the game is amazing.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												I don't consider myself a person who easily identifies with some pre-phrased choices given to me by the authors of an artificially constructed phantasy. I'm a person of science, never were a believer, and I certainly don't put a lot of value in certainty. Yet this game, with its story about belief, certainty and purpose manages to put tears into my eyes because during its final moments I'm suddenly overwhelmed by this sensation of being understood, because among all the fixed categories I'm given the option to deny categorism. Because while I'm making these choices, my faith in not putting blind faith into authorities is actually being tested. This is a game that has put questions into my mind, and I daresay I normally have very straight answers to the wannabe-challenging issues raised by people with a philosophical agenda. Given this dimension of storytelling, it should be obvious that this game is a literary work with a deep relevance to the questions of our time, and the fact that I can actually discuss it on this level makes it one of the most impressive games ever made. That said, you obviously have to be willing to deal with the game on some kind of intellectual level to be able to enjoy these things. I'm not even talking about technicalities like mechanics or graphics, which are also great btw.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												A game made perfect by the dedication of those involved with it and the support of fans. The writing alone sets it apart, as it doesn't ever feel any need to pander to tired clichés or cater to the whims of ignorant marketing departments. It will surprise you. It will shock you. It will build you up and then knock you down, and you will never see it coming. It will give you triumph, and snatch it away, because a true story is never quite so simple as that.Are you still reading this? You should be playing this game for yourself.  What are you waiting for?It's not entirely without its flaws, as there are some bugs and other issues that mar it, but honestly, it's better than any triple-A title you could name in every way, shape, or form. You're still reading. Why?

content:
Posted: February 1
												While Pillar's of Eternity is a good game, and I bought it to support the genre, I do NOT recommend it to fellow CRPG fans on a tight budget. As many reviews suggest this game could be seen as a successor to Infinity engine games (ie Baldur's Gate), but only from a mechanical standpoint. Saying this game is the _spiritual_ successor to games like Baldur's Gate is an overstatement, and maybe even offensive..With that in mind, I will anchor my review to two key Infinity engine games (Baldur's Gate 1 and 2) to show what is missing. There are lots of reviews highlighting what's good in this game, but I hope this comparison gives a better picture of what NOT to expect.- To start with don't expect an immersive story. It's very difficult to justify and be part of the main quest. Without any spoilers, certain things happen to the PC, but it's absolutely not worth going through life dangering situations. Like, really.. This leaves you doing stuff because the journal says you should, not because you are interested.- Characters are very shallow and predictable. Banter options are limited, Remember unforgettable party members from BG 1 or 2? Not gonna have them here.- The main villian isn't interesting and doesn't feel like a real threat. Jon Irenicus (or also Sarevok for that matter) were scary mysterious figures. Both were real threats and hooked the player into the game. Same cannot be said for this game's villian.- Quests aren't interesting or satisfying. Yes, there are different ways to solve almost every quest, and that is a fresh new take, but the actual content of most side quests is just meh. There has been way more focus on giving the player options, but the developers haven't seem to have thought as much about why you would want to be involved in the first place.- Walls of text, everywhere. While the writing is impressive (and I thought hard whether I should even mention this bullet), everything is extremely wordy and sometimes reading all that text on a screen becomes so exhausting, it makes one think whether there is something as too much content.- Worst of all, there are a crapload of features that are just Kickstarter bonuses and all of them come at the expense of immersion. And the only response to "why?" is "because money"..For these reasons, I do NOT recommend this game,  unless you are a fellow fan of the genre or the game goes on a crazy discount.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is an uneven, yet excellent game.  Without spoiling anything, the story follows your made character as they get exposed to, basically, dark magic and is granted the ability to read souls. From here, you pursue your Nemesis across the realm in an attempt to find meaning and answer.At times, Pillars is completely brilliant. The first 1 1/2 acts of the game is some of the best I've played. The story is riveting, the characters are interesting, the combat is complex and there's promise of some cool upcoming features that are hinted at in these early segments.Unfortunately, the game mostly falls apart about halfway through Act II. The game loses any semblance of challenge it had, the story and characters and insane amount of side-quests all kinda boggle among themselves and the writing drops a few notches. You'll likely find yourself starting to get bored nearing the end of Act II (also right when I hit the level cap) and rush your way through Acts III and IV. There are some cool features that I was excited about that don't seem to go anywhere. Building your own keep was a cool idea I haven't seen implemented anywhere in a game like this, but it actually does absolutely nothing in the game. Money is pretty infinite by the time you start building your keep. At that point, it's just time-gated. You can take prisoners.. but why? They just sit there doing nothing, occasionally offering bribes to be released. The crafting and enchanting systems are useless. Consumables are a joke (often taking longer to consume than they heal or buff). Some spells are ridiculously overpowered (Level 5 mage Charm is insanely powerful). Even with all of this, I highly recommend this game. The visuals are fun, the characters and plot are largely interesting. The dialogue paths numerous and the endings multiple. The combat in the first half of the game is near perfect until you start getting overpowered. Tl;dr: Pillars of Eternity has a slew of great ideas, some poorly or half implemented. But the core gameplay is amazing, the story is fantastic and the characters are interesting. The game is also 65+ hours long (supposedly 80-90 if you do all the content, but I rushed Act III and didn't do much in the way of side quests) and has a ton of content. B+

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Excellent successor to Baldurs Gate. Took me nearly 80 hours to finish (with White March) and I don't claim to have done all the sidequests.Pros:- Atmosphere, story, art- Usually (in sidequests) there is no clear 'evil' or 'good' which side you can take. For example: Animancy is the study of spirits. Animancers try to find the cure to the disease that plaque Dyrwood. But it is also very close to necromancy. When do the deeds they make to further the study into the disease get 'evil'?- Black & White text- based scenes- Weapon enchanting, crafting from the loot/herbs- New ruleset (non D&D). Especially differentation of endurance from health is great idea!- StrongholdCons:- Loading times between maps are quite long (2.01)- New rule set (non D&D). Takes some time to get into. To see what attributes matter to what classes etc etc. Gladly the White March expansion lets you rebuild your character- Stronghold. Could have had something more to make the place livelier.Also could have some better indicator which map/dungeon is for which level characters. Got stomped a few times when venturing forth to a wrong area at a wrong time (especially in WM dlc)Rating: 9.5

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity set about to be the spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and Planescape: Torment.Nailed it.Offering a wide variety of difficulty options and many ways to play, this game is both a reminder of our past for those of us who enjoyed the afforementioned games as youngsters, and a great primer for the genre (and, dare I say, a possible fresh start for the genre?) for neophytes to it.If you enjoyed the old D&D games (or similar ones, such as Arcanum) you'll want to experience this fantastic journey.If you haven't played any of this genre before, but like epic story telling, challenging tactical combat, some of the best voice acting *ever* in a video game, and gorgeous immersive worlds, give PoE a try. It will test your tactics and your morals in the best possible way. Expect some small stumbling blocks if you've never played a game like this before, so if you're not comfortable getting used to a new style of game you may not want to pick this up before watching some let's plays of it. By an hour or two in you'll be as comfortable with PoE mechanics as you've been with any others.Story: 10/10Strong, engaging, exciting.Music: 8/10Fantastic sound track, only complaint is that there's not more of it.Art/World: 10/10Mind bogglingly gorgeous in every possible wayCombat: 7/10Can be heavy on micromanagement on harder difficulties, may take some getting used to the unique systems, otherwise greatRoleplay: 10/10Immersive roleplaying with tons of dialogue options that help you really connect with your character. Choices make noticeable impacts on the game world and often have ramifications down the roadOverall: 9/10One of my all time favorite games already, and I still have tons left to explore. In a word (well, two): Buy it.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												I'm still working through this game after about a year now. I really like the engine, most of the lore, and a lot of the interactions in the game including character development, text based challenges, etc. The thing that really holds this game back is the horrid combat. Perhaps it is more accurate to call it a spiritual successor to Torment than to Baldur's Gate games, as the combat is just in the way of everything else. The pace is ridiculous, you can't tell what is going on half the time, the spells are all random combinations of any of 20 friggin' status effects (do we really need stuck, dazed, prone, stunned, and paralyze to be separate things?). On top of that, you can't even prepare for battle beforehand, which was one of the most important aspects of Baldur's Gate. Honestly, what is the point of stealth if you can't scope out the area beforehand and then buff?Finally, the enemies, while beautiful, are irritating as hell. No matter how hard you try to prepare and protect your squishies, they can literally teleport on top of them OR teleport them to themselves without any way to stop them. Also, there are enemies that literally stun with every hit, which permastuns anyone they attack. I can't comprehend that the developers actually played through their own game and found combat fun.I really hope they slow down the pace of combat, allow preparation, and generally make it more like Baldur's Gate combat if they decide to make another game. And FFS, allow coop.I would only recommend this game if you are the biggest CRPG fan out there, and even then it will disappoint you with some of the design choices.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												I had high hopes for this game. Added it to me wishlist back when it first showed up on Steam.  I did not pick it up however till it was on sale for 50% off. It had many good reviews, so I gambled and bought it.  It's not a bad game, the story is decent enough so far. I can't say it really grabbed me, and made me not want to stop playing like other games have in the past. Some of the game mechanics, while novel, I just don't care for.  Healing your health is only possible by camping or spending the night at an Inn.  This is seperate from Endurance, which I believe everyone can heal at some point in the game with magic, talents, or abilities, etc. I have heard there are healing potions, but, as of yet, have not found any myself. It might just be the old school RPG player in me, but, this system seems very counter intuitive.  If I just got mauled by a bear, how is spending the night in an Inn or camping in a tent going to heal those wounds up, and yet the classes that in most RPG's online or pen and paper, that can traditionally heal with magic, can't do anything but restore endurance...which is what I consider to happen while resting in an Inn or elsewhere, to do. I have seen several comment on this in various forums, saying it creates a challenge, or finite resource, yadda yadda.  It's a deal breaker for me.  I'm not playing an RPG, for the challenge of deciding how to reduce how many times I have to go stay at an inn or buy more camping gear. But, that's just me I guess.Visually, it's a good looking game. Some of the maps are a bit small, but, everything I have seen so far, looks good. Spell effects and lighting are well done.Character creation is fairly in depth.  Various choices can create different play styles from the same class. Classes are not restricted to certain weapons and armor, which I did like.  The weapons and armor do have tradeoffs, such has speed of attack, recovery time after using abilities, etc. This in itself creates a new challenge of optimizing your gear to suit your abilites and combat/play style. One of the concepts that I could work with.Combat is fast paced, and had many options to autopause on various events happening. Also several options for the AI behavior during combat. Although a few times, it seemed like the AI was doing it's own thing, regardless of the settings I had selected. Overall, just not my cup of tea I guess. Would rather play Balders Gate again or fire up Neverwinter Nights.  I wish I had done a bit more research on it. But that is just speaking for me.

												This is without a doubt one of the best games I have played in a long time and I've only clocked 11 hours of playtime.The soundtrack is just amazing and it really sets an atmosphere for the game, especially at key story moments and in combat, the wide variety of combat tracks is impressive on its own. The visuals are brilliantly crafted, in my personal opinon making it look better then most games these days simply because of the brilliant art style that obsidian have used, it  truely is nostalgic and gorgeous.The character creation is also extremely impressive for a game which doesnt even allow you to see your character closely except in the inventory menu, allowing you to give your character a personal touch, from a variety of races, cultures,classes and backstories along with a generous amount of voices to choose from.The lore of the universe is also extremely interesting along with the intriguing storyline which I have yet to unravel.Overall I would recommend Pillars of Eternity for anyone who is a big RPG fan, especially of old-school RPGs. This game truely has restored my love of RPG's as It has been too long since there was one as great as this.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I know I just scratched the surface so far but... holy crap is this game awesome! The look is just gorgeous and it takes you back to the younger days of PC gaming where the games were hand drawn and they had "a soul" (no pun intended). The gameplay is just right - meaning it IS hard and you will be punished for blindly running into the fights. However, it's not as clunky as the fights in Baldur's gate were, and having the fights in real time instead of turn-based makes it even better.Pausing the fight is a must and there's no way you can kill anything in a group larger than 2 without some tactics. Especially in tight areas or smaller rooms where you can't fit your whole party. There's a decent number of side-quests and lore, as well as side-characters that have their own stories to discover. The only remark I have are the long loading screens you encounter when you leave/enter each zone. But it's not a big deal.If you consider yourself a RPG lover, and you want a huge nostalgia fix at the same time, just stop reading this already and get the game.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												Grade: 88/100I love this game.  It isn't perfect.  However, besides Divinity Original Sin, this is the best thing since toasted bread.  Nothing is better than throwing the difficulty all the way up, and setting it for trial of iron.  Nothing like really caring if your character dies (No pause/task manager quits either).  It isn't perfect, but it's great.  Pros(1) strategy - depending on the level you play at, you better take a moment to seriously consider how you are going to win a fight.(2) Party makeup choice - I have played with several different party make ups, and there really is no right way to play.  (3) customizable/toggleable difficulty(4) detail(5) There are some cool things to try - for example kill everyone at the initial camp site and be amazed at the gem you get for that accomplishment.Cons(1) The game has a very convoluted plot.  I'd say that it has as much or more backstory as the Dragon Age trilogy all stuffed into one game.(2) I don't feel that the choices are as meaningful as they should be.  I say that despite some choices leading to some straight-forward different consequences.  But in a game where you can kill a mad duke, there should be some more serious world shaking consequences.(3) Some minor things: No multi-classing, bizarre over-complicated health/stamina system; and No Romance(4) My personal pet peeve in an RPG - the game doesn't respect rogues.  I think the the the entire rogue system is broke.  Everyone can sneak.  And the rogue has significant functionality in the game.  I recommend this game.  And it deserves a few play throughs.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Excellent CRPG "feel" which includes fast (and sometimes chaotic) combat. Tons of customization for your character. Absolute industry best writting in a fantasy genre. Obsidian has also maintained support for Pillars of Eternity over the last year which includes 2 expansions that tie into one another. The White March. Additional support has comes in new abilities, NPC AI, new quests and on going balance and fixes. Obsidian is the type of developer you want to support in these days of big promises and shallow delivery. They have made a modern classic RPG that will be the bench mark of comparison for upcoming titles. My only negative perspective is that this game not meant for a casual gamer. It's clearly aimed at fans of RPGs who enjoy slow , built up story lines that require a LOT of reading. As a potential customer , you should be aware this game plays like an interactive novel more than Mass Effect , which I consider a action RPG.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Wanted to like this game but another one of those where you will end of saving every few seconds and some ways of implementing things that just make the game the opposite of fun.-Spell use - limited by number of casts between sleeps (meaning you better carry tons of firewood) .  Reminds me of C&C 4 and the depature from typical RTS.  Just makes the game un enjoyable. Some say they do this to make it more challenging and or casters are too powerful. I personaly would rather see less dmg on a caster with the ability for me to actually cast without having to rest.  Never knew micromanagement could be done in an RPG - these programmers found a way for that.- Gone with the Wind type texts for everything.   Overwelming amount of texts for the most simple things.Way overly compliacted.  You have 5 main upgrade choices on levels. Lore Scroll reading, Survival (consumable duration), Stealth,, Mechanics (lock picking), and Athletics.Typical RPG's use INT / STR / DEX / CON etc where you apply points into these when leveling - not here.  I only found gear could upgrade those and very modestly.  Items / Gear upgrades are very anti - exciting as you realize that any low level item can be "enchanted" to Exceptional / Superb which is the same as the drops you get from bosses - making the boss drops nothing special.  Endurance is now part of the equation similar to "health" - when your endurance hits zero you pass out (in a fight) but your health doesn't improve.  There is no healing or health potions - just endurance.  But you can die apprently if your health goes to zero. Not sure why not just sticking to basic Hitpoints was a bad thing.MOBS you kill give you virtually no xp - experience gain is mainly quest driven. The items dropped are just an overabundance of useless items maybe for potions or vendor trash.  One aspect I liked was owning a "stronghold" so you can rest there and get bonus'.  Initially it was great until you realize it's nightmare always attenidng to "unwanted visitors" that you have to pay off to not stay (it brings negative prestige) or escort and are constantly getting invaded that I have to go back to the stronghold (2 days travel) to fight.  You can have it auto resolve by hiring defenders that get paid but that means you can take damage to your stronghold.  Good idea that turned into more micromanagement.Some may like this unobvious level of micromanagement throughout the game- but I hated it.  I will almost guarantee most any person that plays this game will saving every few minutes if that gives an indicator of frustration.    The dragon fights (possible 3)  - I never got through any of them - not even close to defeating one (i was level 12 the max level).  The main battle at the end same thing.  I got to the end - but game so frustating - uninstalled the game with only 1 boss to kill at the end.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Worked in Windows 8.1 with both nVidia and AMD cards.3/5 stars, but thumbs down (details below, includes minor spoiler about the existence of a game location).I paid $22.50 for this on sale, expecting something akin to a Baldur's Gate 2 experience. What I found was a strange "fantasy" story with inconsistent and not entirely logical insertion of low technology and Celtic references. The tepid story already had me on the fence as to whether I wanted to continue or not, but when I got to the  - Minor Spoiler - ...castle with the so-called "endless" dungeon underneath, I got annoyed and stopped playing. Now, don't get me wrong. I don't have a problem with dungeon crawler games per se, and I own a few rogue-likes; sometimes you just want to beat up some monsters. But this is supposed to be a story-based game, and a 15-level dungeon filled with a menagerie of monsters with no cohesive fictional basis for being there completely breaks any real immersion. Ogres on level 3! Vampires on level 8! Oozes! Beetles! Undead! A dragon on level 15! Can you imagine a 15-level dungeon filled with 22 different kinds of monsters underneath King's Landing in the Game of Thrones universe? Under Mount Doom in Middle-earth? It would feel silly. The "endless" dungeon in this game screams "filler content to artificially increase play time", not "great fiction." That gets my thumbs-down at the current price point of $45, as well as the $22.50 I paid. This is a thoroughly average $10 game.

content:
Posted: January 6
												I wanted to like Pillars of Eternity. The thought of an independent, modern party-based RPG with pausable real-time combat was very appearling. The reviews that buzzed about the "depth" of the fantasy world in which the game had me looking forward to the experience of playing the game. Unfortunately, it doesn't live up to the hype. Part of the problem is that the rich history (and it is rich, to be fair) of the world, Eora, is neither properly explored nor suitably limited in the beginning of the game. The character is posiitioned in a caravan travelling from somewhere to somewhere else and has no particular purpose for the journey, which makes some of the conversations strange and stilted. A strange storm then gives our character some special powers, including the ability to "talk to souls". This manifests as characters during the game about which the player is able to glean some (often beautifully-written) history. However, it is not possible to interact with these characters in any other way, making the whole thing seem very gimmicky, although it does provide the essential motivation for the ongoing story (the player must seek out someone who can help them understand this power). The additional characters are fleshed out to some degree, but lack of context makes it difficult to form a real attachment or sense of either world or personal history. There are vague references to a "dead god", Waidwen, who was apparently killed at the hands of humans and left a curse behind which causes some children to be "hollowborn", but it's not even particularly clear what that even means, and the story of why humans would want to destroy a god is mostly unexplained. With all that in mind, the story just doesn't grab me. Additionally, gameplay has some flaws; combat seems to require significant and unrewarding micro-management in order to use the array of skills available; it's possible quite early to find areas which are simply too difficult for low-level characters, with no suitable warning. You just end up dying repeatedly before you realise that you need to go elsewhere. It's unsatisfying and tedious. This game is ok if you love hack-n-slash, but it's no Dragon Age and barely makes the cut of Baldur's Gate IMO.
