content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This game has no edge. Icewindale 2? The story of twin Demons kicked out of hell, who decided to go on a rampage because the human world rejected them? That's edge. Min/Max stats for godly mages/fighters, edgy. Fun.Pillars is, the higher your level, the more overpowered you become, end of story. It gets to a point where your six-peon squad is so deep in DPS that you stop casting spells, buffs, and mostly just watch your team go to town while using a handful of abilities to kill everything, at all times. Pre-buffing was eliminated. Tweaked? Nerfed? No, gone. Armor restrictions as well, which makes for awkward scenarios where I have a Druid in full plate swinging a giant mace in the middle of a fight with the rest of them. I got half way through the game with that character and thought, wait, that's a Druid?In Wasteland 2, when I make a team, they have character, my sniper can't move, but kills everything and can take weapons apart to boot. My run and gun is a team leader with great charisma and great bomb disposable skills. My specialist knows the ins and outs of computers, locks, and safes, while being a smart♥♥♥♥♥ but dose the least damage.My fighter eh.. uh. My fighter, is in a DPS race with my rouge, and my cipher. Everyone else just kinda stands around taking up space. In pillars I can't latch onto anything I create because the system isn't integrated enough with itself, or with the world it occupies. I have 200 hours and beat the game once, because once you hit lvl 10, you know that's as much fun as you're going to get, and the rest is just talking to uninteresting people, and slogging through what's left.I dunno, what's going on Obsidian? Where is the beef? Why didn't you just make the god-bomb plot the story of your game? That was edgy, exciting, instead it's background info. What's better, the reincarnation of a god going toe to toe with locals and ending the game with a big frickin' explosion? Or playing as some guy chasing down another guy, cause he has voices in his head? Please, get some bolas before you make Pillars 2.

												I love games like this. I grew up on them and played them for hundreds of hours. This feels like uninspired garbage. 24 hours of play, multiple starts, tried about every class/build, and it still feels lacking. I feel like this is a ripoff of the old games with a slightly new skin, just executed in a pretty pathetic way. Yup, lets remake an old goodie. When we do it lets rip out its soul and ruin everything fun about it!Combat is lame and unispired. Not to mention the really stupid mechanics. Itemization in the game is horrible. The magic system made me want to throw things. Mages were my fav in BG2. They are pitiful in this game. I feel like there aren't any real differences in the classes/character builds other than the animation that executes.Also seems like you end up with 3 types of character: 1. Glass cannon that gets munched in one or two shots. 2. Tank that would lose in arm wrestling to a three year old, but can take a beating like a porn star. Oh, yeah, they don't get any effective combat management skills either....3. Middle of the road that ends up not good or bad at anything (but you miss all of the dialogue options without having at least one buff stat). Seems like you spend a lot of time building a character to not have it mean anything. It really torqued me that I coudn't build a chracter that did what I thought it would do.Loading screens... With a modern system and SSD's this game shouldn't be such a slug. I like to read but there are ridiculous walls of meaningless text less interesting than a high school social studies book. Meh. End rant.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												Let me start by saying I was one of the backers for this project, so I am very into this sort of games. That being said, I can't force myself to finish this one. I was going back to it from time to time but it always ends up the same - combat, leveling and magic is just plain wrong.Maybe this type of combat experiance is cool for someone who loves to micro manage every move of each team member - and you very much have to do this even for "trash" groups - but not me. I like to focus on managing my main character and set other party member AI scripts and let the PC run them - except for the hardest fights. In this game it is simply not possible as the team AI is dumb, while on the other hand enemy AI is sharp as a rezor. There were fights where my mage was dead before he was even able to cast a single spell. Add to this that you absolutely cannot pre-buff for a fight - like who on earth thought this would be a good idea, it makes no sense?!Same goes for the stats system. I have over 90h in this game and I still don't understand what half of the things do. You can compare items with the ones you are wearing but there is no indication of how it will affect your statistics - and believe me - it is not easy to determine this on your own because most stats doesn't stack. Thats right, you have to remember what bonuses all your other items have to know if the item you are looking for is an upgrade or not.Level balance is yet another issue, before the expansion came out I maxed level on each of my character by the end of act 3 (out of 4 in total) and I was pretty much looking at 1 full act worth of game being robbed of the character development aspect of the game. Seriously, no one calculeded avaialble XP to predict this can happen to somone who compleates all the side quests?Another problem is that sitting max level, I did not felt as a hero who laughs at any danger ahead and is destined to save the world from certain destruction - especially since I was playing severely underpowered mage. I was hoping for that excitement you get from casting Abi-Dalzim's Horrid Wilting on room full of enemies but it never came. Spells do look very appealing but their effect is - well - underwhelming to say it diplomatically.The other thing is that despite the story being interesting and writing good, the places you visit just don't seem alive. I see absolutely no reason why old school style RPG would abandon all the advancements that were introduced in the genre since Icewind Dale 2, especially knowing that Obsidian was working on projects like NWN2.While I still have no regrets that I backed this game, and no regrets that I got the expansions, I can't simply say it is a good game. It has serious gameplay mechanics issues at the design level, and I am not suprised because Obsidian tried to match complexity of modern AD&D system having maybe a year to achive this.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Before 2.0 I would have given this a recommendation. If they fix 2.0 I'll update it with a recommendation.Until then, steer clear, because:-Pathing in combat is broken. Your characters will refuse to go where you click, often going an entirely different direction if they move at all.-Various spells and powers don't work without setting AI to Aggressive (I don't want AI on at all), which is just silly.-Enemies randomly stop attacking and begin regenerating endurance rapidly. Sometimes combat music stops when this happens. Sometimes the re-aggro. Sometimes they don't.This is the majority of the problems, but there are other small issues that were introduced as well.I hope it's fixed. I really want to recommend this game because it was really good when it was playable. It's just a total mess right now. Combat is unavoidable at various points for many quests, so the whole game is borked at the moment.EDIT:I'm not removing the above, because the fact that it happened at all is a travesty, and should not be forgotten.I'm still leaving a negative review, because I realised something: I just don't care any more.The loading screens... by the time the next area loads, I've lost the will to live, let alone keep playing, and you'll see them A LOT, especially once you get to the city.Ye gods! The city. "Yaay, made to the city! Might be able to get some cool stuff, meet some important people, do some stuff!""Go run errands and fart around, then fight a horde of undead and necromancers that are nigh-impossible to kill until you level up. You'll need to run many more errands to become strong enough to fight them". I liked 'no combat xp' until this sort of thing kept happening. FORCED meta-gaming. THANKS.The stronghold is just... VIDEO GAMES! Why can I just spend money from a menu? Because VIDEO GAMES! Why do huge stone things just get fixed in days? Because VIDEO GAMES! Why do I just get _handed a castle_? VIDEO GAMES!The quests all start out sounding interesting, and end with some petty quibbling, a heavy-handed 'moral decision' that affects nothing, or some combat. That's it.All these cool mechanics. All this great lore... for a generic, two-dimensional (metaphorically speaking) game.Oh, and Obsidion relased 3.0 and changed just enough of the base mechanics of the game that I'd want to start over. Then I find out they're working on a licensed digital card game for ♥♥♥♥ing Pathfinder, when I knooow more bugs will creep in.I don't care any more, Obsidian. You've squandered the potential this game had.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												WARNING BEFORE YOU BUY THIS GAME; TL;DR - Incredible gameplay and story, with heartbreaking loading times FOR SOME COMPUTERS. Download a third-party mod to disable auto-saving for a semi-fix.Due to the auto-save feature requiring the saving of extremely large file sizes (gets worse as the game progresses) each time you load up a new or old area or even a house within that area there is a 1-2min load time. Sounds small, but there are a lot of areas in this game. This is so bad that there is a fairly successful mod designed to simply enable the ability to turn off the autosave feature - this mod has been updated 73 times (upon writing this). A simple fix of allowing the option disable the auto-save feature would make this game playable without mods. Note that mods are made redundant with each new update to the game - avoid updating the game until the mod is updated... THIS DOES NOT APPLY TO ALL COMPUTERS - check online first to see if someone else has had this problem with your system. I experienced this on a fairly old Mac, however I've read this happens with better systems as well. A quick bit of research could save you 20-50 bucks. The few hours I put into this game were incredible. The story, the combat, the difficulty and the progression are amazing. It's a shame that I had to cut it short because I don't feel like spending half my play-time on loading screens. Around about 15-20 hrs into the game the load times become unbearable.  It's a shame that the publishers decided to promote expensive DLC before doing (presumably) simple playability fixes on a game they've obviously put a lot of love into.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												Really, really frustrated with this game. Having been obsessed with the previous incarnations of the infinity engine, this the most recent, and by far the most disappointing of all of the gamesThe good:A well balanced class system, and a feeling of fairness in how mechanics work here.Owning a keep was fun.The bad:ENDLESS text wallsClunky and underdeveloped story (To be very clear, adding a♥♥♥♥♥♥load of useless information, doesn't constitute a story)The offensive comparisons to baldur's gate (Baldur's gate was/is so much better than this game I am rather shocked.)Why is it offensive? Because the story-line of Baldur's gate is epic, in an incredibly uplifting way. You feel awesome, your part god, and not just part god... you're partially the god of murder, and you can ascend to godhood. In this game, you have a strong soul, and you survive an odd soul storm. Your major goal in this game is to take that event...and undo it. I repeat, your goal is to undo the only thing that make your character unique. That is not exciting, and if you backed this game with high expectations... your probably going to have to hope Tides of Numeria does a better job.The constant feeling of the game being unfinished. Whether it's the nearly empty locations you can go to, or the party member quests being both tiny, or part of the main quest, you are left wanting. I repeat from above, comparing that to the 2-3+ hours you could spend on some of baldur's gate companions is offensive. Jaheria's quest/story-line in BG2 should be proof enough for that statement, see the rest of the BG cast for additional proof.The fact that I have been so frustrated with this game, that I wrote my first negative review, ever.I could continue, but 50$, and the time it's taken to hate this game, and to write this review is just making me more sad I pressed "Purchase"

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Ugh, i really wanted to like this game, but it's not for me. I've been a huge Baldur's Gate fan since forever ago, and i'm really happy that the genre legacy continues (since stupid Dragon Age keeps moving further and further away from it, i'm glad at least someone still tries making these types of games). But I just couldn't get into this one. I think if you're into hardcore d&d and read a ton of that kind of literature - you'll love this. For me the appeal of these games is combat and strategy and it just wasn't enticing enough here. I got so bored towards the end that i rushed through everything, skipping through every dialog.On an unrelated note i thought it was funny that they had that combat music that's pretty much straight out of De-Arnise keep (BG2). And Twin Elms had a theme that was very Kuldahar (Icewind dale).Pros: Baldur's gate gameplay. Story is not stupid and cheesy.You can create your own party and not have to use official companions.There is a bit of that keep management stuff (although not much).Decent amount of content.Some interesting combat ideas but read on for cons because those mechanics get meh further into the game.Party members have decently unique personalities. Even the bland♥♥♥♥♥elven mage was spiced up with a secret.Cons:Wayyyy too much reading: paragraphs and paragraphs of text on every dialog. That may be a pro for some people, but i've read enough in my lifetime and i'm tired of it.Combat mechanics too complicated (too many different defenses/resistances/stats/conditions, it may not be more complicated than modern d&d rules but d&d rules have been building up slowly for a long time, while this game just jumps straight into complicatedness.) And i either never found much explanation on how stuff works as far as damage application goes, or i found it and it was more paragraphs of text and i got bored reading it.Party members join up too easily and will never leave you, so there wasn't that much roleplaying with them, and also no alignment thing that dramatically restricts how the world perceives you, (yeah yeah there is reputation with different factions but i didn't notice much gameplay difference with that).Unique items: that's one of the main complaints i have. They weren't amazing enough or hard enough to get. I want stuff like Carsomyr +5 (BG2). You had to kill one of the hardest enemies in game for it, and only a specific class could use it, but once you get it - it makes a huge difference, (and then you can go after Kangaxx! :P). Here - i got so many clutter drops from enemies and every once in a while there was a small upgrade but it never really made a big enough impact.Anyway, overall this is not a bad game, and if Steam used a number rating i'd give it a 7 out of 10 maybe. But i didn't love it, i have no desire to replay it, and i wouldn't recommend it to any of my friends. It was like going to steak and shake late at night. Nothing else is open, and the milkshakes are good, but the service was mediocre at best and if I had a choice - i would have gone somewhere else.

												The good- Animations were top notch- The dungeons held a lot of neat secretsThe Bad- Most quest lines end up you just killing everyone- There is a "optimum" way to play- The stronghold is a huge waste of time and money- The story is VERY word heavy, the creators really don't understand the concept of show don't tell.- The resolution of most of the art is way to tiny, you're most often just gonna see lots of flashing lights and red pixels.- The class's are bland and unbalanced.- The backer NPC's may or may not ruin your experiance (varies from person to person)- Your party will only activly spot traps in scout mode- Scout mode is super slow- Party AI is is pretty bad, you will have to manually control them through a lot of the fights.- Party AI does not know how to use healing items, or items with special abilties- Party AI dosn't really know how to use healing spellsI may or may not have missed more good and or bad things to list, but it comes down to this. If your on the fence about buying this game, don't buy it. If you like reading lots of descriptions of characters features and actions, not to mention reading a lot of ingame books and in menu lore, read a book.If you like reading descriptions of people, places, and things, and indepth desciptions of people, places and things, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: February 9
												First of all, I love RPGs in general and I do enjoy games with lots of well-written and interesting text.But in my opinion, Pillars of Eternity's writing is neither really good nor is it interesting. I have played for about 20 hours and the main plot still is completely boring. My party consists of six members and only two of them have at least some personality. Most quests so far are shallow and don't feel impactful at all. It seems like every other NPC wants to tell you the story of his or her whole life for some reason, but when it comes to topics that could possibly be interesting or intriguing, they suddenly fall quiet and sparing with words.Overall, the conversations feel just far too wooden and humourless for me to be enjoyable. I'd definitely recommend you to watch a few videos about the game, so you can make sure that you actually like this style of writing. Otherwise playing such a text-heavy game will just be exhausting.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												Cannot recommend it. Can not hold a candle against old school RPG's like Baldurs Gate or the Black Eye (the very very old one). It looks okay on the first glance, but the deeper you go the more boring it gets. Sure, there's a ton of spells and recipes and skills. But all the spells are for damage or protection, the enhancements is just luck about what you will find (no foraging skills or anything like that). The levelups are to far between. The whole thing is more trying to confuse you in quantity instead of quality. That is also true for the group. 6 guys plus 1 pet and if you have a few creature spells you are with 12 guys in a fight. It's just to much. The AI is dumb as f*** and no matter what you activate, if you don't control each one of these guys by hand and tell them to use a special attack they really won't be efficient or use it clever at all. And so the fights become more of a bore then fun. And really, without the fights there isn't much left. The world feels stale. Characters just stand around doing nothing. Also finding quest givers is hard work, there is no indication where they could be.I can only imagine that the high ratings for this game come from the fact that there is simply no alternative if you like remotely this kind of game. But really, I prefer to pack out Baldurs Gate again then playing this crap any further.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												I really want to like Pillars of Eternity.  I really do!  I'd even go as far as to say that I've had lots of fun playing it, but having gotten this far in, I have to say, I don't think they finished this.  Let's go down the list...PROs: Character creation is robust and fun! It offers a lot of options, bonuses for character background, race, lots of standard and original classes, Really great on all levels, and the choices you make feel like they matter in a real way, being used not only to determine character stats, but NPC interactions and events in the world. The visuals are stunning! Arguments could be made as to why they would go back to prerendered backgrounds instead of a full 3D world, but whether for nostalgia or not, the end result can't be denied, the game LOOKS GOOD, and the world feels real, and lived in. Combat is engaging and tactically satisfying! Once you get a propper party together, it feels like a great accomplishment and mastery of the characters and classes you include feels meanigful and rewarding. When you take down that ogre or dragon, you know it was because of good decisions leading to that point, and it feels like an accomplishment. Party building! While you meet a lot of interesting, and thankfully not trying-too-hard-over-the-top characters along your journey, you can fill out the rest of the spots on your team with characters you build yourself. I was super excited when I discovered this! I've always loved character creation, and building adventuring parties, and this is a perfect example of it! Conversations that matter! While not always perfect, and often being wall of text-y, the conversations with NPCs seem to offer a lot of options, and are generally a really fun part of the game. Also, the long conversations or reserved for when they DO matter. No going through 5 pages of text every time you want to see a shop keeper.  The voice acting that's inclused for certain parts of the story is generally pretty good too.Now, the CONs: The "powers" you character recieves as part of the plot don't seem totally fleshed out. The parts that have to do with the main story, or quests seems fine, but there are various NPCs in the world you can use them on too...for no reason. They exist as nothing but walls of text. I guess if you really like reading short stories, it's alright, but none of it ever goes anywhere. There's no option to talk to any of these people, just "touch their souls" which leaves me wondering what all these characters think of some random person coming up and staring at the silently, them walking away. Nothing is well explained. I had to figure out a lot on my own, such as that I could even CREATE new characters for my team, or set my own party formations. Now, I'm old school, almost 40, and I've been well aquainted with Obsidian's past works, and am not adverse to opening a game's instruction manual, but a lot of these mechanics, integral to gameplay, should have been spelled out somewhere in the game. The stronghold, while an awesome feature, just isn't finished. I and many others have already run into numerous bugs and incomplete features when dealing with the stronghold (guards being "Currently Unpaid" seems a big one)  If there's something we should be doing different, it's, again, never explained anywhere, and just generally confusing.Now, while the pros definitely outnumber the cons here, the cons' existance is baffling to me.  When Obsidian announced that there game had gone "GOLD" I assumed these things would have been taken care of.  I, as a Kicksatrter backer had to wait a FULL YEAR longer than promised to play this game while it sat in Early Access, available to anyone who came along after the fact. The damaged customer experience that caused aside, this game frankly still feels like it's there.  Full of potential, but not quite complete.All in all, I could call it a decent game, but that's weighing in that I only paid $25 for it.  At $45 or more, it feels like the customer can expect a little more polish. With the Early Access thing,a nd this surprizing price tag, it just fels like Obsidian got greedy somewhere along the way, and maybe pushed the game out a little early to keep that money flowing.  I would have happily waited another year for a game that felt complete.  I just can't reccomend Pillars of Eternity as it is.

number of helpful: 23 of 43 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												A game in the vein of Baldurs Gate and Planescape: Torment sounds really awesome, but unfortunately it's not this one. It's not a bad game in itself, but considering the developer and their claim to fame it's quite a bit of a disappointment. If they had left out the references to Baldurs Gate and Planescape: Torment, kept expectation low and called it a "spiritual successor" to Icewind Dale all would be well. Compared to  Baldurs Gate this game lacks interesting characters, romances, combat mechanics, character scripting.. It's a long list, really. Cut short: The only thing these two games have in common is graphical by nature like graphic style, dialogue windows, fonts and loading transistions. Quite superficial.Compared to the masterpiece Planescape: Torment, this game feels like a fumbling rookie. There is a massive amount of content of which a lot is just useless filler, longwinded, dull and uninspired. Sometimes it feels as if the game was supposed to be a text adventure, because it describes everything you see. It suffers the same weaknesses as in the comparison with Baldurs Gate, the game simply lacks the passion, drive, point and intriguing gameplay. So what do you get? You can make a character from a wide array of classes, races and backgrounds of which nothing really matters. Along the way you can have people join you or you can go to an Inn and create all the characters you need by yourself, but the self-made ones don't have companion quests, of course. Each companion has a quest of a kind, but the characters themselves are really quite balanced, ordinairy and mundane. You will not find a Minsc, Edwin, Viconia, Korgan, Imoen, Dakkon, Morte or Annah here. There are no romances and all the companions are like wallpaper, somehow, without colour, edge or character. Combat is.. never gratifying. Mostly just a mess. Some builds work and some really don't. The leveling system is horrible. Combat is the meat of the game, but somehow it's mummified. You get virtually no Experience from kills and not really that much from quests either. It feels quite linear, that way. Sound is okay..Graphics are pretty, but dull and lifeless. Loading is slow even on SSD; I am confused. Tilt: Since I finished it. I have had absolutely no desire to play this game again. I played Baldurs Gate a least a dozen times, both good and evil and tried out pretty much every combo of companions, married them all or ditched them all.. Planescape: Torment; I finished at least a half a dozen of times and I really loved Annah.. There were some dialogues that really left me breathless.. This game is total crap in comparison. Shallow, boring and forgettable. What was it again?!Take away all the references to past awesomeness and you've got a fairly average follow-up to Icewind Dale. Why didn't they just slab an Icewind Dale 3 sticker on this game? Probably,  because it's not taking place in Icewind Dale, but seriously, why should that be a limitation for a game so limited?-- Edit: fixed a few minor typos and grammar ---

												I like this game, and it has a ton going for it. It's a fun RPG setting and an interesting story. I spent a lot of time on it (which makes #2, below, so bad). You can tell a lot of passion went into it.  It's very close to a 'yes' recommendation.But...  here's the reasons for a 'no':1) Loading screens and load time. One of my main NPCs (Eder) I took out of my party for a little bit, and when I put him back in, all of his gear was gone, he was level 1, and the next time I loaded, he was missing from my character roster completely. Losing an entire character with a lot of time-earned gear was very frustrating.3) The lore comes at you with an assumption that you already know some of it, or so it seems. It can be a bit overwhelming at first, throwing names of regions, races, gods, historical events, etc, at you. It might be a bit better paced, but that could be preference.4) Minor, but... The kickstarter backer NPCs. They're pointless, and they're all over the place (the first town is especially bad). I wish I was warned about them before reading like 15 of them (which I did because the 'soul reading' mechanic made me think they were important.)

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												So, if you're a fan of the classic Infinity Engine games such as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale then you're bound to feel at home here. A self-proclaimed spiritual successor to those titles, Pillars takes from them an enormous amount of what is good and familiar and applies a sleeker, modern veneer alongside a multitude of quality-of-life improvements.You probably know that already, though.So I'll just hit on a few things that I think worth mentioning:- Even though I was expecting something very familiar, the similarity to old IE games surprised me still. It really feels like they went out of their way to re-create that experience piece-for-piece.- The game took me just over 50 hours to complete, including all 15 levels of the Endless Paths of Od Nua and most (not quite all) side quests. This isn't bad, but it's not quite up to Baldur's Gate 2 in sheer scope of content, either.- The storytelling and art compliment each other well. The game is dark and atmospheric with a story that generally feels quite heavy while managing to avoid many fantasy RPG cliches. As far as the quality of narrative goes, this is one of the best in recent memory; better, I'd say, than nearly all D&D games.- I encountered a bug or two, but as of the time of this writing, nothing game-breaking.- I played on Normal for my first run through, and the difficulty seemed right on-par. Some encounters were challenging, many were not. The bosses weren't overwhelming, but didn't feel like complete push-overs either. Options exist to scale the difficulty upwards quite steeply, for those who do want an extreme challenge.- Many people are saying that the stronghold feels tacked-on. They're right, for the most part -- building it up doesn't feel terribly useful or rewarding. It's still neat, though. I'd rather have it there than not.- The way that combat experience works, you're awarded experience for killing new creatures up until a certain point (once the beastiary entry is completed). This is an interesting attempt to balance passive and aggressive play styles. It does seem to accomplish its goal, but I still think I would have preferred a traditional 'kill a mob, get some exp' system with a higher level cap. I hit 12 before the end of the content, after which fights began to feel a little more tedious.Overall, this is my favorite new game that I've played in a long time. It was great to be able to take (most of) the things I love about my favorite classic CRPGs and experience them as applied to a modern game and a new, awesome story.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I'm an oldschool rpg-fan with tons and tons of hours in Baldurs Gate and the like. So, of course I also bought Pillars of Eternity, but I have mixed feelings about it. On the one hand, they did a good job, I won't deny that. Loading Screens wherever you go is a HUGE pain in the a** but otherwise it is fine. Pathfinding in Combat could be better, too. I hope both will get better with later patches.I won't go into detail about the graphics. You like the look or you don't. It is obvious from every single screenshot or video available that this isn't the witcher 3. In my opinion they capture the spirit of the game very well.  The story is ok. I'm intrigued enough to read it and not just click away the pages, but I can't say that I feel a sense of immersion. The same with sidequests, solid, nothing too fancy. After some patchs a very good german translation btw. also I swithed back to english anyway.Combat is decent, although I feel like I'm using the same few moves over and over again. Than again I'm only Level 6 or 7 on normal difficulty, so I won't complain on that matter.The depth of character design is a bit overhyped in my opinion, as the idea of everyone being able to learn everything (not concrete skills, but things like mechanic, lore etc) makes planing in a complete party rather unnecessairy. The "exotic" chars like cipher or their version of the bard aren't exactly that new as the idea of building up one ressource (or time) to use special ability has been around at least since...well...forever I guess. I'd call the charaters solid again with some nice special abilities on the different races but nothing really innovative.So, what are, on the other hand, my problems?First of all the maps outside the villages feel rather empty. In BG2 there was quite a bit to discover, most (not all!) maps had their own little story. In PoE there seem to be a lot of "filler maps". Not saying that there aren't any tasks, but most of the maps I've visited so far required me to sneak on speed mode until I find a group of monster, kill it for various components and continue to the next group. Second point is the need for micromanagement. Yes, of course, I'm leading a group and it is supposed to feel oldschool. But why they had to go one step behind Baldurs Gate and remove the archetype automatics like "healer", "DD-Mage" and so on is beyond my grasp. Hack, even the automatic attack doesn't work half of the time. While I'm very sceptical of modern gaming in general, the posibility to assign a solid makro to your group and so reduce the tedious part of tactical planing to a pre-combat phase is something I really liked in games like the Dragon Age series or FF XII.Third point is that I somewhat dislike the choices they made for NPCs. Hard to explain and completely due to my own taste, but I simply don't care for them like I did for Minsc and Co. Could be a problem of being older, though ;)I compared PoE to B♥♥♥♥ lot because in my few BG2 is still the benchmark for epic group rpgs. In the end, I'd say PoE is one step forward from(technical issues, crafting, attitude system) but also two steps backwards. So, do I regret buying this game? No, absolutely not. It is fine and once I'm in the right mood I'm sure I will add something like additional 20 hours to finish my started playthrough and I will feel entertained while doing so. The devs definitely deserve my money for that, especially the ~20€ I paid for the hero edition on a sale. It is simply not what I hoped it would be.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												What started out as a relatively fun callback to classic isometric RPGs quickly becomes a very frustratingly dense experience. In the end, Pillars of Eternity taught me why a lot of these old RPG tropes have become extinct.I had fun with the game, relatively speaking, but in the end I spent way too much time being stumped by the way this game seems to enjoy complexity for the sake of complexity. There is so much reading to do in the initial character creation that it nearly turned me off, but I gave it a fair chance. The game seemed to be deep and it looked like a lot of fun... and then I had to restart my entire game because somehow I had gimped my character and the first actual combat I came across post-tutorial was completely unwinnable.By the midgame, I had grown incredibly weary of spending hours in each quest hub reading seemingly endless dialogue. It took me a few hours just to gather sidequests and orient myself. The story was convoluted, dry, and appeared to be going nowhere. The stronghold was a nuisance, rather than anything interesting. Combat had switched from a terrifying problem to a boring chore.By the endgame, combat had become more of a chore than anything, especially coupled with the amazingly terrible combat AI your party is equipped with. They don't like to listen to your directions, and they don't like to do anything that makes sense. The story had become so amazingly cloudy that I wasn't sure of the motivations of any of the characters. The final quest hub area was a pain. Combat was totally simple.And then, suddenly, the final boss battle was stupidly difficult and caused me to rage quit the whole thing altogether.I don't think this game was meant for me, even though I'm a fan of classic PC RPGs. It seemed to have all the weaknesses of Obsidian games with none of the strengths. I guess I endorse it because it is clearly a labor of love on the part of Obsidian, but I wouldn't put my full support behind it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Worth playing, with reservations.I backed the Kickstarter and feel I got more than my money's worth. If you've never played a CRPG before this would be a good one to start. There is a bit of a learning curve on the controls and you might want to customize and play around a bit, but once you get a handle on things the game flows and feels really good. My recommendation is to create custom NPCs as absolutely soon as you are able. The standard NPCs are not bad, but the more you can beef up your party in the early game the more fun you'll have with the battle system. Inventory management is adequate. The bottomless stash is a great concept, but there's still a lot of menu micromanaging. The story so far (about midway through Act 2) is solid enough, but pretty much all the dramatic context is buried in text. As such it requires real effort on the player's part to give a ♥♥♥♥ about what's going on. Even if you stop caring entirely, the battle system is still fun enough to justify playing. There is a ton of replay value in trying out different parties, builds, and choices. Ultimately an 8/10, and a solid 9.5/10 when you consider it was made on a Kickstarter budget.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												It is very honest and well executed successor of the Baldur's Gate series, but there are a few things that I find a bit disturbing:- the game mechanics when it comes to battle are a bit too fuzzy for my taste.You don't often get a sense of "whoa, I want this weapon" or "nice armor" that was one of the biggest things in Baldur's Gate series. In Pillars of Eternity it's more like "meh, I really don't know if this is an improvement or not and I don't really know what caused us to win the battle". It is a bit too fuzzy and unintuitive when it comes to battle mechanics. I enjoy more clear systems where +1 means something and you know you don't have enough points yet.- too many npcs in comparison to party size. I hate it when you have 3-4 characters waiting in line and you want to have chat with each one of them and play the story with each one of them but you can't because they don't fit in your active party. I'd either have fewer more intricate characters that I can play with at the same time instead of excess amount of characters that I have to juggle all the time in and out of the party to get everything out of themBut still recommended as the storyline is well written and atmosphere is really close to what made BG series so good. But doesn't get to Planescape: Torment level.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												I was a kick-starter backer for this game and am very happy with the end-result. Being a big fan of story-driven RPGs with nice gameplay elements this game fulfills both niches. A throwback to the 2d isometric hand drawn environments for those of us who are fans of nice illustrations.This is not the typical RPG we may be used to where we "kill ever bad guy or enemy" we come across. Albeit you can play it like that (I am heh), you'll just find it very difficult if you do if you're also on the hardest difficulty setting. For those who enjoy challenges this will definitely scractch an itch. But one may equally talk their way out of many hostile situations or simply avoid them.My only complains is that there's a bit too much side-content that draws me away from the main story for too long. Being a completionist I like to do every side-quest but occasionally I found myself rushing through them because I really wanted to get back to the main story. The fact that certain achievements are tied to these side-quests didn't improve matters, but hey I'm probably the only person who'd complain about too much content.If you enjoyed old-school rpg series like Buldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Torment you will definitely enjoy this game as well. Kudos to the devs developing a unique mechanic system since they couldn't very well use DnD rules :P.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												There should be a "maybe" or "depends" button on whether to recommend the game. Pros:  Awesome customization of characters that act and feel differentYou can create you own charactersThe difficulty is actually doing a good job of showing the difficulty.  Not like Wasteland 2 where it seemed like BS magic. The game is huge and in the cities at least, diverse.  You get your own castle.Fighting is fun and challenging.  Cons:  You can create your own characters and thus the characters you can pick up seem static and not worth talking to.    I like the old Baulders gate where your companions where unique, but here they are all the same.  Sadness.  Lack of good side quests.No ability to find stuff on the map.  You can get quests which take HOURS and HOURS to complete simply because you didn't talk to the right people in the right order.  So annoying.  This makes the game longer but not in a good way.  Bugs.  Lots of bugs.  At least when I played, I found several bugs such as the infinite fireball, that loaded back in when I came back to my keep.  I can thus never own my keep, because a fireball is going off in my dungeon all the time.  LOL.  So ya, if you have lots of time.  I HIGHLY recommend this game.  If you are going to only play an hour of this a night.  Stay as far away as possible.  The lack of map help for the quests is a killer.  Only a few quests I found ever showed up on the map.  It may sound lazy, and it is.  But I don't care.  I want map help.  I play for the story and fighting, not fetch quests.  My name is not Rover.  Sorry fan boys.

												You have to imagine that people have a very wide range of expectations about how a classic RPG should look like. PoE satisfies most of those by including a massive amount of optional content. Those complaints I read of in other reviews that aren't complete nonsense (due to that high amount of optionality), are  about the main story. For a large amount of time you will not know why you are doing what you are doing or how that would be helpful for solving the main quest. Partially that is because you are fighting a secretive organization with unknown goals, but it can be annoying nontheless. Or maybe its just a general problem with big RPG games, where people interupt the main story to fininsh side quests. So when you contine your main quest again after hours of side questing the story will not be as immersive as when you actually had to follow the main story strictly.

Posted: June 29, 2016
												The game plays brilliantly. You can spend hours exploring the maps, reading books (and I actually WANT to read books here, I never do in any games!), talking to people, exploring side quests, and you still have all of the main story line to go. The world is wonderfully atmospheric thanks to the level design. The characters you encounter are well written and the fact that there is not only voice acting involved but that the text is also written at the bottom of the screen (with annotations to the characters' facial expression, mood, change of tone etc) makes it feel a little like reading a book. If you can afford it, do get it at the regular price, you won't regret it. The current 60% off sale offer is SO worth it. The only thing that I don't like so far are the loading screens. They're a little bit too long. It doesn't break immersion for me, but it is noticable. Forget about any responsibilities you might have had - your only responsibility now is this game :D

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I'm an oldschool rpg-fan with tons and tons of hours in Baldurs Gate and the like. So, of course I also bought Pillars of Eternity, but I have mixed feelings about it. On the one hand, they did a good job, I won't deny that. Loading Screens wherever you go is a HUGE pain in the a** but otherwise it is fine. Pathfinding in Combat could be better, too. I hope both will get better with later patches.I won't go into detail about the graphics. You like the look or you don't. It is obvious from every single screenshot or video available that this isn't the witcher 3. In my opinion they capture the spirit of the game very well.  The story is ok. I'm intrigued enough to read it and not just click away the pages, but I can't say that I feel a sense of immersion. The same with sidequests, solid, nothing too fancy. After some patchs a very good german translation btw. also I swithed back to english anyway.Combat is decent, although I feel like I'm using the same few moves over and over again. Than again I'm only Level 6 or 7 on normal difficulty, so I won't complain on that matter.The depth of character design is a bit overhyped in my opinion, as the idea of everyone being able to learn everything (not concrete skills, but things like mechanic, lore etc) makes planing in a complete party rather unnecessairy. The "exotic" chars like cipher or their version of the bard aren't exactly that new as the idea of building up one ressource (or time) to use special ability has been around at least since...well...forever I guess. I'd call the charaters solid again with some nice special abilities on the different races but nothing really innovative.So, what are, on the other hand, my problems?First of all the maps outside the villages feel rather empty. In BG2 there was quite a bit to discover, most (not all!) maps had their own little story. In PoE there seem to be a lot of "filler maps". Not saying that there aren't any tasks, but most of the maps I've visited so far required me to sneak on speed mode until I find a group of monster, kill it for various components and continue to the next group. Second point is the need for micromanagement. Yes, of course, I'm leading a group and it is supposed to feel oldschool. But why they had to go one step behind Baldurs Gate and remove the archetype automatics like "healer", "DD-Mage" and so on is beyond my grasp. Hack, even the automatic attack doesn't work half of the time. While I'm very sceptical of modern gaming in general, the posibility to assign a solid makro to your group and so reduce the tedious part of tactical planing to a pre-combat phase is something I really liked in games like the Dragon Age series or FF XII.Third point is that I somewhat dislike the choices they made for NPCs. Hard to explain and completely due to my own taste, but I simply don't care for them like I did for Minsc and Co. Could be a problem of being older, though ;)I compared PoE to B♥♥♥♥ lot because in my few BG2 is still the benchmark for epic group rpgs. In the end, I'd say PoE is one step forward from(technical issues, crafting, attitude system) but also two steps backwards. So, do I regret buying this game? No, absolutely not. It is fine and once I'm in the right mood I'm sure I will add something like additional 20 hours to finish my started playthrough and I will feel entertained while doing so. The devs definitely deserve my money for that, especially the ~20€ I paid for the hero edition on a sale. It is simply not what I hoped it would be.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												What started out as a relatively fun callback to classic isometric RPGs quickly becomes a very frustratingly dense experience. In the end, Pillars of Eternity taught me why a lot of these old RPG tropes have become extinct.I had fun with the game, relatively speaking, but in the end I spent way too much time being stumped by the way this game seems to enjoy complexity for the sake of complexity. There is so much reading to do in the initial character creation that it nearly turned me off, but I gave it a fair chance. The game seemed to be deep and it looked like a lot of fun... and then I had to restart my entire game because somehow I had gimped my character and the first actual combat I came across post-tutorial was completely unwinnable.By the midgame, I had grown incredibly weary of spending hours in each quest hub reading seemingly endless dialogue. It took me a few hours just to gather sidequests and orient myself. The story was convoluted, dry, and appeared to be going nowhere. The stronghold was a nuisance, rather than anything interesting. Combat had switched from a terrifying problem to a boring chore.By the endgame, combat had become more of a chore than anything, especially coupled with the amazingly terrible combat AI your party is equipped with. They don't like to listen to your directions, and they don't like to do anything that makes sense. The story had become so amazingly cloudy that I wasn't sure of the motivations of any of the characters. The final quest hub area was a pain. Combat was totally simple.And then, suddenly, the final boss battle was stupidly difficult and caused me to rage quit the whole thing altogether.I don't think this game was meant for me, even though I'm a fan of classic PC RPGs. It seemed to have all the weaknesses of Obsidian games with none of the strengths. I guess I endorse it because it is clearly a labor of love on the part of Obsidian, but I wouldn't put my full support behind it.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												The combat system in this game is fresh and innovative; nearly all encounters are challenging and tactically fair. The difficulty is in line with BG, Wasteland, IWD, BG2, NWN, TOEE, Oblivion, NWN2, Fallout3, Skyrim, and Wasteland 2.I was nearly killed during my first Triple Crown (permadeath + 50% enemy stats + reduced metadata) attempt by equilevel enemies (sp Ogres), The priest was crushed to a pulp by the final-standing Ogre, following a relentless assault on Magor's fortitude. Man, I'm high strung, but my adrenaline was pumping as Eirglass kited that last Ogre with less than 20 HP. She was in this several-minute long kite that I wasn't sure she could succeed -- after all, the polygonal pathfinding of the AI in this game is second-to-none, which is to say, the pathfinding algorithm has been optimized to satisfy the most trivial case. Moreover, I suspect the game uses an inefficient purely functional game state (which despite it's many technical and political advantages, has managed to lose me at least a Belt of Might +3) which is slower than O(1); indeed I have an i5, GTX 570, and 600MBps SSD.Armored lightly by a robe, his service was succeeded by Walter the Holy Nut-Puncher, an unarmed priest of Wael,The first Moon-Goddess chanter Luna was slain, after which her more constitutional Lunie chased the party to achieve the justice unobtainable by Eder or that other priest of Magran. I mean. these other guys have a lot of excellent things to say. Most of the time, the dialogue between Kana and the druid are preferable to the quiet between Mr. Mage_A and Mrs. Cipher_B.Either way, I can be blamed for expending more than 200W * 200 Hours= 40kWH on this game. I'm still enjoying it.If we have to wait a year for the sequel, that will be evidence that the CRPG genre is dead. This is genuinely an excellent game, even if it's lacking the storytelling authorship of a Stephenson/Baxter/Vonnegut/Geothe/Shakespeare/God.If you have thought about your D&D tatctics for more than a half hour out of character, then there is no question that you will enjoy this game.BRB, gonna go get the best Arquebus in the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												I don't write reviews for games because I feel the need to keep my opinions to myself and let people exprience games for themselves and not be influenced by others to find themselves as a gamer. That beign said here it goes.I remeber playing thousands of hours just playing Baldur's Gate: Tales of the Sword Coast and Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn and it's expansion Throne of Baal. I remember Icewind Dale one and two. I remember playing Pool of Radiance: Ruins of Myth Drannor and other countless D&D and RPG titles like Niverwinter Nights. Very selddom does a game bring me back in a way to the feelings I had about those games. I love RPGs they, to me, embody what a game should be. It sucks you into your own world that is just yours, the decisions you make effect you, charatcers that have a special place in your heart, I'm talking about you, Minsc and Boo!This is one of those rare games that I play and I feel the magic I felt about games when I was a kid. The trail and error, the building a character and finding what playstyle works for that class, the dungeon crawls that I play for hours and don't realize it is time to eat. Instead of my mother calling me down for dinner it's my wife, or my kids sitting next to me going "Dad we are hungry can you pause it after you kill this monster?" and when I pause it they groan with annoyance that it needs to stop. Now instead of playing solo like when I was a kid I have 3 of my own to share the magic with, and the memories I make I now share with them. I hear their laughs as the characters banter as you walk through the cities and caves and forests.My oldest is now trying to battle her way onto my computer to play this game bcause it is like the games I loved when I was a kid. Simple yet complicated, easy yet hard, and it has all the makings of a classic. If you are a RPG fan or a fan of any of the Baldur's Gate games or Neverwinter Nights and you don't buy this game your are an idiot. This game will take you back to a time when games were amazing and not just good. I know I might catch some flak for that but how many games that have come out in the past 8 years have made you wanna go back and play them through 20 times? I can count the number on my hands. Yes there are fun games to play that are good for one maybe two play throughs but seldom suck me into my own world for hours and hours and hours of gameplay. I have about 50 hours on this game and I got it just a few days ago. I can't get enough and niether can my kids.While it has it's drawbacks like any game and they are few and far between, such as the double clicking inventory bug, but they are so few I have yet to find one that is game breaking. you can't even say that for Skyrim or any other RPGs that have come out within the past 5 years. If you don't like RPGs then this game is not for you, if you never played Baldur's Gate and never will this game is not for you. But if you love them and want a game that takes you back then get this game.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												A game I see myself replaying in the future; a well-crafted classic with just a few snags.I have come into my own as a gamer playing Baldur's gate II and Planscape Torment and spent good part of growing up with 3rd edition Dungeons and dragons. Even before this game came out, I enjoyed reading up on the dev's updates and how they were planning to tweak the game mechanics. A lot has changed since BG II and the game presents us with polished and improved battle mechanics that have less exploits and frustrating bits. That said, the devs did not try hard enough to make the game accessible to an inexperienced audience - the easy difficulty leaves the monsters' stats and battle rules unchanged, which means you still need to understand the mechanics and be able to adjust your strategy with every battle. On the other hand, the games offers several ways to scale up the difficulty, if that is something you desire.One of the goals this game set for itself was "mature storytelling" and I think they succeeded well enough. I mostly paid attention to the main story it and enjoyed it, which is rare for me. I tend to skip over text and not care that much what is happening between the banter with my party and all the monster-killing. One unattractive blemish is the issue of hollowborn children - basically a metaphor for disabled people who are nonverbal and need help with daily activities. In the game, these children are like this, because they are soulless. As a cognitively and developmentally disabled person I did not enjoy reading about people resembling me and my friends being inhuman. Unfortunately this is part of the main plot and as such unavoidable.The characters, which are one of the main draws of a game like this, were well executed. They range from cute to intriguing to deliciously hateable. Their personal stories are interesting, if a bit short. What I felt was lacking, was the depth of interaction you have with them as the PC and the interaction they have between themselves. The banter is funny, sure, but I am used to drama complete with hissy fits and threats of leaving the party (now I miss BG II).All in all - a good staple for those long weekends where you don't feel like doing anything.P.S.: At the time of writing this, I am almost done with the game. A few days ago White March II has come out, with a patch for the regular game. Unfortunately I can't comment on the changes right now, because there is no time left for me to explore them.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												Let me just preface my comments about Pillars of Eternity by saying that I played and completed Planescape Torment long ago, but still hold that game's story as the best that I have ever encountered in any game, RPG or otherwise. I am forever spoiled in that regard. Pillars narrative comes close, but does not quite hit the mark. There is a slight disconnect (perhaps by design?) that keeps it from hitting me in the gut the same way Planescape Torment did. However, it is much more complex, well-written and different enough from the usual run-of-the-mill plot you will find in it's peers. This is a rich, deep storyline, one in which the decisions you make as the player will determine the outcome. The isometric point-of-view provides value: strategic real-time combat that can be paused at any moment to issue orders (a must really), and an old school RPG feel that will give fans of Planescape Torment, the Baldur's Gate series, and the Icewind Sale series a tinge of nostalgia. You will encounter various NPCs, called companions, who can accompany you on your journey. Each one has a narrative that you can explore; this makes for a richer experience. While all are well written, some truly stand out, such as the Grieving Mother, Durance etc. The artwork in this game is fantastic. From the carefully crafted maps, the detail on the characters, and wonderful particle effects.Sound wise, I have no complaints. The soundtrack is atmospheric and the voice acting (especially for the companions) ranges from decent to excellent, nothing is subpar. If you are tired of saving the world from some great evil out to conquer it, time and time again, play this game. While the story won’t leave you thinking about it days after you complete it like Planescape Torment did, the journey is well worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Second try of writing a review as my first one was rather unforgiving...TLDR: Not wholy oldschool but pretty good. As a fan of the old infinity engine games you should really try it. Younger RPG lovers should also get it.Now I'm a seasoned Planescape and Baldur's Gate (also NWN) expert so I'll use those classics as reference in mind.Graphics are nice but old style, Divinity looked more modern but still every equipped armor shines neatly.Music is Conan style, no surprises but good and fits. Sounds like Baldur's Gate.Voice acting - good but we expected this.World and lore is a copy of forgotten realms essentially. Standard fantasy you'll feel right at home.Rule system is somewhat on par with D&D2 and slightly inferior to D&D3, no multi-classing either.Party, choice of the assorted fleshed out companions, those have a lot of personality, bicker as always and come with a quest. You can also create more adventurers for small coins if you rather want custom characters. Companions are on par with the averagely made Baldur's Gate companions say Corgan, Keldorn or Mazzy and better in cases. No Minsk, Imoen, Morte or Annah though.Quests - those are very good. The main story is high above average game standards. Souls, reincarnation, unearthing the past, all of that. After reaching act 2 the plot gains some depth.Yeah the game tends to the casual player, quest givers are conveniently next to locations, companions can hardly be missed, game is not really punishing, skill reset possible.  I hardly got lost and there are no riddles. You can out-level hard battles. Still you can break quests like by force-attacking friendly people which is even an option. I haven't seen such for years now. Still you can win battles by the skin of your teeth - I like that a lot.There's no good/evil but a Divinity like stoic/rational/passionate etc. rating system of character, those are heavily used in dialogues as are skill, attribute and background checks where Torment fans feel at home.Formations are in, companion AI is in, most gamebreaking is ironed out. One hang in all my playtime. Several difficulty settings, one deep optional dungeon, ton of loot. Stonghold - check. Crafting is in but really an afterthought. It's fair to say you won't be getting a better infinity engine-like RPG in a long time. 9/10

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												This game is for players who are looking to dump 100+ hours to complete an rpg game from 0-100% with little guidelines on how to do so.  The game expects you to talk to everyone, use every dialogue option and explore every nook and cranny of its relativly linear open world for a complete experience. Though the game has great dialogue options it feels that to get the "perfect" clear you have to play a nosey white knight that has a wiki in their back pocket telling them were to go, who to talk to and when to talk to them. Were I prefered rgps to have less guidelines and more open quests the game feels like it has some parts that are over developed and some parts that recived far less developement, starting areas and certain companions had a plethera of interesting interactions, well designed quests and fun easter eggs that you could find. I recomend taking an hour or so before you play the game to read indepth what each class gets and the recomended way to play them, this will allow you to make your ideal party and plan for level ups far into the future. Overall this game is about a 3/4 and though I wouldnt kick it out of bed for crackers I wish I could have seen so much more.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Second try of writing a review as my first one was rather unforgiving...TLDR: Not wholy oldschool but pretty good. As a fan of the old infinity engine games you should really try it. Younger RPG lovers should also get it.Now I'm a seasoned Planescape and Baldur's Gate (also NWN) expert so I'll use those classics as reference in mind.Graphics are nice but old style, Divinity looked more modern but still every equipped armor shines neatly.Music is Conan style, no surprises but good and fits. Sounds like Baldur's Gate.Voice acting - good but we expected this.World and lore is a copy of forgotten realms essentially. Standard fantasy you'll feel right at home.Rule system is somewhat on par with D&D2 and slightly inferior to D&D3, no multi-classing either.Party, choice of the assorted fleshed out companions, those have a lot of personality, bicker as always and come with a quest. You can also create more adventurers for small coins if you rather want custom characters. Companions are on par with the averagely made Baldur's Gate companions say Corgan, Keldorn or Mazzy and better in cases. No Minsk, Imoen, Morte or Annah though.Quests - those are very good. The main story is high above average game standards. Souls, reincarnation, unearthing the past, all of that. After reaching act 2 the plot gains some depth.Yeah the game tends to the casual player, quest givers are conveniently next to locations, companions can hardly be missed, game is not really punishing, skill reset possible.  I hardly got lost and there are no riddles. You can out-level hard battles. Still you can break quests like by force-attacking friendly people which is even an option. I haven't seen such for years now. Still you can win battles by the skin of your teeth - I like that a lot.There's no good/evil but a Divinity like stoic/rational/passionate etc. rating system of character, those are heavily used in dialogues as are skill, attribute and background checks where Torment fans feel at home.Formations are in, companion AI is in, most gamebreaking is ironed out. One hang in all my playtime. Several difficulty settings, one deep optional dungeon, ton of loot. Stonghold - check. Crafting is in but really an afterthought. It's fair to say you won't be getting a better infinity engine-like RPG in a long time. 9/10

												This game cemented the return of the infinity engine CRPG (for those that don't know what this is, it's a real time battle system that allows pausing to issue commands to a team of 4-6 adventurers of different classes to make a well ballanced killing machine)I had not played an IE game before this one, but I grew up on table top wargames so it appealed to my straight away.If you, like me missed Baldurs gates and Ice wind dales the first time around, but want to see what it's all about, Pillars of eternity is the perfect starting point as it's not hindered at all by out of date UI's and such.I fell in love withn the game almost imediately, it's beautiful hand draw invironments, the in depth class system and well written story, detailed lore, it's all here.Since the sucess of this game, more games are starting to appear like sword coast, using a siumilar system. PoE is the original in terms of bringing back an almost dead genre. Whether you're new to IE or a vet who played all the originals, you will feel at home here.For a nos BS, roots RPG experience, look no further. My game of the year so far and also one of the best combat experiences I've had in any gameIf you're tired of AAA, watered down nonsence, all our old favourites being made more action orientated to appeal to the masses, get on board with a real game like Pillars Of Eternity and show the devs some love..If you want a future of gaming that isn't shaped by COD-loving teenagers, "Frag-Master-Camper" get on board with the Renicance revival, buy this♥♥♥♥♥♥now, smoke a fat bag and enjoy.thank me later.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												What started out as a relatively fun callback to classic isometric RPGs quickly becomes a very frustratingly dense experience. In the end, Pillars of Eternity taught me why a lot of these old RPG tropes have become extinct.I had fun with the game, relatively speaking, but in the end I spent way too much time being stumped by the way this game seems to enjoy complexity for the sake of complexity. There is so much reading to do in the initial character creation that it nearly turned me off, but I gave it a fair chance. The game seemed to be deep and it looked like a lot of fun... and then I had to restart my entire game because somehow I had gimped my character and the first actual combat I came across post-tutorial was completely unwinnable.By the midgame, I had grown incredibly weary of spending hours in each quest hub reading seemingly endless dialogue. It took me a few hours just to gather sidequests and orient myself. The story was convoluted, dry, and appeared to be going nowhere. The stronghold was a nuisance, rather than anything interesting. Combat had switched from a terrifying problem to a boring chore.By the endgame, combat had become more of a chore than anything, especially coupled with the amazingly terrible combat AI your party is equipped with. They don't like to listen to your directions, and they don't like to do anything that makes sense. The story had become so amazingly cloudy that I wasn't sure of the motivations of any of the characters. The final quest hub area was a pain. Combat was totally simple.And then, suddenly, the final boss battle was stupidly difficult and caused me to rage quit the whole thing altogether.I don't think this game was meant for me, even though I'm a fan of classic PC RPGs. It seemed to have all the weaknesses of Obsidian games with none of the strengths. I guess I endorse it because it is clearly a labor of love on the part of Obsidian, but I wouldn't put my full support behind it.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												The combat system in this game is fresh and innovative; nearly all encounters are challenging and tactically fair. The difficulty is in line with BG, Wasteland, IWD, BG2, NWN, TOEE, Oblivion, NWN2, Fallout3, Skyrim, and Wasteland 2.I was nearly killed during my first Triple Crown (permadeath + 50% enemy stats + reduced metadata) attempt by equilevel enemies (sp Ogres), The priest was crushed to a pulp by the final-standing Ogre, following a relentless assault on Magor's fortitude. Man, I'm high strung, but my adrenaline was pumping as Eirglass kited that last Ogre with less than 20 HP. She was in this several-minute long kite that I wasn't sure she could succeed -- after all, the polygonal pathfinding of the AI in this game is second-to-none, which is to say, the pathfinding algorithm has been optimized to satisfy the most trivial case. Moreover, I suspect the game uses an inefficient purely functional game state (which despite it's many technical and political advantages, has managed to lose me at least a Belt of Might +3) which is slower than O(1); indeed I have an i5, GTX 570, and 600MBps SSD.Armored lightly by a robe, his service was succeeded by Walter the Holy Nut-Puncher, an unarmed priest of Wael,The first Moon-Goddess chanter Luna was slain, after which her more constitutional Lunie chased the party to achieve the justice unobtainable by Eder or that other priest of Magran. I mean. these other guys have a lot of excellent things to say. Most of the time, the dialogue between Kana and the druid are preferable to the quiet between Mr. Mage_A and Mrs. Cipher_B.Either way, I can be blamed for expending more than 200W * 200 Hours= 40kWH on this game. I'm still enjoying it.If we have to wait a year for the sequel, that will be evidence that the CRPG genre is dead. This is genuinely an excellent game, even if it's lacking the storytelling authorship of a Stephenson/Baxter/Vonnegut/Geothe/Shakespeare/God.If you have thought about your D&D tatctics for more than a half hour out of character, then there is no question that you will enjoy this game.BRB, gonna go get the best Arquebus in the game.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												One of the retro RPG games quite similar to Dragon age Origins. You command created character (you) that travels through the world to uncover deep mystery. While doing so you do many side quest and tasks and find (or create) other companions. You can go with up to 5 another champions in your adventure party (total party size is 6) while others take care of your keep which you are repairing from by enemies infested ruin to glorious castle.>> Pros+ Deep characters system (stats, classes, etc.). You even develop reputations (like honest, diplomatic or aggressive) by way you interact with NPCs.+ Way you created and developped your character is reflected in conversation choices available to you. This means if you create different type of character you can have different experience while playing again.+ Story is strong and well told.+ Combat feels balanced and rewarding.+ Graphics is simple yet nice with no extreme hardware requirements so you can play it on notebook.+ No internet connection required for play.+ Several difficulty settings that can be combined. It is not just basically divided into easy->hard options but you can turn on or off several difficulty features as well.>> Cons- Sometimes too many text to read.- Only few texts are voiced (some texts are only part voiced which feels really strange).- Extremely stupid AI of both your companions and opponents in combat. Characters stucking when available path is just next to them, going somewhere for no reason or just staying idle while few meters away there is battle is shamefully frequnt.- Poor auto management of characters automatic behaviour in combat. You can't tell what abilities your character can use like in Dragon Age but you can only pick template like "Aggresive" or "Support" which mostly doesn't meet your expectations and you are forced to handle all champions yourself, which is exhausting after several time.If you like to care mostly only your character, 2 last points above are really irritating. If you like to manage all your champions yourself they hardly matter.>> Pros or Cons? (depends on your personal taste)o No free world. You have system of little maps connected by their borders. In the end there is very little of true exploration because on every piece of living space there is something.o Nothing hold your hand in terms of quests means no arrows, question marks or explamation marks. You must find your quests by talking NPCs around and if you wish to not miss any you need to talk them all through. It's similar to Divinity Original Sin.o I personally found crafting useless except enhancing weapons which is exact opposite and is necessary.If you like those types of RPGs it is a good choice. If you like retro type games (no hand holding) do not hesitate a second, you will love it. It is not game for everyone though as it may seem slow and boring for modern type gamers used to Diablo 3 or Dragon Age Inquisition like games.

												Great game. Much more interesting combat system than in Baldur's Gate. Though it is not polished well so sometimes battles look like you are a lumberjack in the woods. And that trully pays for regular grinding. The plot raises some questions about religion so some might consider playing it for some theological interest.  Nicely polished dialogs and great sound!

content:
Posted: January 8
												Let me just preface my comments about Pillars of Eternity by saying that I played and completed Planescape Torment long ago, but still hold that game's story as the best that I have ever encountered in any game, RPG or otherwise. I am forever spoiled in that regard. Pillars narrative comes close, but does not quite hit the mark. There is a slight disconnect (perhaps by design?) that keeps it from hitting me in the gut the same way Planescape Torment did. However, it is much more complex, well-written and different enough from the usual run-of-the-mill plot you will find in it's peers. This is a rich, deep storyline, one in which the decisions you make as the player will determine the outcome. The isometric point-of-view provides value: strategic real-time combat that can be paused at any moment to issue orders (a must really), and an old school RPG feel that will give fans of Planescape Torment, the Baldur's Gate series, and the Icewind Sale series a tinge of nostalgia. You will encounter various NPCs, called companions, who can accompany you on your journey. Each one has a narrative that you can explore; this makes for a richer experience. While all are well written, some truly stand out, such as the Grieving Mother, Durance etc. The artwork in this game is fantastic. From the carefully crafted maps, the detail on the characters, and wonderful particle effects.Sound wise, I have no complaints. The soundtrack is atmospheric and the voice acting (especially for the companions) ranges from decent to excellent, nothing is subpar. If you are tired of saving the world from some great evil out to conquer it, time and time again, play this game. While the story won’t leave you thinking about it days after you complete it like Planescape Torment did, the journey is well worth it.
