number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												I guess the first thing you would notice is that I have very little time with this game. That is true and that is why I'm writing this review now. I have tried five or six times to get into the game and found it just wasn't for me. To me, there is nothing worse in game reviews (or any review) than "this game sucks" or "I wasted my money". That is not helpful to anyone and incredibly short sighted. This game is exceptional for what it sets out to be. I don't have enough time with it to speak to bugs or issues within the game itself. As poilished as it is; I suspect there aren't many if any at all.So look, the fault lies with me. It just didn't fit my likes for RPG type games and that in no way reflects on Obsidian or Pillars in any way. I know other reviews have criticized people like me saying that we just cant be bothered with reading and maybe there is something to that. I read science fiction and fantasy books, started out gaming on Infocom titles that were text only in the 80s, and somewhere along the way found that stopping the game minute after minute to read a page full of storyline takes me right out of it. That's just me.Pillars to me was a heck of a lot of reading with brief snipits of combat thrown in. I felt more like I was reading a "choose your own adventure" type book than playing a game. The combat to me was not what I enjoy in a game. I'm sure others love it, but I don't need to pause and use this, pause and do that. That's just me. :)I don't think there is any question that Pillars is far deeper and far more story driven than most other rpg's out there. But, we all have different aspects of a game that matter to us the most. I tend to enjoy faster paced games that move out. I enjoyed the hell out of Titan Quest, the Diablo series, Torchlight 1 and 2, and I'm loving Grimm Dawn. Those (I think) tend to put more "A" in arpg.Regardless of what I spent on this title, it was in no way a waste of money to me. I tried it, didn't like it, moved on. It's not the fault of the game or the development team that my tastes differ. Bottom line: If my purchase in some small way helps promote the development of role playing games going forward...I'm all for it. We're all better off as a result.All that said, I am absolutely recommending this game because it is a great game. I have nothing bad to say about it. Fantastic job with the bits I saw in game. But, if you are into action rpg's and you identify with the games I've listed above, I'm not sure you'll feel at home here.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												After spending around 60 hours with this game, I'd have to say that I absolutely love it. Having not played any of the decades-old isometric rogue-like games, I didn't have much in terms of nostalgia for this type of game to bias my initial opinion, though I very much loved Divinity: Original Sin which came out much more recently. Plain and simple, this game is not for everyone. The combat is hard but very deep and rewarding once you learn the ins and outs of the mechanics and statistics. I've put in almost 60 hours, with one restart after the first 5 hours or so to try a different class, and I've only gotten through 2 of the 4 acts of the game. The game world is large, yet incredibly packed with stuff to do, people to meet, and big baddies (or goodies) to kill and loot!The only real cons in my opinion are:1) The AI pathing is kinda totally borked. In tight spaces, you and your companions rarely take the route you expect them to take, and while this is slightly frustrating on its own, it wouldn't be so bad except when combined with...2) "Engagement" - People who haven't played yet won't understand this much, but essentially during combat your characters are locked in place with the first melee fighter they come in contact with, and if you move your character away, the enemy gets essentially a free, immediate, hit. I wouldn't mind this mechanic if there were a way for your melee classes to pull aggro off of other characters so that you can attempt to control the battlefield better, but this seems to not exist (although admittedly I haven't played all variations of all classes, so the talent may be there somewhere, I just haven't seen it). Needless to say, combined with #1, it is frustrating to attempt to position your characters during a fight so that your melees engage the enemy melees, then have your glass cannons in the back accidentally be engaged because whoops now they're in the front because your melee character decided to go frolick in the flowers.3) No friendly combat AI option available. This one is a nit-pick, but for me there were many fights which didn't need my direction every second, but I wish the companions would use their abilities as necessary. I wish there was at least an "enable companion use of 'per encounter' abilities". Micro-management is fun during tough encounters, but for the more trivial ones, I wish there was more of an autopilot setting.4) No monk, barbarian, or rogue companions unless you hire them as adventurers (with no dialogue). Particularly monk and rogue companions would have been a great plot addition in my opinion.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												If you loved Baldur Gate series then this will be the game you're looking for.  From it's beautiful rich environments, great story line, and intriguing companions, the game brings you into a great new world to immerse yourself in.  Some small game mechanics are still a bit wonky (pathing for your companion AI is one) but it barely bothered me.  The new system with Endurance vs. Health was strange but refreshing and by the end I actually loved the idea of it.  One of the biggest problems I had in BG series was the need to rest everytime I had my wizards use their spells, however in POE that wasn't an issue at all.  The same problem applied for health in BG but again, in POE with the Endurance vs Health system it drastically cut the need for me to be resting all the time to replenish 'health'.Another part of the game I loved was the different routes of personality you could take in this game.  The many different options to reply ingame allowed for multiple ways situations could play out.  Also if you didn't care for any of the ingame companions AT ALL you could hire/creat your OWN PARTY.  I don't know why you'd want to do that though...Eder/Aloth/Durance for life.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I personally loved the game.  It certainly captures the feel of the IE games, particularly the first Baldur's Gate.  The art style is gorgeous, particularly when water is on the screen.  Your companion characters are interesting and well written.  I feel like Eder in particular is likely to become an all timer companion.  Make sure to use a variety of them, their responses in conversation with other NPCs can be great, particularly Kana.  The game handles well, although at times the combat can get a little chaotic.  Make sure to use the auto pause options to slow things down if you need to.  The main story is also great, dealing with the Gods and a curse effecting the region's children.  Basically, if you like the IE games, or just well written party-based RPGs, be sure to give PoE a try.

Posted: April 23, 2015
												A wonderful walk back to the days of issometric non 3D cRPGs. Wonderful draw graphics, great music and enviroment. And a not too bad story. Overall not perfect, but what is. Still I really enjoyed it and I also enjoyed finishing it and it never felt like a real drag.My really negative points here are mostly the constant load screens when switching areas. This can get really tedious when you are in a city and need to go from the second floor from one building to another in a nother district. That is five load screens. And I do no think that would have been necessary. Divinity: Original Sin did it without.Second would be the spells. There are too many and a lot of them feel just too similar with no big difference. You pretty much use you standard spells and thats it. There is no need to change or use different ones because the enemy has some certain high protection against it.The path finding can be really atrocious and often very hampering during battle. Too often one character is stuck because the AI is too stupid to walk around some object.Still, with all those complaints, I would highly recommend it to anyone who like cRPGs. I hope we get some really nice extensions to this. Or even something like a part II that will be so super awesome like Baldurs Gate II was over Baldurs Gate I.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												(NO SPOILERS)EDIT: I have since played Pillars to completion multiple times, and can now offer a more satisfactory review. STILL, I'll leave the old review down here for future reference.>>OLD REVIEW<<<This is a great game that combines many of the aspects we enjoyed from old-school CRPGs like Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights... ...except, I found myself that I am too old and lacking in time to enjoy games such as these anymore. And it is a crying shame, because from what I've played, Pillars of Eternity gets the formula just right, as expected of Obsidian. As such I must warn you that I barely even scratched this game's surface, but from what I've played, it's stupendous.>>NEW, UPDATED REVIEW<<It's great.I just didn't enjoy it.It's the mechanics, mostly. They just didn't click with me. It's to be expected. I unfortunately completely missed the Infinity Engine games when I was young, and so didn't develop an early taste for the classics, such as Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment and all that.So - yes. The moment-to-moment gameplay felt like a chore to me. This is a COMPLETELY SUBJECTIVE NOTION and shouldn't be taken as an absolute. That's the reason I'm still giving this a positive review, and with a wide berth at that. Yet - I -had- to play it. I loved Tyranny to bits. It felt like Pillars-lite to me, and the mechanics clicked nicely with my preferences, even though they're not THAT different from it's spiritual predecessor. However, I realized that that game would probably never get a sequel, right around the time that Pillars 2's crowdfunding campaign came out. When I learned that it would import saves and decisions directly from the first game, I just had to buckle up and play it - four times, to be precise.It is with no shame at all that I'll say that I cheated all the way through. That's why I have no achievements, even though I spent quite a bit of time playing it. I had no love for the mechanics - I was just there because I'm a huge sucker for Obsidian's storytelling. In that, I can confidently say that Pillars did not disappoint. Not even a bit.My main, not-so-subjective criticism: Pillars isn't your babies' first medieval fantasy. There's a lot of very interesting lore all over the place. The problem being, that the game's first act is painfully, grindingly slow, and takes a while to hook you in. That's what turned me off in the beginning. Once I got past that, I was in the clear, and every morsel of lore felt like a reward.That's it, really. I won't spoil anything, so I'll just go ahead and say that the journey was long and at times painful - but definetly worth it if you're a fan of Obsidian's stuff. The story is compelling, the characters are universally fun and well-crafted (Well. Some more than others - looking at you, two characters written by Chris Avellone that are really hard to NOT keep in my party), and if you're a fan of the Infinity Engine cRPG formula, you're in for a blast.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Probably the best RPG experiences I've had to date. My first playthrough was on Hard difficulty, and I'm working on a PoTD playthrough. Pros: -character building is impactful, unique (the interaction between stats happens in a way I haven't seen before), and fair. There are a lot of viable ways to build your party. The key is balance and having ways to solve certain types of puzzles. -Story is pretty good. and the choices your pc makes affect what happens in the world pretty significantly. I really enjoyed the ending :) -Fights are (in my opinion) quite fun in a technical way. Some of the basic mobs have really "interesting" traits that force you to think a bit. It's hard to cheese unless you build your party specifically for hit and run strats. Additionally, the game does a good job of mixing the mob types and environments to present some surprising challenges. Particularly in the expansions.-No experience for killing people, avoiding the common rpg pitfall of "complete the quest then kill everyone" with a gating mechanic. -Lots of well written and interesting side quests-Dev commentary is cool! -Puzzles that you can actually solve without a wiki ::glares at divinity::Cons: -NPC attributes are locked in. This feels bad, since the NPCs are so much more interesting than custom characters. -Last area feels like it's not fully fleshed out. -DLC content throws off the scaling of the game. You can adjust to improve enemy strength, but either way a well built party will make the game trivial later on (besides bosses, which always require planning + attention). I felt that the balance of the game was spot on before doing WM. -Lack of good attribute choices at the highest character levels. In a lot of cases you'll end up just taking stuff you ignored for better things at previous levels. Definitely recommend for anyone who likes a mental challenge and doesn't mind a lot of reading.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												PILLARS OF ETERNITY a fabulous rpg which has tons of stats and classes with layers of graphical depth to make one's character unique and their own in every way possible. Exploration and combat are excellent with graceful smooth interaction which enhances the magic and wonder of discovery with the contrasting explosive tense combat. It is a much welcomed evolutionary step up from the BALDUR'S GATE series of old.Music is soothing and transcending touching the mind with soft kisses from another world. Graphics are thick with endless variety and detail making the world feel alive with sensual delights and death threatening terror. Lighting is a mixture of the surreal, eerie and haunting casting a shimmering glow upon dungeon walls and lighting wooded areas with torches that can also be used in combat to set enemies on fire. Ancient machines glow with futuristic energies from unimaginable dimensions where time seems to have been shattered as glass into a nullified state where it has no bearing. Nights are a spooky neon blue or romantic velvet blue for the lovers out there.Voice acting makes me connect with my character and the npcs of the world triggering emotional moments whenever the unexpected happens. Alongside the incredibly well written grim story and theatrical effects like dramatic music while cutscenes play out or a battle is about to begin these are some of the best things about Pillars Of Eternity.I love how pausing was implemented during combat and how it can be turned on or off in the options menu. Combat is very fluid along with movement and has a certain action packed motion to it making one thirst for more battle which in turn made me want to explore every nook and cranny of the world not only for treasure,alchemy ingredients,supplies,npc interaction etc but for lethal visually stunning death dealing encounters.Another great thing are the options for people who suffer color blindness as well as font scaling to make text bigger which is great for.. older eyes :) You can also set up the pace of combat and many other things in the options menu to make things as comfortable as you want them to be according to your play style.Writing is truly stunning in its excellence. Its on a level of high caliber literature bringing the story home with the sizzling steak appeal of a LORD OF THE RINGS movie. Characters come across with endless range of personality making them very likeable even if they are scoundrels. Best writing i have seen in a rpg in ages since PLANESCAPE TORMENT complimented perfectly by top notch professional voice acting.Indeed PILLARS OF ETERNITY is a beautiful and shocking harsh world which draws one in and does not let go in its seductive hug er i mean grip yea BONE CRUSHING GRIP. Before i knew it three hours had passed and i was still hankering for more but alas real life needs a chore or two done :)If your looking for a very intense modern day Baldur's Gate style experiance with a different combat system with its mix of pause/turned based action Pillars Of Eternity is the rpg to satisfy the dnd fever in you with mind blowing writing fleshing out a grueling story of a brutal world where every day is a dark journey to survive.Thank you OBSIDIAN and congratulations on your magnificent creation.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Old school RPG for the modern times.You will feel right at home if you ever enjoyed games like Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Icewind Dale and the original Fallout. If you never played such games, here's what you need to know:This a Classic Isometric RPG and it doesn't focus on action, but rather STRATEGY and MICROMANAGEMENT. As such, it could be overwhelming to those new to the genre, however the developers have managed to make it accessible to everyone with a wide selection of difficulty options that range from "almost godmode" to "dark souls on cocaine". Also the narrative is delivered through text. A LOT OF TEXT. Seriously there's enough to read here to fill a novel and if you don't like reading, you'll be in trouble. The plot is good, albeit not mindblowing, but what is worth praising is the detailed Lore created for this game.PROs+ Amazing pre-rendered 2D backgrounds packed with details+ Music fits perfectly with the high fantasy genre+ Loads of details in the lore and narrative+ Lots of hours of gameplay, especially with the expansion+ Works great on older systemsCONs- The lore is dumped on you quite abruptley and can cause confusion in the beginning (it gets clarified later on)- Central plot could've been more interesting- Minor inaccuracies in the in-game descriptions of items and spells- Steep learning curve on account of the lackluster tutorialsEasy to find at a decent discount these days, worth every cent!

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												Played the game 3 times through. Twice without the addons and 2 times on PotD. I ♥♥♥♥ing loved it!The gameplay is great! Wonderfully created locations, rich with detail and supported with beautiful music that let's you immersively sink into the INSANELY deep lore. Characters come across differently, you earn a reputation and make decisions which change dialogue options and events as the game goes on. Combat is great and challenging. Encounters feel different every time. 2/3 runs of mine were on the highest difficulty and it was always fair. You had to plan everything, make use of traps, potions, crafting, scrolls, debuffs, etc but at NO point ever was it unfair. I always went for immersion, none of my 2 PotD chars were minmaxed!9/10-1 point for little details, that could have made immersion a little little bit better. Like the choice to make AoE completely INT-based, which meant that barbarians had high Intellect (RP-wise nonsense). Same for various reputations which got seperate numerical values. So you could have Deceptive 3 and Honest 4 and get a comment on your deceptive 3 or honest 4 reputation rather than a Honest 1-comment.But after all I would TOTALLY recommend this game! It'll be a great experience!

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												I guess the first thing you would notice is that I have very little time with this game. That is true and that is why I'm writing this review now. I have tried five or six times to get into the game and found it just wasn't for me. To me, there is nothing worse in game reviews (or any review) than "this game sucks" or "I wasted my money". That is not helpful to anyone and incredibly short sighted. This game is exceptional for what it sets out to be. I don't have enough time with it to speak to bugs or issues within the game itself. As poilished as it is; I suspect there aren't many if any at all.So look, the fault lies with me. It just didn't fit my likes for RPG type games and that in no way reflects on Obsidian or Pillars in any way. I know other reviews have criticized people like me saying that we just cant be bothered with reading and maybe there is something to that. I read science fiction and fantasy books, started out gaming on Infocom titles that were text only in the 80s, and somewhere along the way found that stopping the game minute after minute to read a page full of storyline takes me right out of it. That's just me.Pillars to me was a heck of a lot of reading with brief snipits of combat thrown in. I felt more like I was reading a "choose your own adventure" type book than playing a game. The combat to me was not what I enjoy in a game. I'm sure others love it, but I don't need to pause and use this, pause and do that. That's just me. :)I don't think there is any question that Pillars is far deeper and far more story driven than most other rpg's out there. But, we all have different aspects of a game that matter to us the most. I tend to enjoy faster paced games that move out. I enjoyed the hell out of Titan Quest, the Diablo series, Torchlight 1 and 2, and I'm loving Grimm Dawn. Those (I think) tend to put more "A" in arpg.Regardless of what I spent on this title, it was in no way a waste of money to me. I tried it, didn't like it, moved on. It's not the fault of the game or the development team that my tastes differ. Bottom line: If my purchase in some small way helps promote the development of role playing games going forward...I'm all for it. We're all better off as a result.All that said, I am absolutely recommending this game because it is a great game. I have nothing bad to say about it. Fantastic job with the bits I saw in game. But, if you are into action rpg's and you identify with the games I've listed above, I'm not sure you'll feel at home here.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												I was a kick-starter backer for this game and am very happy with the end-result. Being a big fan of story-driven RPGs with nice gameplay elements this game fulfills both niches. A throwback to the 2d isometric hand drawn environments for those of us who are fans of nice illustrations.This is not the typical RPG we may be used to where we "kill ever bad guy or enemy" we come across. Albeit you can play it like that (I am heh), you'll just find it very difficult if you do if you're also on the hardest difficulty setting. For those who enjoy challenges this will definitely scractch an itch. But one may equally talk their way out of many hostile situations or simply avoid them.My only complains is that there's a bit too much side-content that draws me away from the main story for too long. Being a completionist I like to do every side-quest but occasionally I found myself rushing through them because I really wanted to get back to the main story. The fact that certain achievements are tied to these side-quests didn't improve matters, but hey I'm probably the only person who'd complain about too much content.If you enjoyed old-school rpg series like Buldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Torment you will definitely enjoy this game as well. Kudos to the devs developing a unique mechanic system since they couldn't very well use DnD rules :P.

												Probably the best RPG experiences I've had to date. My first playthrough was on Hard difficulty, and I'm working on a PoTD playthrough. Pros: -character building is impactful, unique (the interaction between stats happens in a way I haven't seen before), and fair. There are a lot of viable ways to build your party. The key is balance and having ways to solve certain types of puzzles. -Story is pretty good. and the choices your pc makes affect what happens in the world pretty significantly. I really enjoyed the ending :) -Fights are (in my opinion) quite fun in a technical way. Some of the basic mobs have really "interesting" traits that force you to think a bit. It's hard to cheese unless you build your party specifically for hit and run strats. Additionally, the game does a good job of mixing the mob types and environments to present some surprising challenges. Particularly in the expansions.-No experience for killing people, avoiding the common rpg pitfall of "complete the quest then kill everyone" with a gating mechanic. -Lots of well written and interesting side quests-Dev commentary is cool! -Puzzles that you can actually solve without a wiki ::glares at divinity::Cons: -NPC attributes are locked in. This feels bad, since the NPCs are so much more interesting than custom characters. -Last area feels like it's not fully fleshed out. -DLC content throws off the scaling of the game. You can adjust to improve enemy strength, but either way a well built party will make the game trivial later on (besides bosses, which always require planning + attention). I felt that the balance of the game was spot on before doing WM. -Lack of good attribute choices at the highest character levels. In a lot of cases you'll end up just taking stuff you ignored for better things at previous levels. Definitely recommend for anyone who likes a mental challenge and doesn't mind a lot of reading.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												If you want a modern version of a game like Baldur's gate, this is your answer. This game DELIVERS. EASY but good craft system, loot system is alright, the graphics and spell effects are very good -- there's a LOT to try and to enjoy here. More classes than you can fully expore in a playthrough -- more spells then you can shake a stick at. Multiple caster types, all of which play differently. Fun and simple leveling system that also has it's subtleties in build creation. Story? It's got STORY for DAYS -- literally! Quests everywhere you explore, with multiple factions in each area with a reputation system that effects your dealings with them and has a genuine effect on the endgame. The game keeps a BIOGRAPHY of your character you can read like a story of your adventure -- All sorts of little things like this make this game a splendid example of the genre, but in addition to that there are little improvements here and there that just make it a better game than you're used to playing regarding games of this type. Your character's race/class/religion/etc really factor in to many exchanges and I felt like I got an ending which reflected the decisions I made -- with better detail than any game I can think of previous, and not always in ways I expected! In short, a real fun game, and despite it being a long ride I might actually play it to win it a second time... Not all RPGs can boast that. Combat is fun and strategic. Any cons? Sure -- I wish othere characters than the main character had more participation in dialogues, especially for a game where the dialogues are so strong. Beyond that, the game can be a little text-heavy in places -- long flowery descriptions of places, or dialogues that are longer than we might be accustomed. HOWEVER, I can't really gripe about having MORE content -- just be ready to read if you get into the game as much as I did. THOROUGHLY recommended.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												A resurgance of traditional RPG gaming on the PC. Taking the core gameplay style of the original Baldur's Gate, combining it with the storytelling of Planescape Torment and creating a whole new world with new character classes, skills, magic, and abilities. Obsidian have managed to create a new classic and benchmark for RPG games in this decade. One of the great features of the game is the way that skills, character class, race, past choice in conversations etc. all give you different options in conversation with NPCs and especially in scripted moments. Being without a particular skill is never game breaking but they can give you an edge when exploring, dealing with a villain or looking for loot. The game itself is huge with lots to do, many side quests and enormous replayability with the way that the main story unfolds. It incorporates morality, the nature of religion, good vs. evil and the player character in a closely interwoven development that has you almost wanting to skip the side quests just to findout what happens next. A must have for RPG fans.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												If you want a modern version of a game like Baldur's gate, this is your answer. This game DELIVERS. EASY but good craft system, loot system is alright, the graphics and spell effects are very good -- there's a LOT to try and to enjoy here. More classes than you can fully expore in a playthrough -- more spells then you can shake a stick at. Multiple caster types, all of which play differently. Fun and simple leveling system that also has it's subtleties in build creation. Story? It's got STORY for DAYS -- literally! Quests everywhere you explore, with multiple factions in each area with a reputation system that effects your dealings with them and has a genuine effect on the endgame. The game keeps a BIOGRAPHY of your character you can read like a story of your adventure -- All sorts of little things like this make this game a splendid example of the genre, but in addition to that there are little improvements here and there that just make it a better game than you're used to playing regarding games of this type. Your character's race/class/religion/etc really factor in to many exchanges and I felt like I got an ending which reflected the decisions I made -- with better detail than any game I can think of previous, and not always in ways I expected! In short, a real fun game, and despite it being a long ride I might actually play it to win it a second time... Not all RPGs can boast that. Combat is fun and strategic. Any cons? Sure -- I wish othere characters than the main character had more participation in dialogues, especially for a game where the dialogues are so strong. Beyond that, the game can be a little text-heavy in places -- long flowery descriptions of places, or dialogues that are longer than we might be accustomed. HOWEVER, I can't really gripe about having MORE content -- just be ready to read if you get into the game as much as I did. THOROUGHLY recommended.

												PLAY THIS GAME IF YOU LIKE AMAZING STORIES! SERIOUSLY IT IS ABSOLUTLY AMAZING!i only played it for like 40hours before finishing the main story and i didnt even complete all the sidequests, and ALL of the sidequests have a little bit of story so i kinda felt like i missed some story when i completed it. DO NOT rush through this game it is horrible if you do, there isnt much in terms of replayability unless you like the old school style turn based combat on harder difficulties (i do) and if u do rush through this youll probably finish it in like 20hours or less (probably much less) in which case youll feel like you didnt get enough for your money. if u love isometric rpgs with amazing storys then get this regardless of a sale. if you just want a good story but dont like this games kind of combat just wait for a sale and set the difficulty to easy or story mode so you dont have a tough time with it because it can get quite challenging especially early on and on the higher difficulties since u might accidentaly stumble on a high level dungeon or area and just be completly outmatched by the enemies there.

												Worth every penny. Best Baldurs gate style game since the legendary game itself...it brings a nice engine a great plot, atmospheric music and a great feel to the whole game. content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												If you're an RPG fan like me who loves the classic RPG games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and Planescape Torment, then you will love this game. The party characters are likeable and you get to have conversations with them whenever. Sadly there isn't any romances, but I was okay with pretending I was in one with Aloth. The gameplay is fun and challenging even on easy mode. You find yourself strategically playing the game and pausing a lot, which is a neat change in comparison to how I played Baldur's Gate. I love the storyline and all the lore in this game as well as the enemy. Having your own fortress that you build up and protect is pretty awesome and then the neat dungeon system underneath is even cooler. While it didn't last as long as Baldur's Gate and other Forgotten Realms games did, it was well worth playing and I will definitely be playing it again. While I was broke and only had $1 to give, I was glad I helped Kickstart this game. I definitely look forward to more games like this in the future. :)

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Let's get the bad things out of the way first.Cons:- Terrible default controlsThat's about everything I hated in this game, but after much strategizing and rebinding, which involved: - Moving the map scroll keys from the directional pad to WASD- inventory to C, - map to TAB- next char/prev char to Q and E respectively, - reveal interactable objects to VAnd a whole bunch of other QoL improvements. The general idea is to completely remove my reliance from the other half of the keyboard, particularly the right side since I am right-handed and that's reserved to my mouse. Infinity Engine games needed this option like real bad. My settings are not intuitive for the casual gamer, but Diablo 3 taught me there were better ways to access my inventory besides going all the way to I. And Diablo 3 is pretty casual.But once all these are set, and I got used to my own controls, I am able to immerse myself in the game completely. No more glancing on the keyboard, no more groping for the right key - my eyes are on the game 100%, enjoying the sheer narrative bliss, the engaging tactical combat, and the captivating story that keeps me at the edge of my seat.This is a true successor to the infinity engine games. I would love to see Baldur's Gate on this engine, with its stunning visuals, pleasant to the eye yet evokes the imagination. This is the enigma that Bioware left behind instead of improving upon. While Dragon Age: Inquisition is a glorious adventure in its own right, my heart belongs to Eternity!Long live Obsidian!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												People spend a lot of time reminiscing about their gaming past. Few sub-groups do this as vocally and with as much affection as fans of traditional RPGs like the near-legendary Infinity Engine games: Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter, etc. This might be because so many of those gamers found these games in tandem with traditional pen-and-paper RPGs, which is understandable when you see how much similarity there is between the two. Publishers and developers of course play on this nostalgia and claim that their title will be the game that ushers in a resurrection of the classic RPG - a grand return to the days of high adventure. And of course they are consistently wrong because pitching a 50+ hour game with thousands of pages of text to read through is a hard sell.Fear not these false prophets, though, for Obsidian has delivered unto you a second coming of traditional swordplay, wizardy, and esoteric lore. Lead us not unto Dragon Age. Deliver us from The Witcher. For Pillars of Eternity is the power and the glory. It's every D&D session in a moldy basement, every late Saturday night in the cold glow of a CRT displaying Icewind Dale, distilled into one game and freshened up just enough to make it more functional to a current audience. And that's it. It's a very *pure* experience. I can't give it better praise than that.This shows you what a team can do when the budget isn't being poured into marketing, graphics, and bloated staffs. Exemplary work.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												"By the time the final credits roll, you’ll be left in no doubt that what you’ve experienced is a modern classic of the role-playing game genre. Obsidian set out to create a spiritual successor to classic role-playing games. But instead of feeling like a pale imitation of past glories, Pillars of Eternity manages to join their ranks. It is, quite frankly, one of the best role-playing games ever made."http://www.continue-play.com/review/pillars-of-eternity-review/I think that quote sums it up. I grew up on Neverwinter Nights 1, and Baldurs. Replaying this feels like the past is stepping into a modern light. It's surprisingly difficult, even on easy setting, but anything worth while is worth effort. I found myself exploring side quests, factions in a rich setting filled with waring factions, a declining empire, and the settlers vs. natives. The story is surprisingly detailed, I'll give you all the praises in the world about Pillars of Eternity but you have to try it yourself.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												In the first few minutes of play alone I am brought back to the game that began my love for RPGS: Neverwinter Nights.Pillars of Eternity not only puts the player in the middle of the conflict, it makes them a part of it. While that may seem like trivial semantics, the sense of involvement it creates for me is phenominal.Unlike other "classic" RPGS like Baldurs Gate and Wasteland 2, that special sense of attatchment you feel to the first character you roll up doesn't get taken away by an overbearing story you are being told. Nor is your party just a bunch of different stats you chose to make up for the weaknesses of other party members. Like a true session of table top role playing, you are given a situation and asked to participate. Just keep in mind you aren't participating alone, despite this being a single player game.If you are a fan of interesting stories and characters, consequential decision making outside the good and evil spectrum, and RPGs in general, this game is for you.If you enjoyed The Witcher, Neverwinter Nights/NWN 2, Starwars: Knights of the Old Republic, or Dragon Age: Origins, you will enjoy this.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I'm getting all emotional over this game now. It's like Baldur's Gate 2 but way better. This is like Baldur's Gate 3 with enhanced visuals and game mechanics to make it smooth and fun to play on modern systems. The game is challenging, but it gives you multiple ways to complete your objectives.What changed from Baldur's Gate 2:+ 3D models+ The stat system has been reworked (It got better)+ There are multiple ways to complete your objectives while still keeping the game challenging (more immersive, better)+ It's slightly harder. (I've only played the game on hard difficulty) (I like it)             An ogre for example looks more dangerous and hits harder too.+ Classes and skills have been completely reworked to make every class viable. This is a huge difference and major improvement. The bard for example used to be a silly character running around playing his harp in battles. The chanter from pillars of eternity on the other hand is totally badass.Obsidian has succeeded in making a game that gives you that same awesome look and feel you had when you were playing Baldur's Gate 2 on release day, and made it possible to enjoy this on modern machines with modern mindsets.The only negative point I can think of in this game is that at some point in the future I will finish it, which is sad because I want this experience to last.I've read some negative reviews to see what people could have issues with.I'll comment on some of them based on my experience (Check my playtime)Here are their gripes:-  Game is bugged.      -> I have only encountered 1 bug, The game completely crashed once.          Starting it back up I was able to replicate the issue, but it was easy to get around.          For a game that has just launched it could be a lot worse IMO- I'm stuck and had to go hire some toon to get my mechanics up     -> The  developer had apparently anticipated this problem and           they have actually implemented multiple ways to complete objectives.           This problem does not exist in the game in my experience.          Use your head and think of other ways. The game challenges you.- The combat is slow and it sucks    -> It's not an action RPG. If you have never played a game like Baldur's Gate, I suggest perhaps watching a tutorial video, but it really isn't that hard.That's it for my review. This is the best game that will come out in a long time still.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												I'm one of the old school RPG fans and a KS backer.To be perfectly honest, just because it was a crowdfunded project, my expectations weren't very high.But here we have THAT game of our generation. Generous story, great art, well thought classes, smooth interface - everything that next game (BG3, PS:T2 or IWD3, whatever you wanna call it) needs to be.First off; the negative reviews, I believe they are written by people that are old time RPGers but are bored of the genre now.As for my expectations and what I got:* Setting: The setting is brand new, and backed up with an amazing historical background. It's rather too "normal" for my taste but Obsidian has done a respectable work in just 3 years. 4/5* Story: It never let's you go. It has tons of cliché moments in it but it manages to surprise you time to time as well. I could do with a more personal story but guess customized characters don't allow it. 4/5* RPG mechanics: These are new too. They work quite well, and there are almost no trash stats at all. Perks and talents are quite interesting as well - I just wished some fun perks or traits but it can come in a later expansion. 5/5* Interface & gameplay: This is probably the strongest side of the game. The interface works flawlessly, especially when compared to older IE games. 5/5* Visuals: To put it simply; they're amazing, in terms of quality. The map designs may be a little too bland for some people's taste but the customers asked for a better version of Baldur's gate series and they got it. 5/5* Music: Very atmospheric. It's not everywhere but when you hear it, it makes a difference rather than making background noise. 5/5* Companions & NPCs: Both your companions and NPCs are very detailed and involve unreadable amounts of text. Your companions are interesting enough, so you don't really want to make a custom party. However as a PS:T fan I was expecting some extreme characters such as Morte or Nordom - with unique non-class based mechanics. But now I'm not sure this franchise is going that way. 4.5/5Final: This is an awesome, huge, fresh game for all RPG fans but targets especially BG fans, which I'm not. I mean, Baldur's Gate is a Bioware franchise and Bioware games are rather bland and dull compared to Black Isle/Obsidian. Still they have colored this new "BG world" with lots of Obsidian colors and they managed to capture me easily. It's better than all past Bioware games (BG & DA series) but a little duller compared to past BI/Ob franchises. Best game I've played in the last 2 years and one of the top 10 RPGs of all time. 4.8/5All we need is Obsidian to make xpacs & sequels to this game - preferable a little more courageous.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												Simply a great game. I see people saying stuff like it's the "best since Baldurs Gate", but in my opinion, that's wrong. This is better than Baldurs Gate. I'm not aware of any current RPG that can match this game, neither in story nor gameplay. It's very deep in the character customisation, which is what's lacking in most modern RPGs, and the most important thing for me when it comes to these kinds of games.I'm not sure I like the game setting all that much, though. It is a bit lacking in atmosphere. The races and classes aren't very inventive either. You get the impression they feel they need to be original and have to make up their own stuff, but in the end they really might have just as well gone with the standard elves and halflings and all that - their inventions really don't add anything to the experience.Those are obviously minor problems. The game setting is a bit boring, but not annoying like the Elder Scrolls one for example. The good really outweighs the bad here. There is also a lot of emphasis on exploration, which is another thing i enjoy in games, and I think the solution to the balance between exploring and fast travel works well. Also, the music is wonderful, which is allways a great plus and increases immersion in and enjoyment of the game.I would most definately recommend this game to any fan of rpg-type games, for the reasons stated above.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
Product received for free
												Fantastic game. 14hrs logged time, many more while offline here in Iraqistan. If you loved Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, or any other similar isometric, party-based, D&D style rules RPG, buy this immediately.This game is somewhat a tribute to classic RPG games, hailing inspiration from such games as mentioned above, and it delivers on every aspect. Characters have depth, the plot twists and turns, the lore is deep, and combat can be as simple or micro-managed as you please. You can liberate and mange your own castle, Caed Nua. Hell yeah! Your choices may not always be truly black & white, and without reading ahead it can be hard to predict what consequences your choices may have. This has been one of the highest rated games of its kind since its release, and deservingly so. Make sure to pick up whichever edition comes with the documentary on how this game came to fruition through kickstarter, it was an interesting story itself.I recieved this game as a going-away gift, but I would gladly pay the full price on a pay-day.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I am an oldschool RPG fan, and I have to say that I played every big RPG back in the days and some I have finished multiple times like Planescape Torment, all Fallout games, all Black Isle games like Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale etc. so I think that I am a person who can give a really sober and neutral review for someone who needs the kick before buying the game.The first thing that caught my attention after starting the game were the visuals. The graphics are just amazing. I was really amazed when I saw it, especially after I re-played Icewind Dale the so called HD edition. That graphic compared to Pillars is like from B.C. Pillars look gorgeous. I really really appreciated the zoom in/zoom out featuire which these types of 2D isometric RPG's were always lacking.The music is also very good, and some songs are epic. Remind me the good old times from Baldurs Gate. Fits very very well to this fantasy world. My only problem here was, that after a while it felt repetetive. I am not sure of the songs are just similiar or there arent many of them ( didnt heard the ost ) but I had the feeling when I entered a map that the same music is playing .... again, or atleast a very similiar one.The story overall, is basicly what makes these games so good. The story is always huge and complicated in these games. Yes, you read a lot in this game. I am a person who not only read in games ( RPG's ) , but I also read a lot of books and not only fantasy. I must say that the story in Pillars for me was mediocre, or below avarage at its best compared to other games aswell, like Final Fantasy, Baldurs Gate, Planescape Torment ( one of the best ). Pillars just doesnt catch up here. People who never played a good story based game, or never read a very good book... they might like Pillar's story but dont expect something mind blowing or something that gives you chills everytime you think about it. It's just not there for me.Speaking asbout the story, I think that the NPC's I had in my group or Castle ( waiting for me to pick them up ) werent interesting. Eder ? Aloth ? I really wanted to like them I really tried.... I just couldnt care less about their story. It's not Minsc and Boo from BG, it's not Morte or the Nameless One, It's not Morrigan from Dragon Age. Thats why I created 4 characters on my own and just ignored almost all the NPC sidequests. I didnt enjoyed them. But you dont have to care about this if you didnt played any of these games, it is my little little note which I wanted to share.The biggest feature of this game is always the combat, which is amazing in Pillars. It is very dynamic, fast, colorful, bautiful... and also chaotic at the beginning. You can slow it down anytime, or even pause to assign commands. Basicly it works like this. You press spacebar to pause the game, assisng command with every party member. For example, the Paladin activates this spell, atatck with Warrior this enemy, Cast a Fireball with the Mage, Cast a AoE defensive buff with your priest etc.... once you done, you unpause the game and every command you did during the pause will trigger and happen at the same time. Then, you press pause and again.... you assign command ans so on. Easy enemies can be beaten easily without the pause button, but tougher bosses or encounters literally are unplayable without the pause. But thats ok, combat is designed around this in these games.The lack of D&D features, names, spells is also a letdown for me. This is not the Baldurs Gate 3 I wanted. I want my Magic Missile not some other looking ( similiar ) spell which is called Minoletta Missiles, it is very confusing at the beginning. You know what was really good in all the previous games ? Once you played any of them and then you jumped on the other one, you didnt had to study all the spells because in the world of D&D every spell did always the same. You had a Magic Missile, Mirror Image, Fireball wtc. in every Black Isle fantasy game. Here I had to read, study, find out what works and what not on my own... I didnt liked it too much, but again IGNORE all this if you never played the previous games. This is my personal note. I understand that implementing the D&D rules is a matter of a lot of money and license but.... oh well.Took me 60 hours exactly to beat the game. At 51 hours, I was at the final boss, but sadly I couldnt beat him because I was level 7-8 with my party. Had to return here at max level which is 12 btw, and it was suddenly super easy. The point is, that the game didnt told me to do all these sidequests to actually even have chance to beat the final boss. I always thought sidequests are optional, not recommended. A mistake. so dont do the same. You cannot beat the boss I think under level 10, but max is recommended.Overall the game is really really good. A lot of gametime, possible replayability with multiple and different endings. Looks very pretty, plays very smooth. I had a great time. A comeback of a classic RPG. A reminder in the modern days, what we loved so much in the late 90's. Definitely recommended.8/10

content:
Posted: March 7
												First of all: I'm not good at reviews. But I felt compelled to write on for this game. Second: Yes, this is a decent game. Do I recommend i? I really don't know. Part of me wants to say Yes because I'm hoping for a better cRPG in the future (maybe Pillars of Eternity 2?), part of me says No because this wis simply a subpar game.This game has been called the spiritual successor to Baldurs Gate. And so I will compare it to BG extensively in this review. Baldurs Gate IMHO looms as a menacing shadow over every cRPG out there. Now, PoE may be Baldurs Gate's successor "spiritually", but it's definitely not quality-wise. It is impressive how a game that is almost two decades older is still better. Off the top of my head, there are only two aspects I can think of that PoE does a better job of than Baldurs Gate: 1) of course graphics, 2) UIThat's it. Everything else is just decent but certainly not overwhelming: 1) PoE's plot is introduced to the player with walls of text. While text and lengthy dialogue aren't bad per se (see Planescape: Torment), presentation is key. And the way it is presented to the player is not very captivating. In fact, for quite some time, I didn't really understand anything about what was going on. And worst of all, I didn't really care because I got bored of it real fast.Compare that to, say, the start of Baldurs Gate 2 and you immediately see the vast difference: You play through, your character "lives" through what's happening. It is presented in such a way that it's involving and immersive rather than spamming walls of text at you. 2) Next is content: This game is very slim. I don't know if that's a lack of recources on Obsidian's part or what. Let's just say that. While Baldurs Gate is bursting with content, in PoE, you wander through these tiny maps that barely contain any quests or points of interest. You could spend dozens of hours in the starting city of Athlatka alone in BG2. More importantly, BG's locations feel alive. It feels like the devs put a huge amount of work and detail into each and every map, into each and every quest. PoE, in comparison, looks pretty but feels empty. 3) Characters: I'm not good at names, I forget characters fast. So it means something if I still remember the crazy Minsc who constantly talks with his space hamster, the strong personality of Jaheira, the outcast Harper who lost her husband, Nalia's silly notion of being the one privileged to help the needy, the slightly annoying Aerie who lost her wings, Yoshimo who always made fun of martial arts cliches and so many other notable heroes. In PoE, the only character I feel I'm gonna be able to recall in a few months is Durance. 4) Replayability: What incentivizes you to replay this game? Not only is it lacking in content, there are no real major decisions to be made by the player that would alter the game in such a way that you would miss out on something in the first playthrough. Whether that's good or bad is another question. I wouldn't replay, say, The Witcher 3 either. But it is said that there people who replayed Baldurs Gate about a dozen times. 5) Combat mechanics: This was the biggest letdown for me, personally. I can overlook lack of content or a less entertaining plot if the game's mechanics are good. In BG, you would reload battles over and over again (at least with certain mods that made the AI smarter). At some point, you would find a way to win them. With the right pre-battle buffs, the right potions quaffed before the battle started, the right spells, you could eventually win. You wouldn't just spam everything you had, you actually had to think. And then you would hear from a friend about another way to do it. Almost every battle was exciting and had countless possibilites of how to approach it. In PoE, while there are huge amounts of stats and extensive tooltips explaining each and every one, combat more often than not felt like a mindless spam fest. You just clicked through all the characters' abilities and talents and hoped they would do enough damage to bring the next group of mobs down. At times, combat felt like a mere ARPG with the need to pause only because you have six characters rather than one. Never did I need to think about tactics, about what certain spells or abilites actually did specifically. That's my 50 cents. And again: Just because it tries to revitalize the old-school cRPG genre, it should receive an A for effort.

Posted: March 28, 2015
												This game is great! Highly recommended. If you take the time to learn the system, lore, and combat/exploration mechanics you will enjoy it thoroughly. Just get it and play!  Wonderful!EDIT:  After playing many more hours I just want to reiterate how excellent this game is. Even if you have not played the older classics like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale or Planescape and you want to play a Dungeons and Dragons "type" game with a marvelous story, well written dialogue and lore, really fun combat, great graphics, and cool items and spells ("Calling the World's Maw", the 4th level Druid spell is AWESOME and hilarious!) then this really is the game for you. Don't expect to rush through it like Diablo. Don't look for 1st person angles and total open-ended environments like Skyrim. DO look for a really interesting leveling system, fun and funny stories, and an addictive experience. I am having a hard time NOT playing this game...  or even thinking about it while I am at work.  MANY STARS OUT OF MANY STARS is my rating.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												BASED ON 50+ HOURS PLAYED, NO SPOILERS: Obsidian set out to recreate the wonderful Infinity Engine games and succeeded thoroughly. Although it deviates from the classics in quite a number of ways, it is a wonderful interpretation of what made those games amazing while distinctly setting itself apart as an amazing cRPG on its own merit. Pillars of Eternity showcases how much amazing writing can do while offering you immense control over your own narrative through the highly varied dialogue options. Combat is fast (comparatively) and highly enjoyable, offering a great stategic challenge and allowing the eleven different classes to have their own playstyle. This is as close to a perfect cRPG as you will get. Full video review:

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Disclaimer: This piece was not intended as a review. Therefore it is written with a lot of personal opinions from me as a gamer perspective. This has little to no analysis as me the game designer.The short version is that I greatly enjoy Pillars of Eternity. It brings some old school game design and emotions back to the industry. There are moments where a critical eye towards modernizing aspects would've been welcome. I would personally enjoy it if games like these would maintain their old format with modern elements. That way this genre can be revitalized and enjoyed for generations to come.–-------------------------------------------------I can understand how some might find the pace slow. Thankfully I play a wide range of games going from the past paced Wrack to turn based games and everything in between. Each genre has its own pace to work with and switching between them can be tough as a gamer. It took me a while to get used to the pace of Serious Sam and Wrack, because everything is so damn slow these days to begin with. Even the "fast" shooters are really slow compared to games in the past. I didn't even notice this until re-playing some of them. Not so weird seeing how most "fast paced" games are made with console controllers in mind. Those are just slower to begin with and have invaded PC gaming as well. In that regard I can somewhat understand how some people might have trouble getting used to the slow pace of Pillars of Eternity. Simply because its on the other extreme end of the pacing scale.So far I've restarted Pillars a total of 3 times. But I always end up going back to the same party build up. You need 2-3 tanks to get by. Especially against larger groups of opponents. In that regard I find that it doesn't really matter what kind of a character you make yourself. You'll have to make one to fit one of the group roles. The battles won't drastically change all that much. Only the interactions with the world and dialogue options will alter. Even that seems to be limited. I clearly see old DnD dungeonmaster techniques in which you create the illusion of freedom and diversity. Your character might not have 18might to scale that wall. But hey just have Eder do it for you and then drop a rope so you'll still end up on top of the wall. You'll never really have a win-lose situation due to that. Only in places like Raedric's hold you actually have 3 choices on how to enter his hold and deal with the situation. Downside is that if your main char lacks the stat to climb vines you won't be locked out of that route and have to use one of the remaining entry points. You will get the option to have one of your party members to take your place. One hand that is only logical and real since you work as a team. Other hand you won't get any real win/loss situations.Different dialogue options is more fun. At times you do get some results that are different then another playthrough. Especially since it is also combined with your reputation. As well as the reputation how how you usually respond such as diplomatic, cruel, benevolent etc. Also nice that, just like D&D, there are different DC's (difficulty checks). There are chat options at 13,15,17,20 etc which unlock different responses and interactions. Catacombs under Defiance Bay is the first place where you'll actually notice this aspect most clearly. How you developed your character and gained reputations will matter. Choices you made up to that point will have their impact. Something you don't really see in many games.Combat is clunky as hell. Even if you enjoy turn based like I do it still is annoying at times. I can understand how many of us, me included, like games that capture that old school feeling. That doesn't mean games like this need to be full with outdated game design philosophy. Some elements would benefit from being modernized while maintaining a critical eye on the how. With all the spells and skills available it is only normal to use pause a lot and have a relatively slow pace. There simply is a lot of depth and choices that need to be made almost constantly. Sure the tanks do nothing but use knockdown combined with a load of passives to engage large groups of opponents and staying alive. But the rest of the group is a lot more work. Especially with cone shaped AoE spells that require some to get into proper positioning in order to work. Strategically this type of combat is fun and challenging. But at times it simply isn't intuitive and smooth...with moments that are downright unresponsive. With large fights the screen gets cluttered with all those little boxes above the character's heads and spell effects and the rings on the ground indicating what's going on. I would've loved if games like this would incorporate a camera that you can rotate just like Grim Dawn has.Which brings me to the Graphical Aesthetics. As always I love it. Everything blends well together. The first time you temporarily lose camera control for a small "in-game cut scene" conveyed the emotion of nostalgia and familiarity. This looks and feels like those old school cRPG's which most of us love. You see the love for D&D world building and tales of a fantastic story. The art style and how certain elements get portrayed early on in the game immediately set the right tone. It felt as if I had missed it more then ever realized. Almost had to pink away a tear in the corner of my eye. On the other hand it also has a downside in modern times. All art is pre-rendered and has to be fully loaded when entering a new area. Which means A LOT of annoyingly long loading times. Something that would occur less with 3d models that would be rendered by the graphics card when getting near the location. And using 3d models would also let people rotate the camera for a better and clearer overview of crowded battles. Question remains how going to 3d models would effect the aesthetics of the entire game. Would it effect it in such a way that those conveyed emotions would no longer be generated?Regarding modernizing games like this... Well I don't want them to become fully fleshed 3d open world games. Let them be isometric, top down or whatever. But that doesn't mean some Quality of Life changes can't be made. For example the TAB button is getting worn out drastically. I move a lot in stealth and after every move action I press the TAB to see if there is something hidden. If you have a high enough perception you'll notice things without using this method. When it comes to D&D, especially since 4th Edition, I found passive Perception and active Perception a very pointless mechanics. The same is being used in Pillars of Eternity it seems. It is something that needs to be looked at. Then find a proper solution for this mechanic.The group stealth issue still annoys me. After your characters reach lvl 3 or 4 they are becoming truly powerful. No more issues of survival, lack of damage or whatever. They feel solid like adventures should. The rogue, combined with the right passives, will cut through opponents like a knife through hot butter. That is awesome and what we'd expect. However the other aspects of a rogue don't work well at all. Placing traps seems rather pointless. Out of the many that I've placed in front of a door that opponents have to run over...only 1 actually activated. Using Stealth to sneak into a room and ambush opponents with a first strike isn't going to happen...EVER! I've been investing in stealth for all members in the group. It has happened how the entire group could stand beside a troll without it noticing us. But using the backstab of the rogue...still not happening. Something is seriously flawed here. The rogue needs to be able and use stealth on its own for the combat aspect. Outside of combat you simply select the rogue and move it on its own away from the group. Such as scouting ahead and removing traps for example.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
At 15 hours of gameplay I strongly recommendIf you liked games like Icewind Dale and Baldur's Gate, or are a fan of classic style RPGs you will enjoy this game.The pricepoint may be discouraging to people who look at it as $45 for a 2D game but the RPG elements are truly well done, the world is immersive, the characters are interesting and the gameplay has that familiar tough but fun feel of older RPGs.Rather than write paragraphs of why I'm enjoying this game I've decided that a list would be both easier to read and summarise the features that I've found enjoyable: The 2D art is amazing and the pre-rendered backgrounds look excellent The conversation has a depth that allows your character's background or attributes to be relevant There are multiple paths to the scenarios I've encountered so far Combat on higher difficulties requires thought and careful planning The classes are interesting, and while there are still a few familiar faces amongst typical RPG classes there are a few classes may have been inspired by more recent RPGs which brings new facets to classic gameplay The stronghold is a more recent feature to RPGs that allows players to become invested in an asset which functions in game time SO MUCH LORE. There are a lot of short stories tied to named characters for those who like to readAnd finally the two most important features I'd like to note: There are Elves I can play a RangerI would have liked to have seen the option for LAN or Internet connection for cooperative multiplayer, a little more customization for the character models and portraits, and I have the concern that players that are new to this kind of game may get lost (I know I've felt a little lost once or twice already and needed to consult the Journal).

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												At 10 hours in I feel I have still barely scratched the surface of this game. Though the ruleset has changed, the look and feel of Baulder's Gate have been inherited in almost every way. The writing is amazing and your peanut gallery of a party always enjoys giving their two cents. I have yet to see what challenges are brought along with keep ownership, but I know being a money drain seems to be the first. Those of you familiar with this sort of pause-based gameplay will feel right at home. The part which grabs me the most, however, is the look and feel of the world: a Forgotten Realms aesthetic with what looks to be a splash of the first Diablo's darkness.The spirit of Black Isle and the soul of Bioware seem to reside in Obsidian, and I can't wait to see what's on their horizon.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												This game is great! Highly recommended. If you take the time to learn the system, lore, and combat/exploration mechanics you will enjoy it thoroughly. Just get it and play!  Wonderful!EDIT:  After playing many more hours I just want to reiterate how excellent this game is. Even if you have not played the older classics like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale or Planescape and you want to play a Dungeons and Dragons "type" game with a marvelous story, well written dialogue and lore, really fun combat, great graphics, and cool items and spells ("Calling the World's Maw", the 4th level Druid spell is AWESOME and hilarious!) then this really is the game for you. Don't expect to rush through it like Diablo. Don't look for 1st person angles and total open-ended environments like Skyrim. DO look for a really interesting leveling system, fun and funny stories, and an addictive experience. I am having a hard time NOT playing this game...  or even thinking about it while I am at work.  MANY STARS OUT OF MANY STARS is my rating.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												BASED ON 50+ HOURS PLAYED, NO SPOILERS: Obsidian set out to recreate the wonderful Infinity Engine games and succeeded thoroughly. Although it deviates from the classics in quite a number of ways, it is a wonderful interpretation of what made those games amazing while distinctly setting itself apart as an amazing cRPG on its own merit. Pillars of Eternity showcases how much amazing writing can do while offering you immense control over your own narrative through the highly varied dialogue options. Combat is fast (comparatively) and highly enjoyable, offering a great stategic challenge and allowing the eleven different classes to have their own playstyle. This is as close to a perfect cRPG as you will get. Full video review: 


YouTube™ Video: Pillars of Eternity 50+ Hours REVIEW (No Spoilers) 

			Views: 39,482		

			► Support me on Patreon! https://www.patreon.com/HaasGaming ...in which I nitpick about my favourite game in years. With Pillars of Eternity, Obsidian attempts to recreate the wonder from the old...

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												I'll try to be short cause most people don't read long reviews anyway..My opinion of the game after having finished it and having 90+ hours of gameplay is :-- it's basically a remake of Baldur's Gate § Neverwinter Nights with today's graphics and technology.The story is different, but everything else is either identical or slightly modified.+ vs -+ it's polished, I hardly had any bugs at all, it runs smooth, except for the loading screens and save/load games which became longer and longer as I played+ The monk (which in other games I played was underpowered) was absolutely awesome without being OP. I loved playing that character.+ The story is ok, actually, it's more than ok, i'ts very detailled and interesting. I even find it well written at times.+(?) it's got a lot of feature identical to Baldur's Gate, even the "help a man in a fight outside a bar and he joins your party afterwards" (NW2 with the dwarf), to many, this is a positive thing I guessI can't really think of anything else, it all runs smooth with not to many hiccups.- It feels like it's not a finished product- It feels shallow and not coherent, example : big city has riots, you go back there after a short while, almost everything is as before except for one or two NPCs who say a few different things- though the background story is pretty good I think, the actual conversation scripts and peripheral story writing can be absolutely terrible at times, I was sometimes literally smacking my head- they did reproduce from the old successfull RPGs, but reproducing from a good game doesn't make a game good.... they didn't build on anything, they didn't push any barriers, they didn't bring any depth to the characters and the story or even the setting, the world and so on.It felt like a polished but unfinished game. There was no creativity, there was nothing "new" except for details mostly related to modern technology.Conclusion : It's like playing Baldur's gate I and II and NW 1 and 2 mixed together with today's technology and a different story.ie, nothing special.conclusion : I did enjoy playing it for a while though I got bored as well after a while, I only finished it out of principle. And I'm sure many people will enjoying playing it, in fact whoever's reading it, you'll probably have a "nice" time playing it.But it's certainly not an exceptional game, certainly not as good as all the hype was saying and certainly not worth the price when you compare that to games like The Witcher 3.10-20 euros, yeah, good buy, but other than that ..and that was my short version :p

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												This caught me in an interesting time: I didn't want to play any games, my intentions were to sit down reading a well written story. And it appeared I could get the best of both worlds with Pillars! Its quality storytelling and rich language would make any book proud, and the gameplay, despite being tedious sometimes with lots of micromanaging, is nicely balanced and provides an tactical challenge. The game is way more user-friendly than BG and won't punish you too much for your decisions, making it more fun to really play your role.I was kind of afraid to get a typical fantasy setting with elves, magic and ancient artifacts… well, you get a little of the latter (and the former as well), but just by making gods and reincarnation a major part of the world Obsidian made it fresh and original, with just the correct amount of disturbing. You get to decide on difficult topics like morality of science and the role of religion.This is definitely not the right game if you want to hack-n-slash to the bad guy and make it a day (but even in this case the game may not be so disappointing). It is thoughtful, beautiful, and emotionally delivering.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												I don't usually write reviews for games, but I felt compelled to this time. I didn't find out about Pillars of Eternity in time to back it on KS, but I began supporting it as soon as I learned of its existence :)As a kid I played the old Infinity Engine games. I think my first was Fallout 2, then Fallout, then Planescape: Torment, then everything else. Basically, I cut my teeth in gaming on some of the best (arguably the very best) Western-style CRPGs ever made. It gave me a sincere appreciation for storytelling in games that has served me really well since, though I think any fan of RPGs remembers the dry spell in the 2000s where it looked like CRPGs might irrevocably change to something much lamer, or just not get made anymore. If I had to pick a game that ended that negative outlook, probably The Witcher, by my reckoning, and it has been a great deal better since. I guess it's a real resurgance of craft and storytelling in CRPGs :)This game is the best one out of any that I've played since Planescape: Torment, though. Bar none. It has an engrossing story, a brilliantly realized and organic (but mystical!) setting, places that feel truly alien through sincere and earnest effort on the part of the developers. Interactions with NPCs carry the dramatic flair that a VERY good dungeonmaster can bring to a P&P tabletop game, and that feeling is only further enhanced by the clever system of scripted events in the game that have multiple stat or skill checks and require some thought to navigate without peril. They don't happen often enough for you to start predicting every time you'll have one, but they do happen often enough that they are a serious gameplay element and not a gimmicky afterthought. The user interface is a brilliant combination of accessibility and feature-richness, evoking the Infinity Engine interfaces in general but without their frustratingly restrictive control schemes.I haven't played enough to assess how the game will be in retrospect, after the story has ended. But I am absolutely enthralled by my role in the story so far, and I am not looking forward to the end of it so much as having gone on this awesome gaming journey. You don't get stuff like this often. Buy it, if you're even a little interested you ARE the type of gamer it's for. This will rekindle any person's love for old CRPGs, and I bet it'll make a lot of new fans too!

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												An isometric RPG following in the steps of predecessors like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale,Pillars of Eternity might not be as good when compared to them but remains nonetheless an enjoyable experience.Pros:-nice story overall,some companion and side quests are very nice aswell-decent graphics,even though they don't hold up when zoomed close-good soundtrack-a few interesting classes amongst the usual archetipes-good character customization-nice party banter-lots of dialogues,books,things to check to flesh out the game world-the stronghold is pretty interesting-good amount of zones to explore and lots of quests-the game system-not the usual DnD fare-is pretty interesting-original setting-you can create your own party members if you don't want to use the story onesNeutral:-lots of micromanagement party-wise,you're expected to pause often in combat to give orders/activate skills-some fights can be difficultCons:-while the story is interesting overall it's very slow to unfold and lacks the sense of grandiose that was found in older games-the game system isn't fully explained,leaving one to guess certain game mechanics,this is even more troubling during character creation-some pathfinding issues-some areas are poorly designed for combat,leading to the party getting stuck in narrow corridors/doorways and being unable to fully engage the enemy-lack of proper party AI leads to the aforementioned micromanagement,which can get tiring in the long run-not all party members are equally interesting,some are a bit boring or have lacking quests-some quests can be a bit dull,or have pooor directions,especially when you're trying to remember where the original quest giver was-stealth is a bit hit or miss (no way to stealth single characters,must stealth to find traps/secrets)Overall this is a good game that sadly suffers a bit when compared to its predecessors,it lacks the engaging story and characters and the depth the DnD system and setting gave to the games of old. I got it for 25$ and am satisfied with the purchase,but considering the Enhanced Editions of Baldur's Gate are available for even less makes it a tough call overall.Still,if you already played those and are looking for more-or just want something more modern-Pillars of Eternity does have enough going for itself to make it a worthwile purchase and an interesting experience to play through, especially considering isometric RPGs are not that common these days (even though we're enjoying a resurgence with other good titles like Shadowrun and Wasteland 2).
