number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I've broken this review about Pillars of Eternity (PoE) into two parts, story and combat. An entire section could be devoted to the mechanics but I will simply say they are great in my opinion.Story: PoE is a book wrapped as a game and the storyline is novel quality that would scare young adult fantasy readers. If you are in it for the story-line alone play PoE on the easiest difficulty with all the help you can get. You create one character and over the course of the story have up to an additional five characters join you. You can even create your own and not bother with the in-game characters. You may want to have as many in-game characters as you can in your party if you want to see the story-line mature fully.Combat: First, I am playing the game on what is called "hard" difficulty and with a special setting called "expert" mode. PoE's expert mode turns off a lot of helpful information so you must learn what enemies are weak to and much of the information is hidden. Based upon my settings my overall assessment of the combat is brutally difficult, imagine playing chess-master on a grandmaster setting but instead you don't know what all the pieces do but computer does and often has more pieces than you until you get a full party... and even then the enemy will often outnumber you. This is refreshingly positive experience as I am expecting to steamroll the AI as I do in most games. Even with these difficult settings the battles with the AI enemies still feels fair. I feel like I am playing more a game of chess on equal footing than what most games do to make up for bad AIs such as give special bonuses and stats to the AI to make it difficult instead of developing a tactically smart AI. The AI in PoE feels like they are fighting for their life, targeting certain members of my party and using the strengths of their pieces to the best of their ability and even minimizing losses to win the complete battle at times (which is game-over for the player).  The downside of such a difficult AI is a slight draw away from the storyline, in that I've found that I won't bring the in-game characters because they aren’t min-maxed enough for their particular role which means I may be missing out on some dialogue. PoE does have an even higher difficulty but it just increases the stats of the enemies and I'm not interested in that. PoE even has an iron-man mode for the masochist which could make for a fun easy difficulty iron man story.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												The bugs that people are citing as reasons to avoid the game simply are not that bad. Don't double click inventory. If you encounter one of the other bugs, sorry, but the game itself is imminently playable as is. The combat is hard but fun (once you get past the first town's temple which has inexplicably engagement breaking enemies). The art is beautiful. The character creation is extensive and meaningful. The story is rich. The world is rich. The quests are varied. The companions are varied (though they can't compete with nostalgia). The dungeons are deep. It's not perfect but it's one of the best RPGs in years. It's not trying to be an MMO like some modern RPGs. It can be obtained legally without DRM! That in and of itself is amazing. While the Dragon Age series has gotten more and more faceroll with thin plots and a built in dating sim, Pillars has focused on making intense, tactical combat and a rich game world, and they did it very well. Does the might stat make sense? No. Are there a couple bugs? Yeah. Is it fun as heck? Yes. It's an experience I would recommend to anyone, as it doesn't jerk you off while picking your pocket as is the modern trend. It delivers a real game, with real depth, and many hours of play. It's exactly what games should be.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E30 Pillars of Eternity 

			Views: 239		

			Continued... Sorry the review was too big for Steam and YouTube so I had to split it up. You can find the first part of the review on my Steam Page here [http://steamcommunity.com/id/invadersean300/]...		

Pillars of Eternity: Pillars of Eternity, a Kickstarter (77,000!) CRPG developed by Obsidian Entertainment and published by Paradox Interactive. First a bit of a disclaimer, I have NOT completed the main story of Pillars of Eternity, I am currently in Act 2 and have put almost 30 hours into the game already. Anyways, on with the review! ---->This game takes lovers of RPGs back to some of the roots of some of the most beloved video games ever, titles like Baldur’s Gate, Icewind Dale and my personal favorites Fallout and Planescape: Torment are all great examples of CRPGs and some of the highest rated games of all time. I could go on, but, just know that Pillars of Eternity is a game that will take you back to those great experiences while delivering its own. Like all CRPGs the game takes an isometric point of view, you see everything from the sky, looking down, giving you the ability to appreciate grand landscapes and structures that are beautifully done in the game.Things like large buildings, bridges, forest, swamps, the ocean, all are beautifully crafted and the isometric point of view has always been perfect for show-casing these types of games, it looks beautiful and you don't need a top-of-the-line gaming computer to appreciate it. The music scores in CRPGs are usually on par with its excellent graphics and Pillars of Eternity is no different. Every soundtrack fits the mood perfectly and really compliments the atmosphere and setting, the only music that will get annoying is when combat starts, it’s the exact same every time and gets a bit annoying, but the rest of the tracks are amazing. ---->Gameplay is pretty straight forward, use the mouse and click on the ground to move your character, the mouse is your primary device, you have plenty of keyboard hot keys to use as well to assist with things like selecting characters, formations and dialogue options. The interface is nice and slick, not too barebones, not too cluttered and laid out in a very nice fashion, and easily customizable as well. Speaking of customization the character builder in this game rocks! You have a total of five races to choose from, many of which have sub races, then you have eleven classes to choose from, each one quite unique and different and most importantly, useful, you will definitely find favorites but, from my experience, every class can easily be useful alone and in a group and that is a welcomed addition to any RPG. You'll also get to choose color pallets for your characters, multiple voices, and very beautifully detailed portraits. You could and easily will drop many hours in the character creator and still find new characters to create, the best part is the game allowing this to be used throughout the game, as you get the ability to create new companions in addition to finding story ones early in the game, it’s a nice feature, allowing you to create one of every class and try out a multitude of playstyles and strategies for combat.---->Combat can be hit or miss, I personally enjoy it, but, I can see it being boring or frustrating to some. First, your characters never do anything on their own, even when getting abused with mace blows or shot at with pistols they will stand there taking it all without ever attempting to retaliate. You HAVE to tell your companions exactly what to do no matter what it is, they will not do anything without an order, and when it’s a party of six, fighting multiple bad guys, that can get a bit slow, this isn't helped by the fact that you'll be pausing combat a lot to tell a character to do something after they've done their previous action. Another annoyance with combat is that characters will often run into each other, and will not attempt to move around each other instead, just running forward till whatever is blocking them is out of the way, this makes unit placement annoying and frustrating, I cannot stress enough how important it is to create custom formations to help alleviate this head ache. I'm harsh on the combat but, overall, I enjoy it a lot, the game lets you be as brute force or strategic as you wish and really rewards you for coming up with clever combos and will definitely challenge you with tough fights that will require every bit of cunning and cleverness you can muster. Magic is a lot of fun, spells are flashy and look amazing and actually feel like they pack a punch, they're exciting to use and I would strongly suggest bringing magic along for any fight. ---->Something else you also get fairly early in the game is the Stronghold, this is a player home that you get to upgrade throughout your adventure, allowing you to add multiple shops, a bounty board, a treasury and more. It’s in a ruined state and will look quite impressive as you get closer and closer to completing all of the upgrades, you'll also be able to hire guards to help defend from interlopers, you'll receive taxes to help fund your adventures, and side missions for your companions to do. It’s an awesome castle they give you early on and access to one of the biggest dungeons in the game, there are some missed opportunities with the Stronghold, one that I will share is you can actually arrest NPCs in the world and put them in your prison...and that’s it. You never get to do anything outside of that and your only option is to release them or they will escape on their own eventually. I'm not sure what the point is and haven't discovered anything you can do with it so it just seems kind of pointless, still the Stronghold is awesome and I devoted almost all of my resources early on to restoring it and exploring the dungeon beneath. ---->So the story, hmm, well I haven't finished it so I can't give you a full debrief on it, however, my impression is that it is not as strong or gripping as it could have been. You find out early in the game that you are what is called a Watcher, someone who can peer into the souls of the living, and see the past lives of that person. Unfortunately this awakened something inside yourself and as told to you by a crazy man, you too will suffer the fate of all of your past lives all living with you at the same time, driving you insane and ultimately to your doom. You set out to find a cure and get swept up into other bigger things going on. The story sounds great, the idea of the Watcher is awesome, it just isn't utilized to its fullest; the world becomes background to your concerns, that is to say that at least from the point I’ve played, the world doesn't seem to care about your success or demise. That is a very fitting setting, but it’s a tough sell to engage the player in, since there isn't a life threatening doom approaching, what was needed was strong personal reasons to motivate the player. Again, this all seems very passive and aside from the occasional staring into space, being a Watcher doesn't seem to really be as bad as the world cracks it up to be. ---->Again this is from my point of view and I admit I have not finished the story, but there are only a few acts and by now I would expect to have a full understanding of all that is going on, if they reveal something later on perhaps my opinion will change, but, it shouldn't take till Act 2 to be invested in any story...[Video Review at: www.youtube.com/RoyialNetwork] (Review was too big for Steam and YouTube, so its been split up link to video above, sorry about that! Thank you for reading and watching!)

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												So, Pillars of Eternity.I was very excited about this game after watching the kickstarter video. I was/am a huge fan of many Obsidian games, including the Fallout series (the early ones plus NV), Planescape Torment etc. I pledged a decent amount of money and followed this game's development.I'm not even sure as I write this if I'm going to end up giving it an up-thumb or a down-thumb. Pillars is a classic RPG. There are clunky mechanics, done that way unapologetically. It has tons and tons of content. So many character customization options. Interesting story and characters although I find sometimes the micromanagement can get in the way. The combat can get fairly repetitive, although it can also be interesting in its own way. For if I'd recommend it, it depends on if you're a patient person or not. I've played through mostly as a wizard and the resting mechanics can get beyond annoying since the game restricts how many spells you can cast per rest (the flip side of the coin being the spells are powerful) with the game difficulty restricting how often you can rest. There is no romance in the game, which can be a good or a bad thing depending on your tastes as a player.I guess you could liken it to something like Baldur's Gate, but it's much less based on D&D than BG was. It has its own combat and ruleset. It's done from an isometric perspective and has real time with pause type combat. I am not a fan of that type of combat, I much prefer Wasteland 2's turn based combat, and I think that's a fair comparison giving the similarity of the development teams and the release date of the games.On a personal level, I'd give the game about 7/10. It's exactly what it aimed to be, but what it is isn't always my cup of tea. Having to return to inns or go back to buy more camp supplies really messes with me as I'm someone who likes to start something and then just progress through it, not to chain runs back to town. That was one of the main things that turned me off of Fallout 4, the chain runs back to camp to lug loot and crafting supplies. That being said it's very well written, and most problems have different solutions, some of which are gated by skill checks. Also, the choices you make aren't "requires most skill is automatically the best one", you have to read the dialogue and options and sometimes choose the thing with the lower skill check because it's more logical, and the game is crafted in a way that you get the better outcome that way.That being said, there aren't enough of those events in the game. If you were expecting it to be like Planescape: Torment in that it'd be riddled with such interesting events, it isn't. Much of the game is walking into areas and clearing them out using their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat system. The combat system essentially requires continual pausing in order to make characters do logical things, but of course once one character has started his action, all the other characters are acting as well. That might mean you have a character get himself into trouble while you were issuing commands to the prior character. I find the combat in this game almost as much a case of putting out fires as it is meaningful choices and action. I think my final reaction to it is one of mild dissapointment in that it was a game made by a company who has given me some of the best storytelling I've experienced in games (New Vegas, Torment) and it simply hasn't lived up to my expectations so far. I'm currently doing a second playthrough, I never finished the game the first time. I got bored of it and switched to other games. I intend to finish it this time, and if my opinion on it changes I'll come back and change my review, but for now, it's a down thumb.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												It's boring. The combat is dull and the story isn't interesting. Maybe it gets better as you progress, but it's very boring to start. At least BG gave you an interesting story from the start. The combat itself actually feels like a step back from BG. The real-time aspects do nothing to make it more interesting and the AI is so bad that you have to micromanage them... sadly, there's not a lot to manage. There's not many abilities to work with, and a lot of them are per-rest rather than per-encounter. So, you either rest frequently or auto-attack your way through battles. Your main character is so pointless in the game that there's little reason to have one. Your character in the story is essentially a faceless/pastless character in a new land. Nobody knows or cares who you were. The characters you meet join you at the drop of a hat, and bring nothing beyond their lackluster skills. It's a far cry from BG and I'm pretty disappointed.

content:
Posted: March 6
												Pros:- Excellent story and engaging setting- Interesting and story-rich companions.- Customizable characters and interesting zones.Cons:- Combat is unbelievably slow and complicated.- Long sections of dull, repetitive content that are required to get to the good bits.- Arbitrary gating of story choices and resolutions behind other, less interesting content.- The "Nevermind-factor"Review:All of the pieces are there for PoE to be a smash hit, but for some reason it just doesnt quite come together.The main story is impressive and engrossing. However, I often find myself slowed to a crawl by tedious sidechores - Sidechores that you are almost required to do if you want to be powerfull enough to even survive the next leg of the story.I am not just speaking of sidequests, whose quality varies from pretty good to absolutely atrocious, but also of story-less and repetitive content such as bounty hunts and..URGH..The Endless Depths of Cad Nua. A dungeon crawl that is so long it could be its own standalone game, but it is mind-numbingly repetitive, as are many of the "dungeon" segments in PoE. They are long, tedious, punish any attempt to get through them faster with traps and obstructions, and offer no fun at all. This is further hampered by an overly complicated and very punishing combat system that makes even small skirmishes a long slog to get through.In addition, the "perfect" resolution to story quests often requires you to do other quests first. Sometimes to insane levels. For example: To resolve a critical battle in the ideal manner, you first need to completely finish the 2 expansion packs before you can proceed. The end result is that I cannot for the life of me motivate myself to keep playing through the game - For every good segment, I feel like I need to grind through mountains of repetitive and dull content if I want to finish the story my way. And I just dont want to do that. It requires so much effort and time to carve through the boring sections that on every attempt I end up throwing my arms into the air and saying: "You know what, Pillars of Eternity? Nevermind. Just -nevermind-."PoE is the "Nevermind factor" made real.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												For whatever reason my long, thoughtful review didn't go through 2 times, so here's the short version: Boring combat (you need a meat shield and you choke point juggle, that's it) Boring RPG aspect (your followers are 1D, the story choices have no consequences, overall just no real Role-Playing) Stronghold is a waste of time and feels completely tacked-on for no reason The sneaking mechanic sucks all the fun out of the game (and double speed ruins immersion, so choose your poison) Information overload and I wanted to read stuff, just the majority is just too damn boring and meaningless Weak classes (Rogue is the most useless class in the whole game) Weak items (you stop caring about items 1 hour in) Boring level ups Lots of odd mechanics (infinite, permantly accessible storage no matter where you are - wtf?, crafting that can be done everywhere, anytime from the menu by clicking a button - wat?)In summary the game just wasn't fun. Then I checked what others complained about and it was pretty much the same, even by people who played 100+ hours. Therefore, I can rest assured the game is not for me and I cannot recommend it.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												It is hard to rate this game, as I did find the game's first 20 - 30 hours amazing - which is more game time than most standard AAA released today.  However, after playing that long you will start realizing some serious flaws in the game...* All the classes will start to feel the same* You'll start realizing the limitation of the skills system* Main quest starts strong, however, gets weaker later on* Visiting dungeons starts to feel like a hack and slash (every room/hallway filled with red to kill)   -  Hardly any unique loot to find      - This promotes their simplified enchanting/upgrading system (know all recipes, upgrades level capped)* No experience from killing enemies after logged in bestiary* The companions have banter and seem fleshed out, but seem to be missing the flair/annoyances to be remembered* Stronghold could have been better implemented.   -  Also hate that some events could start while traveling and go away before you reach your destination to enable    eventThere is more, but I guess I am being a bit nit picky.  Perhaps future installments of PoE will expand/improve, but as a stand alone game for isometric party based RPG, it is far from reaching the BG series/DAO.  Would definitely wait for the game to be 50% off, especially if you're expecting BG series/DAO.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												Tried twice now to get into this game - just can't do it. So damn boring - far too much "lore" that the game has failed to give me any reason to care about. Numerous gameplay annoyances such as being arbitrarily pulled out of stealth so enemies can talk to me, stupid overpowered enemies with instant stunlock/2 second kill your best tanks. Almost non-existant loot. Tedious micro-management of combat with all these damn abilities, yet my characters feel ineffective and differences between characters feels marginal at best. Baldur's Gate is still my favourite and i'll probably do another full run for the billionth time after this. The thing is that it's also heavily flawed yet i'm still here in 2016 waiting for something beat it. Very disappointed...When I think about it both BG games were fairly linear but you could go off and adventure, finding and raiding dungeons, bring up wheelbarrows full of loot, get tons of XP, build overpowered character combos (especially with BG:T or the new enhanced edition). The story wasn't really anything to write home about but it kept you moving forward and the fights were challenging but fair for the most part (the original not BG2). The lore was never being rammed down your throat, if you wanted to get more immersed in it then you could do so but it was always your choice to do so. The characters and banter were awesome, I've created numerous parties just to see the different combinations and see fireworks fly between some of them.

number of helpful: 22 of 42 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9
												It pains me that I have to write this review, but I've put so many hours into this game, hoping that in the next chapter it would get better, that the story would pick up, and the world would come alive, but it never does. The world is dead, it never comes alive. The characters have a lot to say, but they never really talk about anything meaningful. The dialog is well written, but this does not hide the lack of substance. The lore is almost all about rebirth, souls and a war involving a god. There are no cool cultures with interesting histories and weird customs here, it's a generic medieval world with swords and dragons.  If you are going to try and make a game like Baldur's Gate why would you refrain from using the rich world of D&D that Baldur's Gate had? This was a huge part of the game... And why would you not use the infinity engine? Baldur's Gate 2 is seen by many, including myself as the best rpg ever made. If you are going to try and make a game like this, you should be hoping to get close to it. I would have been happy if it was similar to the first Baldur's Gate. (Which it is not) Such a game is considered a master piece precisely because it has very little flaws, how arrogant can you be to think you are going to improve upon it's mechanics? No matter how you tweak the difficulty, the game is either boring and too easy, or it is tedious and hard. Fights often last 15 to 20 minutes which means it will take you hours to clear one map. On the harder settings you get tempted to fight without resting, since you need camping supplies for this. Often this means you are starting a fight you cannot win. So you constantly have to run back to town to get more supplies which involves multiple load screens that take ages to finish loading. I suspect they made this game in 3d and locked the camera in place, which would mean much more stuff to load compared to the 2d sprites of BG. The only thing they did right are the graphics, every area feels unique and has nicely detailed graphics just like BG.EDIT: If you are interested in this game because you want to play something like Baldur's gate, and you enjoyed BG for it's story, characters and rich world then I would not get this game, it has very little of this. If you liked BG for other reasons then maybe you will like this. It is not a terrrible game. I got it because they promised another BG, but they failed to deliver this, hence my disappointment.

content:
Posted: April 2
												6/10 or 7/10 at the most. I know that many people bought the game because they thought that it would be like Baldur's Gate 2, myself included. And yes, the two look very much alike. But that's one of the problems really, because it's not fair to compare this game to the legendary BG2. When I heard about the game, I was thrilled. I bought it as soon as I could. I really tried to get into this game, but I soon lost my interest in it. The storyline wasn't bad, but the side-quests weren't so good in my opinion, so eventually I started skipping them. And the battles I didn't like one bit, so they were only a necessary evil to me that kept me back from continuing the storyline. I also didn't like the long descriptions on what the other characters look like or what they do, because they just made the conversations heavy.What I really liked were the atmospheric cutscenes, but the backer NPCs only harmed the atmosphere in my case. I also appreciate the graphics because I'm not a fan of anime-style graphics with flashy colours and exaggarated huge weapons and armors.All in all I think the story of the game was good and the graphics were okay, but pretty much everything else didn't work. Battles were tiresome, building and equipping the characters felt pointless and side-quests didn't help to create an interesting and alluring world. This game just didn't convince me.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Wow... the depth, the immersion, the absolute perfection of the story telling - this game has it all. It's a wonderful experience, and it had me enthralled from the first to the last. All of the characters were interestering, and it was rough only having to choose certain party members to tag along at any given time. The combat was great, the humor better, and the storyline was well done.The only issue I really had was in the AI pathing of my party members - they were dumb as stumps. I would set em up in acertain way, then they'd do something else at time. The number of times I accidentally fried one of my own teammmates was crazy, not to mention having them try to hit an enemy standing next to them, only to see them run around an entire pack of mobs to get the hit in at a different angle was mind boggling. Still, this was a relatively minor issue. Loved loved loved the game, and as soon as I was done I was looking for an expansion...

												Solid game, spent 91 hours in my first playthrough and still didn't find everything. Combats can be extremely tough, Ogre's just flatten groups if you don't take them seriously. The intensity of the last combat is out of control, took me five tries to make a solid strategy to take it down. Old Nua is by far the best dungeon crawl I have had in a long time, it reminds me of Pathfinder's Emerald Spire, just a drag down, soul crushing grind to make it to the last floor, and than you have a boss thats harder than anything else expierence in the game.Three thumbs up, Im working up the courage to give this game another play through at a harder difficulty setting. This is also important. The characters you get to recruit, make sure one of them has a stupidly high mechanics score.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												This game is everything I hoped for and more. Ive been a big fan of RPG's in general, but lately it seems that the newer ones are dumbed down so that they will sell to a larger demographic. Games like Mass Effect while a decent game, is more of an action game with RPG elements, you never had the freedom to do what you wanted like you had in Fallout 1 and 2, and the Balders Gate series. This game delievers an old school RPG experience with enhanced graphics and great dialogue. The writing in this game is so good that its almost like reading a book. If you have any interest in RPG's, especially old style Fallout or Baldurs Gate, do yourself a favor and buy this game.  This is my first review I have ever written on a Steam game which should go to show how much I think of it.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												First review ever!Loving this game so much, thought I would share a few thoughts.First and foremost.....Fun.50 hours in.  So much choice and diversity.  Regret going basic fighter as my first choice, but can choose new skeletal characters from tavern and make them your own to fill your party.  Or you come along premade characters throughout your journey that will fill out your group.  Just made a paladin and ran into a ranger to fill out my, 2 fighter, 1 wizard, 1 cleric group to 6.  Have a chanter at my home castle to do quests for me.As a D&D fan this game really holds true and makes me feel like I made the character on paper and now am in a Dungeons Masters elaborate adventure. Best game I have played in a while.  Feel like 50 hours in I am just scratching the surface.  Probably have 150 in before I can beat the game. If you are in to more turn based RPG games, I recommend Wastelands 2.  Just beat it before I picked this up.  Loved it.  Graphics are behind the times, but gameplay and story were phenominal.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Pillars is a great game in it's own right. If you loved Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment or Icewind Dale, then you will feel at home. The game is very detailed and Obsidian took great care in making every area interesting to explore. There is much dialogue and while the story not as memorable as Planescape: Torment, it still intrduces us to a new world to look to in the future. The game has replay value and Obsidian continues to patch it up. The combat is fun and you will get obliretaed if you don't plan out your strategy. Character builds are very detailed as well, so take your time with that build. Be forwarned though, the game is very buggy and crashes randomly to the Desktop. F5 frequently so that you don't loose progress. I am almost 70 hrs into the game and I am still on Act 2 since I take my time with the game. I highly recommend this game to anyone that loves this genre. It's definitely helped me with my vocabulary.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												This is, hands down, one of the best games I´ve ever played.  Because that I grew up with Baulders gate 1 and 2 this is a game well suited for me. A lively atmosphere and rich enviroments with great music to boost it. They said that they aimed to bring back the feel of the old infinty engine games (Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale e.t.c) and they did just that. Not just the isometrical camera and live turnbased combat (pausable, of course). They looked to the smaller things, such as the good old "You must gather your party before venturing forth" as well.Apart from that the game is also littered with alot of community written content wich shows that they really cherish the community they have gathered. There is no real downside to this game, it offers great replay value, great challenges and hours upon hours of gameplay.Should I really search for a downside I could find two things1: The UI has a button wich reveals that you will acquire a stronghold at one point, it could have been covered up as not to spoil a great surprise.2: I easily reached the levelcap way before reaching the end of the game, mind you it took alot of sidequesting and it kept me from being way overpowered for the endgame. A slight to much sidecontent in relation to maincontent.That being said, I strongly recommend it. It brought back so many good memories of what I love about roleplaying games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I'm not much of a review writer (I think I've written maybe two before this one), but...this game's deserving of a good review, and as I finished my first playthrough earlier today it seemed the ideal time. Unfortunately, I'm not a wordy person, so I'll point out some quick bits and leave the description of the plot out apart from some very simple comparison to its grandparents:Story - 6/5. Seriously, it's so multi-faceted, between the main questline and all of the side quests, it's the type of story we haven't seen since the good old days of cRPGs (aka Pillars' grandparents!). Other, more recent RPGs are definitely steered towards the action side of things, and while the Bethesda games do have a fairly expansive story/lore (well, fond memories are especially coming to mind about Morrowind when I'm thinking of that), there's just something great about a game's story relying a lot on making the player read. Combat - 5/5. I've never been the best at party-based RPGs (though they're very probably my favorite style, go figure), but playing through this game has been a real learning experience. While it's not super dense, it's not too simplistic either, and it allows you to play it however you will. Eventually I got to the point where I could tell which battles required strategy to win decisively and which I could just essentially auto-smash. The variety of combat styles available through the different character classes is great, and the two unique classes added to the eschelon were fun and interesting to learn and play. There was only one battle which I ended up taking an alternative method to solving...needless to say, I tried to persevere and win it out through blood and steel, but all that was happening was my party's blood was being spilled at alarming rates and their steel was being dropped by their limp, lifeless corpses. Non-combat gameplay/exploration - 4.5/5. One of the first things which really impressed me about the game is how a character's stats and skills regularly affect gameplay outside of combat. Whether it be in conversations or scripted events or what have you, I regularly saw options I couldn't go with (a few of which unfortunately made my character act contrary to the sort of personality I'd developed for him throughout the game) and many which I could. My only complaint about this system, and it's a small one since in reality it just gives me more reason to go back and play again as different styles of characters, is that none of your companions' stats or skills can be used in any of these situations. I understand that your PC is, of course, front and center and does most of the talking, but I found myself wishing on occasion that I could have had my companions weigh in a bit more.  Pets - unrated/5. I didn't, in all honesty, see the point of having the pets around. They didn't detract from the experience at all, but they didn't add to it much for me either. They just sort of followed us around, all behaving as placidly as the others while all sorts of crazy situations unfolded around them. Stronghold - 4.5/5. Only complaint about the stronghold is there's no way to combine at least some of the resting bonuses you earn from building the various parts of the stronghold...would have been nice since there were so many lucrative rooms to stay in at the inns in various towns/cities. I enjoyed piecing the place together, and it added a fun little side-mechanic to distract me on occasion. Music - 5/5. When it needed to be atmospheric, it was atmospheric. When it needed to be a bit tense and...battle...ish....it was that. The music was well composed, varied and interesting. Graphics - 5/5. I love this style! Replayability - 5/5. The amount of variation possible between playthroughs is obscene depending on race/background/class/personality/decisions/penchance for violence/completist attitude/etc etc etc.There are still a few bugs/glitches/typos in the game, but I know the guys at Obsidian are working on getting it all ironed out. Final thoughts - I can't wait to get around to playing through this again, though I'm going to take some time off between playthroughs so I don't tire myself out of it (and so I can give some much needed attention to other games I've bought lately). I saw an interview with one of the creators stating that they're already working on putting together a story for a substantial expansion (YES!), akin to those expansions from all the older classics of the genre. This game, man. It's worth your time and money if you're into this sort of thing, and it's got me eagerly awaiting any future developments. A game destined to remain in the glorious halls of classics. TL;DR: 5/5!Final words I forgot the other day: You must gather your party before venturing forth.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Baldur's Gate.Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn.Baldur's Gate II: Throne of Bahl.These, particularly the last two, forever exist in my experience as high pinnacles of storytelling and gaming. When I first played them in my early teens I had no idea what D&D was. I did not know the 2ed Rules. I cheated extensively just to continue the story and interact with my companions. The Baldur's Gate series set the bar for any and every future RPG, and for the most part, set it too high.At times my nostalgia and heart have been tickled by others... By Mass Effect, by Neverwinter Nights and its expansions, and Dragon Age II (yes... the second one). However, nothing has ever given me half a whiff of what BGII did; to the point that I bought BGII again on GoG just to be able to play it on a modern OS.Until Pillars of Eternity. The engine? Basically the same. The character details rarely mattered; the portraits and interactions always did. PoE isn't like Skyrim or Mass Effect: You won't be spending 2-3 hours designing your protagonist. Instead, you'll choose a look and then actually step into their shoes through choices and dialogues.The settings and backgrounds range from "Yeah, this really is a dirt road through nowhere" to "Bawls, that is a beautiful set-piece!" More than once I stopped or backtracked to look at a particular sculpture again, or re-loaded just to get another glimpse before a fight. There are some stunning places and things to be at and look at in this game.The characters are strong. By that, I mean they are consistent, different from each other, and overall endearing. I have not tried them all (I, apparently, didn't find all of them through my first complete playthrough!), but the ones I eventually settled on were living, breathing beings with their own pasts, desires, and beliefs. Not every one is an enigma wrapped in a riddle wrapped in a bow -- but not every single one needs to be. The major fights in this game, as I played on Normal, were on the easy side with the exception of the dragons.The story was long. Much longer than I thought -- both to my delight and occasional frustration. There are weaker parts and stronger parts, but the pressure of the main plot only felt light once or twice. The mystery is well played, and I didn't see the ending coming at all; though (reminiscent of other RPGs) the final few acts felt somewhat underwhelming. When I replay it (and it's definitely a "when") I'll have a much narrower idea of what I want to do, and I believe I'd even enjoy one more playthrough after that.The game's mechanics are easy to get a jist of, but too ambiguous to really min-max on your first go through. A second playthrough is warranted based on what options you missed by 1 stat or 1 skill alone.Who will like this game? Anybody and everybody who enjoyed the Baldur's Gate series. Anybody who likes RPGs with squad-based micro-management and has the patience to play a game like this through (60 hours was my minimum, though I think you could squeak by your first time with 40-50 hours).It may only be 85% of what Baldur's Gate II: SoA + ToB is to me, but to be likened to my personal pillar of gaming is high praise from me since so many others claimed BG2's heritage and didn't just underdeliver, but fell painfully short. PoE is a good game, and will be a good game whenever I play it again and again.  It's the type of game I may not play for months, or years, but when I do it will fulfill a very specific need: The need to immerse myself in a different world and with fully formed characters to go on an adventure.Heartily recommended.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Pillars of eternity, Pillars of frustration, Pillars of reloading, Loading screens of eternity. Pillars of awesomeness!Yes, it's true, the game is hard and frustrating, and also very retro. But I love it, it's huge, and the story and deep combat suck you in, if you don't give up after the first hour. But you really have to like this sort of thing, reading a lot to immerse yourself in the story, you need to learn what's what in order not to get trashed by even a spider. This all takes time, and it's not for everyone. I did not play Baldur's Gate,and I'm not really nostalgic for isometric RPGs. I actually wish you could rotate the camera, because sometimes a column or door will block your view. In my opinion, they could have made a few things less nostalgic (eg why so much backtracking in this time and age, why so much useless loot, and why so many loading screens?), but these are ultimately minutiae and I can definitely look past them, because it's objectively a great game.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												It is a pretty good game. It is what you would expect from an old school RPG like Baldurs Gate. However, the graphics could be better (try zoom in and you can see how unclear the visuals look). Some of the dialogue is voiced, but most is not. Maybe they will do more voiced dialogue with updates. I think the game is worth the money, but I feel it could have been better. The gaming experience is not "WAUW OMG!", but it is a  pretty good game in the genre. There is a lot of quests with lots of story and dialogue (if you dont like that, then you wont like the quests very much - although you can skip them and let the quests descriptions in the journal guide you instead, if you dont care about the stories anyway. Thus, it is not a huge problem). I would say that game is like 7,5/10 for its genre. There are some combat mechanis from Divinity of Original Sin, which you could have taken into this game. Fx. lightning on pools of water make it electrical and gives lightning damage to those going into it, or being able to freeze a pool of water into ice. The music and sounds in Pillars of Eternity is much better than in Divinity of Original Sin. Also, the characters in Pillars of Eternity are interesting, which makes you want to them a little better. Anyway, all in all it is a highly recomendable game for those who like the genre. You pretty much get what you would expect and there is a lot of hours of gameplay in it, so you get the moneys worth of content.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												A New School Game for Old School Gamers!Pillars of Eternity brings back the Infinity Engine style RPG that many of us played and loved. Taking inspiration from Baldur's Gate. Icewind Dale, and Planescape: Torment, Pillars of Eternity offers up a great experience for anyone who was a fan of those old games and are looking for a new game to play in a similar vain. It definitely lives up to its status as a "spiritual successor." While playing, it has the depth and story of Baldur's Gate, a soundtrack and tactical combat of Icewind Dale, and the walls of text and fluff that Torment had.Even if you have not played those styles of games, Pillars is a great game to play still. The positives of Pillars of Eternity include:1.An in depth character creation system including many different races and unique classes (and backgrounds!) that only fuel the RPG experience2. A unique system that still has a pen and paper feel to it3. A game that facilitates role playing a character and developing them.4. Both recruitable NPCs and the ability to make your own recruitable party members.5. An engaging story set in a unique and interesting worldOne of Pillars downsides is it lacks the multiplayer mode that Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale had, but hopefully an update or DLC will add it. If not, I sure hope a sequel does. Now you may not view this as a downside, so that may not be a concern to you. Also wish the Stronghold function had a little more depth to it.All in all, Pillars of Eternity is a great game that harkons back to the old days of some of the best RPGs and can now consider itself amongst their ranks. Get it. Play it. Enjoy it.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												My recommendation does not extend to the DLC which I do not own and probably will not. The Basic game is enough bang for the buck if you get this on sale. I found it to be very similar in style to its predecessors by Bioware, Baldur's Gate etc. But the character generation is not 100% D&D as you know it. It is very nicely done and makes you feel as if you are immersing in the creation as opposed to just checking off tick boxes here and there. The story line is also immersive and interesting if the plots tend to thread a bit longer than I like and involve some fed ex type quests that leave one wishing travel were a little faster. (Even with the fast mode it takes time.) Similar in that sense to NWN. The stronghold is a better done version of the same idea as the one in NWN 2. Though it is rather matter of fact once you get it. It seems a bit like there is a common sense way to level it up and then the foolishness of choosing a different order.  But in the end the update lengths aren't too tediously long and you should have it complete well before Act III. Especially if you do the tasks as well as the side quests. I have not finished the game yet, but I felt it has earned a thumbs up review where many games at this many hours in might start to be disappointing or discouraging completion. This one does not. I don't feel I misspent my $ on this at all.I should note that because of the depth of the character generation system and the reputation system in game you might find the replayability higher than normal rpgs. Overall 9 out of 10 in ALL areas. Especially enjoyed hearing Matt Mercer's voice as Aloth and others.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												An O.K. game. My complaints:1. Spells are very damage oriented. You don't have very many interesting utility spells or out of combat spells like in Baldur's Gate or even Neverwinter Nights.2. It feels like Keep management is half-finished. You build a bunch of stuff and post guards to protect it, but all of that investment doesn't really pay off. Feels like a strange mini-game.3. Not sure about Might influencing spell damage. Lets you play a literal muscle wizard wielding a two handed sword and wearing full plate. For some people this will be a plus - for me, it's not.4. I encountered no less than 3 game-breaking, play through ending, bugs upon launch. Thank goodness for multiple save files.5. This is nit-picking, but I hate the way that all the characters run in sync. For some reason it distracts me.On with the good.1. Some characters are fairly well written, particularly Grieving Mother and Durance.2. The story is, although somewhat predictable, fairly good.3. Scratches the cRPG itch.4. Nice soundtrack. 5. Nice art style that nods back to the golden era of cRPGs.All in all, a good, but not great, game. Noticed that there are 4 more spell levels that aren't even touched in the game, which implies there will be expansions. Might be better after DLC / expansions. Would not recommend at the price point of $45 USD - get it on sale or through a third-party site.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Baldur's Gate.Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn.Baldur's Gate II: Throne of Bahl.These, particularly the last two, forever exist in my experience as high pinnacles of storytelling and gaming. When I first played them in my early teens I had no idea what D&D was. I did not know the 2ed Rules. I cheated extensively just to continue the story and interact with my companions. The Baldur's Gate series set the bar for any and every future RPG, and for the most part, set it too high.At times my nostalgia and heart have been tickled by others... By Mass Effect, by Neverwinter Nights and its expansions, and Dragon Age II (yes... the second one). However, nothing has ever given me half a whiff of what BGII did; to the point that I bought BGII again on GoG just to be able to play it on a modern OS.Until Pillars of Eternity. The engine? Basically the same. The character details rarely mattered; the portraits and interactions always did. PoE isn't like Skyrim or Mass Effect: You won't be spending 2-3 hours designing your protagonist. Instead, you'll choose a look and then actually step into their shoes through choices and dialogues.The settings and backgrounds range from "Yeah, this really is a dirt road through nowhere" to "Bawls, that is a beautiful set-piece!" More than once I stopped or backtracked to look at a particular sculpture again, or re-loaded just to get another glimpse before a fight. There are some stunning places and things to be at and look at in this game.The characters are strong. By that, I mean they are consistent, different from each other, and overall endearing. I have not tried them all (I, apparently, didn't find all of them through my first complete playthrough!), but the ones I eventually settled on were living, breathing beings with their own pasts, desires, and beliefs. Not every one is an enigma wrapped in a riddle wrapped in a bow -- but not every single one needs to be. The major fights in this game, as I played on Normal, were on the easy side with the exception of the dragons.The story was long. Much longer than I thought -- both to my delight and occasional frustration. There are weaker parts and stronger parts, but the pressure of the main plot only felt light once or twice. The mystery is well played, and I didn't see the ending coming at all; though (reminiscent of other RPGs) the final few acts felt somewhat underwhelming. When I replay it (and it's definitely a "when") I'll have a much narrower idea of what I want to do, and I believe I'd even enjoy one more playthrough after that.The game's mechanics are easy to get a jist of, but too ambiguous to really min-max on your first go through. A second playthrough is warranted based on what options you missed by 1 stat or 1 skill alone.Who will like this game? Anybody and everybody who enjoyed the Baldur's Gate series. Anybody who likes RPGs with squad-based micro-management and has the patience to play a game like this through (60 hours was my minimum, though I think you could squeak by your first time with 40-50 hours).It may only be 85% of what Baldur's Gate II: SoA + ToB is to me, but to be likened to my personal pillar of gaming is high praise from me since so many others claimed BG2's heritage and didn't just underdeliver, but fell painfully short. PoE is a good game, and will be a good game whenever I play it again and again.  It's the type of game I may not play for months, or years, but when I do it will fulfill a very specific need: The need to immerse myself in a different world and with fully formed characters to go on an adventure.Heartily recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												As an avid fan of the old Infinity Engine games, and after all the rave reviews, I was very excited to be able to finally play this game, and for the first couple of hours I was impressed at the scope, the overall quality, and the succesfull way in which an old gaming formule was brought into the 21st century. A couple more hours in, I am still impressed by the scope of Pillars of Eternity...but somehow I can't help but feel slightly let down.That's not to say that there isn't an awful lot they DID do right. The combat, e.g., has been given a successful overhaul. It's still  fun and deep, but plays out a lot faster and seems far less dependent on fairly random crowd control effects from the old games. I also like the little touches like the per-battle (rather than per-day) abilities, the fast movement mode, and innovative classes like the Chanter.Also, in general the story and dialogue are interesting, although I do agree with some reviews that the entire affair does tend to get a bit long-winded and a bit too serious at times. That being said..I feel the whole thing is a bit uninspired. The quests, the level design,  and even the loot (basically you get very little good stuff, you have to enchant it) certainly get the job done, but it never strays far from the established formula and all feels a bit...bland. Compared to the freshness of e.g. Divinity: Original Sin, which did manage to bring something truly new to the table in spite of being decidedly old school as well, PoE is a letdown. It also falls quite a bit short of the game it's so obviously paying hommage to, Baldur's Gate 2..that game constantly managed to surprise you with great level designs and quests..here I've waded through 7 levels of Endless Path dungeon without anything that stood out. Maybe this comes across as overly harsh, since it is a good game and I am enjoying it, but it does feel like quantity over quality..they basically throw everything but the kitchen sink at you and hope it will stick. Most of it does, and there are some really good idea on display here, but a lot also feels like padding (far too many samey accounters, a flimsy stronghold...ironically, exactly the things that Dragon Age origins also did wrong)

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Pillars is a great game in it's own right. If you loved Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment or Icewind Dale, then you will feel at home. The game is very detailed and Obsidian took great care in making every area interesting to explore. There is much dialogue and while the story not as memorable as Planescape: Torment, it still intrduces us to a new world to look to in the future. The game has replay value and Obsidian continues to patch it up. The combat is fun and you will get obliretaed if you don't plan out your strategy. Character builds are very detailed as well, so take your time with that build. Be forwarned though, the game is very buggy and crashes randomly to the Desktop. F5 frequently so that you don't loose progress. I am almost 70 hrs into the game and I am still on Act 2 since I take my time with the game. I highly recommend this game to anyone that loves this genre. It's definitely helped me with my vocabulary.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												This is, hands down, one of the best games I´ve ever played.  Because that I grew up with Baulders gate 1 and 2 this is a game well suited for me. A lively atmosphere and rich enviroments with great music to boost it. They said that they aimed to bring back the feel of the old infinty engine games (Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale e.t.c) and they did just that. Not just the isometrical camera and live turnbased combat (pausable, of course). They looked to the smaller things, such as the good old "You must gather your party before venturing forth" as well.Apart from that the game is also littered with alot of community written content wich shows that they really cherish the community they have gathered. There is no real downside to this game, it offers great replay value, great challenges and hours upon hours of gameplay.Should I really search for a downside I could find two things1: The UI has a button wich reveals that you will acquire a stronghold at one point, it could have been covered up as not to spoil a great surprise.2: I easily reached the levelcap way before reaching the end of the game, mind you it took alot of sidequesting and it kept me from being way overpowered for the endgame. A slight to much sidecontent in relation to maincontent.That being said, I strongly recommend it. It brought back so many good memories of what I love about roleplaying games.

content:

												As an avid fan of the Baldur's Gate series and most sorts of RPG's in general, Pillars of Destiny has quickly risen to be one of my all time favourites in just a small amount of time. The game is incredibly detailed story-wise to in game lore, the combat system is true to the old school Baldur's Gate-style "pause-plan-act", character depth and customization is without end, and the world scenery is damn near fantasy perfect.I love this game... And I plan to spend many, many hours more to come in the enchanted world of "Eora". This is a must-have of 2015 for all true RPG-fans.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												I am totally swept of my feet. I have been waiting for such a game since P:T in 1999. Many games went out during that 16 years, but none were so perfect as Pillars are. It has everything a perfect RPG might need. Deep, interesting world, great visuals, awesome music, truly living npcs with their own backgrounds. I am really amazed by the hit system. No more binary hit/miss with flat 5% crit chance. The mechanics built for attack rolls and miss/graze/hit/crit is really awesome. And the best thing is, it works the same on every aspect. Exactly the same formulas work for swinging a sword and casting a spell. I am playing a paladin and I am really happy that for the first time paladins aren't just uber-good warriors in shining armors. You can select from multiple ways of life, you can be a cruel/aggresive paladin, honest/diplomatic, rational/stoic and more. There is no trivial good-evil axis. There are many dispositions, many possibilities of action.It is like taking all that is best in Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Planescape: Torment and improving it 300% so that it matches the expectations of today's gamers.I am harsh when it comes to rating games, but Pillars of Eternity is peremptorily 10/10.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												This game is a good game, a very good game ! It captured the essence of what made infinity engine games so enjoyable to play and I see myself as a youngling in front of his computer once again.That being said, this game is, actually, overrated. In fact nearly everything is better executed in BG2. The AI  (ennemies or friends) was better, the UI was better, the story too (event though I'm not nearly finished with it, I played for some times, 10-12 hours, and it is slow to take off...), spell variety is lacking....And if you think it's nostalgia, I played my last BG game one year ago. In Pillars, when you are behind a tree or a house you see nothing (no option of semi-transparency), you cannot force the orientation of a non-walking character, you don't see what you gain from quest ("Well, thank you. Here seome gold as rewards !" - wanna know how many ? Well open the inventory before talking to the PNJ, loot at your amount of gold, talk to the PNJ, substract...). The pathfinding is shamefull, especially in combat ; the other NPC lacks depth ("Hmmm I'm bored.... I guess I will come with you. I just like defying death for no reason") ; secondary quests are somewhat superficial...And some things in need of a serious upgrade were not done (formation is well and good but if they do not move like it it's useless).I repeat : it's a very good game for RPG lovers such as myself. But the realization is not on par with a 15 years old game.... So even if it's a good game it does not gain his place as one of the best RPG of all times : too close to Infinity Engine games to not be compared, with too much downscale from this games (even though there's some enhancement like character animation).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Before i say anything, i just want to point out that this game kicks butt of ALL bigger title RPG's that have been made recently. I cant believe that Obsidian was almost on the verge of shutting its doors, and then they came up with something like Pillars of eternity. In my opinion, the brightest star of RPG industry currently and the best possible tribute anyone could have done for Baldurs gate's, Icewind Dale's etc. PC D&D rpg games.If baldurs gate's 1/2, icewind dale's 1/2 were you thing back in the days, i can tell you Pillars of eternity just brought the genre back! Beautiful hand made graphics, orchestral music, top notch plot etc. brings me back to the days when games had just the right amount of difficulty and the player wasn't lead from the hand in every turn.And dont worry, the game isnt stuck to the early years of rpg's. The UI is very well made to the modern standards, as is many other things such as possibility of "hiring" a companion wich is basically creating a filler character in your group by yourself. The hiring system is a genius idea honestly, as you want to have a full group as soon as possible early on in the game. Later on you can also of course find groupable NPC's that have a personality, opinions and own agenda wich you can choose to proceed if you will. So now you get to make a group with every other npc character in game, as you can simply fill the empty spots with the hiring system. Smart.As you play the game a bit further, you get your own stronghold where you can build stuff, switch your companions, get buffs after sleeping there etc. Its a great idea, because you start to get overflowing with money at some point eventually. You need to hire guards wich take weekly payment etc. Also you can send your overflow hirelings to do your bidding in case you get a writ. Usually a smart move too.One thing i really loved, was how the inventory was made. Can't tell you how many times i almost lost my nerve (except in bg2 with bag of holding :) when i had inventory full of stuff and no idea where to put all that junk.And now... the part that i really REALLY love in this game:You can carry as much stuff as you ever will want. You have an option to drop stuff to stash whenever you want, and your inventory will never be stuffed of hundreds of "junk" -items, wich btw are worth collecting and selling to vendors as you get back to town.Also i've found out that all the items you find (mushrooms, jewels etc.) are in fact useful and worth keeping instead of selling. All books, papers etc. include tips if you read them carefully and use your imagination. If you find jewels and herbs etc. you can use them for enchanting/crafting. I even found vendors selling crowbars, climbing hooks with rope, torches etc. All these items that i found useful eventually. Every now and then you gotta pry some bars aside, climb a wall, or possibly torch something up possibly.AND yes! You can craft anywhere! You can select the item you want to "enchant" and just do it on the spot without finding a forge and flapping thru useless junk in your inventory for hours. This makes the game much more straightforward (in a good sense) and you dont get stuck at inventory for ages.Also no grinding is involved for crafting. Theres no skill's or such required from what i've seen, no farming etc. You simply check what enchants, foods, potions you want/can make and just hit craft. Sometimes you can learn a recipe or such, but overall ive found crafting ever so deliciously simple. Obsidian clearly has realized that spending time in inventory instead of playing has been a fun killer for ages. Theres a lesson to be learned from this for all the big budget RPG -maker's.What i've played this game so far, only problem i find that im scared as heck to play it because time goes like ZAP!I've allready washed my laundry twice and forgotten it to the washing machine. 3rd time is about to happen, because i'm just too stuck on this game... ;D

												Am really enjoying this game so fare and looking forward to continue playing it. I Have only encountered one bug so fare which was bad enough to make me cuss which was a character became stuck in place unable to move during a boss fight which meant I had to restart from a previous save (cussed because had won a difficult fight but then had to do-over).Other slightly odd things are creatures such as slime's or shades or the like being able to be tripped over?? or animal companions/ summons being able to start dialogue (can set up party then move up animal to start a dialogue which leads to combat meaning you are not caught out of formation), supper sneak (get a good look at whats ahead with animals who seem to be able to get closer to mobs than party members without being detected), animals can climb like people (if you go up a ladder or climb a vine pets should have to wait/ especially an animal which couldn't be carried by the party .i.e. bear). As I mentioned at the start I am loving this game and looking forward to continue to play, and I am sure as time progresses and the game is patched and updated it will evolve. I do very much like how combat is calculated and the HP and resting system which makes for a more tactical play style. I also like that I am not picking up +10 item of kill everything every other battle, and that monsters more often than not are dropping the items which they are using .i.e. they are not using a basic weapon in combat but then drop some amazing magical item (which just wouldn't make any sense).Thanks for the great game and the hours of enjoyment I have had and have left to enjoy, looking forward to any additional content/ updates.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												This is my first review ever, i will start by saying that this a great game, well worth the full retail price, Obsidian has done great work considering the budget that they had to develop this game on. The game may have a few bugs but i did not run into any on my time playing it and if there are any they would not detract from the fun romp this game is.Pros-Great Story-Great Companions-Choices that actually matter-You actions shape other characters opinons of you- People will reflect to you differently depending on your disposition- one character may try to kill you while that same character could listen to reason depending on your disposition.-Challenging Gameplay- ability to structure game for either old school gaming or for those who enjoy the story based aspects more.-Replayability- Different dialogue choices for different classes and races provides a reason to replay-Great art style- the storyboards look very good, the hand drawn maps look well crafted and have a certian appeal to them-15 level dungeonCons-Story takes a while to pick up you do not know a lot about what is going until the middle of the 2nd act -AI- the game needs the ability to better micromange your characters- the fact that you can not assign standard behaviours to your characters (e.g. heal yourself if under certian edurance/ health) forces to pause and play after each move, this can get frustrating particularly in the large fights with lots of mircomanagement where one wrong move can kill your party (Characters not moving if you have not selected them- they should at least have a default attack)-Stronghold Management- feels a bit lacking while the bounty quests are good, the stronghold just seems to be a a way to spend the large amount of money you will not need to spend, finished the game with no cash than i needed- A few pathfinding issues

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												I haven't yet finished this game, being the type of person who likes to complete every possible side quest and explore every area in RPG's, but I feel like I have seen enough of the game to write this review. Pillars of Eternity is a game moulded very much in the fashion of some of my favourite games of all time; Baldur's Gate (I & II) and Icewind Dale, and it definately justifies it's position sitting side by side with these greats.Being a top down RPG it doesn't have the flashiest or most breathtaking visuals, nor the fast paced combat of many of today's modern games, but it doesn't suffer for it in the slightest. A fascinating, dark and gritty high fantasty world, bursting with interesting and entertaining characters in which you search for answers to a mysterious event from the start of the game set the stage for the telling of a very well devised story. Like most games of this genre, it features a reasonably well detailed character creation system which allows you to feel that important attachment and immersion during the story, and the voice acting/script writing work is very well done. Expect to be amused, baffled and enthralled in equal measure by the numerous NPC's with which you can party up and travel with (all with their own backstories, most of which I found pretty neat).Combat-wise the game is solid, being pretty much standard fare for this type of game, but it felt nice and smooth and there is a good variety and diversity of skills amongst the classes. Loot is also varied and interesting enough to keep you constantly on the hunt for that next upgrade or nice drop. One thing I found very pleasing about the game was the abiluty to acquire and upgrade your own "Keep", which was obtained through a very interesting quest and worked solidly with the main story line of the game, intermingling seamlessly as I quested back and froth between them.Overall this is a game which borrows, and to a small extent, builds on the solid foundations of prior games in this genre and couples it with a beautiful and detailed world and engaging story. There is nothing particularly groundbreaking added in this game (or at least, what I have experienced of it this far), but there a few new features here and there which fit in very well with the overall experience, without parting too much from the old school feel the game conveys. Highly reccomended, especially if you already a fan of similar games.

												A fantastic (in the true sense of the word) adventure with a capturing story, great delivery and atmopshere, alright character-development and DnD-esque combat and conversation. This is for anyone in love with the DnD-esque genre. I would say that if you expect something like Torchlight/Diablo just because its isometric, you're in the wrong genre. Combat is slow, tactical and at times a challenge or a chore. The main bright spots of this game are the story and the lore and the atmosphere. It really does feel like an adventure or a quest.Here's the deal though: it is not worth 40 euros. Buy it in a heartbeat if its 50% off or more, but any price large than 20 euros is honestly pushing it. Its a really great game, but the genre generally belongs to the past for a good reason, and lore can only carry a game so far.8/10 , great game, awful price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I'm not much of a review writer (I think I've written maybe two before this one), but...this game's deserving of a good review, and as I finished my first playthrough earlier today it seemed the ideal time. Unfortunately, I'm not a wordy person, so I'll point out some quick bits and leave the description of the plot out apart from some very simple comparison to its grandparents:Story - 6/5. Seriously, it's so multi-faceted, between the main questline and all of the side quests, it's the type of story we haven't seen since the good old days of cRPGs (aka Pillars' grandparents!). Other, more recent RPGs are definitely steered towards the action side of things, and while the Bethesda games do have a fairly expansive story/lore (well, fond memories are especially coming to mind about Morrowind when I'm thinking of that), there's just something great about a game's story relying a lot on making the player read. Combat - 5/5. I've never been the best at party-based RPGs (though they're very probably my favorite style, go figure), but playing through this game has been a real learning experience. While it's not super dense, it's not too simplistic either, and it allows you to play it however you will. Eventually I got to the point where I could tell which battles required strategy to win decisively and which I could just essentially auto-smash. The variety of combat styles available through the different character classes is great, and the two unique classes added to the eschelon were fun and interesting to learn and play. There was only one battle which I ended up taking an alternative method to solving...needless to say, I tried to persevere and win it out through blood and steel, but all that was happening was my party's blood was being spilled at alarming rates and their steel was being dropped by their limp, lifeless corpses. Non-combat gameplay/exploration - 4.5/5. One of the first things which really impressed me about the game is how a character's stats and skills regularly affect gameplay outside of combat. Whether it be in conversations or scripted events or what have you, I regularly saw options I couldn't go with (a few of which unfortunately made my character act contrary to the sort of personality I'd developed for him throughout the game) and many which I could. My only complaint about this system, and it's a small one since in reality it just gives me more reason to go back and play again as different styles of characters, is that none of your companions' stats or skills can be used in any of these situations. I understand that your PC is, of course, front and center and does most of the talking, but I found myself wishing on occasion that I could have had my companions weigh in a bit more.  Pets - unrated/5. I didn't, in all honesty, see the point of having the pets around. They didn't detract from the experience at all, but they didn't add to it much for me either. They just sort of followed us around, all behaving as placidly as the others while all sorts of crazy situations unfolded around them. Stronghold - 4.5/5. Only complaint about the stronghold is there's no way to combine at least some of the resting bonuses you earn from building the various parts of the stronghold...would have been nice since there were so many lucrative rooms to stay in at the inns in various towns/cities. I enjoyed piecing the place together, and it added a fun little side-mechanic to distract me on occasion. Music - 5/5. When it needed to be atmospheric, it was atmospheric. When it needed to be a bit tense and...battle...ish....it was that. The music was well composed, varied and interesting. Graphics - 5/5. I love this style! Replayability - 5/5. The amount of variation possible between playthroughs is obscene depending on race/background/class/personality/decisions/penchance for violence/completist attitude/etc etc etc.There are still a few bugs/glitches/typos in the game, but I know the guys at Obsidian are working on getting it all ironed out. Final thoughts - I can't wait to get around to playing through this again, though I'm going to take some time off between playthroughs so I don't tire myself out of it (and so I can give some much needed attention to other games I've bought lately). I saw an interview with one of the creators stating that they're already working on putting together a story for a substantial expansion (YES!), akin to those expansions from all the older classics of the genre. This game, man. It's worth your time and money if you're into this sort of thing, and it's got me eagerly awaiting any future developments. A game destined to remain in the glorious halls of classics. TL;DR: 5/5!Final words I forgot the other day: You must gather your party before venturing forth.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												As an avid fan of Baldur's Gat I & II as well as Planescape Torment, it was an easy decision to back Pillars of Eternity on Kickstarter. When the final product came out with glowing reviews, my anticipation was high. Luckily I can say POE lives up to the promises of the Kickstarter; albeit with its own caveats.What's amazing about POE is that it's easily the most accessible for newcomers and veterans alike. You can simply toggle on or off tutorial menus and the like whenever you want. There are new additions to the gameplay and interface that made me admire the attention to detail. Don't be scared off if you've never played this type of game.On the whole Pillars of Eternity feels like it needs just a bit more creative time in the oven. The core story is a bit lackluster. I never cared for the world or truly understood what the threat was. The writing quality and quantity is still very high, but the stakes never seem worth it. It's like I was back home but all the people and furnishing were different. And when compared to other games in their library, this appears even paler in comparison. The characters also aren't as interesting or memorable for the exception of a couple. There's still a TON of story in this game. You can always find a new tome or book on a shelf ready to be read. Yet I always sold these books at markets instead of reading them. I just kinda wanted the main adventure to be over with.Side quests are plentiful although a tad redundant. Most missions are kill or retrieve. The consequences of your actions doesn't feel as dramatic as Baldur's Gate II. Plus your options in the dialog tree, while there, don't feel like they're as deep.Dungeoning is still fun. The action is as intense as before. Spell casting doesn't seem to be as fun. It didn't quite feel like I was on a huge adventure for some reason. Like the confines of the maps were smaller than before. This game is definitely challenging especially if you're not ready for it. It's good to see that the pause mechanic and planning out your attacks is still in good form. I love playing as the ranger class but I was sad to see that there are no arrow/projectile types that you can manage and buy. If you have a bow, crossbow, or sling you have an infinite amount of ammo as your disposal. I guess they came to the conclusion that this got in the way of the fun factor.What I loved about the original Baldur's Gate games was the sense of an inhabited world. Random events, character interactions, and grand adventures seemed to spring out of nowhere at any time. All distinct and unique from each other. Pillars of Eternity feels like it's cut short in most categories; although, it's still quite up there in terms of quality.For the year this came out in, it's easily one of the best games of the year. In terms of the Baldur's Gate and Planescape Torment games, it's in the back of the pack but a welcome addition. A sequel is warranted.
