content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Overall, a pretty entertaining game.The combat is alright, I can never decide if I actually like this sort of game, but it seem to work pretty well for the most part. If it isn't your thing, just turn down the difficulty of the game. I personally prefer easy difficulties for this sort of thing as I find the combat more entertaining when you don't have to worry about it so much.For those unaware, the system is that of a top down, pausable RPG where your characters have various abilities you can use which are either per-encounter, per-rest, or use some kind of in combat resource (i.e. monks use "wounds" to power their stuff). I'm not personally a fan of per-rest stuff, as I find it tends to be that I just avoid using certain abilities unless I really need them, which is kind of lame because it makes the combat have a lot less variety. There's also a mechanic called fatigue which makes your characters weaker if you don't rest for a long time, and I'd have preferred to see that more fleshed out in place of a hard limit of "this ability can be used twice per rest". The story and interactions is where the game stands out though, and for me is the real reason to play it. There's quite a wide variety of things to do and people to talk to, with many response options to choose from (I'd recommend turning off the option to see why you can choose certain options though, as I find it makes the interactions more interesting - often if I see I've unlocked an option by having X stat, it will make me want to choose that option. If I can't see that, then I just choose more naturally what I want to do). Overall pretty fun though, in particular if its on sale I'd recommend picking it up - it's worth one playthrough at least if you can get it for a good price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												PoE is one of the best RPGs I have ever played (and I've been playing them for decades).  It is the first game that actually succeeds at recreating the strategic fun of the Infinity Engine games (Baldur's Game, Icewind Dale, etc.) while updating the style and gameplay for the modern day.  This is an insanely deep game, which is obvious from the get-go tons of player choice everywhere.  Not only that, but Obsidian created a totally unique character development system for players to experiment with that affects both combat and story.  This isn't your typical Str, Dex, Con-based game, but more of a hybrid including elements you might see in a Fallout-style game (stats and chosen origin will give you dialogue options).I don't think anything can touch the storyline of the Baldur's Gate games in my mind, but I've been enjoying PoE's very much, with all of its twists and turns and options to discover through exploration.If you like RPGs, especially deep, tactical RPGs, I recommend PoE.  If you've been looking for Baldur's Gate III, you need PoE now.

But once you're into the game and the story, Pillars is definitely a game that's going to keep you busy. It's too bad that you have to spend so much time looking at loading screens, because otherwise the game would easily keep you going when you should go to sleep (okay, you could call that a good thing if you like to be awake when you have to work). If you're just looking for a action packed RPG, Pillars might not be the thing for you, but if you like a deep story, reading massive amounts of text (it's insane really) and decent tactical D&D-style combat, then Pillars is the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												A New School Game for Old School Gamers!Pillars of Eternity brings back the Infinity Engine style RPG that many of us played and loved. Taking inspiration from Baldur's Gate. Icewind Dale, and Planescape: Torment, Pillars of Eternity offers up a great experience for anyone who was a fan of those old games and are looking for a new game to play in a similar vain. It definitely lives up to its status as a "spiritual successor." While playing, it has the depth and story of Baldur's Gate, a soundtrack and tactical combat of Icewind Dale, and the walls of text and fluff that Torment had.Even if you have not played those styles of games, Pillars is a great game to play still. The positives of Pillars of Eternity include:1.An in depth character creation system including many different races and unique classes (and backgrounds!) that only fuel the RPG experience2. A unique system that still has a pen and paper feel to it3. A game that facilitates role playing a character and developing them.4. Both recruitable NPCs and the ability to make your own recruitable party members.5. An engaging story set in a unique and interesting worldOne of Pillars downsides is it lacks the multiplayer mode that Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale had, but hopefully an update or DLC will add it. If not, I sure hope a sequel does. Now you may not view this as a downside, so that may not be a concern to you. Also wish the Stronghold function had a little more depth to it.All in all, Pillars of Eternity is a great game that harkons back to the old days of some of the best RPGs and can now consider itself amongst their ranks. Get it. Play it. Enjoy it.

												Best game of its type since Baldur's Gate 2. Item diversity could have used some work, as could the crafting system. Also no romance options, which was a bummer, since those were some of the best story sections of games like Baldur's Gate 2.  You could tell they wanted to do everything but ran out of time or money at some point.  Looking forward to expansions/sequels/new games of the same type now that Obsidian has decent proof that games like this can make a profit.Just... if you liked BG2, buy this game.  Buy it to relive the nostalgia of playing a story-heavy well written game of this type.  Buy it to encourage game devs to keep making these.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Early ReviewYes I spent the $45 on it and so far I'm very happy.  This is Baldur's Gate for 2015.Pros:-- Character Creation:  Excellent setup - great back stories, plenty of customization.  Talents, skills, and point distribution.--  Difficulty Settings:  several different options here - which should give it high replay value as well.--  Storyline:  so far so good.  Got me involved right from the beginning.  The main story-arch is developing nicely and gradually.  Good voice acting and dialog seems to flow - feels genuine--  Combat - similar to BG of course--  Crafting -- oh yeah!  That's a nice touch, nothing too dramatic yet - but you don't just have to sell junk - you can craft some useful combat buffs.-- Stash - very helpful--  Recruit mercs - early on even you can recruit some party members for reasonable amounts of copper.  Very helpful in those sticky places--  Stronghold - just just started this part.  But seems like a nice developing touch of building your stronghold - looks like you can develop some residual incomeCONS--  Graphics are so-so but this isn't a big con for me.  In a top-down 3rd person, I can live with it.  Some like it, some don't.--  Combat sometimes is overwhelming.  Getting into some places early on where I'm completely overwhelmed.  Could be frustrating to some.--  Fog of war feels a bit tight, but not incredibly so.That's all I can think of now - will update more later.Overall I have no hesitation in saying it's worth the money.  As a BG / Icewind / RPG fan, I'll get every penny's worth out of this one.This game will make great grounds for future divorces.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Just to clarify before I dive into the review, Pillars of Eternity is a MASTERPIECE! *cough* OK, it is hard to not compare it to Balder's gate (and in turn The White March to Icewind Dale) Balder's gate 2 is my all time favourite video game. Now I am being pedantic here but it is not Balder's gate 2, quite. It is closer to part 1. (which really makes me want a Pillars 2!) I don't like the level cap being so low and I would have prefered a few more spells. Please though, this is only while comparing to BG2. If you've never played any of the games this is almost a homage to then you will be blown away by the variety in combat. As a story, it's stunning. Keeps you gripped and has many twists and turns along this long road. It actually gets quite intense. The homestead parts I found a perfect retreat from the world around. You see it build, it grow,many quests stem from there, it becomes home. Gameplay wise, if you know isometric games then it's a piece of cake to pick up, but very tricky to master. In my eyes, and I have read people say the combat is boring (???) .... The combat is deep and complex with many possible outcomes. The companions are superbly written and come with very interesting quests and personalities. One gripe I had, no evil team. I always liked a run with the good, and the bad, but it wasn't to be. Graphics are ace, it's smooth, beautiful and gripping. A true masterpiece of modern gaming. I want to give it 5 but just because of a couple of minor let-downs I give Pillars 4.8 out of 5. Any RPG fan should own this!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												To all the fans of Baulder's Gate: you need this game in your life.Incredibly deep and wonderfully immersive, Pillars of Eternity is absolutely stuffed to the brim with so much lore that you'll wonder which has more - this, or Skyrim. With tons of races, classes, and choices of playstyle, you're guaranteed to find the perfect fit.As someone who has no patience for turn-based combat, I'm rather fond of the fact that I can just let my party go at it with enemies on auto-pilot. Very often I'll find they've decimated the opposition so quickly that some summoning spells have just been cast and now I have to wait that extra second or two for the summoned allies to disappear before I can loot all those corpses. Other times, I'll find my party absolutely destroyed because I've run headfirst into a difficult fight that really shouldn't be attempted without using the turn-based combat system properly, or else over-leveling by a lot.One of the most intensely satisfying things about Pillars of Eternity is the vast number of choices in dialogue and how different choices affect your story in different ways. This is not the game to go about "exhausting all the dialogue options" - often, if you try to, you'll find that you've♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥someone important off, or doomed a character's fate, or swayed a faction's views in the opposite direction from your intention.So! Do yourself the favor: Buy this game. Play it. Immerse yourself. And don't look back.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity is an incredibly good game in the spirit of Baldur's Gate and Planescape: Torment, though fans of Spiderweb Studio game's such as Geneforge and Avernum will also feel at home.The combat system seems to inspired by the tabletop game Dungeons and Dragons 4th edition, with your abilities being split into encounter and daily powers that reset either after the end of every fight or after each rest. While I am not a fan of D&D 4th, I have always said that their combat system would work better in a computor game, and I feel that Pillars of Eternity proves me right here. I did not play Pillars for its combat system, but I enjoyed the tactical battles none the less.Without mentioning any spoilers, the storyline for Pillars of Eternity is fantastic. There are a myriads of options and solutions to most if not all problems in the game, with significance to your characters reputation which I felt led to natural consequences throughout the game. While there were some small handful of places where I felt like I could have done with slightly more branching paths in the storyline, I were pleasently surprised when the game often gave me choices that I did not expect.The companions are a colourful collection of eight, and while I love them and my characters' interaction with them, they may well be my biggest critique in the game. While their quests are interesting, and while I grew attached to their bantering in the background in the course of our adventure together, I felt as if they are largely ignored by the world. They will sometimes comment upon an ungoing dialogue, yet the NPCs will often neither remark upon or indeed notice your companions contribution. This makes them feel sadly invisible and unimportant. I still love them, I simply wish that they had more of an impact on the overall game.The music of the game is discrete and enjoyable. I am generally the kind of gamer who will turn the music off while playing to listen to my own, yet I left the music on throughout the game as I felt that it heightend the experience without being all up in my face.To round things up, I would recommend Pillars of Eternity to any cRPG fan out there, and also to anyone who wishes to get into cRPGs as the learning curve is not too steep, certainly not as steep as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. The game caters to many different kind of playstyles, so anyone who likes seeing their own character grow forth as a person in and of itself is bound to enjoy this wonderful game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I finished the game with about 99% of all quest/explorations done.It is a decent spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate 2 and an absolute piece of art in it's scenery and graphics. You can notice the art team did an amazing job down to the details.The problem is that the game is still quite buggy, I came across a lot of them, including major ones that wouldn't allow me to continue and would make me load an older save file. So keep this in mind and save often and in different files.The battle is often poorly balanced because of it's system. It feels as if they tried to make this revolutionary system of endurance with armors, damage reduction, graze/crits being more realistic. But it fell short in the execution and you will notice battles can be quite draggy, often going for much longer than it should despite having the most powerful weapon and a high level character. I feel they could have achieved more by sticking with a stable equipment system (+1,+2, etc) and spending more time polishing the game, removing bugs and adding more depth to quests and NPCs.The Stronghold  was extremely positive, adding a lot to the game without disrupting your adventures around. But the Endless Paths could definitely have used more time. Some levels were quite plain and could easily be just part of other levels. And safe a few levels, most of them didn't have any characteristic or good NPCs or puzzles such as Watcher's Keep did in BG2.Having said that, I really enjoyed the game. It doesn't have the magic that Baldur's Gate series had had (every area had so much depth and quests and interesting NPCs that is hard to compare), nor Pillars of Eternity has a very surprising storyline. But I quite enjoyed it and I think everyone will feel accomplished by the end of the game.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												As an avid fan of Baldur's Gat I & II as well as Planescape Torment, it was an easy decision to back Pillars of Eternity on Kickstarter. When the final product came out with glowing reviews, my anticipation was high. Luckily I can say POE lives up to the promises of the Kickstarter; albeit with its own caveats.What's amazing about POE is that it's easily the most accessible for newcomers and veterans alike. You can simply toggle on or off tutorial menus and the like whenever you want. There are new additions to the gameplay and interface that made me admire the attention to detail. Don't be scared off if you've never played this type of game.On the whole Pillars of Eternity feels like it needs just a bit more creative time in the oven. The core story is a bit lackluster. I never cared for the world or truly understood what the threat was. The writing quality and quantity is still very high, but the stakes never seem worth it. It's like I was back home but all the people and furnishing were different. And when compared to other games in their library, this appears even paler in comparison. The characters also aren't as interesting or memorable for the exception of a couple. There's still a TON of story in this game. You can always find a new tome or book on a shelf ready to be read. Yet I always sold these books at markets instead of reading them. I just kinda wanted the main adventure to be over with.Side quests are plentiful although a tad redundant. Most missions are kill or retrieve. The consequences of your actions doesn't feel as dramatic as Baldur's Gate II. Plus your options in the dialog tree, while there, don't feel like they're as deep.Dungeoning is still fun. The action is as intense as before. Spell casting doesn't seem to be as fun. It didn't quite feel like I was on a huge adventure for some reason. Like the confines of the maps were smaller than before. This game is definitely challenging especially if you're not ready for it. It's good to see that the pause mechanic and planning out your attacks is still in good form. I love playing as the ranger class but I was sad to see that there are no arrow/projectile types that you can manage and buy. If you have a bow, crossbow, or sling you have an infinite amount of ammo as your disposal. I guess they came to the conclusion that this got in the way of the fun factor.What I loved about the original Baldur's Gate games was the sense of an inhabited world. Random events, character interactions, and grand adventures seemed to spring out of nowhere at any time. All distinct and unique from each other. Pillars of Eternity feels like it's cut short in most categories; although, it's still quite up there in terms of quality.For the year this came out in, it's easily one of the best games of the year. In terms of the Baldur's Gate and Planescape Torment games, it's in the back of the pack but a welcome addition. A sequel is warranted.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Overall, a pretty entertaining game.The combat is alright, I can never decide if I actually like this sort of game, but it seem to work pretty well for the most part. If it isn't your thing, just turn down the difficulty of the game. I personally prefer easy difficulties for this sort of thing as I find the combat more entertaining when you don't have to worry about it so much.For those unaware, the system is that of a top down, pausable RPG where your characters have various abilities you can use which are either per-encounter, per-rest, or use some kind of in combat resource (i.e. monks use "wounds" to power their stuff). I'm not personally a fan of per-rest stuff, as I find it tends to be that I just avoid using certain abilities unless I really need them, which is kind of lame because it makes the combat have a lot less variety. There's also a mechanic called fatigue which makes your characters weaker if you don't rest for a long time, and I'd have preferred to see that more fleshed out in place of a hard limit of "this ability can be used twice per rest". The story and interactions is where the game stands out though, and for me is the real reason to play it. There's quite a wide variety of things to do and people to talk to, with many response options to choose from (I'd recommend turning off the option to see why you can choose certain options though, as I find it makes the interactions more interesting - often if I see I've unlocked an option by having X stat, it will make me want to choose that option. If I can't see that, then I just choose more naturally what I want to do). Overall pretty fun though, in particular if its on sale I'd recommend picking it up - it's worth one playthrough at least if you can get it for a good price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												A New School Game for Old School Gamers!Pillars of Eternity brings back the Infinity Engine style RPG that many of us played and loved. Taking inspiration from Baldur's Gate. Icewind Dale, and Planescape: Torment, Pillars of Eternity offers up a great experience for anyone who was a fan of those old games and are looking for a new game to play in a similar vain. It definitely lives up to its status as a "spiritual successor." While playing, it has the depth and story of Baldur's Gate, a soundtrack and tactical combat of Icewind Dale, and the walls of text and fluff that Torment had.Even if you have not played those styles of games, Pillars is a great game to play still. The positives of Pillars of Eternity include:1.An in depth character creation system including many different races and unique classes (and backgrounds!) that only fuel the RPG experience2. A unique system that still has a pen and paper feel to it3. A game that facilitates role playing a character and developing them.4. Both recruitable NPCs and the ability to make your own recruitable party members.5. An engaging story set in a unique and interesting worldOne of Pillars downsides is it lacks the multiplayer mode that Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale had, but hopefully an update or DLC will add it. If not, I sure hope a sequel does. Now you may not view this as a downside, so that may not be a concern to you. Also wish the Stronghold function had a little more depth to it.All in all, Pillars of Eternity is a great game that harkons back to the old days of some of the best RPGs and can now consider itself amongst their ranks. Get it. Play it. Enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I'm not much of a review writer (I think I've written maybe two before this one), but...this game's deserving of a good review, and as I finished my first playthrough earlier today it seemed the ideal time. Unfortunately, I'm not a wordy person, so I'll point out some quick bits and leave the description of the plot out apart from some very simple comparison to its grandparents:Story - 6/5. Seriously, it's so multi-faceted, between the main questline and all of the side quests, it's the type of story we haven't seen since the good old days of cRPGs (aka Pillars' grandparents!). Other, more recent RPGs are definitely steered towards the action side of things, and while the Bethesda games do have a fairly expansive story/lore (well, fond memories are especially coming to mind about Morrowind when I'm thinking of that), there's just something great about a game's story relying a lot on making the player read. Combat - 5/5. I've never been the best at party-based RPGs (though they're very probably my favorite style, go figure), but playing through this game has been a real learning experience. While it's not super dense, it's not too simplistic either, and it allows you to play it however you will. Eventually I got to the point where I could tell which battles required strategy to win decisively and which I could just essentially auto-smash. The variety of combat styles available through the different character classes is great, and the two unique classes added to the eschelon were fun and interesting to learn and play. There was only one battle which I ended up taking an alternative method to solving...needless to say, I tried to persevere and win it out through blood and steel, but all that was happening was my party's blood was being spilled at alarming rates and their steel was being dropped by their limp, lifeless corpses. Non-combat gameplay/exploration - 4.5/5. One of the first things which really impressed me about the game is how a character's stats and skills regularly affect gameplay outside of combat. Whether it be in conversations or scripted events or what have you, I regularly saw options I couldn't go with (a few of which unfortunately made my character act contrary to the sort of personality I'd developed for him throughout the game) and many which I could. My only complaint about this system, and it's a small one since in reality it just gives me more reason to go back and play again as different styles of characters, is that none of your companions' stats or skills can be used in any of these situations. I understand that your PC is, of course, front and center and does most of the talking, but I found myself wishing on occasion that I could have had my companions weigh in a bit more.  Pets - unrated/5. I didn't, in all honesty, see the point of having the pets around. They didn't detract from the experience at all, but they didn't add to it much for me either. They just sort of followed us around, all behaving as placidly as the others while all sorts of crazy situations unfolded around them. Stronghold - 4.5/5. Only complaint about the stronghold is there's no way to combine at least some of the resting bonuses you earn from building the various parts of the stronghold...would have been nice since there were so many lucrative rooms to stay in at the inns in various towns/cities. I enjoyed piecing the place together, and it added a fun little side-mechanic to distract me on occasion. Music - 5/5. When it needed to be atmospheric, it was atmospheric. When it needed to be a bit tense and...battle...ish....it was that. The music was well composed, varied and interesting. Graphics - 5/5. I love this style! Replayability - 5/5. The amount of variation possible between playthroughs is obscene depending on race/background/class/personality/decisions/penchance for violence/completist attitude/etc etc etc.There are still a few bugs/glitches/typos in the game, but I know the guys at Obsidian are working on getting it all ironed out. Final thoughts - I can't wait to get around to playing through this again, though I'm going to take some time off between playthroughs so I don't tire myself out of it (and so I can give some much needed attention to other games I've bought lately). I saw an interview with one of the creators stating that they're already working on putting together a story for a substantial expansion (YES!), akin to those expansions from all the older classics of the genre. This game, man. It's worth your time and money if you're into this sort of thing, and it's got me eagerly awaiting any future developments. A game destined to remain in the glorious halls of classics. TL;DR: 5/5!Final words I forgot the other day: You must gather your party before venturing forth.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												It's like a love letter, sitting there in front of your tiny screen and waiting for Baldur's Gate to finish installing on your Windows 98. The sheer awe that would await, did not prepare you for the journey that would take place. The experience was a profound one, one that would shape the way you viewed your future roleplaying gaming sessions. BAM! ZOOM 17 YEARS LATER AND WE GOT PILLARS OF ETERNITY UP IN THIS HAY.On a stupid sidenote: Chris Avellone's characters, Greiving Mother and Durance, are the best companions in any game ever, as expected out of his god damned sexy handsome genius. I already hyped these characters when they were announced as being written by him and sure enough, they are some of the most well received. Too bad the fanfic backers ruin the immersion. One of the first [Yellow] namned NPC's in a house can be googled into a closed off "My OC" anime forum. I did think it was too stereotypical to be true, but the whole godmode and calming down was too much fanfic-levels of writing and googling it was too much. Now if only you could kill more of them, too bad only 5% of them are any good reads.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Pillars is a great game in it's own right. If you loved Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment or Icewind Dale, then you will feel at home. The game is very detailed and Obsidian took great care in making every area interesting to explore. There is much dialogue and while the story not as memorable as Planescape: Torment, it still intrduces us to a new world to look to in the future. The game has replay value and Obsidian continues to patch it up. The combat is fun and you will get obliretaed if you don't plan out your strategy. Character builds are very detailed as well, so take your time with that build. Be forwarned though, the game is very buggy and crashes randomly to the Desktop. F5 frequently so that you don't loose progress. I am almost 70 hrs into the game and I am still on Act 2 since I take my time with the game. I highly recommend this game to anyone that loves this genre. It's definitely helped me with my vocabulary.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												This is, hands down, one of the best games I´ve ever played.  Because that I grew up with Baulders gate 1 and 2 this is a game well suited for me. A lively atmosphere and rich enviroments with great music to boost it. They said that they aimed to bring back the feel of the old infinty engine games (Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale e.t.c) and they did just that. Not just the isometrical camera and live turnbased combat (pausable, of course). They looked to the smaller things, such as the good old "You must gather your party before venturing forth" as well.Apart from that the game is also littered with alot of community written content wich shows that they really cherish the community they have gathered. There is no real downside to this game, it offers great replay value, great challenges and hours upon hours of gameplay.Should I really search for a downside I could find two things1: The UI has a button wich reveals that you will acquire a stronghold at one point, it could have been covered up as not to spoil a great surprise.2: I easily reached the levelcap way before reaching the end of the game, mind you it took alot of sidequesting and it kept me from being way overpowered for the endgame. A slight to much sidecontent in relation to maincontent.That being said, I strongly recommend it. It brought back so many good memories of what I love about roleplaying games.

Yes, there were still some bugs, but the developers seem intent on fixing them even after all this time.I think part of the problem a lot of people had w/ this game is that, based on what they thought it would be (how it would play), they got frustrated when their preconceptions about character classes, abilities, attributes (stats), etc. weren't met. I'm not saying I blame them (e.g., why would you think to max out Intelligence on a Barbarian in a D&D-inspired game? Yet, that's a great idea given the mechanics of PoE!), just that it helps to come into the game w/ an open mind. I certainly struggled for a while to understand combat mechanics in my 1st game, but came to love it.I can't wait for the sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												A very well done, Infinity Engine (i.e. Baldur's Gate and company) style game.  They really nailed the look and feel of the interface and graphics.  The game is pretty superb in all other areas but doesn't quite reach the level of Baldur's Gate 1 or 2 in my opinion.They created their own world and lore, and while well done it, just didn't capture my imagination as much as the regular AD&D setting.  They also created their own rules system, and I think this is where it lacks the most.  I love a lot of things they did, but they really missed the mark with stealth and loot.  Stealth is just hard to pull off and was originally a group only ability.  This was changed in the expansions though.  The loot to me just wasn't very exciting.  Even late into the game I was still using some of the same equipment I found pretty early on.  Many, supposedly high end items I never even equiped as what I had was better, or was at least better for me.  I think the problems stems from the fact that equipment has certain enchanting rules and it just makes many items feel bland.  This was improved upon in the expansions but not a whole lot.The difficulty of the base game seemed fairly easy to me.  I played on hard / expert and only had problems with some of the end game level battles.  Can't say the same for the expansions but that is for another review.Anyway, those are some of the negatives.  Most of the rest is very good / great level so it is still a great game for those craving RPG's of the past.

												Huzzah for Pillars of Eternity! This is a terrific RPG! Obsidian has rolled a Critical Success with this 3rd Person Fantasy adventure! I have thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.-Beautiful graphics!-Lots of conversation choices-Many different classes and races-Running and optimizing your own castle and soldiers-Ability to craft and enchant items-Funny interaction between NPCs in your party-Stable as a rock, no technical problems at all-New world, very unique and different from typical D&D fare-Easy to play, no great learning curve-I LOVE the limitless inventory and not having to worry about buying and carrying arrows-Customizable characters, including your backstoryI have not yet finished the game, but I have played more than 40 hours as of this writing. I am very much hooked and wish to press on, exploring more and learning more about the world that I am in.I you liked the Baulder's Gate series or Icewind Dale - this is a natural fit.This is a great, well made game. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												If you love classic CRPGS like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale or Planetscape: Torment then you owe yourself to pick up this game. I've played almost 50 hours now and it's utterly brilliant. In a time where CRPGs have been reduced to AAA titles with QTEs, linear progression and being spoon feed every morsel of information Pillars comes as a blessing of both nostalgia and fresh air. The character creation is brilliant, the classes deep and interesting and the combat is strategic and tough, yet very rewarding. But it it's the lore and the graphics that really makes this game so brilliant. Your adventures in Dyrwood will immerse you into a world with a rich history, interesting races, frightful monsters, a pantheon of gods, and tons of interesting NPCs. The hand drawn graphics really brings this wonderful world to life in a way 3D graphics just can't. For the younger players or those who never played the classics CRPGs of the late 90s, get ready for a bit of shock. Be ready to spend hours reading text, from old tomes, diaries to treaties on local history, books on culture, religion and factions. You'll also spend lot of the game time reading descriptions of characters and events. The game won't spoon feed you lore, it asks you to find out by yourself. It asks you to explore and understand, like all great RPGs should. This is a game that asks you to invest and apply yourself, but if you do it will reward you handsomely for it. The world feels more real and immersive because of it.In short, this is wonderful game and all RPG fans need to pick it up, because we need more games like it.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												This game is an excellent bar to set for other game companies. The story is one of the best I've had the pleasure of experienceing. My favorite picks would be BG2, BG2TOB, NWN, BG1.Combat is flawless and follows to a small degree(loosely) the DND ruleset which is known in IE games for being a staple mechanic.The sheer amount of content with the Endless Dungeons and bounties adds much flair and things to do. Let's not forget that you get your own keep and can upgrade it AND pay people to guard it! There are multiple secret areas and numerous items good and bad to find. This game from start to finish took about 32+ hours to complete with about 60% of the game explored and completed.There are multiple facets that I havn't even discovered and I plan on replaying through the game again solo.Giving this game anything below a 9 would be ludicrous.My only complaint is that this game advertised that it is able to be solo'ed. So far the balancing of the classes other than a barbarian is kind of messed up. This game would be a perfect 10/10 for me if I could actually solo it. I've obtained a platinum in the Dark Souls series and Bloodborne but, even those games are not as hard as Pillars of Eternity solo on NORMAL. Please make a selectable option for solo that scales down the enemies a bit for a solo run or, take out the level cap for solo-runners.Story: 9.5Combat: 9.6Content: 10/10Play Time: 32 hrs 9.1/10Replayability: VERY HIGH 10/10 Solo: Currently undoable for anything but barbarians.Overall: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												This is effectively the successor we've been waiting for BG2. Does it hit as hard as BG2? No, it's hard to do that. BG2 existed in a kind of beloved universe by nerds, cultivated with a rich goofy history from Dungeons and Dragons.This attempts to do it's own thing, though common fantasy tropes are brought in. None the less it's interesting and takes a strong themeatic focus upon the concept of the soul, which here is a particular thing with particular qualities, capable of being approached in an almost scientific manner.The gameplay is essentially turn based though real time, you will pause often. AI can be preset for companions to make it flow easier and I've found it to work fine. The classes are many and interesting while the stat system is a little more forgiving, as usefulness is spread out wide amid the stats. It's hard to build yourself into a character hole.The dialogue and reading is plenty. Play this game ever night, a little bit, before you go to bed. It's like cozying up with a book. It isn't supposed to give you an adrenal rush, but be an enjoyable journey.I would suggest playing it on the harder difficulties, I did at first and rarely had any issues save for near the end. The final boss can be a real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: January 8
												A game stripped off of the glamour of modernity does not always hit home. Next generation graphics and mechanics have always taken the industry to the next level. Every once in a while though there comes a rare jewel that makes us take pause -- makes us stop and revisit what was and see it in new light. Pillars of Eternity has done that for me so far. It has been a while since I've played a CRPG, and at first I felt it jarring to be taking the slower pace in gaming once more. But let's all admit that there is an undeniable pull for the old and time-tested models of the past against the flashy, glossy and cinematic titles of this day. It isn't anything ground-breaking mind you.  Pillar of Eternity is true-to-form to the way I remember Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate were when I first played them years ago. There are, however, some modern fixes that make the journey more streamlined without breaking the nostalgic feeling of playing this sort of game. Settings and options make the game friendly to old fans and would-be followers alike. Sure the art is dated and often times may feel so limited -- but hey -- that's both the challenge and reward of opening such a treasure. I can't say much for the narrative save for the fact that there is a warm feeling experienced from reading through a lot of narrative texts and deciding on the next course of action of your personally crafted heroes and story-rich NPCs. And speaking of heroes - the game offers a lot of exploration in hero-crafting, offering alternative class types such as the Chanter and Cipher that is quite akin to the trinity-breaking hybrids of modern role-playing anti-molds.  The best advice I have if you're picking this up (about two years after it has been out and patched to death) is just play it without any of the distractions brought by the wikis and forums of the world. I think that that is the best dose of nostalgia titles like these bring to the table -- a time when you were just left with a game and nothing else mattered.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I bought PoE because I was interested in the story and, to be honest, because I was curious how similar the game was to the Baldur's Gate etc.I was entertained. True, I didn't care much for the story (the whole soul thing didn't strike my fancy, and the world and races simply didn't knock my socks off), but I was entertained, alright. On the one hand there was, of course nostalgia, on the other the game simply oozes the designers' lifeblood. You can feel it in all the little details and every line of text, from the dialogue to the virtual novel style elements. This is not a "medal for effort", though. Only a game that shows that the developers cared - really cared - can hope to be  good, or even great game and lately too many games are released that show quite the opposite. All in all PoE is worth playing; be it out of nostalgia, the love of role playing games or the respect for devs who actually care! However this is game is not the holy grail some people claim: it's nostalgia, first an foremost! If you loved Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Planescape Torment you probably will feel right a t home in PoE. 												I used to play a lot of Baldur's Gate back in the day, it was one of my favourite games.Pillars of Eternity is an accurate recreation of the old RPGs like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale.Storyline, rule set, voice acting, soundtrack, magical items, monsters, combat system: you name it this game does everything right. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												TLDR; it's like Baldur's Gate but with way better combat and character building.A worthy successor to the D&D cRPG classics. It's a true western cRPG with an interesting story that builds as you play and well-written characters to interact with. It's dialogue is well-written and provides many different opportunities for a variety of character builds and behaviors through scripted interactions.The major improvements to combat are the hallmark of the game's excellence. The biggest improvement of Pillars of Eternity over its spiritual predecessors was adding a great deal of variety and balance to the classes and the attribute system. No attribute is inherently dump-stat material (like Intelligence in Baldur's Gate).Combat is also more fluid and exciting, with better UI and feedback. The melee engagement system (a formalized game mechanic of the Attack of Opportunity system) gives combat better flow and allows you to maintain real battle lines and manage more purposeful positioning in a fight.Definitely one of the best RPGs of the decade so far, and a worthy successor to its past.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Where to start with Pillars of Eternity. OverviewLike most of us here on steam, we have that infamous library of shame, and for the longest time, this hidden gem was one of them. I can't even remember how I came to acquire this game in all honesty, but however I did, I am beyond grateful for the purchase/acquisition.If you like RPG games with a rich story, true player choices that affect the game in subtle, but dramatic ways, than Pillars of Eternity is for you. It is a party based game where you can either use the companions the game provides, or spend some in game gold and hire your own adventurers, which are customized from the ground up if you purchase them after level 1. So the amount of player options is truly amazing for this style of game, and the story... I could write a ten page review as to why this is one of the best stories in a game like this. But I will let you experience it for yourself. No spoilers.. Yay!It takes a bit of a different approach to the party based mechanics, where you are allowed to pause the game to issue commands to each person. Though this might break immersion a tinsy bit, since some of the combat is very faced pace and you might not have enough time to dictate your actions, you can find your healer or archer dead before you can even blink.  Or worse yet, have your strongest person be temporarily mind controlled against you! I can't attest to how many times that ability made me grumble and want to smash my keyboard.  There is also the wonderful thing of trial and error, there are some combat set ups that simply can't be done with some party builds, or at least ,not without being a massive pain in your♥♥♥♥♥♥ The game does not hurt you for this, and gives you ample opportunity to find just the right set up to get whatever your mission is done.With that said, below is my summary for the game. Keep in mind this is my opinion, and you should take it with a grain of salt. After all, this type of game is not for everyone. Good Rich, detail oriented story Challenging combat system The world looks absolutely beautiful, and feels like it is living on some level. Companion banter can be quite hilarious. Challenging bosses even when at max level/have amazing gear. Not to many puzzles, but the ones that are present are challenging and require digging in game (provided you don't cheat with google!) High learning curve. The game gives you the basics, and it is your job to shift through the abilities, stats, and what not to build your own character. ((personally a good thing for me, some might disagree.))Not So Good No respawning enemies, once you clear out a map it remains clear (makes getting more loot items impossible) No weapon crafting, would be nice to be able to make custom weapons, especially for end game.Final ThoughtsIn short, if you love RPG games that have in depth story, sophisticated combat, and interesting side quests, this is a game for you! I will leave it at that however, and let you decide for yourself if this is a worthy game for your money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												I usually don't like single-player games that make me micro-manage multiple characters; it tends to make me focus on inventory and number-crunching more-so than the story and the adventure.  With that said, I bought Pillars of Eternity because I was looking for an adventure akin to table-top RPGs and also out of support for the cRPG genre.Unlike its predecessors, Pillars of Eternity shaves off a lot of the busywork of babbysitting companions. Stuff like streamlined inventory management, leveling and other features such as the combat AI, the game was a lot easier to get into.Speaking of "easy", I think my main gripe with the game was in its difficulty.  While not a complete stranger to strategy games and RPGs, I found myself struggling in "easy" mode yet, at the same time, was not getting a satisfactory victory in "story time" mode (as things died WAY too easily for my tastes).  After completing the game after only 9 hours, I suspect that my issues were due to me not exploring enough and/or not participating in enough side-quests; leaving my group under-leveled for the content.  Still, I find it odd that, even in "easy" mode, some group of monsters were able to completely crowd-control and annihilate my entire party; regardless of how often I'd reload the game and tried different tactics.  So, for anyone who's looking into getting this game, I'd watch out for that.I'm definitely going back in with a new character, exploring more content (including the game's DLCs) and hopefully try to play through it in "normal" difficulty.- The various vistas are great to look at; lots of details without confusing the eyes and without taxing the computer.- The (usually rare) voice-overs performances are serviceable and soothing.- The music is enchanting (I especially enjoy the light-hearted tone from the combat track ~ which is rare these days).- The story, while confusing and slow, is still pretty good.I was pleasantly surprised.  An RPG that encouraged me to role-play; it's been a long time since.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												50+ hrs played I waited till I hit the 50+ hrs point to write this review so that I had a complete feel for the game before I made any desessions about the game. All in all I give the game a 85/100. And the -15 is mostly just personal perference not things that are wrong with the game itself. Pillars is a great game with 100's of hrs of game play and a large amount of replayability. Of course you have to like playing with a team of six characters of different classes. I prefer games like Skyrim where you mostly play just a single player. Pillars has a great story line with a mostly open world and you get to chose what order to solve the quests you have. There is a large amount of treasure and items to be bought with nothing bring over powering. The game can be difficult at times. And I do wish they had put a level system in the journal so you know if the quest was to high above your level to complete. The 2 dlc's are a must. And should be bought at round lvl 7 and played before you finish the main game. You can go back to the main game after the dlc's and there is some great loot that can be used like better armour and weapons to give you a better edge also. another fun option in the game is you can have a Keep which you can upgrade and make your home. This is a great game. Read all the reviews you can and get it on sale even better. Also look at all the hrs a lot of people have spent playing this game. That was the biggest factor that told me that this was a good game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												This game was good, but I couldn't help feeling like it wasn't as good as it could have been.  It feels like editorial mandates got in the way of the story that some writers were trying to tell and gummed up the works.  Quests can feel disconnected and companions occasionally feel neutered by editing, especially those written by Chris Avellone.Don't get me wrong, the story is fantastic and the companions break the Bioware mold that many RPG's find themselves stuck in.  The world is fantastically realized, being both dark and gritty while also maintaining a sense of wonder not always found in contemporary fantasy.  The lore is also well written and interesting, avoiding some of the pitfalls of other games of the genre by making the lore seem too distant from what is actually presented and giving a real sense of belonging within the game world.The graphics are another high point, for the most part.  All the backgrounds are well detailed with particle effects that just pop, but the models aren't really consistent.  For an indie game of this magnitude, they do look very good, but if you are expecting highly detailed, AAA models, look elsewhere. Occasionally enemies will have their models go over scenery that they really shouldn't, it is most notable when they die.  Despite those flaws, the overall artistic design is stunning.Music is okay, nothing really spectacular, but it more than does the job.  For the most part, it is rather sparse and when it does come in it is typically light and unintrusive.  While this can feel immersive, it means that I wouldn't really say any of it stands out.Overall, it is a really good game, that seems like it could have been better with more time and money.  That said, it is probably the best singleplayer RPG in years and without a doubt the best throwback to the old infinity engine games on the market (although with Numenera looming on the horizon, that may be a better option long term).  8.5/10

True, I didn't care much for the story (the whole soul thing didn't strike my fancy, and the world and races simply didn't knock my socks off), but I was entertained, alright. You can feel it in all the little details and every line of text, from the dialogue to the virtual novel style elements. This is not a "medal for effort", though. Only a game that shows that the developers cared - really cared - can hope to be  good, or even great game and lately too many games are released that show quite the opposite. All in all PoE is worth playing; be it out of nostalgia, the love of role playing games or the respect for devs who actually care! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												A game stripped off of the glamour of modernity does not always hit home. Next generation graphics and mechanics have always taken the industry to the next level. Every once in a while though there comes a rare jewel that makes us take pause -- makes us stop and revisit what was and see it in new light. Pillars of Eternity has done that for me so far. It has been a while since I've played a CRPG, and at first I felt it jarring to be taking the slower pace in gaming once more. But let's all admit that there is an undeniable pull for the old and time-tested models of the past against the flashy, glossy and cinematic titles of this day. It isn't anything ground-breaking mind you.  Pillar of Eternity is true-to-form to the way I remember Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate were when I first played them years ago. There are, however, some modern fixes that make the journey more streamlined without breaking the nostalgic feeling of playing this sort of game. Settings and options make the game friendly to old fans and would-be followers alike. Sure the art is dated and often times may feel so limited -- but hey -- that's both the challenge and reward of opening such a treasure. I can't say much for the narrative save for the fact that there is a warm feeling experienced from reading through a lot of narrative texts and deciding on the next course of action of your personally crafted heroes and story-rich NPCs. And speaking of heroes - the game offers a lot of exploration in hero-crafting, offering alternative class types such as the Chanter and Cipher that is quite akin to the trinity-breaking hybrids of modern role-playing anti-molds.  The best advice I have if you're picking this up (about two years after it has been out and patched to death) is just play it without any of the distractions brought by the wikis and forums of the world. I think that that is the best dose of nostalgia titles like these bring to the table -- a time when you were just left with a game and nothing else mattered.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												As a Kickstarter backer, I have to say, I got my money's worth.  Pillars of Eternity really captured the feel of the old Infinity Engine games (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, etc), but modernized and improved.  The story isn't as strong as the Baldur's Gate games, but the world is unique and well realized (and the central question of the game was a welcome surprise).  It starts off a bit slow, and the NPCs you gather don't seem that interesting at first, but by the end they really grew on me. To the point that I felt guilty for not finishing one's quest.    The game manages to feel short, even after 60 hours of play - there are still several things I didn't do (and I would have appreciated a little more warning when I got to the point of no return for the end-game), and there are a number of extra missions that can be explored, several of which I failed to complete (and may go back and do, even if I don't re-beat the game). But overall, I was very happy with the game; they achieved their goal of reviving the style and adapting it to modern gamers.  There are still some niggling things they need to do (the filter on store items actually remove items rather than graying them out, better multi-step planning and visibility in battles), but those are minor flaws on an otherwise sparkling gem.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												Great cRPG. Story was intriguing, though the main & side quests weren't always as thematically connected as I would have liked. In particular, there's a sort of "twist" at the end (regarding the gods) that's almost never discussed or hinted at - and it really should have been. Still, minor gripe. The characters, while perhaps not quite reaching the level of some of BG2's or DA:O's companions (and the villain coming nowhere close to Jon Irenicus), had interesting personalities and dilemmas. Eder & Durance were my two favorites, though I'm sure mileage may vary.I was entirely satisfied with the combat system. You'll be pausing a lot (more on harder difficulties) to cast spells, drink potions, and change positions or targets. Aside from Chanter, every class felt powerful and useful, and I often had a hard time choosing between which companion I wanted to bring. What's especially nice is that every stat is useful for every class, so if you want to make a battlemage who's in the thick of melee, that's entirely possible and even encouraged by some of the wizard spells.I'd be remiss if I didn't mention some great innovations in combat as well. First off, D&D's "attacks of opportunity" are implemented via an engage system. Enter in melee range and you're engaged. Exit and you'll be hit by free attacks. This helps tanks tank, while also making enemies who can teleport into your midst even more dangerous. Second, the infinite-rest problem in other cRPGs is ameloriated by requiring you to spend limited camping spells in order to sleep. Some reviewers have complained about it, but I very much appreciated it. I had to be smart about using my skills & spells. At the same time, I never felt hugely limited. Many skills, for example, are actually usable a # of times per ENCOUNTER (rather than per rest).One area in which I felt let-down was the magic items. There's not much of a sense of progression. For example, I defeated this bad mafa dragon near the end of the game, but his items were mediocre. And the best 2H weapon in the game (a pike) is bought IN A STORE. Even beyond that, the items and their modifiers rarely felt unique. Nothing like getting Lilarcor or Carsomyr in BG2.All said though, it's great. I beat it without White March, and, frankly, am glad I didn't. I was ready to move on.DIFFICULTY RECOMMENDATION: I beat the game on Hard and some fights were quite difficult, especially a few near the beginning (I beat Raedric at level 4, with a party of 3, lawl). But I breezed through many more (especially near the end when I'd hit the level cap and optimized my gear). As such, I wish I had stepped it up to Path of the Damned. Thus, if you're a thorough completionist who enjoys difficulty (e.g. Dark Souls), I'd start with Path of the Damned. It'll be tough, but you're given the tools to overcome that toughness.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												50+ hrs played I waited till I hit the 50+ hrs point to write this review so that I had a complete feel for the game before I made any desessions about the game. All in all I give the game a 85/100. And the -15 is mostly just personal perference not things that are wrong with the game itself. Pillars is a great game with 100's of hrs of game play and a large amount of replayability. Of course you have to like playing with a team of six characters of different classes. I prefer games like Skyrim where you mostly play just a single player. Pillars has a great story line with a mostly open world and you get to chose what order to solve the quests you have. There is a large amount of treasure and items to be bought with nothing bring over powering. The game can be difficult at times. And I do wish they had put a level system in the journal so you know if the quest was to high above your level to complete. The 2 dlc's are a must. And should be bought at round lvl 7 and played before you finish the main game. You can go back to the main game after the dlc's and there is some great loot that can be used like better armour and weapons to give you a better edge also. another fun option in the game is you can have a Keep which you can upgrade and make your home. This is a great game. Read all the reviews you can and get it on sale even better. Also look at all the hrs a lot of people have spent playing this game. That was the biggest factor that told me that this was a good game.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												An incredibly well-written game that is a throwback to classic computer RPGs.  As someone who missed out on Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale (curse you responsible choices!!), but played the Gold/Silver box D&D RPG games to death finding this game was a stroke of luck.  There is a lot to like, but what stands out is just the strong dialogue and sense of place this game creates.  This is one of the few games that I've played recently that I don't care very much about min/maxing my character, but instead I find myself reading the in-game books and looking forward to tracking down various side-quests.  I find myself reloading to see how a different set of choices would impact a particular side quest.  It is an engaging and atmospheric game...well suited for a leisurely play through.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												If you're looking for a game that pulls you into a rich and intricate fantasy world, this is worth a play-through. It's got a lot of replay value, and it's pretty well written. I found it challenging in some areas, though that may just have been because I like to explore before leveling... The lore was in depth and interesting, the characters were well fleshed out, and I loved that my words and actions had an effect on how I was perceived by my companions. The story is solid.The only annoyance was the loading screen time, which was just a touch longer than I'd have liked, but even this wasn't a deterent. I recommend this game to anyone who loves fantasy stories and RPGs. The only way I could see this game being even more fun is if it somehow became multiplayer and my friends could join my party, but I can't even begin to imagine how difficult that would be for the dev team. This game is worth a shot, as I said before. Try to get it on sale, though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												What a game! Or maybe "what a world" would be more accurate. Pillars of Eternity certainly pulled me in from the start. Oldschool Infinity Engine -style isometric CRPGs are the type of game that has long been missing from modern gaming. Now they're back, and in what a spectacular fashion!Get ready to lose yourself in the fantasy setting of Eora; a world full of juicy lore, masterfully written characters, and intriquing stories and plot. The writing is the highlight for me, because there's a lot of it, there's reactivity, there's philosophical stuff as well as political forces. The balance between reading and being involved in combat situations is a very nice fifty-fifty I'd estimate. My thorough playthrough of the game + both expansion took 130 hours.Speaking of combat, oh what a treat this old style tactical party management in real-time with pause. It sure has a lot of variables and micromanagement like positioning characters, pausing at every second to issue new commands or use different abilities - which might deter many players more used to action RPGs or simply not interested in micromanagement in their RPG combat systems, but I certainly love it all. Good news to players who struggle with or dislike this sort of combat, there are multiple difficulty settings, especially the Story Mode, which lets you learn the combat mechanics without being constantly overwhelmed.The art and environments are unlike any other, this is the hand crafted 3D into 2D style from the older CRPGs, but elevated into delicious levels of eyecandy. Top that with amazing spell and sound effects, good looking animations and the absolutely wonderful music and voice acting, and the experience is simply astounding.I love the adventuring from area to area on the world map, which depends on what direction you decided to exit to, brings freedom and excitement to going into new areas. I love the unique items, quests and NPCs that one encounters, so much cool stuff to discover. I love the party NPC characters that you can have adventuring alongside you, very memorable personalities, they feel very alive and I certainly started to care about many of them very quickly.There are so many details I could go into, so many things about this game I could gush about. But let me say it all in the simplest way I can: I've long held that my favorite game of all time is Baldur's Gate 1, this game is a worthy spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate 1, and I will go as far as to say, that Pillars of Eternity is now my new favorite game of all time.Highly recommended for RPG fans, especially fans of oldschool CRPGs.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												I was never a huge isometric RPG guy and missed a lot of the classics, like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. That being said, I've always been a fan of D&D and fantasy settings, as well as strong narratives. PIllars of Eternity delivers on this and more. The mechanics are fine-tuned, the plot is good, the writing is fantastic, the content is enough to give you information but not so much reading you go cross-eyed (unless you choose to talk to everyone or read every book).Above all, the game just has a great flow to it. It can be difficult but never '♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t'. Some spells/abilities are better than others, but they are all fun to use (and you will use everything over the course of the game). The combat is pausible so you can play at your own speed, and the game looks great too.A fantastic purchase!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												I'm just going back for my second play through and I'm realizing (again) what an amazing game this is. I'd say this is easily the best CRPG ever, for me at least. Divinity Original Sin is close, but Pillars wins it for me. The combat is fantastic with plenty of options for how to build your party and play them. All classes feel equally (or nearly equally) viable - there are many ways to play each class, and the combat is challenging. The story and lore are the best - I'm not the type to get wrapped up in the books you pick up in games like Skyrim, but here I eat it all up. There is a TON of content here, especially with the two expansions (but 60-80 hours without, easy). The exploration feels so good too, I'm totally wrapped up in this game. I wish there were more RPG's like this, most can't keep my attention for very long. This one I'll play through multiple times.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												I'm editing this review so i'f you've viewed it before, you may wish to change your opinion. I'm still recommending the game though. My original review was shadowed by my inabilty to understand how combat works. After beating the game i still dont understand it. But after paying cash to reset my character and try 3 builds, the last one working the best I was ultimately less angered.Alright. This game has a good story. It really does, especially if you like thinking about what gods are. It is however very short on anything else story wise. Not that there arn't side stories here mind you. There are but ultimately it all kinda boils into the main storyline because like religion in real life it permiates everything else. Everything in the game is basically about the gods. Well anything really interesting anyway. Or its about the Egwithans and their crazy ancient stuff.Visually the game is impressive and very nice to look at. Character design is rather strait forward and easy to understand, at first. As time goes on I begin to wonder why there are so many options when it comes to building your character. So many options just seem.. not worth it and dont really seem to play a part in the story at all. I really cant put my tounge on why I do and dont like character building; maybe if they were to retool the various bonuses and things it would be better? The backgrounds are interesting but are really nothing more than additional choices in dialog here and there and with some updates they play more of a role in some quest choices and dialogs. Still though.. something in the way you build your character and just doesn't add up for me and all in all it comes off as unenjoyable.Character appearance feels like a side note for the game devs. I think the species look interesting, but there just isn't that many options on how your character will look. It almost doesn't even matter with the camera angel you play at. Still though it'd be nice to be able to have more options.The portaits are.. not good. They arn't I DONT LIKE THEM. There are mods that add more, i recommend using them. As they are basically the only way to make your character look different.I was dissapointed by the lack of story dealing with effecting the local governments. Sure you have a end game effect, but there isn't really much story dealing with helping or harming the local governments. I mean it seems at first that you might be, but you only real effect the second tribal government. Defiance bay has very little politcal intrique. Even working for the local mod is kinda boring. It also doesn't make a ton of sense when your party of six "sneaks" into someones home for one quest in particular only to immediately be discovered and have to kill everyone on that floor. How the people below you dont here their cries for help.. I dont know.The ending.. is actually good. I liked it a lot. I felt as if my questions were answered and I had many options to explore the paths and dialog options that led up to it. I enjoyed my bitter sweet ending through and through.Combat.. I have absolutly no idea what is happeneing in combat. Seriously.. I dont understand it. I just set the AI, click to start on a enemy or location to position my characters and occasionally I manually control my healer and my damage spell caster. Other than that.. I only really clicked on them to force party members to use potions or items or in very specific fights I would direct my main character to attack a specific person or use a specific ability. Seriously though, letting the AI run your party is almost always the best bet.The characters. I liked them quite a bit. Eder was one of my favorites with Durance being my absolute favorite above all else. Aloth is interesting but his quest line seems.. kinda boring? Even with the " twist " at the end. Speaking of companion story lines.. Eders was.. dissapointing And so was Durances. I really expected SOMETHING to happen with a hammer that may or may not have something to do with the gods. I also really expected Durance to do something about the truths he finds sometime before the game ended. Though I suppose what we all do with truth can be a very interesting thing.Over all I dont regret buying this game, because I had fun with it. It does feel short though, once you hit your stride and combat becomes less intense with a full party, one that has balance, you dont really need to pay a ton of attention, at first though depending on your build it can be rather unfair. Esecially if you dont just run strait to the first town and get some allies.The voice acting for this game is very good. I mean REALLY good. I can only say I WISH THERE WAS MORE OF IT. Because and lets be honest here.. who really read the entirety of every dialog box or even half of them? I know I didn't and I'll be damned if anyone else did either. There is a ton of reading here and while that isn't a horrible thing, it is a bit overwhelming. Making me often wish there was more voice work going on. I mean the voice actors are so damn good, i just wanna hear them talk more anyway.Visual interaction with the game. By this i dont mean its looks i mean when you do something in a cutscene where you have a choice to make something happen, more times than not its just a quick visual effect or someone dies or something like that. That aspect of the game feels less good and more meh.Effecting the world. Not all games have to effect the world the players runs their pc in. However.. who plays games like this and doesn't want to effect the world? You can and Do obviously by the end game... but I just feel like more could be added and made to better flesh out that part of the game.If you wanna see a review of mine that is totally nothing but rambling because i didn't enjoy a game and wanted my money back you can check out Age of Decadance review. I rant and rave and whine like the best of them.Pillars of Eternity is a good game and worth buying. Even if.. i could never beat that one dragon in that one.. VERY DEEP location.sry for typosEdit: Oh yeah the stronghold feels totally tacted on. Its cool sometimes and then boring later except for them lower levels, but it feels like a last minute addition or something along those lines. I really wish there was more to it. I've also not played the expansions. Something to keep in mind.
