number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
Pillars Of Eternity is a glorious also-ran. It is a flawed but ultimately worthy imitator of the great Baldur's Gate series, and a promising sign of things to come.If you are the kind of person who has purchased any of the recent Black Isle remasters from Beamdog, then let me tell you in no uncertain terms that you should go buy PIllars of Eternity right now. It is the nearest thing to Baldur's Gate II since Baldur's Gate II, and if that doesn't already make you champ at the bit, then let me tell you that its a darn good facsimile. If you aren't the kind of person who has done something like that, then the first thing you'll want to know is that Pillars of Eternity is an isometric party management RPG in the style of the old nineties and noughties games, complete with their beautiful writing, massive single player adventure, and difficulty. While you start off going through the familiar motions of building a character, Pillars of Eternity introduces a few new wrinkles that make it interesting. For starters, while all the familiar archetypes are represented, some truly weird and original character classes exist here, including the chanter who sings harmful and helpful chants, and the cipher, who wields eldritch power to corrupt and destroy the souls of your foes. All the classes feel suitably different, and at time of writing the balance seems to be fairly good across the board. Another thing that Pillars of Eternity does that will probably surprise newcomers to the genre is that every single stat has a direct and significant combat impact. There are no dump stats here and while this means min-maxers will probably be arguing amongst each other for months to come, it is now pretty tricky to gimp your character.You can also supplement your party of six adventurers by hiring characters you create from scratch at any inn. But this would be a mistake. The game includes 8 NPC companions, and you should do everything in your power to have all of them in your party at some point in the game as their writing and acting is so well done you would be robbing yourself of the experience by building a custom party of adventurers. This quality of writing extends to virtually everything else you'll encounter during the course of the game to boot, and it is consistently excellent from start to finish (with two minor and largely irrelevant exceptions which I mention below). Without spoiling anything, the world of Eora will seem immediately familiar to anyone who has spent any time travelling around Faerun in the Forgotten Realms, but it doesn't just feel different enough to be fresh - it's positively revelatory.Oh, and did I mention its gorgeous? The area maps are eye poppingly beautiful, and the characters actually animate splendidly, plus there are loads of cool spell and ability effects. In fact, sometimes they can even be a bit overwhelming. There were moments, especially early on when I was finding my bearings, where I couldn't tell what was going on in fights.The game also features a brand new, proprietary combat system that you'll need to spend a little time getting your head around. And I really do mean that, because this game is hard. Even on Easy or Normal difficulty (which you should probably stick to if you're the kind of person who only plays games once) you will sometimes find yourself badly overwhelmed at strange points as though the game was poorly paced. The learning curve is hardly gentle either, and even if you know your way around this sort of game, there are variations both intentional and unintentional that you wont anticipate in your first few hours with the game. It's a recipe for frustration, and while genre veterans are likely familiar with that feeling, if you're not used to that kind of abuse, expect Pillars of Eternity to test your patience from time to time. Still, the challenge rarely feels unfair (though make no mistake - there are some moments where it feels EXTREMELY unfair in some of the optional endgame content), and it is immensely satisfying to finally triumph over a difficult encounter.Partly this is because a job well done is its own reward, but partly this is because of the loot! And Pillars Eternity has a heck of a lot of it, and it comes in a pretty smooth progression that reminds me of the best moments of Baldur's Gate II, when you were excited to pick up the burning sword that the most recent boss left behind when he finally keeled over. And best of all, the game smartly does away with the old dumb system of playing inventory tetris, Pillars of Eternity allows you to have an unlimited number of items in your inventory in the form of a stash chest that is accessible at any time with a single mouse click whenever you bring up your inventory screen. For anyone who is used to juggling arrows and quest items, it feels downright civilized.The game is not perfect, however. Even after a patch designed to address it, the game features a strangely low level cap that you will absolutely hit. "But wait," I hear you say, "Baldur's Gate had a level cap!" This is true, but it was one that you could only hit by importing your heroes and taking them through the game, and subsequent games abandoned them entirely. By contrast, you may make the unpleasant discovery that you are max level just around the time you really feel like you're starting to cruise. It's jarring and unpleasant, and it's best you're aware of it now.Further, a lot of the kickstarter stretch goal content is terrible. For example, early on in the game you encounter a stronghold which you capture and make your own. While it houses the biggest and best dungeon crawl in the game, it also features a stronghold building metagame that is deceptively terrible. The game is also awash in backer NPCs and memorials - NPCs and gravestones designed by kickstarter backers identifiable by their yellow name bars and tombstone icons. These are uniformly terrible, and you may make the mistake of wasting time reading through them when you first boot up the game. The serious player should regard them as unfortunate concessions to people who wanted to overpay for the game and ignore them completely. It is a real shame to think that these efforts could have been spent on shoring up the game itself.The only other objection I have with Pillars of Eternity is that it is just a little more segmented than it should be. In each Act you are gated on the world map in some ways that feel pretty silly, and while it still feels pretty modern, it lacks the freeform feel that the very best games in the genre had. Still, this is a minor complaint, and there is lots of great sidequesting and adventuring to be done.Overall, Pillars of Eternity feels like it has all the things that a throwback to one of the old greats should have, plus a few smart new inventions. It's actually a little short and content light by genre standards, as the game clocks in at around 40 or 50 hours for an leisurely, exhaustive completionist playthrough, and perhaps a little more than 30 for a more main-story-only run. But if we're being honest with ourselves, that's still a whole lot of bang for your buck, and oh boy, what a ride Pillars of Eternity is if you're up for its challenges.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												First of all, my general opinion of Pillars of Eternity: This game is a work of art. Seriously, it seems like every little thing in this game has been carefully thought-out and is there for a reason. But yeah, there are some bad things too. Not many of them though.First of all, the positives: The game is beautiful. The art style is pretty, the UI is functional, yet nice to look at. I especially like the illustrations which are visible in the cut scenes and the painted character portaits. The classes are not exactly boring standard fantasy stuff, instead they are some small, interesting aspects about every one of them. For example, the mage can only equip a small number of spells at any time, and he's also not able to spam them but has to think carefully if the fight is important enough to warrant the usage of spells. Although PoE is a old-school kind of game, there are many things which make a player's life easier. For example the fast mode and slow mode. No more waiting several minutes until your party is on the other end of the map, just turn on the fast mode! Another nice design choice: There is a really large crate the party is carrying at all time, which can be used to store all of the loot one wants to sell in the next city. Like said before, PoE is in the vein of those old-school-RPGs many of us loved as children. Siege of Avalon, Lamentation Sword or Diablo 1 - PoE has aspects of all of them, but with vastly improved graphics, handling and freedom of decision when it comes to quests. The battle system is turn-based, but it feels much more fluent and fast than, for example, the slow-paced battle system of Divinity: Original Sin. I also really liked the fact that the player gets a stronghold later on in the game, gives another little touch of strategy to the game. There are many small little things that, while not important, add quite some immersion to the game. The descriptions on items or enviromental objects, hidden caches that observant players can find, the small stories behind the characters in the world. PETS. The player can pick up certain pets from the ground and equip them. How cool is that?!Of course, there also are some negative aspects. The first thing that comes to my mind is the animations, especially those of the playable characters. They seem to start at the same time, so when you order your party to move it looks like a bunch of clones is running around. There are no differences in running animation depending on race or gender, which is kind of sad. Although it is expected from a game like this, the difficulty spikes can be a little too extreme. Sometimes the player is left to feel pretty frustrated because there are no quests to level up left, yet the boss fight is so hard that it's only doable by cheesing around (if at all). Additionally, the tutorial windows seem to forget a few important aspects. Maybe I'm just stupid, but - for example I did not know that one can hire customized mercs at the inn. I was running around with 2 characters, wondering why the fights are so hard. Sometimes the characters bug out in the battles and get stuck somewhere, although they could just move a few steps to reach the enemy. The game also has a few visual bugs, at times buttons are invisible and you've got to click where you think the button is.Overall, the positive aspects of PoE outnumber the negative ones and I'd recommend this game to every fan of old-school fantasy RPGs.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity, what can I even say that has not been said about this masterwork.  Being a fan of Infinity engine games of old, ie Baldurs gate 1 & 2, Planescape Torment, Arcanum.  Among other non infinity games such as Neverwinter knights, Dungeon Siege ect.  This game is the glorious return of the infinity style isometric rpgs.True Strategic Combat,  every engagement in this game is dangerous, you can easily wipe your party against even the simplest of enemies, especially on Path of the Damned difficulty.  This game nails the pausable real time combat system from the days of old in a way Dragon Age Origins only dreamed it could.  This is the true sequel that the infinity engine games deserved back then when Bioware decided to go for the more casual approach.  A deep compelling story and companions.  Hundreds of pages worth of dialogue (some is even voiced)  deep conversation trees, meaningful responses, so far beyond a simple good and evil system a la Mass Effect or dragon age.  Each companion has real in game world beliefs, aspirations, interests ect.  I find myself dripping at the mouth for more, where in some other games I've found myself wanting to skip dialogue.  The world building is astounding and it sucks you in almost instantly.  Mature dark fantasy at its very best.  No shoe horned in sex scenes or cheesy lines can be found here.  The world is so well developed and so believable that I just cant pull myself away.I can't say enough good about this game really.  It is the true Baldurs Gate 3 that everyone has wanted for years, all shiny with a coat of new paint and modern game play improvements without leaching out the life that makes these games so loved.  When I compare this to an attempt like Dragon Age it's almost laughable.  Dragon age is the definition of streamlining, casualization and consolitus,  and even though Origins was a good game it really did destroy the line of games and turned them into something more accessible.  Pillar's does this in the right way instead.  It makes the game more accessible but not at the expense of difficulty or charm.  It's sure to spawn a fantastic new series, and will spearhead the renaissance of CRPGs.  Obsidian, along with other companies like Larian, with their fantastic Divinity Original Sin, and inXile with their Wasteland 2 and upcoming Torment: Tides of Numeria are proving that a game doesn’t have to be all about multiplayer and graphics, and that not every gamer wants their games easier with every new iteration.I played Dragon Age Inquisition,  the tactical camera made me want to vomit, its completely unusable, and the game has essentially devolved into a strategy-less third person hack n slash game.  Bioware, oh why have you fallen so far, Just take a few pointers from Obsidian here, they made the game you have been incapable of making for the last 20 years, and they did it right the first time.  If you are in any way a fan of RPGs or Strategy games, you woudl be doing yourself a huge favour by pickign thsi game up.  It's net even the price of a full game, and it has more content and depth than most 70 dollar games even dream of having.If you are a fan of Dragon Age or Mass Effect, I strongly urge you to pick this game up, and see how much deeper an RPG can be when the chains of mass market and console release are removed.  I guarentee you will not be dissapointed.It would be foolish to overlook Pillars of Eternity.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity was designed from the ground up not only as a love letter to isomeric cRPGs of the past, but also as a continuation of that legacy. From the green character selection circles to the infamous 'You must gather your party' notification, anyone who enjoyed the Infinity Engine games will feel right at home, and still everything isn't just the same as it was. This isn't a remake or rehash: the classic intelligence and dexterity attributes have been tweaked to have more relevance outside of combat, the lion's share of level growth no longer comes from killing monsters but from conversation, reputation is made up several different expected character traits now instead of the single, universal number it was before. But still I felt compelled to collect and read every book I came across, speak to every person I came across (Even the jarring, overly Godlike backer-made NPCs), just like I did when first playing Baldur's Gate.  The world is new, but the feeling is the same, and what's changed has done so in an effort to better support that familiar experience. These improvements, however, can sometimes act as a double-edged sword. While each character that joined the party did so as a fully fleshed out person with their own motivations, those same motivations ask the unanswered question of why they were continuing to follow me on this death defying quest. Knowing many of them had their own important concerns elsewhere made it hard to imagine that they were all as interested in the approaching conclusion as I was. The game's storyline is similarly fully formed which leaves the end with a sense of finality. There's no cliffhanger here to breed anticipation for a continuation of the world. I'm left wanting more and not having any idea of how it will come about. That thought, that all the essential questions about the world have been answered, is troubling, but only if you assume there aren't any new ways to surprise us.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												More than 70,000 backers have placed their trust and their Christmas bonus in the Obsidian Kickstarter campaign for its initial "Project Eternity"... And what a result ! Traditionnal RPG in all its splendor, with a deep and original universe, a great personnalisation of characters, class and talents which allow you to play or fight the way you want. The sound track is also really involving to me. Only played ten hours so far and I already can't make differences between the main and side quests for how interesting and depp all of them are.  What a pleasure it is to explore the huge variety of maps and to get lost in Eora's universe! Running on a system of active break, allowing a single press of the space bar to pend the action to study the ground and make your adventurers strategically ; there is also a possibility to programm the AI of your team to adopt a specific tactic which can be appreciable for the exploration random combats. Fortunately, this ode to nostalgia is offset by a very well thought out combat system, balanced between a resistance bar swhich can be increased by consumables, equipment or statistics separed from the proper life bar. Only small flaws for me would be the HUUUUUGE reading parts to describes actions and dialogs, that are certainly mastered and really well writen but sometimes also stopping the dynamism of a scene and quite tiring for the eyes after a few hours. Also ther are some pathfinding problems. Yep, that's it... Now running back on it!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												My original review of this game was negative. There were a great many things missing and just didnt warrant the price.Now I reluctantly give a thumbs up (6 or 7 out of 10) as i have returned to finish the game. Some great strides (bug fixing, party AI) make this a great buy on sale, but i think a more full experience requires the expansion (which are woven into the main story). Negative points for me:-Odd Design choices still (stuff like not being able to rename the animal companion or vanity pets or for 1 character to carry more than like 20 item icon (bag has X slots, small parties very loot unviable). Doesnt weigh heavily, but hard to swallow the tooltip importance of animal companion that is simply 'bear companion').-Loading screens. Just simply a lot of loading screens. Even with specs that crush the recommended on a SSD, they are just frequent. Load into the keep yard and go to the manor, load into the manor. Talk to someone with a problem, loading as it 'gets your companions' (faster fade to black transition than area). Load to leave manor, load to enter the inn. Load to go to 2nd floor of inn. Sleep transition, load to leave 2nd floor. Load to leave inn back to keep yard. Load to leave keep. I would estimate each screen around 3 seconds, so definitely not bad, but there are a lot of them. (i would estimate 30 seconds of loading screens for a quick visit to the keep for housekeeping. You can sleep from menus and avoid some of the screens, but the high horse of Role playing excellence and immersion gets much lower imo, but options are prefered).-Pay to win. There are two 15$ expansions that are woven into the main story line. Cool, but I am running into quests where "you cannot achieve the noble/nicest ending here unless you bought the expansions" and i think that is crap. Point in case is the Yenwood conflict. I absolutely adore Capt. Emery and you can certainly gain a respect and mutual understanding with her, but you will fight to the death unless you bought the expansions (if you bought the expansions, you can make good on the benevolent dialogue that she agreed with and not have to fight to the death). Something rubs me wrong about being forced to kill an NPC that I like and that likes my PC, but because I didnt buy the expansions yet, we have to fight to the death. I have no idea how many other outcomes are like this.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity, what can I even say that has not been said about this masterwork.  Being a fan of Infinity engine games of old, ie Baldurs gate 1 & 2, Planescape Torment, Arcanum.  Among other non infinity games such as Neverwinter knights, Dungeon Siege ect.  This game is the glorious return of the infinity style isometric rpgs.True Strategic Combat,  every engagement in this game is dangerous, you can easily wipe your party against even the simplest of enemies, especially on Path of the Damned difficulty.  This game nails the pausable real time combat system from the days of old in a way Dragon Age Origins only dreamed it could.  This is the true sequel that the infinity engine games deserved back then when Bioware decided to go for the more casual approach.  A deep compelling story and companions.  Hundreds of pages worth of dialogue (some is even voiced)  deep conversation trees, meaningful responses, so far beyond a simple good and evil system a la Mass Effect or dragon age.  Each companion has real in game world beliefs, aspirations, interests ect.  I find myself dripping at the mouth for more, where in some other games I've found myself wanting to skip dialogue.  The world building is astounding and it sucks you in almost instantly.  Mature dark fantasy at its very best.  No shoe horned in sex scenes or cheesy lines can be found here.  The world is so well developed and so believable that I just cant pull myself away.I can't say enough good about this game really.  It is the true Baldurs Gate 3 that everyone has wanted for years, all shiny with a coat of new paint and modern game play improvements without leaching out the life that makes these games so loved.  When I compare this to an attempt like Dragon Age it's almost laughable.  Dragon age is the definition of streamlining, casualization and consolitus,  and even though Origins was a good game it really did destroy the line of games and turned them into something more accessible.  Pillar's does this in the right way instead.  It makes the game more accessible but not at the expense of difficulty or charm.  It's sure to spawn a fantastic new series, and will spearhead the renaissance of CRPGs.  Obsidian, along with other companies like Larian, with their fantastic Divinity Original Sin, and inXile with their Wasteland 2 and upcoming Torment: Tides of Numeria are proving that a game doesn’t have to be all about multiplayer and graphics, and that not every gamer wants their games easier with every new iteration.I played Dragon Age Inquisition,  the tactical camera made me want to vomit, its completely unusable, and the game has essentially devolved into a strategy-less third person hack n slash game.  Bioware, oh why have you fallen so far, Just take a few pointers from Obsidian here, they made the game you have been incapable of making for the last 20 years, and they did it right the first time.  If you are in any way a fan of RPGs or Strategy games, you woudl be doing yourself a huge favour by pickign thsi game up.  It's net even the price of a full game, and it has more content and depth than most 70 dollar games even dream of having.If you are a fan of Dragon Age or Mass Effect, I strongly urge you to pick this game up, and see how much deeper an RPG can be when the chains of mass market and console release are removed.  I guarentee you will not be dissapointed.It would be foolish to overlook Pillars of Eternity.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Play this game if you ever enjoyed Infinity Engine games of decades past.Are tired of the consolefication of RPG's? The easy mode that is most games these days, or the games that are straight console ports that give no design regard on to control a game? then play this game at leat once.The Good: This game is a well done copy of the interface that made games like Planescape, Baldur's Gate (I, II, SoA), Fallout great games of their time.  Graphically it is not going to blow you away, but the game still looks nice and I hope that it leads to more story driven game set in the same engine.The world is fleshed out and the writing is well done. The character options are diverse, even if at this time I do not know how much it will effect the story as I only have one play through.The combat is adequate. Easy difficulty provides a cake walk, Normal makes you think about a fight (but not have to min/max). Hard and PoD mode require to meta game. Lack of character AI means that on harder modes you need to make liberal use of formations and command issuance, but it did not feel like a burden on my first play through.The system they created does seem to create dead end characters that could happen in the D&D systems, but some combinations are more effective than others. The lake of restriction on armor and weapons makes this game much more variable.  Want a Wizard wearing plate armor? Can do. Want your fighter to use wands? Go ahead.Options in game to customize your game play are nice.  Do not want to have to go back to town and sell every 15 min? Enable access to your stash and adventure till you run out of camping supplies. Want to know if there are other options if you have high enough stats? Turn on that option.The system of the game is very well done and lays the ground work for future game set in the same system, all that would be needed is new art and writing.Now the bad:  The game is not BG2 level and it not fair to compare Pillars of Eternity with one of the greatest games of all time, but lets be honest we all hoped that this game would be BG3.The party NPCs are little bland and you do not form connections with them like BG2 managed.  The NPC;s do not seem to align themselves, none I would call evil and they all seemed (with one exception) "good" I hope my evil play through will change this perspective but I have not been able to yet.There is still game play bugs, thought not as numerous as I would have feared and hopefully patched out within a few months. Save often and not just with the quick save.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
Pillars Of Eternity is a glorious also-ran. It is a flawed but ultimately worthy imitator of the great Baldur's Gate series, and a promising sign of things to come.If you are the kind of person who has purchased any of the recent Black Isle remasters from Beamdog, then let me tell you in no uncertain terms that you should go buy PIllars of Eternity right now. It is the nearest thing to Baldur's Gate II since Baldur's Gate II, and if that doesn't already make you champ at the bit, then let me tell you that its a darn good facsimile. If you aren't the kind of person who has done something like that, then the first thing you'll want to know is that Pillars of Eternity is an isometric party management RPG in the style of the old nineties and noughties games, complete with their beautiful writing, massive single player adventure, and difficulty. While you start off going through the familiar motions of building a character, Pillars of Eternity introduces a few new wrinkles that make it interesting. For starters, while all the familiar archetypes are represented, some truly weird and original character classes exist here, including the chanter who sings harmful and helpful chants, and the cipher, who wields eldritch power to corrupt and destroy the souls of your foes. All the classes feel suitably different, and at time of writing the balance seems to be fairly good across the board. Another thing that Pillars of Eternity does that will probably surprise newcomers to the genre is that every single stat has a direct and significant combat impact. There are no dump stats here and while this means min-maxers will probably be arguing amongst each other for months to come, it is now pretty tricky to gimp your character.You can also supplement your party of six adventurers by hiring characters you create from scratch at any inn. But this would be a mistake. The game includes 8 NPC companions, and you should do everything in your power to have all of them in your party at some point in the game as their writing and acting is so well done you would be robbing yourself of the experience by building a custom party of adventurers. This quality of writing extends to virtually everything else you'll encounter during the course of the game to boot, and it is consistently excellent from start to finish (with two minor and largely irrelevant exceptions which I mention below). Without spoiling anything, the world of Eora will seem immediately familiar to anyone who has spent any time travelling around Faerun in the Forgotten Realms, but it doesn't just feel different enough to be fresh - it's positively revelatory.Oh, and did I mention its gorgeous? The area maps are eye poppingly beautiful, and the characters actually animate splendidly, plus there are loads of cool spell and ability effects. In fact, sometimes they can even be a bit overwhelming. There were moments, especially early on when I was finding my bearings, where I couldn't tell what was going on in fights.The game also features a brand new, proprietary combat system that you'll need to spend a little time getting your head around. And I really do mean that, because this game is hard. Even on Easy or Normal difficulty (which you should probably stick to if you're the kind of person who only plays games once) you will sometimes find yourself badly overwhelmed at strange points as though the game was poorly paced. The learning curve is hardly gentle either, and even if you know your way around this sort of game, there are variations both intentional and unintentional that you wont anticipate in your first few hours with the game. It's a recipe for frustration, and while genre veterans are likely familiar with that feeling, if you're not used to that kind of abuse, expect Pillars of Eternity to test your patience from time to time. Still, the challenge rarely feels unfair (though make no mistake - there are some moments where it feels EXTREMELY unfair in some of the optional endgame content), and it is immensely satisfying to finally triumph over a difficult encounter.Partly this is because a job well done is its own reward, but partly this is because of the loot! And Pillars Eternity has a heck of a lot of it, and it comes in a pretty smooth progression that reminds me of the best moments of Baldur's Gate II, when you were excited to pick up the burning sword that the most recent boss left behind when he finally keeled over. And best of all, the game smartly does away with the old dumb system of playing inventory tetris, Pillars of Eternity allows you to have an unlimited number of items in your inventory in the form of a stash chest that is accessible at any time with a single mouse click whenever you bring up your inventory screen. For anyone who is used to juggling arrows and quest items, it feels downright civilized.The game is not perfect, however. Even after a patch designed to address it, the game features a strangely low level cap that you will absolutely hit. "But wait," I hear you say, "Baldur's Gate had a level cap!" This is true, but it was one that you could only hit by importing your heroes and taking them through the game, and subsequent games abandoned them entirely. By contrast, you may make the unpleasant discovery that you are max level just around the time you really feel like you're starting to cruise. It's jarring and unpleasant, and it's best you're aware of it now.Further, a lot of the kickstarter stretch goal content is terrible. For example, early on in the game you encounter a stronghold which you capture and make your own. While it houses the biggest and best dungeon crawl in the game, it also features a stronghold building metagame that is deceptively terrible. The game is also awash in backer NPCs and memorials - NPCs and gravestones designed by kickstarter backers identifiable by their yellow name bars and tombstone icons. These are uniformly terrible, and you may make the mistake of wasting time reading through them when you first boot up the game. The serious player should regard them as unfortunate concessions to people who wanted to overpay for the game and ignore them completely. It is a real shame to think that these efforts could have been spent on shoring up the game itself.The only other objection I have with Pillars of Eternity is that it is just a little more segmented than it should be. In each Act you are gated on the world map in some ways that feel pretty silly, and while it still feels pretty modern, it lacks the freeform feel that the very best games in the genre had. Still, this is a minor complaint, and there is lots of great sidequesting and adventuring to be done.Overall, Pillars of Eternity feels like it has all the things that a throwback to one of the old greats should have, plus a few smart new inventions. It's actually a little short and content light by genre standards, as the game clocks in at around 40 or 50 hours for an leisurely, exhaustive completionist playthrough, and perhaps a little more than 30 for a more main-story-only run. But if we're being honest with ourselves, that's still a whole lot of bang for your buck, and oh boy, what a ride Pillars of Eternity is if you're up for its challenges.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												First of all, my general opinion of Pillars of Eternity: This game is a work of art. Seriously, it seems like every little thing in this game has been carefully thought-out and is there for a reason. But yeah, there are some bad things too. Not many of them though.First of all, the positives: The game is beautiful. The art style is pretty, the UI is functional, yet nice to look at. I especially like the illustrations which are visible in the cut scenes and the painted character portaits. The classes are not exactly boring standard fantasy stuff, instead they are some small, interesting aspects about every one of them. For example, the mage can only equip a small number of spells at any time, and he's also not able to spam them but has to think carefully if the fight is important enough to warrant the usage of spells. Although PoE is a old-school kind of game, there are many things which make a player's life easier. For example the fast mode and slow mode. No more waiting several minutes until your party is on the other end of the map, just turn on the fast mode! Another nice design choice: There is a really large crate the party is carrying at all time, which can be used to store all of the loot one wants to sell in the next city. Like said before, PoE is in the vein of those old-school-RPGs many of us loved as children. Siege of Avalon, Lamentation Sword or Diablo 1 - PoE has aspects of all of them, but with vastly improved graphics, handling and freedom of decision when it comes to quests. The battle system is turn-based, but it feels much more fluent and fast than, for example, the slow-paced battle system of Divinity: Original Sin. I also really liked the fact that the player gets a stronghold later on in the game, gives another little touch of strategy to the game. There are many small little things that, while not important, add quite some immersion to the game. The descriptions on items or enviromental objects, hidden caches that observant players can find, the small stories behind the characters in the world. PETS. The player can pick up certain pets from the ground and equip them. How cool is that?!Of course, there also are some negative aspects. The first thing that comes to my mind is the animations, especially those of the playable characters. They seem to start at the same time, so when you order your party to move it looks like a bunch of clones is running around. There are no differences in running animation depending on race or gender, which is kind of sad. Although it is expected from a game like this, the difficulty spikes can be a little too extreme. Sometimes the player is left to feel pretty frustrated because there are no quests to level up left, yet the boss fight is so hard that it's only doable by cheesing around (if at all). Additionally, the tutorial windows seem to forget a few important aspects. Maybe I'm just stupid, but - for example I did not know that one can hire customized mercs at the inn. I was running around with 2 characters, wondering why the fights are so hard. Sometimes the characters bug out in the battles and get stuck somewhere, although they could just move a few steps to reach the enemy. The game also has a few visual bugs, at times buttons are invisible and you've got to click where you think the button is.Overall, the positive aspects of PoE outnumber the negative ones and I'd recommend this game to every fan of old-school fantasy RPGs.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												    So...it's time to give it thumb up, isn't it?    Something to note for those who aren't sure about buying this due to having "potato pc" - I played it on notebook with Intel HD 3000... It wasn't flawless fps-wise (common drops below 25) but working and since its not action-rpg it wasn't that painful.    Bear in mind my recommendation is based on game without expansion(s).     What to start with... ok, I would say this game fulfilled my expectation to some extend, not fully, but enough to not make me regret buying it. But still, there are some thing that could be done slightly better, so lets start with things I disliked:uneven difficulty level (regarding fights) - most of them are rather easy on normal difficulty and then you are facing one when whole party gets wiped out instantly... and I'm not talking about the final oneplot seems a bit hasty at the endgeneral map (when travelling between zones) doesn't provide information about nearby locations, you need to check every corner of the zone you are in to make sure you didn't skip something by accidentsome places seems "opened" a bit too early, not letting you take and finish quests you would later could have done with specific abilities/knowledgestronghold... it could have been so much better with more thing to do and some done better with prison being a waste and when you have prisoner, ransom offered for them is almost non-existing... and they can flee anywaycombat log sometimes doesn't provide necessary information, making you wonder how character got killeddescription of what's happening around character or how your interlocutor behave is sometimes a bit too long and sadly only few do described things regarding voice acting (like changing the way they talk for example)only 12 character levels in base game feels odd, but its probably me being used to D&D 2 and 3 amount of levelsfew times I felt there could be more possibilities regarding quests and dialogues, sometimes choosing diffrent option has the same resultreputation system isn't clear, "huge increase in reputation" (without any reputation before) makes you barerly "neutral" for city/village/group"stand-by" companions are leveling up, but it's not shown in choosing screen for some reasonAI is a mess and with only few options avaliable    Now what I liked:character creation - it took me good 30-40 minutes to make up my mind what I want my character to be and it has its consequences the way character statistics work - its diffrent from standard Dungeon & Dragons approach and feels unique, but is clear how it worksmany approaches for quests with few possible outcomes and way they are handled (wish there were more "witcher-like" type of quests, where decision made have consequences later in the game)character reputation systemthanks to this above - lack of aligment system, you are not "evil" or "good", people will look at what have you done to judgefreedom of exploration (to some extend)main plot in general is quite interesting, especially the way its narrated; maybe not Planescape level but still way above the averageside quests feels importantwant companion with specific class? Create him/her just like your main character in innspecific way some encounters are held - with diffrent screen, appropriate artwork and few possibilities of what you want to dodiffrent places when you can met new companionsabout them - great voice acting (I liked especially Duran) and thanks God that translation didn't change voicesendurance and health instead of only health as resource like in most rpg's    In general - I wouldn't call this game "Baldur's Gate 3" because it isn't. It's something slightly diffrent - great story, unique way of handling character creation, "mysterious" past of main character...    I'm recommending this game for every fan of classic RPGs - from Icewind Dale, through Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights to Planescape:Torment. It's good 40-50 hours of gameplay on the first run with good replayability.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I recommend this warily... I will honestly say the game was entertaining for a single playthrough. The story started off strong and engaging but grew weaker and felt more forced in the subsequent acts. The ending was terribly crafted; it made absolutely no sense and only served to highlight a slew of plotholes. The companions were unique and interesting but neither remarkable or memorable. Compared to other, much older games in the same genre, Pillars of Eternity's story and characters were extremely bland.As for gameplay, it was pretty standard, which is to say it did nothing really new and that isn't exactly a bad thing. There were some things I didn't like, none of which "broke the game" or were difficult to overcome, but were noticeably annoying. Such as...-They tried too hard to be different from D&D and make their own mark by creating a whole new system but you find yourself asking, "Was this really necessary?" Attributes are designed to be compensated for by gear and food but the only time you find yourself desperate for an attribute bonus is for conversation rolls (which was the only time I ever bothered to use food). Other than Mechanics and Lore, the abilities play their biggest role in conversations and interactive cutscenes.-The food system was completely pointless. Perhaps it plays a very defining role in harder versions of the game, but for a normal playthrough it was just an extra thing on the side you never thought about or needed.-The player defenses worked really well if the enemy wasn't better than you in the first place and really poorly if they were. Sometimes, they didn't matter at all. Will, for example, supposedly prevents you from being charmed. But I had guys will incredibly high will scores that got charmed every. single. time. And for enemy defenses, in the end, they hardly mattered. There were only a handful of fights that couldn't be solved by an abundance of traps, summoned creatures, and/or zerging.-The AI and engagement rules, which worked rather haphazardly. EXAMPLE: you direct your priest to go heal an ally. He runs toward the ally in need of healing and a mob barely backs into him. He immediately stops moving to heal the ally and begins attacking the enemy. Forget what I told him to do... mob must die... clearly he is contributing to the success of the group. Oh, now everyone is dead because the AI does what it wants. Clearly you must double and triple pause to reissue the same commands over and over because that's how a tactical game should operate.-Combat pathing was ridiculous. Once combat starts, characters can't seem to find their way around a damn rock in the middle of the street. "GUYS, HELP! I'm stuck on this pebble! I can't hit the mob! I'm sorry you're all dying!"-The load times were inexplicably atrocious on a good computer.I know this sounds incredibly negative. I blame the ending entirely, as it just made all of my minor qualms explode into major ones. Had the game ended even remotely intelligently, I would have happily recommend it. As it stands, it was a fun experience up until the end, which ultimately ruined it.

Pillars Of Eternity is a glorious also-ran. It is a flawed but ultimately worthy imitator of the great Baldur's Gate series, and a promising sign of things to come.If you are the kind of person who has purchased any of the recent Black Isle remasters from Beamdog, then let me tell you in no uncertain terms that you should go buy PIllars of Eternity right now. It is the nearest thing to Baldur's Gate II since Baldur's Gate II, and if that doesn't already make you champ at the bit, then let me tell you that its a darn good facsimile. If you aren't the kind of person who has done something like that, then the first thing you'll want to know is that Pillars of Eternity is an isometric party management RPG in the style of the old nineties and noughties games, complete with their beautiful writing, massive single player adventure, and difficulty. While you start off going through the familiar motions of building a character, Pillars of Eternity introduces a few new wrinkles that make it interesting. For starters, while all the familiar archetypes are represented, some truly weird and original character classes exist here, including the chanter who sings harmful and helpful chants, and the cipher, who wields eldritch power to corrupt and destroy the souls of your foes. All the classes feel suitably different, and at time of writing the balance seems to be fairly good across the board. Another thing that Pillars of Eternity does that will probably surprise newcomers to the genre is that every single stat has a direct and significant combat impact. There are no dump stats here and while this means min-maxers will probably be arguing amongst each other for months to come, it is now pretty tricky to gimp your character.You can also supplement your party of six adventurers by hiring characters you create from scratch at any inn. But this would be a mistake. The game includes 8 NPC companions, and you should do everything in your power to have all of them in your party at some point in the game as their writing and acting is so well done you would be robbing yourself of the experience by building a custom party of adventurers. This quality of writing extends to virtually everything else you'll encounter during the course of the game to boot, and it is consistently excellent from start to finish (with two minor and largely irrelevant exceptions which I mention below). Without spoiling anything, the world of Eora will seem immediately familiar to anyone who has spent any time travelling around Faerun in the Forgotten Realms, but it doesn't just feel different enough to be fresh - it's positively revelatory.Oh, and did I mention its gorgeous? The area maps are eye poppingly beautiful, and the characters actually animate splendidly, plus there are loads of cool spell and ability effects. In fact, sometimes they can even be a bit overwhelming. There were moments, especially early on when I was finding my bearings, where I couldn't tell what was going on in fights.The game also features a brand new, proprietary combat system that you'll need to spend a little time getting your head around. And I really do mean that, because this game is hard. Even on Easy or Normal difficulty (which you should probably stick to if you're the kind of person who only plays games once) you will sometimes find yourself badly overwhelmed at strange points as though the game was poorly paced. The learning curve is hardly gentle either, and even if you know your way around this sort of game, there are variations both intentional and unintentional that you wont anticipate in your first few hours with the game. It's a recipe for frustration, and while genre veterans are likely familiar with that feeling, if you're not used to that kind of abuse, expect Pillars of Eternity to test your patience from time to time. Still, the challenge rarely feels unfair (though make no mistake - there are some moments where it feels EXTREMELY unfair in some of the optional endgame content), and it is immensely satisfying to finally triumph over a difficult encounter.Partly this is because a job well done is its own reward, but partly this is because of the loot! And Pillars Eternity has a heck of a lot of it, and it comes in a pretty smooth progression that reminds me of the best moments of Baldur's Gate II, when you were excited to pick up the burning sword that the most recent boss left behind when he finally keeled over. And best of all, the game smartly does away with the old dumb system of playing inventory tetris, Pillars of Eternity allows you to have an unlimited number of items in your inventory in the form of a stash chest that is accessible at any time with a single mouse click whenever you bring up your inventory screen. For anyone who is used to juggling arrows and quest items, it feels downright civilized.The game is not perfect, however. Even after a patch designed to address it, the game features a strangely low level cap that you will absolutely hit. "But wait," I hear you say, "Baldur's Gate had a level cap!" This is true, but it was one that you could only hit by importing your heroes and taking them through the game, and subsequent games abandoned them entirely. By contrast, you may make the unpleasant discovery that you are max level just around the time you really feel like you're starting to cruise. It's jarring and unpleasant, and it's best you're aware of it now.Further, a lot of the kickstarter stretch goal content is terrible. For example, early on in the game you encounter a stronghold which you capture and make your own. While it houses the biggest and best dungeon crawl in the game, it also features a stronghold building metagame that is deceptively terrible. The game is also awash in backer NPCs and memorials - NPCs and gravestones designed by kickstarter backers identifiable by their yellow name bars and tombstone icons. These are uniformly terrible, and you may make the mistake of wasting time reading through them when you first boot up the game. The serious player should regard them as unfortunate concessions to people who wanted to overpay for the game and ignore them completely. It is a real shame to think that these efforts could have been spent on shoring up the game itself.The only other objection I have with Pillars of Eternity is that it is just a little more segmented than it should be. In each Act you are gated on the world map in some ways that feel pretty silly, and while it still feels pretty modern, it lacks the freeform feel that the very best games in the genre had. Still, this is a minor complaint, and there is lots of great sidequesting and adventuring to be done.Overall, Pillars of Eternity feels like it has all the things that a throwback to one of the old greats should have, plus a few smart new inventions. It's actually a little short and content light by genre standards, as the game clocks in at around 40 or 50 hours for an leisurely, exhaustive completionist playthrough, and perhaps a little more than 30 for a more main-story-only run. But if we're being honest with ourselves, that's still a whole lot of bang for your buck, and oh boy, what a ride Pillars of Eternity is if you're up for its challenges.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												My original review of this game was negative. There were a great many things missing and just didnt warrant the price.Now I reluctantly give a thumbs up (6 or 7 out of 10) as i have returned to finish the game. Some great strides (bug fixing, party AI) make this a great buy on sale, but i think a more full experience requires the expansion (which are woven into the main story). Negative points for me:-Odd Design choices still (stuff like not being able to rename the animal companion or vanity pets or for 1 character to carry more than like 20 item icon (bag has X slots, small parties very loot unviable). Doesnt weigh heavily, but hard to swallow the tooltip importance of animal companion that is simply 'bear companion').-Loading screens. Just simply a lot of loading screens. Even with specs that crush the recommended on a SSD, they are just frequent. Load into the keep yard and go to the manor, load into the manor. Talk to someone with a problem, loading as it 'gets your companions' (faster fade to black transition than area). Load to leave manor, load to enter the inn. Load to go to 2nd floor of inn. Sleep transition, load to leave 2nd floor. Load to leave inn back to keep yard. Load to leave keep. I would estimate each screen around 3 seconds, so definitely not bad, but there are a lot of them. (i would estimate 30 seconds of loading screens for a quick visit to the keep for housekeeping. You can sleep from menus and avoid some of the screens, but the high horse of Role playing excellence and immersion gets much lower imo, but options are prefered).-Pay to win. There are two 15$ expansions that are woven into the main story line. Cool, but I am running into quests where "you cannot achieve the noble/nicest ending here unless you bought the expansions" and i think that is crap. Point in case is the Yenwood conflict. I absolutely adore Capt. Emery and you can certainly gain a respect and mutual understanding with her, but you will fight to the death unless you bought the expansions (if you bought the expansions, you can make good on the benevolent dialogue that she agreed with and not have to fight to the death). Something rubs me wrong about being forced to kill an NPC that I like and that likes my PC, but because I didnt buy the expansions yet, we have to fight to the death. I have no idea how many other outcomes are like this.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												It took nearly 15 years to finally get a proper follow-up to Baldur's Gate 2, but here it is. Having said that, times have-a-changed since the glory days of the infinity engine. While there are a number of quality of life changes in the game system, it still has one foot planted firmly in the past. This will probably rub some people the wrong way, (Vancian spell casting seems to invite a lot of ire for example) but POE's reverence for all things old will delight just as many people.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Allright! let me just start off by saying, im very biased due to having played a lot of these games throughout my life, and i will be comparing them to it.First offThe game is really well done, its pretty, its intruiging, and its class system is well done.However a few things do annoy me.1: the Druid form is overpowered at low level, then becomes utterly useless higher up, it just doesn't scale well.2: the stronghold seems unfinished, it doesnt make you FEEL like a lord of the castle.3: the level 12, i find it too low as you reach it easily before you even GET to act 3...which seems rather silly to me.4: the armor system? here comes the bias, it doesnt work, recovery increased from heavy armor? wheres the spell casting penalty? the skill check penaltys? anything really...5: the skill system, it seems useless except for mechanics which seems to be needed too much.6: theres quite a few gamebreaking bugs, i havent gotten them myself but i know people who did, things that literally stop your game from moving, an example of this is a bug where if you kill people when they attack you instead of doing their dialogue through something you just 'have to know'. the game gets stuckapart from these thigns the game is amazing, really one of the best RPGS, in fact id call it the best since neverwinter nights 2.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
												Amazing!  A++  One of the best games I've ever played!I've been a huge fan of AD&D infinity engine type games like Baldur's gate and Icewind Dale since the first came out in the 1990s. I've played through every one that I could get my hands on and for about a decade now, I have been waiting on someone to release a game that continued the legecy, then I found Pillars of Eternity.The system is not a copy of the infinity engine.  It is quite different, but only in ways that either seem to make the game more convenient for the player. I could sit here all day and tell you how great this game is, but if you liked Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale, just play this game.  It's as close as you're going to get to Baldur's Gate 3.  The only negative mark I would give this game is for charachter creation. It's pretty good, but you don't get as many options as in some other AD&D type games. No multiple sub-classes for rogues, druids, or mages. However, your charachters are very customizable as you level, and the game makes up for this in many other ways.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Pillars of Eternity is a classically styled RPG akin to Planescape Torment and Baldur's Gate. It is a 2.5D isometric game that successfully capitalizes on what made those classic games good.In this case, what I really liked about Pillars of Eternity was its story. While I'm typically not one for fantasy settings, Obsidian did a good job at writing a story that kept me interested -- focusing on a central theme and running with it. Yes, it's still got those tropey races and classes. Godlikes are Tieflings in everything but name. Hobbits, elves, those kinds of generic things rear their heads. However, the game doesn't spend too much time focusing on those races, as much as it does on the idea of "souls".The combat mechanics are, honestly, none too amazing. But I came to Pillars of Eternity for the same reason I come to most Obsidian games -- satisfactory writing. And I got what I wanted. If you like a solid fantasy game with a well fleshed out universe, and good writing with great choice/consequence systems and replayability, give Pillars of Eternity a shot. I didn't regret paying full price for this game at all.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												    So...it's time to give it thumb up, isn't it?    Something to note for those who aren't sure about buying this due to having "potato pc" - I played it on notebook with Intel HD 3000... It wasn't flawless fps-wise (common drops below 25) but working and since its not action-rpg it wasn't that painful.    Bear in mind my recommendation is based on game without expansion(s).     What to start with... ok, I would say this game fulfilled my expectation to some extend, not fully, but enough to not make me regret buying it. But still, there are some thing that could be done slightly better, so lets start with things I disliked:uneven difficulty level (regarding fights) - most of them are rather easy on normal difficulty and then you are facing one when whole party gets wiped out instantly... and I'm not talking about the final oneplot seems a bit hasty at the endgeneral map (when travelling between zones) doesn't provide information about nearby locations, you need to check every corner of the zone you are in to make sure you didn't skip something by accidentsome places seems "opened" a bit too early, not letting you take and finish quests you would later could have done with specific abilities/knowledgestronghold... it could have been so much better with more thing to do and some done better with prison being a waste and when you have prisoner, ransom offered for them is almost non-existing... and they can flee anywaycombat log sometimes doesn't provide necessary information, making you wonder how character got killeddescription of what's happening around character or how your interlocutor behave is sometimes a bit too long and sadly only few do described things regarding voice acting (like changing the way they talk for example)only 12 character levels in base game feels odd, but its probably me being used to D&D 2 and 3 amount of levelsfew times I felt there could be more possibilities regarding quests and dialogues, sometimes choosing diffrent option has the same resultreputation system isn't clear, "huge increase in reputation" (without any reputation before) makes you barerly "neutral" for city/village/group"stand-by" companions are leveling up, but it's not shown in choosing screen for some reasonAI is a mess and with only few options avaliable    Now what I liked:character creation - it took me good 30-40 minutes to make up my mind what I want my character to be and it has its consequences the way character statistics work - its diffrent from standard Dungeon & Dragons approach and feels unique, but is clear how it worksmany approaches for quests with few possible outcomes and way they are handled (wish there were more "witcher-like" type of quests, where decision made have consequences later in the game)character reputation systemthanks to this above - lack of aligment system, you are not "evil" or "good", people will look at what have you done to judgefreedom of exploration (to some extend)main plot in general is quite interesting, especially the way its narrated; maybe not Planescape level but still way above the averageside quests feels importantwant companion with specific class? Create him/her just like your main character in innspecific way some encounters are held - with diffrent screen, appropriate artwork and few possibilities of what you want to dodiffrent places when you can met new companionsabout them - great voice acting (I liked especially Duran) and thanks God that translation didn't change voicesendurance and health instead of only health as resource like in most rpg's    In general - I wouldn't call this game "Baldur's Gate 3" because it isn't. It's something slightly diffrent - great story, unique way of handling character creation, "mysterious" past of main character...    I'm recommending this game for every fan of classic RPGs - from Icewind Dale, through Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights to Planescape:Torment. It's good 40-50 hours of gameplay on the first run with good replayability.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I recommend this warily... I will honestly say the game was entertaining for a single playthrough. The story started off strong and engaging but grew weaker and felt more forced in the subsequent acts. The ending was terribly crafted; it made absolutely no sense and only served to highlight a slew of plotholes. The companions were unique and interesting but neither remarkable or memorable. Compared to other, much older games in the same genre, Pillars of Eternity's story and characters were extremely bland.As for gameplay, it was pretty standard, which is to say it did nothing really new and that isn't exactly a bad thing. There were some things I didn't like, none of which "broke the game" or were difficult to overcome, but were noticeably annoying. Such as...-They tried too hard to be different from D&D and make their own mark by creating a whole new system but you find yourself asking, "Was this really necessary?" Attributes are designed to be compensated for by gear and food but the only time you find yourself desperate for an attribute bonus is for conversation rolls (which was the only time I ever bothered to use food). Other than Mechanics and Lore, the abilities play their biggest role in conversations and interactive cutscenes.-The food system was completely pointless. Perhaps it plays a very defining role in harder versions of the game, but for a normal playthrough it was just an extra thing on the side you never thought about or needed.-The player defenses worked really well if the enemy wasn't better than you in the first place and really poorly if they were. Sometimes, they didn't matter at all. Will, for example, supposedly prevents you from being charmed. But I had guys will incredibly high will scores that got charmed every. single. time. And for enemy defenses, in the end, they hardly mattered. There were only a handful of fights that couldn't be solved by an abundance of traps, summoned creatures, and/or zerging.-The AI and engagement rules, which worked rather haphazardly. EXAMPLE: you direct your priest to go heal an ally. He runs toward the ally in need of healing and a mob barely backs into him. He immediately stops moving to heal the ally and begins attacking the enemy. Forget what I told him to do... mob must die... clearly he is contributing to the success of the group. Oh, now everyone is dead because the AI does what it wants. Clearly you must double and triple pause to reissue the same commands over and over because that's how a tactical game should operate.-Combat pathing was ridiculous. Once combat starts, characters can't seem to find their way around a damn rock in the middle of the street. "GUYS, HELP! I'm stuck on this pebble! I can't hit the mob! I'm sorry you're all dying!"-The load times were inexplicably atrocious on a good computer.I know this sounds incredibly negative. I blame the ending entirely, as it just made all of my minor qualms explode into major ones. Had the game ended even remotely intelligently, I would have happily recommend it. As it stands, it was a fun experience up until the end, which ultimately ruined it.

With the recent 3.0 patch i decided to give it a go. The game starts slow, very slow. It gives you the time to learn about this new setting and savour the world it takes place in.It really is a modern Baldur's Gate 2 with a bit more exploration (the thing i like the most about BG1), The characters seem a bit hollow at first, after all they don't banter much between them. Until you get to advance on their stories, that is. I came to write this review after one of my companions shared a little secret (not spoiling it) with my character.The combat requires a bit of getting used to, i think it's a great improvement over the past IE games. Very tactical, be sure to use pause a lot and try to get the hang of all the different companions AI settings (which are not perfect btw).I'm only 20 hours into the game and it really has surprised me in a very positive way so far. Very good, congratulations, devs!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												As a HUGE fan of the early Infinity Engine games I was seriously looking forward to Pillars of Eternity. An old school isometric cRPG? Heck yes I'm in!  Evern if it's a fraction as good as Baldur's Gate or Shadows of Amn it will still be amazing. Like Icewind Dale back in the day.I was a bit worried that Obsidian (formerly Black Isle) would botch this like so many other games in their back catalogue but after about 20-something hours it seems my fears were unfounded. The writing is pretty good and at times really hit home with the imagery they presented in text. The background lore is fairly interesting and the writes did a good job of creating a world with a rich past and interesting conflicts and inhabitants. My only real qualm with the dialogue, writing, and conversations was the voice acting. Sure, hearing recognizable voices was fun but the talking ruins it for me. I want to read not listen. I can read faster than you can talk and give you accents of my own imagining! Gah!The combat is very similar to Infinity games, closer to Icewind Dale II than Baldur's Gate though. Per encounter / Per rest abilities spice things up while you're playing a figher, ranger, or barbarian compaired to BG. The caster classes and spells are all interesting and visually pleasing. I found the difficulty level fairly tame, even on Hard and Path of the Damned (Pillars hardest), but that comes with many years of playing tactical RPG's I think. If you're new to this type of genre you might want to steer clear of anything above Normal.Graphiclly it looks much like other Unity Engine games. Shadowrun Returns, Divinity:OS, and Wasteland 2 all share the engine with Pillars and it's easy on the eyes and I believe Pillars did a better job on scenery than the others. The towns, cities, and wilderness areas are all beautiful. This is a great game for any cRPG / Infinity Engine enthusiests and highly reccomended. If you enjoy a good RPG in general you might want to check this one out.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Modern RPG's have lose something through all the top notch shaders, CG, and innumerable DLC's. They lost their soul. This game feels like any one of the original infinity engine games I would have been playing in the ninties, but with a modernized interface that provides the level of accessibility you'd expect to find this day in age.What sets this game apart is simple: the writing. It's rich in analogy, deep with meaning, and too complex to fit into prototypical archetypes of protagonists and antagonists. Whilw most modern RPG's commit themselves to stamping every binary decision their game offers with a simplified 'good-guy' versus 'bad-guy' system that paints the universe as extremely black and white, (to the point of breaking the immersion of players like myself)  Pillars of Eternity strives at it's very core to create many situations that are composed of 'shades of grey.' You'll want to pick an option, but when you really examine the reasoning for both sides of an argument, you'll have an honest moment of moral dilemma. That is something I haven't felt in decades. Most games will slap labels of paragon and defiler on any action you take, complete with pictures and color coding as if you were too stupid to really figure it out. There's a point in which the agency of a system is made so crystal clear that it practically insults the player for not having the wit to determine their own moral code.Playing Pillars is a rich and rewarding experiance that provided deep player agency, and conveyed a rich plot. Near the end you'll have that revelation, notice the line being drawn between characters and other components of the story, and you won't get that from another EA mass produced garbage RPG.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												Great classic RPG with interesting battle system, story, world and wonderful graphics. I was really captivated by the setting, enjoyed the dialogue system that gave different options based on my stats and reputations.Game’s own leveling system is quite distinctive from Dungeons & Dragons you may got used to, but I think it’s really good – I felt there was no bad class and each level up was a delight for me, when I was able to choose from many interesting perks/abilities to customize my Orlan Monk.The game is quite long - I clocked almost 70 hours and I haven't even completed the second DLC, so I estimate the main game to last for ~60 hours. I think it could be shorter - it was getting a little bit stale at the end - but that's a minor complaint. It was mostly due to fights becoming too easy/predictable. I played on HARD and at first the game was really challenging for me. I had to carefully position my team mates and use active pause a lot. But after some point it got easy - I think DLCs might have upset the balance a bit - even though I always chose "scale enemies to your current level" option, when such option was presented.If you like classic cRPGs – it’s for you. Heck, even if you haven’t played cRPG before – it’s one of the best games to start.
