number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												I have never played any of the classic RPG’s such as Baldur’s Gate or Icewind Dale (but I know now that this was a huge mistake). So if you’re looking for a Review from someone that isn’t biased by nostalgia, you’ve come to the right place.I’ve been a gamer for 20 years now, and I can say without hesitation that “Pillars of Eternity” is one of the best crafted games I have ever come across. You really feel the love and passion that went into it. You find it in the story, in the characters, in the beautiful maps and dungeons full of lovingly crafted detail, in the wonderful music and in the voice acting. There is nothing about this game that isn’t great. But let’s get into a little more detail…First the story and writing. More often than not the stories in PC games are just there to hold everything together as opposed to telling something worthwhile. Not so in PoE. Here the story is really good and worth exploring. It’s dark and sad, has many emotional and dramatic moments, twists and revelations, interesting characters, tons of really good dialogue and a great conclusion. It never feels like the quests that move it along where there first and the story then spun around them. Rather the quests fit into the story very naturally and never seem forced or misplaced. But it’s not just the main story that is worth exploring. You will also find many sidequests, some small, some a bit bigger, that tell all kinds of interesting little stories. Some sad, some funny, some dark, some light, but almost all of them are worth your time.And then there are the books and the souls you can read. And I really recommend doing this! Yes, there is some redundant stuff there, but you will also find some really great little stories or insights about the world and its history. Especially within the souls you can reach out to. Man is there some great stuff there! Some gave me goosebumps, some made me sad, others where funny, and some unsettling, and I rarely read one that wasn’t worth it. The writing overall is excellent for story and dialogue alike, which is a good thing as there is A LOT to read in this game ;-) The characters you meet are well designed and consistent, worth talking to and learn their history. This is especially true for the companions that you can pick up as you travel around. The game does give you the option of creating your own party members but I would really recommend against doing that. Yes you can probably create more effective characters than those you will find on your travels, but then you would miss out on so much great content. All companions offer quests that you can follow, additional insights into the world and the main quest and tons of dialogue to explore. And they banter among themselves which at times can be really funny. The developers really did a great job bringing those characters to live. I just can’t imagine playing the game without them as they just add so much to the experience.As for the game world, again, just excellent work through and through. The world of Eora is deep with rich history and lore. It’s a place of wonder, beauty and adventure, laced with hardship and horror. And the visual representation on the screen is just marvelous. The maps are beautifully designed, filled with tons of detail and are really worth the time it takes to explore every little corner. Sometimes I would just sit there for a moment and marvel at the beautiful landscapes, buildings, ruins or creatures. And all of it is perfectly accompanied by an absolutely beautiful soundtrack that creates a great atmosphere.The games mechanics are also just excellent. I really love how the classes are designed and how they level. Finally a game where you are forced to specialize and cannot max out everything on every character. Once you choose a class you are stuck with it, once you define your characters attributes, that’s it, you can’t raise them further except through enchantments and temporary bonuses. And skills get really expensive on the higher levels, forcing you to specialize your characters as you will only be able to max 1 to 2 skills on each one. Also each class gets special talents and abilities unavailable to other classes. It really forces you to play each character differently and compose a party out of different classes that complement each other. You will need fighters, you will need a priest, you will want a wizard and so on. Every class brings something important to the party and its really just the right mix that will decide how well your party does in battle. The system feels well balanced and plays very naturally, and exploits are near impossible. As a result, combat is very complex and tactical. It starts with the right deployment before battle and choosing the right weapons and spells for what you are about to face. Then once battle starts it’s all about timing. For example spells need time to cast, so if we’re talking about area effects you have to aim them where the enemy will be once they fire, not where the enemy currently is. Or casting a targeted spell on an enemy that gets killed by another party member in the time it takes to cast the spell probably isn’t such a good idea either. You will be pausing a lot, give commands, look at all your options, considering the next move and so on. And you will be reloading a lot! Trust me on this, you will wear out the quicksave and quickload buttons on this game, even on normal difficulty. And don’t get discouraged because your party gets utterly wiped out without the enemy even breaking a sweat. It doesn’t mean necessarily that your party isn’t strong enough, it may be just because of flawed tactics or wrong choices during battle. Try again with a different approach and things may take a different turn. I had battles where my party got annihilated on the first try but finally managed to do just the same to the enemy once I figured out the right tactic and got the timing right. And I can tell you it is a highly rewarding experience. Combat in PoE requires a lot of thinking and effort, but it’s worth it!Is there anything bad about PoE? Well, not really. I can’t find anything wrong with this marvelous game except a few minor things that aren’t really worth mentioning. But for completeness I will talk about them as maybe for some they are not so minor.One thing I noticed and found mildly annoying is an issue with the voice acting. Now I’m perfectly ok with the fact that not all dialogue is voiced. Hell I would also be fine with none of it being voiced. What annoys me a bit however is that there are a lot of conversations where part is voiced and part not. So a character may say something that is voiced, then the next thing he says is not, and the next after that is voiced again. I can’t really put a finger on the reason for this. It seems that fixed dialogue is voiced and dynamic dialogue is not, but I’m not entirely sure about it. Doesn’t matter really what the reason is, I find it a bit distracting.The other thing would be loading screens. Since the game is broken up not only into exteriors and interiors but also the world is broken up into many small maps that you travel between rather than just one lager map where you can roam free you will see a lot of loading screens. And the farther into the game you are, the longer you will see them. Now I have a machine which is really geared towards fast loading using high performance hardware and SSD only, and I find it already a little bit annoying at times. So on computers that are less optimized in terms of loading speed it might be a bigger issue.But as I said, to me these really are just minor annoyances. “Pillars of Eternity” is a fantastic game that I can’t recommend highly enough. If you like roleplaying and are not scared away by an old school approach at presentation and don’t mind having to read a lot then this is really worth your time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10
												Well...Oh man. I'm a huge fan of top down RPGs, and the Baldur's Gate series let me run wild with that and manage a party of 6 built badasses. This product, this game here is no different and it draws on all the great things from it's predecessors while simultaneously remaining new and vibrant. unlike it's cousins it is not multiplayer, so you'll likely be campaigning solo and is probably it's biggest drawback for me. Graphically it's amazing, and VOs and ambience is fantastic. As someone who did play them a lot, it's nice to see one made with some real graphical cheese. It's so pretty, and I love the little bits of continuity, like weapon sets being shown on your character when a different one is in use.The pause break form of combat is great here, swapping between all the pieces at your disposal and assigning combat actions, with the introduction of some scripts that actually help in managing all your casters somewhat (still prefer casting things myself though).I waited for months to buy it, missed its most recent sale, and I do not regret a single thing.10/10 easily

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												As someone who grew up playing fallout 1/2 and diablo 1/2 I've been lost for a decade with all the terrible remakes of our old classics or dissapointing sequels (diablo). Path of exile being one of the few good games we've had, but for what PoE added in good game mechanics is lacked effort in character building and story.Pillar has EVERYTHING, from huge ammounts of effort into each quest, great voice acting that actually adds to the whole experience, i didn't just sit there groaning the voices completely ruined any immersion.  It has a dead catA REAL DEAD CAT! which you can have as a pet may i add, killing feral children, stealing a gem then warning the owner his gem is under threat of being stolen, Going to kill a crazy lord then changing your mind and killing the person who sent you... this game is truely open to play HOWEVER you want. Each class feels unique, combat is fluid and difficult enough to challenge even hardcore rpg veterans. If  I could sacrifice my first born to get a sequel to  this game, i would go out and fertilize every willing subject.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												What can I say really? Um, how about... THIS GAME IS ♥♥♥♥ING STUPIDLY FUN.  Its crazy how it pulls you in, at times the storyline is meh but most of the time its really good.  I have beaten it twice once on normal and then again on path of the damned.  POTD was hard but only at the beginning, with good custom NPCs, you can still crush the bad guys at the end.  I did things totally different with each time I played it and the endings changed and the stories mid game changed and the quest items were different.  I am really really impressed by this game and I cannot wait for the expansion to come out.  I beat this, then said ok time for wasteland 2, after a few hours Im back at pillars.   then i say ok something new time for Divinity, then after a few hours its back to pillars.  I can't get away.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												50 hours into this game feels like the right time to start a review. The fact that I'm 50 hours in and yet have barely scratched the surface of this excellent game, should tell you something about the size and density of this nostalgic throw back to the Infinity games of yore.The first thing likely to strike you will take place in the character generation screens. It's easy to get so involved in this process that an hour will easily flick by. I can think of few games since the Baldurs Gates series or Icewind Dales that have had that effect, perhaps Skrim or Morrowind, but again this just proves the richness of the characters and backgrounds on offer here.Once into the game proper I felt instantly transported to the Baldurs Gate and Torment era. A little further scratching showed that whle POE has stayed true to those great games it does not feel like a game of that generation. Indeed Obsidian have managed to create a modern and innovative RPG that feels just as right in 2015 as would have in 2000 at the height if the Infiity engine age.To name just a few of the things on offer here, player choice, great NPC interaction, a rich and diverse world and an even richer and diverse story. So far I can't find a lot to fault. If I had to come up with one negative it could be that I will struggle to go back and play the likes of Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale again, as finally they will feel aged and matched, if not bettered, by a modern RPG.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												If you are a fan of CRPG's from the 90s into early 00's, then you will likely enjoy this game.  I have not had this much fun playing a CRPG since Planescape: Torment.The game feels like a classic Infinity Engine game (Baldurs Gate, Planescape Torment, Icewind Dale), but revised with modern graphic capabilities.   Some of the best gameplay improvements are:* Half Speed Movement* Double Speed Movement* Inventory Stash to remove inventory management mini-game (easy access can be disabled for the truely hardcore)* Removal of need to monster grind for levels by eliminating XP from monsters after a certain amount of kills of that monster type.  The XP focus is now on initial kills of a monster type and Quest experience.Here are some other gameplay change that you may or may not like. I find that they streamline the game over D&D type rulesets:* Trap Detection / Trap disarmement / Picklocking all covered by same skill: mechanics* Mechanics is a skill that any class can learn, so it is no longer mandatory to have a rogue in order to cover the above thief like actions.* Some spells/skills can be used a certain number of times per combat* mage/priests can cast a certain number of spells of each level per 'rest'; mages can only select 4 spells per level* AoE spells have 2 ranges, an inner range that can target both friend and foe, and an outer range that only can target foes.  In addition some AoE spells are listed as foe-only and can not harm friendly characters.  Stats can increase the radius of an AoE spell.I highly recommend this game for anyone who was a fan of the RPG classics from the 90s and early 00's.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												I actually Kick started this back when it was first announced and I do not regret doing so. If you are familiar with Baldur's Gate 2 and enjoyed it then you will love this game. It feels very familiar and yet brings a lot of new things to the table along with improvements. Even if you are not familiar with Baldur's Gate 2 you will still enjoy this game. The combat is almost exactly the same as Baldur's gate, it's an Action RPG where you can pause mid combat (similar to the modern Bioware games such as Mass Effect etc.). It is very challenging and it actually forces you to think which weapon type and which spells to use on each different enemy. Another great thing about this game is that it really is open, in the sense that there are multiple ways of completing a mission. As an example there is a certain area that you need to enter but it has been sealed off and it guarded by 2 guards. You can either:          1. Kill them and enter anyway          2. Bribe them and enter          3. Go to their boss and gain his favour to allow you entranceThere might be more ways that I haven't come across, but that's just one example. Not to mention this game has mods on steam workshop. Since it is a recent release, it won't have as many mods at the moment, but give it a bit of time and look at the mods coming in. I personally love the endurance mechanism during combat that replaces your health so that when you endurance drops to "0" you are unconcious but once the combat is over you are back up again, but with some sort of injury the second time your health drops below "0" you will die however unless you rest. Unlike BG2 you can't just rest as many times as you like, you need to have camping equipment and you can only carry a maximum of 5 at any one point. Though it's not all great. Some people have been complaining about the speed it takes to load a game once you are quite far in to the game. Personally I don't have a problem with it as back in the day the load times generally were really slow anyway. The other problem is that I feel that there is just too much talking about things that I feel are not really that important to me. I mean sure lore is important, but too much of reading will bore the game, especially when it is not directed to me. My personal issue with the story is there are moments when you can actually choose an option about your past of why you did something or who someone is exactly. (i.e. relative, partner friends etc.) And I feel like that freedom shouldn't be given because the story then feels fabricated rather than customised to you. So overall the story can use some improvement, but that still doesn't mean that the story is bad. It can definitely use some more voiced over lines though, compared to modern games this one is lacking in that area. Though again if you compare it to BG2, PoE feels like it has more voiced over lines despite being a smaller game. Overall I would give it a 8/10. I would have given it more had it not been for the amount of unnecassary lore that was forced fed.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I would like to write a review much earlier, but I thought that it would be better to finish the game first so I can give people who read this a more complete opinion about it. I am a gamer of an older generation and a backer of this game, and I believe that this definitely influences my opinion about this game. Since this game was announced I like the idea of a kickstarter project by one of the best companies in the creation of RPGs . I hate to speak like an older generation, especially in such a thing like games which is mostly destined for young people. but:Even if I wasn't a great fun of Baldur's Gate, I miss the depth and the beautiful stories of games I was playing ten or twenty years ago. New games have graphics and use technology that we, older gamers couldn't even imagine that it would ever exist. The first game I have ever played was in my uncle's Amstrad and there I could control a hero made of less than ten pixels, let alone the limited number of colours of the computer screen (less than 16 in comparison with thousands today). Today's most games are full of great cutscenes which are technologically laudable. Does this make them better games than the older ones??? If you are a gamer of a younger generation you may be used to high technology graphics, so it may be difficult for you to play an older game. For the same reason you may not like Pillars of Eternity. The graphics are certainly of the last decade and not this one, it looks like a game created in the end of 2000's. Does this mean that the graphics do not lookl good? The answer is no. They try to compensate for not being high-tech bY BEAUTIFUL HAND DRAWN BACKGROUNDS AND BEAUTIFUL ARTWORK. the design may not be that of high technology but it EMPHASISES ON LOOKING BEAUTIFUL AND NOT BEING ONE OF THE MOST RECENT TECHNOLOGY IN GRAPHICS. IT LOOKS GOOD IN THE EYE WHERE A LOT OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY TRIPLE A's FAIL. This is is why I give an 8/10 in GRAPHICS.Another relevant you would like to consider, and gamers-older and younger-should consider is whether DO CUTSCENES REALLY MATTER? HOW IS A CUTSCENE A PART OF THE ACTUAL GAME? In the older times I was hungry for new, high tech cutscenes too, but after playing Divinity Original Sin last year, I found out that it is now for me LESS IMPORTANT THAN I THOUGHT. RECENT TRIPLE A'S FOCUS IN CUTSCENES TOO MUCH AND THEYMOSTLY NEGLECT  THE QUALITY OF THE STORY!!! THEY TRY TO MAKE GENERIC STORIES SO THEY CAN SELL IT TO EVERYONE AND NOT GOOD ONES. MOST OF THEM HAVE STUPID STORIES COMPARED TO OLD GAMES. in the beggining I thought that the reason I was tired of playing newer games was because I got older, but then there are games like this one that which give me the excitement that older games were giving me. AND A GOOD STORY MATTERS MORE THAN CUTSCENES. PILLARS OF ETERNITY IS A TEXT HEAVY GAME BECAUSE IT IS A REAL RPG, WHERE STORY DEPTH, CONVERSATIONS AND CHOICES MATTER AND CHANGE THE WORLD AND WHAT HAPPENS IN THE QUESTS. OTHERWISE THIS WOULDN'T BE ABLE TO BE ANYTHING MORE THAN FETCH/KILL QUESTS OF RECENT RPGS. YOUNGER GAMERS COULD TRY TO GET USED TO IT. It is not easy in the Beggining but it pays off. As for me I really need to play games with a story and depth like this one. so STORY 10/10ANOTHER WEAK POINT OF MANY TRIPLE A's IS THE OVERSIMPLIFICATION OF GAMES RULES AND MECHANICS. GAMES WHICH ARE SIMPLER CAN SELL TO A BIGGER MARKET, BUT THEY ARE SOMETIMES INSULTING AND UNCHALLENGING IN COMPARISON TO OLDER GAMES. AN UNCHALLENGING GAME OR A GAME WITH FEW CHOICES IN TACTICS IS MORE LIKE AN INTERACTIVE VIDEO THAN A GAME. PILLARS OF ETERNITY HAS DEEP MECHANICS AND MAKES THE PLAYER TO TRY TO FIND THE MOST SUITABLE TACTICS FOR THE CHARACTERS IN CONTROL. BATTLES CAN BE CHALLENGING IN THE NORMAL MODE EVEN FOR RPG TABLETOPS PLAYERS LIKE ME. I would give it a straight ten if it wasn't for some bugs in the party's AI which make the use of micromanagement inevitable and a bug which I had to tolerate in one of my fighter's abilities(into the fray ability) which made the ability unavailable during the last twenty hours of the game). For this reason. GAME MECHANICS 10/10 BUT GAME'S AI 8/10.ANOTHER PART OF A GOOD GAME. ESPECIALLY AN RPG IS THE LORE. I THINK THAT THE LORE IS AMAZING. I personally prefer this lore to the lore of FR for example, as I find the lore of FR good for designing any kind of tabletop campaign but a bit too generic. BUT THE REAL PROBLEM IS THAT TRIPLE A's worlds are usually too kitch for my taste. I DON'T BELIEVE THAT QUALITY COMES IN BIG NUMBERS. A DRAGON IS A REVERED THING IN HIGH FANTASY. A THOUSAND DRAGONS IS A RIDICULOUS ONE. I FOUND MYSELF DEEPLY INTERESTED IN THE LORE OF PILLARS OF ETERNITY, BUT THAT IS SUBJECTIVE. SO LORE 10/10.MUSIC/SOUND/ACTING: A Game which has not perfect graphics can invest a lot in music and sound. THE MUSIC IS GREAT BUT NOT AS GREAT AS IN THE DIVINITY SERIES. THE THEMES ARE WONDERFUL BUT THERE SHOULD BE MORE OF THEM. For this Reason: MUSIC 9/10. The SOUND IS OKAY NOT EXCEPTIONAL 7/10. The budget was limited so NOT ALL OF THE DIALOGUES OF IMPORTANT NPC'S ARE RECORDED. I THINK THAT THIS IS STRAIGHTFORWARD WEIRD!!! MOST OF THE TIMES IT IS NOT A PROBLEM THOUGH AND I WILL BE LENIENT ON THAT BECAUSE OF THE LIMITED BUDGET. THIS WOULD BE UNFAIR FOR THE ACTORS, WHO DID AN AMAZING JOB AND GIVE EXCELLENT PERFORMANCES. For this reason: ACTING:10/10A 9/10 is a fair score for this game. But in my heart it will always be one of the 10/10 titles. I DON'T SAY THAT THIS GAME IS FOR A EVERYONE. BUT I DON'T CARE. IF YOU ARE BUYING IT YOU SHOULD JUDGE IT ACCORDING TO THE THINGS IT PROMISES TO DELIVER. AND IT DOES DELIVER!!!! HAVE FUN

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												As a gamer who thinks Baldur's Gate-games, and in lesser extent the others created with Infinity engine,  are pretty much the best RPG's ever created, I am jubilant they finally got the offspring we have been waiting for. The fact that it is no longer based on the D&D system was a concern of mine, but the new system works brilliantly. The classes, leveling and talents are solid and fairly easy to understand. Giving up on certain classic D&D rules is a good idea in my opinion. Now you can have your Cleric wield a crossbow, making it a deadly sniper from the back. However, the lack of specialization classes is a flaw IMHO. Also the lack of Party AI (behavior) is a really silly. A lot of micromanagement needed at times.Graphics are very solid, beautiful, yet paying homage to the original games. 3D characters look very good an blend seamlessly into the background. Sounds are also good and the music made me think of old Baldur's immideately. The game feels sublime and finished, and there seems to be very few bugs to encounter.However, the story seems a bit vague compared to the original Bioware games and characters lack charisma. They are not as interesting as say Minsc or Edwin, but still are interesting enough to keep you company.All in all, I am giving this game a strict 8/10.If the party AI is added I would raise it to 9/10. There is plenty of content, but I do hope there will be a substantial amount of extra content in DLC-form in the future.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Warning: might contain spoilers.There are countless people telling you how this game is great and close to flawless so i wont be focusing on that. Ill tell you what is wrong with the game.Roleplay options, - the core stats are a joke. Intelligence recommended for a barbarian, Might not recommended for monk, intelligence on wizard is only good for debuffing and 'dialog'. There are no special changes while having stat a minimum - 3 int talking like normal, 3 dex having no problems swinging 2 swords etc. The system is extremely flawed and its a huge letdown when you make some conceptual hero, take appropriate skills and then they are almost never checked outside prologue. In the entirety of Act 1 i havent seen a single Survival/Stealth/Mechanic/Athletics*past prologue* checked in dialog or events, no finding hidden♥♥♥♥♥♥doesnt count. And it stinks. The game presents itself as hardcore old school RPG which it certainly is if you think♥♥♥♥♥♥graphics, extremely horrible party AI, massive pathing problems equals old school. The same 'roleplay' problem is felt all over - say i killed Roedric and come back to Calisa's sister she is still panicking oh no we'lll get hanged mode. Maxed out reputation with people in the village, the dialog doesnt change with anyone outside random♥♥♥♥♥♥villagers say. Really? This is supposed to be a top tier rpg. I liked how the quests adapted to what you do, like instead of doing the 'make water to brew' you instead murder everyone, that was good and it was a step in the right direction, but it ultimately didnt matter one bit how you went through prologue. The outcome is always the same, same with almost everything you do. They dont change anything on macro level. Say after the other watcher dies there are 3 options to do with his soul, giving roleplay opportunity but they are the same as an outcome... Why even have it then? To show off what it could have been? Dissapointing.The Stronghold felt exciting, yet it feels so dead and depressing when i show up, the events are not fun, they are terrirble, instead of inviting over opressed peasants to provide them heaven or w/e im visited by some duke who i cant even go have a talk with.  It could have been a great addition, but it feels superficial and obsolete since the moment you get it and all through the game. You guys talk about creative freedom for the game, yet the achievements are the most uninspired garbage ever. Kill these many or dont kill as many! Finish the game on highest difficulty and prove you are the TRUE TRYHARD or that you can make a fire godlike monk and play fine with it. Whoever was in charge of achievements - let someone else do this, you are ill suited for the task. They feel tackled on, a 'modern burdern' which they had to make for the check mark at the game launch. For someone not constricted by publishers or backers hurrying you up that was really ♥♥♥♥in bad. Dont want people to spoil story for themselves? Make them hidden or whatnot, make them fun! Technical issues with this game are few...but extremely irritating and game breaking including, removal of passives on doubleclick, having your people stuck somewhere with no option to get them out including: ladders with spaces below them,  treelines post scripted dialog. Game glitching out hard in dialogs if launched for extended period of time...and these are just the ones i saw, i struggle to grasp how many total there are. Realism: a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ village with about 100-200 people in it sustaining a huge♥♥♥♥♥castle fit for a king with more guards then villagers. And other incredible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like that all over the game.And thats all just Act 1. Almost a week past the release there is no patch. Obsidian, you can do better then that. Overall though its still a fantastic game and possible THE RPG of 2015, but it could have been so much more. I give it 8,5/10 Right now and 9.5 when issues are resolved *at least the gameplay wise, i dont expect anyone to figure out a way to fix flawed quest design.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												I actually Kick started this back when it was first announced and I do not regret doing so. If you are familiar with Baldur's Gate 2 and enjoyed it then you will love this game. It feels very familiar and yet brings a lot of new things to the table along with improvements. Even if you are not familiar with Baldur's Gate 2 you will still enjoy this game. The combat is almost exactly the same as Baldur's gate, it's an Action RPG where you can pause mid combat (similar to the modern Bioware games such as Mass Effect etc.). It is very challenging and it actually forces you to think which weapon type and which spells to use on each different enemy. Another great thing about this game is that it really is open, in the sense that there are multiple ways of completing a mission. As an example there is a certain area that you need to enter but it has been sealed off and it guarded by 2 guards. You can either:          1. Kill them and enter anyway          2. Bribe them and enter          3. Go to their boss and gain his favour to allow you entranceThere might be more ways that I haven't come across, but that's just one example. Not to mention this game has mods on steam workshop. Since it is a recent release, it won't have as many mods at the moment, but give it a bit of time and look at the mods coming in. I personally love the endurance mechanism during combat that replaces your health so that when you endurance drops to "0" you are unconcious but once the combat is over you are back up again, but with some sort of injury the second time your health drops below "0" you will die however unless you rest. Unlike BG2 you can't just rest as many times as you like, you need to have camping equipment and you can only carry a maximum of 5 at any one point. Though it's not all great. Some people have been complaining about the speed it takes to load a game once you are quite far in to the game. Personally I don't have a problem with it as back in the day the load times generally were really slow anyway. The other problem is that I feel that there is just too much talking about things that I feel are not really that important to me. I mean sure lore is important, but too much of reading will bore the game, especially when it is not directed to me. My personal issue with the story is there are moments when you can actually choose an option about your past of why you did something or who someone is exactly. (i.e. relative, partner friends etc.) And I feel like that freedom shouldn't be given because the story then feels fabricated rather than customised to you. So overall the story can use some improvement, but that still doesn't mean that the story is bad. It can definitely use some more voiced over lines though, compared to modern games this one is lacking in that area. Though again if you compare it to BG2, PoE feels like it has more voiced over lines despite being a smaller game. Overall I would give it a 8/10. I would have given it more had it not been for the amount of unnecassary lore that was forced fed.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												When I play Beemdog's remastered games, I can't help but feel something is missing.  I think part of it is we have learned over the years how to tell a compelling story, and what works for an open world game.  Take Skyrim...you can both get lost in it and you also have story queues where ever you go.When I loaded up Pillars of Eternity some how the pieces just gell.  I love that anybody can equip anything, but their are trade offs like movment speed.  Also people are just better with some weapons, like a monk with their firsts.  Also all the classes feel destinc, and the races are a nice mix of the familar and new.  I realy feel this is what Dragon Age was trying to be, and only got close to with the latest game.What I mean by that is I spent a good 20 hours exploring what I thought was a good chunck of the map.  After looking at the real map, I discovered my good chunck is about 15% of the map!  I just am realing feeling the blance between story, exploration, and characters.  I love that everyone in my party has their own vibe and that each one is TOTALY different.As in you don't have a fire mage, a enchanter,  and a genralist to chose from.  You have 1 mage, 1 chaner, and 1 Cryptic to choose from.  Each have different mechanics and really play differently.  Like mages have spells like you expect, but they work like sorcers where you have X casts of the 4 or so spells you pick.  Chanters spells can only be cast after you chant so many rounds, and even at 1st level that is 3 rounds.  Cryptics start out with small pool to cast spells from, but then every time you strike you add to that pool.  Also you have to pick your spells on level with these two classes, and can't learn more from spell books like Wizards.Also the new core mechanics deloped for this game both feel familar and fresh.  The art is gorgus, and this is great game that goes beyond the infinity games of the past.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												50 hours into this game feels like the right time to start a review. The fact that I'm 50 hours in and yet have barely scratched the surface of this excellent game, should tell you something about the size and density of this nostalgic throw back to the Infinity games of yore.The first thing likely to strike you will take place in the character generation screens. It's easy to get so involved in this process that an hour will easily flick by. I can think of few games since the Baldurs Gates series or Icewind Dales that have had that effect, perhaps Skrim or Morrowind, but again this just proves the richness of the characters and backgrounds on offer here.Once into the game proper I felt instantly transported to the Baldurs Gate and Torment era. A little further scratching showed that whle POE has stayed true to those great games it does not feel like a game of that generation. Indeed Obsidian have managed to create a modern and innovative RPG that feels just as right in 2015 as would have in 2000 at the height if the Infiity engine age.To name just a few of the things on offer here, player choice, great NPC interaction, a rich and diverse world and an even richer and diverse story. So far I can't find a lot to fault. If I had to come up with one negative it could be that I will struggle to go back and play the likes of Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale again, as finally they will feel aged and matched, if not bettered, by a modern RPG.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												If you are a fan of CRPG's from the 90s into early 00's, then you will likely enjoy this game.  I have not had this much fun playing a CRPG since Planescape: Torment.The game feels like a classic Infinity Engine game (Baldurs Gate, Planescape Torment, Icewind Dale), but revised with modern graphic capabilities.   Some of the best gameplay improvements are:* Half Speed Movement* Double Speed Movement* Inventory Stash to remove inventory management mini-game (easy access can be disabled for the truely hardcore)* Removal of need to monster grind for levels by eliminating XP from monsters after a certain amount of kills of that monster type.  The XP focus is now on initial kills of a monster type and Quest experience.Here are some other gameplay change that you may or may not like. I find that they streamline the game over D&D type rulesets:* Trap Detection / Trap disarmement / Picklocking all covered by same skill: mechanics* Mechanics is a skill that any class can learn, so it is no longer mandatory to have a rogue in order to cover the above thief like actions.* Some spells/skills can be used a certain number of times per combat* mage/priests can cast a certain number of spells of each level per 'rest'; mages can only select 4 spells per level* AoE spells have 2 ranges, an inner range that can target both friend and foe, and an outer range that only can target foes.  In addition some AoE spells are listed as foe-only and can not harm friendly characters.  Stats can increase the radius of an AoE spell.I highly recommend this game for anyone who was a fan of the RPG classics from the 90s and early 00's.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Not that excellent as everyone claims, but a really solid game with in-depth combat strategies and clever plot. Overall impression of the game is very positive. I give it 8,5/10.PROS+ Interesting and clever plot.+ In-depth and mature world.+ Likable and well-considered NPCs - both, those you can invite to your party, and those you just meet on your journeys.+ Excellent graphics. Beautiful, vivid scenery. + Good character creation with interesting attribute dependency.+ Enchanting. Though it needs some polishing, e.g. creating certain point in your stronghold to do enchanting or making it only available at a smithy.+ Well considered and voiced (english) antagonist (Thaos ix Arkannon).+ Well written quests. In most cases you need to think twice before completing and majority of them have more than one solution.+ Challenging combat.+ Experience gain.  You get XP mostly from quests and only limited amount from slaying enemies. It encourages to search for more solutions to quests than just hacking and slashing through enemies.+ Feels almost like good old classics (i.e. Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate series) :)CONS- Too long loading screens.- You have to pay for hireling and they cost you a lot. Also they are always 1 level behind. No option to create custom party to play with.- Maximum character level is 12.- Lack of more choices to make at times. (Like at Readrick's castle. You have to kill either of two brothers without the possibility to spare both on your terms.)- Stronghold is useless. The only good thing about it are additional quests. Apart from that it's pretty much for nothing.**- No use for the mercenaries you hire. If the stronghold is being sieged they can't protect it. They only make diference if you arrive to defend the stronghold yourself. (Then they fight along your side, but what's the point if you can easily handle any kind of threat yourself)*- Prison? No point of imprisoning enemies/characters since you have no further use of them anyway.*- Stronghold buffs. When you rest at your stronghold you get buffs, but they are severely underpowered in comparison to what you get in any kind of inn.- Terrible companion quests. They take too much time to progress. You need to keep talking to your team and some dialogues are far too long, tiring and really boring (like Durance or Grieving Mother quest lines). Also some of them seem to be linked to the main plot which disables you from completing them when you want to but forcing you to drag the NPCs with you all the time even if you don't need them. The best idea of companion quests I ever encountered was in Mass Effect 2, where you were simply given a task to accomplish and after that the companion received a bonus ability and tightened the relationship with the protagonist. Really, THAT simple.- Spell uses per rest. I prefered to use ciphers who have unlimited spells pool and their mana is regenerated according to their participation in combat. I would like to see other casters have mana to fuel their spell uses and similar to cipher mana recovery system. OR simply applying cooldowns for certain spells so that you can use them all the time after they are ready to re-cast.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Took me a while to properly get into since I hadn't played a proper traditional CRPG for almost a decade. But once it grabbed me, it became one of my favourite recent RPGs. Pros:- The combat system, once you get into it, is unbelievably addictive. - Huge amount of variety in skills, perks, spells, etc.- The aesthetic is beautiful. It's not the most advanced game or anything, but some of the handdrawn backgrounds are gorgeous - The sheer amount of content is pretty amazing. I've put a good 70 hours into it and I'm nowhere close to finished - The difficulty, although it has a couple of strange spikes is pretty well tuned. It remains challenging for the most part.Cons: - For people new to the genre, or getting back into it after a while, like me, it's almost impenetrable early on. In my opinion, the game does a poor job of explaining several mechanics. Stealth, for example is barely touhed upon, despite it being extremely useful, and on higher difficulties, absolutely vital. Crafting isn't explained at all too.- The load times are infuriatingly long and far too frequent. A loading screen every time you enter and leave a building? Jesus.- Party AI and pathfinding is really poor. This becomes a huge issue in some of the cramped spaces the game throws at you, and with a party of 6+ NPCs, they constantly get stuck behind doors and in narrow corridors. - Disappointing lack of variety in loot.- The main plot is pretty weakOverall: Flawed, yes, but it's a real gem. Highly recommended for anyone who loved Baldur's Gate/Planescape Torment/Icewind Dale

												Not that excellent as everyone claims, but a really solid game with in-depth combat strategies and clever plot. Overall impression of the game is very positive. I give it 8,5/10.PROS+ Interesting and clever plot.+ In-depth and mature world.+ Likable and well-considered NPCs - both, those you can invite to your party, and those you just meet on your journeys.+ Excellent graphics. Beautiful, vivid scenery. + Good character creation with interesting attribute dependency.+ Enchanting. Though it needs some polishing, e.g. creating certain point in your stronghold to do enchanting or making it only available at a smithy.+ Well considered and voiced (english) antagonist (Thaos ix Arkannon).+ Well written quests. In most cases you need to think twice before completing and majority of them have more than one solution.+ Challenging combat.+ Experience gain.  You get XP mostly from quests and only limited amount from slaying enemies. It encourages to search for more solutions to quests than just hacking and slashing through enemies.+ Feels almost like good old classics (i.e. Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate series) :)CONS- Too long loading screens.- You have to pay for hireling and they cost you a lot. Also they are always 1 level behind. No option to create custom party to play with.- Maximum character level is 12.- Lack of more choices to make at times. (Like at Readrick's castle. You have to kill either of two brothers without the possibility to spare both on your terms.)- Stronghold is useless. The only good thing about it are additional quests. Apart from that it's pretty much for nothing.**- No use for the mercenaries you hire. If the stronghold is being sieged they can't protect it. They only make diference if you arrive to defend the stronghold yourself. (Then they fight along your side, but what's the point if you can easily handle any kind of threat yourself)*- Prison? No point of imprisoning enemies/characters since you have no further use of them anyway.*- Stronghold buffs. When you rest at your stronghold you get buffs, but they are severely underpowered in comparison to what you get in any kind of inn.- Terrible companion quests. They take too much time to progress. You need to keep talking to your team and some dialogues are far too long, tiring and really boring (like Durance or Grieving Mother quest lines). Also some of them seem to be linked to the main plot which disables you from completing them when you want to but forcing you to drag the NPCs with you all the time even if you don't need them. The best idea of companion quests I ever encountered was in Mass Effect 2, where you were simply given a task to accomplish and after that the companion received a bonus ability and tightened the relationship with the protagonist. Really, THAT simple.- Spell uses per rest. I prefered to use ciphers who have unlimited spells pool and their mana is regenerated according to their participation in combat. I would like to see other casters have mana to fuel their spell uses and similar to cipher mana recovery system. OR simply applying cooldowns for certain spells so that you can use them all the time after they are ready to re-cast.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Took me a while to properly get into since I hadn't played a proper traditional CRPG for almost a decade. But once it grabbed me, it became one of my favourite recent RPGs. Pros:- The combat system, once you get into it, is unbelievably addictive. - Huge amount of variety in skills, perks, spells, etc.- The aesthetic is beautiful. It's not the most advanced game or anything, but some of the handdrawn backgrounds are gorgeous - The sheer amount of content is pretty amazing. I've put a good 70 hours into it and I'm nowhere close to finished - The difficulty, although it has a couple of strange spikes is pretty well tuned. It remains challenging for the most part.Cons: - For people new to the genre, or getting back into it after a while, like me, it's almost impenetrable early on. In my opinion, the game does a poor job of explaining several mechanics. Stealth, for example is barely touhed upon, despite it being extremely useful, and on higher difficulties, absolutely vital. Crafting isn't explained at all too.- The load times are infuriatingly long and far too frequent. A loading screen every time you enter and leave a building? Jesus.- Party AI and pathfinding is really poor. This becomes a huge issue in some of the cramped spaces the game throws at you, and with a party of 6+ NPCs, they constantly get stuck behind doors and in narrow corridors. - Disappointing lack of variety in loot.- The main plot is pretty weakOverall: Flawed, yes, but it's a real gem. Highly recommended for anyone who loved Baldur's Gate/Planescape Torment/Icewind Dale

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												First thing I can say, for those of us that played Baldur’s Gate and Torment and Icewind back in the day: this is a true successor.It is not perfect, companions are interesting, but dull to interact with, and they don’t seem to have the depth of banter that you got out of BG2, for example. The story is wonderful for the first 2/3rds building up interest, questions and intrigue.... then in the final 1/3rd it... just seems to stop caring and become a fairly dull romp, at least compared to the first 2/3rds. Such a wide breadth of interesting topics for the story to go down and they just ignored them... almost like they ran out of time and had to finish the end quickly :(. Also was disappointed that I was given a Stronghold and never had to really defend it against a BBEG (I thought this was the purpose of a stronghold in an RPG? :P ).But these are small issues, and this is a great game.Pros:+Pretty. Not gorgeous, or stunning, but the graphics work, they’re pretty and do exactly what is needed.+ Interesting companions+ Lovely assortment of side quests+ Great story up to the riot, downhill from thereCons:- Dull interactions with companions- Endgame is disappointing (compared against what it could have so easily have been with a little more effort)- I needed that weekend for work :(- Still a tad buggy. Nothing game breaking, no crashes, just a few odds and ends, I’m sure this’ll be fixed within the week.9/10. Maybe 9.5/10 if mods really take off.(Or to put it another way: Puched a guy and he exploded: 10/10, would punch again)

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												This isn't Baldurs Gate or Icewind Dale. It's not even close. It's way better.Obsidian reactivity is everywhere, with multiple endings to quests, different ways to influence your companions and a storyline that is similar in theme to Mask of the Betrayer and Planescape Torment.The backdrops are influenced by the Infinity Engine games, but with more interactivity with the environment. Much of this takes place the form of text cutscenes - storyboards that allow some player agency, usually through item or skill checks. These can help you skip past a section of enemies or find hidden treasure.As a backer of the Kickstarter, I'm pleased to see Obsidian do well with a game they've always wanted to make. It looks successful too - here's hoping they can do more games like this. I wouldn't mind seeing another game in this engine, with their kind of reactive storytelling. The next one up is Torment: Tides of Numenera from inXile. That has Black Isle and Obsidian alumni (Kevin Saunders, George Ziets, Colin McComb, Adam Heine) working on it, so my hopes are high. Pillars of Eternity certainly sets the bar.

												This game is all hype.  The magic system is useless.  The experience system is useless.   You have to party with their npc's  (whom are useless) to get the full experience of quests.  The combat is chaotic and there is no turn-base or party A.I.   Re-visit the original Baldur's series for a more satisfying game.  I expected a better product from these companies.   Wait til it is in the $10 bin or on sale at least.  Just make Baldur's Gate 3 already for cryin' out loud.  Sheesh.Oh and please stop comparing this game to BG, Icewind, or Planescape series.  It only looks like those games.  The mechanics and rules are completely different.  It is nowhere near in quality as those games.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Hi people, Casual gamer here,I am truly amazed at this game, how it pieces the story and characters together which i haven't seen this level of story and character interaction since Baldur's Gate 1,2 and Icewind Dale - of those I’ve played. It is easy paced for new comers, and holds challenges for veteran RPG players. Players who like fast-paced action, battle after battle using quick potions and hacking and slashing won't find this game to current RPG's. This game is more thinking how to organize your party, how to micro-manage, and a lot of reading - for puzzles, quests, understanding the abilities and lore. Since the game is single player any player can spend as much time as they want! Which is great for casual gamers like myself. Remembering that initially you are not immortal, but can build up to that premise which is a nice balance. There are a lot of builds and classes and has a lot of re-play ability, you could spend a lot of hours in just exploring each zone, class and story!Overall I highly recommend this game to RPG players with actual role playing capabilities

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Pillars of Eternity (PoE) is an absolutely terrific game. It's not just one of the best 3rd person isometric RPG's of recent years. It's one of the very best period. PoE's main selling point, in my humble opinion, is how it immerses players rapidly and completly. The story is great with many smaller plotlines all across the map, sometimes quite literally. Your primary character is built at start but you gather the rest of your party as you go along. There's stuff to do everywhere and I've come back to several locations just to find out I missed stuff. What really helps is how the areas ooze flavour with the right look and feel and plenty of flavour text everywhere.In party creation Obsidian really shows this game was created through Kickstarter and community support: don't like the characters the game throws at you? No problem, just hire an adventurer and built one to suit you. It allows you to tailor the experience the way you like it. Now, the game party members add their own story to the mix and the tend to be fun and capable anyway so you can go both directions. But as an example: unless you build a Fighter or Paladin yourself you find yourself short of a tank for the first few hours of game play. So hire an adventurer and set off. Absolutely fantastic and 100% geared towards offering an experience you can tune as a player. You can go through all of this in any way you like. Want to be a beneficent hero? No problem. Want to be sadistical piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ No problem. And the world responds to that in all sorts of little things. Again: you get to tune your own experience which is a great selling point for this game.Graphics wise the game isn't anything special. But it runs extremely well and the graphics work well and fit the game. You're not going to get blown away with minute details or spectacular effects but it hasn't bothered me. This game is all about content and immersion and it scores off the charts on both off these aspects. The music is much of the same. Not spectaular but it fits the game and most importantly; it doesn't grate the nerves.Pillars of Eternity is one of the very best 3rd person isometric RPG's I have ever played. I consider it right up there with Planescape: Torment for those you know and remember that legendary game. Yes, I really think this game is that good. For anyone who enjoys RPG's this game is a no-brainer: get it. For everyon else: get it. it's that good.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												Traditional Rating - 79Recommendation - cRPG fans, put this on your shortlistcRPGs have made a triumphant return in recent years. From the Baldur's Gate Enhanced Editions to successful(ly kickstarted) revivals of popular franchises like Wasteland, Torment, Sword Coasts, and even some new ones, there has been more than enough quasi-turn-based party management fantasy to sink your teeth into.Most of those games have been (or will be) fairly modernized versions of the genre, but Pillars of Eternity is the first one to REALLY bring to mind the original Baldur's Gate, in all its pock-marked glory. In fact, if I didn't know any better, I might even be convinced into believing this was just a thoroughly well-done mod pack.It's obviously not, though. This game was built from the ground up in the Unity engine by Obsidian Entertainment who, as you might know, were instrumental in designing everything from Baldur's Gate, to Planescape Torment, to Fallout 2, and even Fallout New Vegas. These are some genre (and industry) veterans, and it shows. Every aspect of this game is well-polished. Stability is rock-solid, the graphics are beautiful and well-optimized, sound and music is fantastic, voice acting is solid, there are lots of interesting NPCs, and the story is interesting.This game is a shining example of the genre, and if you're looking for a cRPG and you loved Baldur's Gate 1, you absolutely cannot overlook Pillars.Over the course of the 50+ hour journey, you'll be exploring numerous towns/caves/ruins/forests, battling evil monarchs and quashing uprisings, helping secure lineages, rooting out corruption, and slaughtering enemies by the hundreds. You'll make friends in one town, enemies in another, and something in between on more than a few occasions. This is a game where your choices can have a profound impact on the world, and the consequences of those decisions will be summed up in brutally painful clarity during the ending.It's hard to know what exactly to start talking about, so I'll choose story. In my 60 hours spent playing, most of my time was spent away from the main quest line, but the game did a pretty good job of tying everything in together. A game like Divinity: Original Sin (D:OS) will have a large series of self-contained quests, each of which you earn exp for, but Pillars' quests are all inter-related. Some will earn you reputation which you can use to persuade other quest-givers, some will enable or lock out other quests entirely, and some will either please your companions into confiding in you or anger them into leaving. The Baldur's Gate games did this too, and it's refreshing to see Pillars keep the tradition alive. I will say I wish there was more clashing between the various personalities within the party (everyone got along a little too well), but your actions can and do have an impact on their opinion of you. The main quest itself twists and spirals around, and while it does ramble quite a bit (and start to go off the rails) towards the end, I thought it came together nicely.Going back to NPCs, I thought that overall, they were really well-done. There's close to 10 of them, and they each have their own quests/goals/personalities, most of which develop quite satisfyingly. It was a source of slight frustration that I had to leave a few of them behind at my citadel to watch over things, but I was able to dispatch them on missions remotely, so it was OK. Interacting with the NPCs all felt very organic, too. Sometimes they would want to talk to you about important things, but otherwise it was up to you to initiate conversations. You'd have to build up trust with them before they would open up to you, and they wouldn't shy away from telling you "that's enough for now". I got along with certain NPCs better than others, and certain ones were stronger than others, but at least they were always interesting. Speaking of talking, not all of this game is voice-acted, and the transitions can be distracting.One area this game differs noticeably from Baldur's Gate is in combat. It's still the same pause-when-you-want, micromanaging type of party control, but they eased back a bit on the brutal realism. Don't get me wrong, there are a LOT of tough fights (adra dragon, for one), but when each battle is over, you don't need to use all your healing spells and camp twice to recover. That was one thing I always hated about the BG games, and thankfully it wasn't a sore spot here. In battles, you have health and endurance (800 health and 160 endurance, for example). When damaged, you take equal hits to both health and endurance, and if endurance drains to empty (in this example, you'd have 640 health and 0 endurance), you are knocked out (in BG, you'd be dead). If the surviving team members win the battle, that knocked out character will stand back up, and endurance will regenerate (health will not). This allows you to fight several battles in between resting/camping sessions, which speeds the game up DRASTICALLY. Obviously there are spells that can heal endurance inside battle, but you will need to rest/sleep to recover any health. If health ever runs out, a character is either maimed or killed. I had a few characters get maimed (temporary stat debuff until they rest), but never had one get killed, thankfully. Resting is always 8 hours, and always fully heals/recovers.I only really had a few sore spots about combat. The first problem is that this game falls prey to the classic Baldur's Gate slog, where it will sometimes take you 40 minutes spread across 6 different boring battles to cover a single screen. Battles here resolve quite a bit quicker than they ever did in BG, but it can still sometimes be laborious. Take step, fight Xaurips, more steps, more Xaurips, etc. I call this Baldur's Gate syndrome because parts of that game were absolutely filled to the rafters with it, so if you played that, you know what to expect. Just remember to take breaks when you start feeling weary, and it should be fine. The second problem I had is classic party management frustration. Giving orders to melee characters quite often ends with them ignoring the orders and continuing with their regularly scheduled programming. This can REALLY be a problem when my priest is getting turned into cheesecloth by archers. My warriors acknowledge my order to disengage and cross the room, but instead take 2 steps, get punished with a disengagement strike, and then turn around to continue attacking their original target again, ignoring my order and letting the priest die. So what you have to do is either re-issue orders every 2 seconds, baby-stepping the warriors across the room while they suffer 8 disengagement strikes BECAUSE THEY KEEP RE-ENGAGING, or just let the priest die. If there are 2 or 3 enemies clustered together tightly, it can be literally impossible to pull a warrior away. This is with the default NPC non-AI, so maybe there's a way to wipe them completely clean or something. As with many other party management games, the AI here is just "smart" enough to screw with my orders.Going along with the slog, I should talk about backtracking. There is a lot of it in this game. The world itself is smallish, and there's a lot of content crammed into it, so quests (which you will have 11 of at a time) will have you heading to A, talking to B, killing C and his friends, returning to D, and turning the quest in to E. It gets rather repetitive, but luckily a lot of side quests are not only unnecessary but also pointless (max level is 12, which completionists will hit early).Overall, I found Pillars game to be a great love letter to Baldur's Gate and its ilk. It certainly has some problems, but it's meaty and satisfying, and as long as you don't mind some momentary bits of repetition and tedium, you should find it enjoyable too. I was ready for it to be over a few hours before it actually was, but it didn't overstay its welcome too much, and I'm glad I visited.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												My name is Jawn. Jawn Ghor. I'm an aumaua from a small island off the shore of The Lands That Live. I used to sell drugs and if a deal ever got too hot, well... I'm a big guy and I've got a collection of blades. Don't get me wrong, I wasn't out to ruin anybody's life or screw up the community, it was just honest business. I guess at some point I realized that I was lying to myself, though. It was around that time that a deal went bad on me. Real bad. The elf in question was a pale sailor who I cursed out in front of his mates. I'll haggle with you, but you'll pay what I want and you'll keep your mouth shut about my island. Should've realized he was psychotic. I went for a drink with my mates on my way home to blow off some steam. Much later, I arrived home to find my wife Maia hung by her neck, blood pooled below from a slit throat. I guess I kinda lost it for a while. The memories are hazy from the drugs and the death and... enough. Vengeance is a hunger that can't be sated, nothing could bring her back. I decided to leave the island, having heard of a settlement called Gilded Vale. Maybe they'd have use for a man with an eye for alchemy and a strong arm. Maybe then I could leave all the bloodshed behind. Or maybe carnage is my nature.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												What we have here is a graphic novel with interactive areas and a bolted on RPG system, leveling seems to take place once every blue moon and I have found characters with a 7 in lore could not use scrolls that needed 2 in lore, so the RPG side is simply not working. It relies heavily on text based story telling to create game play, combat, exploration, all seem secondry to this one part of the games design. Unfortunately the story just is not that interesting, I have put books down that have been more interesting than this. If you check the steam stats and achievements for the game, you will notice a trend, most of the advanced features of the game are not getting used, most folk use the create an adventurer feature, only 25% have actually finished act 1. This should tell you a lot. It actually reminds me of a computerised version of the old paper and pen RPGs where the dungeon keeper tells you what you are looking at. Trouble is, this is computer game where we can see what we are looking at and half the time it does not match the text. I have seen this compared to Baldurs gate a lot, honestly, it is not Baldurs gate, its not even in the same league as Baldurs gate but the game does have its charms if you sit back and treat it like an interactive book with pretty average if long winded story line. If I was to give it a score it would be 7 out of 10. Worth owning but not for £35. I would say pick this up when the price hits £22 which is closer to its truth worth. I would ask obsidian one question though, where did the $4 Million dollars from kickstarter go because this game is not worth $4.Worth buying but wait for the sales.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Hello, finally finished this game on the hardest difficulty settings and wanted to post my thoughts, I'll try to cover up spoilers as best I can.I've put a lot of hours into this game, on various different playthroughs each with a different method of playing, those being Companion playthrough / solo playthrough / minimalist playthrough.**DISCLAIMER** To start of ill point out that my experience with this genre is limited to this game alone and it may be that you are reading this knowing more about how these games work than I. To kick off right from pressing play this game immediately grabs grabbed my interest by dropping me into an event that was covered in mystery, straight it made me want to dive into it no boring introductions to plot smack bang right in the middle of something. Following this little introduction I was given the hero creation screen, to a depth I didn't expect. The game offers you 6 races, each with a number of secondary "habitat" options (these add to bonus stats for min/maxers)following that there are 11 classes all that can be built in their own way, then lastly the creation is finished with some personalisation/previous job roles that adds a few extra stats and gives you a starting armor / weapon set. At no point in the lower difficulties have I felt a need to build my character or her companions strictly in a single linier direction, though in the higher difficulties you may find that the opposite be true.**COMBAT**following this and the opening story portion I very quickly found that this games combat was going to slow my progress down a bit, immediately following the easy monsters in the "training" portion of the game. I died. Needed to restart everything all over again (hardest difficulty) You CANNOT rush this game's combat.that being said the combat in this game never got boring, each pack of monsters offered a different challange and seperate strategy with the number of different resistance types making it so that there wasn't an all rounded effective method of nuking monsters as I also quickly found out. I died again, wondering why my cool fire spell wasn't killing anything.  and take note, on the higher difficulties the game produces more mobs and higher tier creatures in packs at a higher density as on the lower difficulties.**THE PRESENTATION & STORY**throughout my 80 hours of playtime, this games art never once felt to much. The colours were very well blended, with great still painted background artwork and the 3D npc / character models fitted superbly on them. movement was very smooth, soundtrack and foley was great, spell effects were pretty and not to over the top they even included incantations which I personally thought was rather neat. so all that gets a big thumbs up from me! The story and it's delivery was interesting and well paced all the way through, mainquest was entirely voice acted, side quests had great mini stories and some were branched of the main quest. there's public tasks you can do, super crazy hard bounties for the try hards that want a rediculously hard challange and a few more progression aspects in your stronghold. so theres plenty of stuff too keep you busy in the world of Eora!In addition to all the above mentioned the game also offers a lot of very small packets of information and secrets, adding to the story telling that you gain through the abilities you gain throughout the game being that each of the attributes have both combat and social implications. Each playthrough is a different adventure, tailored exactly how you want it to be with the world reacting around you in accordance to your actions the fate of Eora is in your hands! This game gets a 9/10 from me!This is my first review, off a game I have very much enjoyed thoroughly! I hope this review helps you dicide to make this purchase, it's likely i've missed points however. Leave a comment and i'll get back too you if so! :DEnjoy!

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												Like probably the vast majority of PoE players, I'm an old-school RPG nut, having played EOB, Ultima, Wizardry, BG and ID and dozens more.  I'd missed the wonderful RPG worlds created in the IE and when I saw the Kickstarter for PoE I was excited.Has the game delivered?  For me - absolutely!  I love the whole approach to this game.  The designers have deliberately steered clear of D&D and created a whole new mechanic, and, in my opinion, have done it brilliantly.It takes a bit of getting used to but once you work out little things like AoE friendly fire and what the different bonuses and defences actually do then the game starts to make sense.  What about the story?  I'm impressed by the story and the whole world setting and I'm finding I'm getting drawn deeper and deeper into the storyline.  Yes there are some minor gripes but given the expectation for this game I think that Obsididan have delivered a gem.If you become stat-obsessed then I'm sure there are more faults you can find, but as far as just allowing the characters to develop and getting involved in the story, then I think it is a triumph.I have found the AI a little weird sometimes, particularly with party members needing micromanaging around other players to get to targets, but I'm sure the developers will be aware of this and will fix.And the game is....beautiful.  The art and feel of the different areas is a breath of fresh air from the constant 3D churn of recent times.  Those games are great, but 3D is not the be-all and end-all.Long may PoE continue and I hope there is more to come from these developers.  Combined with Tides of Numenera then it is a great time to be an old-school RPG fan!

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												I only rarely write reviews, but I was so sorely disappointed by Pillars of Eternity, that I was compelled warn others. After the many great reviews for this game, including a GameInformer Gold for Game of the Month, I was expecting something special. This game is dull as dull can be.  I was bored out of my mind after only a few hours, and now cannot bear to look at this highly uninteresting game.  Any comparisons to Baldur's Gate are completely off base! There is nothing epic about Pillars of Eternity, and certainly no story or unique perspective worth all the effort of slogging from one spot to another in this utterly lifeless "world". Sorry to the developers, I know you spent some time making this thing, but as something that cost me money, I feel completely disappointed.

Posted: August 9, 2015
												Firstly, I love RPG's, Loved Baldur's gate II 50 years ago.Would have to say this feels a little old, a little dull, combat is ok, greaphics are ok, dialoogue long.If you like lore and reading, fair enough. I usually do, but I found myself being bored most of the time.I can only recommend this game to more advanced players, and people who love D&D, this is perfect for them!If you are a little slow in the head like me or a stoner, and just want an RPG or a more casual game, I think you will have a hard time getting into this.There is a ton of character creation at the start, which is obviously great, but when you havn't even played the game yet and have no idea what most of it means, creating a character that suits you is tricky.There is no co-op? I would be so much happier to play this game with someone else and would just be able to get more enjoyment out of it.I can only assume that the older players enjoyed revisiting these vast lore filled games, and if that's what you want, you can't go wrong with this. love has been put into the game and there is nothing essentially wrong with the game.I still have to recommend because I know so many will still enjoy this.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												i grew up playing games like baldur's gate, icewind dale, neverwinter nights, etc and loved all of them. pillars of eternity really did a fantastic job playing to the nostalgia of consumers like us. poe was marketed as a modernized equivalent of those titles but in the end it really fell short. i really wish steam would change their rating system to stars/points instead of a simple thumbs up/down. i would give this 2 or 3 out of 5. but because of the way it was hyped and marketed, i'll have to give it a thumbs down. you can read all the glowing reviews before me, so i'll just focus on why i just couldn't bring myself to finish the game despite being nearly at the end. i really recommend that you play divinity original sin instead.character progression is very bland in poe. i remember agonizing over which skills to take in baldur/nwn because there are so many fantastic ones to choose from. in poe, a vast majority of skills are pretty useless and most builds will be forced into very similar paths. some levels you will be stuck with only 1-2 garbage skills to choose from. some classes and weapons are so overwhelmingly more powerful than others that you feel gimped not to use them. enemies hit so hard that you end up dumping stats like constitution. dual-wielding or two-handers are very tough to pull off without micromanagement. even if try to use different classes and builds, in the end most of your party will be in the mid/back rows shooting guns with the same exact talents. while your nearly zero dps tanks try desperately to hold the line.magic is really what really makes rpgs well... magical. there's nothing more satisfying than nuking your enemies with massive aoe spells. in poe, spell damage is pathetic. your casters, regardless of class, will be doing crowd-control and shooting guns for damage. all this together really made combat a dreadful chore. every battle began with the same formation, same tactic, same opening crowd-control spells, etc.on top of all that i found the story uninspiring and the recruitable npcs were painfully dull. also, their stats are terrible. in fact, you might as well just hire 5 random characters that you can build from scratch.
